review: The features I have on my 2017 unit have changed. There are no longer some channels that were available freely,  now cost.  It seems as though that midstream news or Euro originated TV shows are not available.  This has become the USA  propaganda biased network.  Do not buy unless you are the archetypical braindead citizen.
Good product. If stick doesn't power up tap the home button.

First of all, this is the lite.. But let's get real here. Do we actually need seperate buttons for Netflix, Disney or Hulu just to pay more? No. The lite does not have those extra buttons but who cares. It still has Alexa voice and super easy to use.1. It's heavy duty remote yet small. Definitely can with stand a fall but the gorgeous sleek design is perfection.2. No it doesn't have the Netflix button, or a volume button. But since my volume stays at one level all the time that does not bother me at all. Plus I really don't care about 4 extra buttons to press for Netflix, Hulu etc. When I can just tell the remote to open the app for me3. It has games to play with your family for free too. Really fun games especially in the covid times when we're all together so much of the time.4. Picture and volume are beautiful on my TV. They fit the screen perfectly5. There are tons of actual FREE apps for movies, TV shows, live TV and more. And yes ALL FREE NEVER CHARGE.Plain and simple this is the best alternative to cable ever. I'm saving 150 dollars a month just using the fire stick. Yes I have a netflixs account and Disney plus I pay for. But I have everything else absolutely FREE. This will NOT DISAPPOINT anyone.Set up is super easy and fast, just plug and play.

This thing is a stupid piece of junk.I bought it because amazon is trash, and I can no longer watch twitch on my roku. So I had to get this thing to watch my dumb speedruns.It's absolutely garbage. Freezes constantly, and isn't smart enough to restart or go to a screen saver (it has screen savers, it just doesn't use them?)I'm basically only using it for twitch, which is owned by Amazon, I would kind of understand if it was struggling with a different service, but it feels like if it worked with anything, it would be twitch.It also only autodetects/outputs at one(?) resolution, so if you'd like to hook it up to an older tv, it will give you a hard time there. Probably not an issue for most people, but we have a 1080i TV in the kitchen.Obviously if you want to use it for twitch, you're stuck with this stupid garbage machine, but if you're using it for Netflix/Hulu/other, I think the Roku is better in every possible way (and probably spying on you slightly less).

This FS Lite is amazing! As fast as a 4K stick! The rom expansion is 10x easier, no annoying ADB Shell to deal with, just plug-n-play the hardware and within 1 minute it formats and is done. Alexa is functional. The 1080 streams are crisp and clear.  You will never find a better streamer for under $30. I run a Shield Pro and Tivo 4K, and will keep this FS Lite in the arsenal. I have nothing negative to say about it. Good job Amazon!

I wanted to write a review to outline how/what we used this for.  We have a older Vizio flat screen TV in a workout room.  We wanted to bring up the Peloton app to access workouts on the TV rather than streaming them on an iPad.  This device gave us exactly what we needed.  While I can access Prime Video, Netflix, etc, we were able to pull up Peloton and it works like a charm.  If you are looking for a simple streaming device for a good price, this works great.

Update: Buyer beware!!!Here’s the problem. There was no instructions in regards to the TV possibly turning black because of the fire stick anywhere that I read in the box it came in. I did not know this was an issue and after 45 minutes of trying to get my living room TV working I thought it was broken. I then purchased and replaced that TV and moved the fire stick to a bedroom where the same issue kept occurring, prompting me to do some research only to find on the internet it was the fire stick causing the issue. I find it quite unprofessional for Amazon, a billion dollar company, to not disclose such problems. I live on disability and buying a new TV took money from me buying food and necessities for the month.

The initial setup process was kind of a hassle. My fire stick lite would not immediately display on my TV. I eventually got it up after many cable repositionings and power cycles of my tv. At this time the device was in Spanish and halfway through setup mode. Luckily I can read Spanish quite well so I progressed through the prompts and got to settings to change the language. Oddly though it only changed it for half my menu options, as you can see in my picture. I had to reset the device and then got all the prompts that I was missing from before. This time it was all in English.When setting up my apps, I found it annoying that I cannot delete certain apps or remove them as an option. This is going into a guest room so I really didn’t want to leave the photos app on there for people to browse. Instead I set up parental controls and luckily from there you can restrict access to the app. Functionality is otherwise easy. Kid friendly remote. Great price point at the $17 sale. Glad my stupid tv can now be smart.

Update Jan 15, 2021: Dolby Atmos for prime video is still not working even after the Fire TV Stick Lite software was updated to the new redesigned Fire TV interface. Fire OS 7.2.2.8 latest as of 1-15-20210. Fire TV Home Version 6300182.1.Bought this since my Fire Cube TV 2 does not do Dolby Atmos for prime video at 1080p. I use a Sony 1080p projector with amazing picture quality, not willing to pay $5,000-$20,000 to upgrade to Sony 4K projector yet. The Fire TV Stick Lite advertises having HDMI pass-through for Dolby Atmos Audio but Dolby Atmos is not working on Denon AVR X6700H 2020 model. (Playing Jack Ryan S2 on prime video app)Please report this bug to the Fire TV R&D & QA team!Additional bugs to report:Adjust Video frame rate stops working, FTV gets stuck at 1080p60 . (Settings>Display & Sounds>Display>Video Resolution> Auto).Best Available sound stops working, FTV sets it to PCM stereo from DD+ 5.1 (Settings>Display & Sounds>Audio>Surround Sound>Best Available)Signal path: Fire TV Stick Lite 2020 model -> Denon AVR X6700H 2020 model -> Sony Projector VPLHW45ES HD 1080pAmazon Fire TV R&D and/or QA feel free to contact me for further details.Please fix this as soon as possible.Fire OS 7.2.2.3 latest as of 11-9-2020. Fire TV Home Version 6241047.1

This stick has a learning curve as far as the eye can see.  (Amazon did offer some help, after 5 minutes getting to the right person, but I'd already spent a couple hours setting the stick up and trying to figure things out on my own.)You can get some content "for free".  (In my experience, you should expect to sit thru multiple ads throughout the program.)  Or you can put out more money to get content, some of which may be worth your time to watch.I feel like I purchased an advertising tool.  I get ads for the services & I pay for the services, or I use "free" services and watch ads.  Stick gets you coming and going.

I have many fire sticks.  As well as an original Fire TV, and 2nd gen Fire TV Cube.  All work great.  First gen sticks are really slow now though; don't use them really anymore (sometimes bring them while traveling to use with hotel TV's).I bought this new lite version because I have a portable projector that I use with fire sticks.  I usually used the old gen 1 fire stick, which again, was slow.  This new firestick is super fast (equal to the Firestick 4k) and works great with my projector.  While using the projector I have no TV or Volume to control with a remote; so, I didn't need those functions.  My projector also only puts out 720.  So again, no need for the 4k.  If you want a Firestick that will last the longest, and provide the best picture, get the 4k stick.  But, for some people, like for my uses, this lite version fits my needs perfectly.

This is not my first fire stick. They wanted to send me a refurbished stick to replace my brand new one. Would not replace with a new one. Prices fluctuated since purchase. They said they would look into it and call me back at an agreed upon time. They did not. Very dissatisfied with this purchase. It is like they didn't want to help because I purchased it on sale. ....

Oh my...I shouldn't have waited so long to purchase.I wasn't sure if I needed it but now I don't know what I would do without it.It was super easy to connect to my TV and setup.It plugged right in and then I was ready to watch my shows in under 10 minutes!
Just got it today and it's stuck on "Checking for updates". I have been unplugging and plugging back in for the last hour.

if you use some of the older Apps such as Sling Player this version will not work, spent over an hour with Support they sent replacements. Still do not work, there must have been some change in the "remote control" code which the developers of this version neglected to tell the App guys and never bothered to test completely.Suffice to say this will probably be never fixed as the App developers are either dead or millionaires and couldn't care less, and Sling will not know where the code is anyway.  Amazon will deny the problem because no one there can understand what the users are sayingAfter this review, finally got to someone in support, that told me that despite this being the "2020" edition it is still a 1st Generation Fire Stick, not that he actually said that I had to parse that info from a 20 minute conversation.To cut a long story short there are Apps this version does not support, good luck finding a list, as the Rep have to call who knows who to find out himself, he said the info in on their site somewhere but despite his protestations I cannot find it anywhere.The limitations associated with this device should be emblazoned on the product page, as Amazon demands of all those who sell on their site.

I have two t.v.s now and have a Firestick with Alexa that changes the volume and turns the t.v on and off.  I thought since this one was made in 2020 it would do the same.  I saw the little t.v. icon on the remote and thought that was the button to turn the t.v. off. My bad. It does exactly what it is supposed to do but I feel kinda dumb for thinking this 2020 version would be better than my old one from last year that handles both the volume and the t.v. turning on and off. I guess I have to use two remotes. No biggie.

Just purchased for use with a projector for outdoor family movies. All are working well - both sound and picture. Only disappointment so far is there does not seem to be a supported Xfinity app - anyone know why? I hope this gets added soon so I can watch live TV as well.
Works like a charm!  Setup was a breeze.  Be patient while it checks for updates.  Got Prime video, Netflix, Hulu all up and running.

Have purchased several Fire TV sticks in past. Just purchased this new "lite" version of it for an additional television of mine. Works just as well as any other version of the Fire TV Stick. Super easy to set up and get started with it. Highly recommended

Firestick lite? I wouldn't say so. This version of the fire stick has all the features of a regular firestick without Dolby quality sound, volume controls, and a power button.Pro’s• It still has 1080p HD quality video, quad core processor and 802.11 AC wifi connection.• Quad core CPU 1.7Ghz• 1Gb DDR4 RAM• 8 gig internal storage. A small portion is of it is used for the OS. So it more like 5 gig for applications.• It’s running the same Fire OS 7.2.2.3 as the regular FIrestick.• Dual band WiFi AC.Alexa voice remote.Con’s (difference) what’s new?- No IR remote control. What this means is:- No power control for TV, or other devices.- No volume buttons for TV.This is what makes it Lite because you don’t get the standard 2nd generation remote.- No Dolby vision- No Dolby Atmos sound. Has Dolby digital+ stream service button.Kind of like a hot key for all your streaming services like Netflix, Disney+, and Hulu.For the price point you won't even miss the volume buttons. And for a person just getting into streaming devices this is the least expensive option compared to all the other devices on the market period. If you've never had streaming device at all you won't miss anything at all.Now if you're not new to streaming devices and you've Hey experience with Amazon products you might just miss the volume control and power buttons, but it's not a big deal.I've had every Amazon device there is from the first gen firestick, the 4K stick to the fireTV cube. I know all the features, the in and outs, and tricks on how to use each and every one of these devices, so when they came out with the lite I had to try it. It doesn't disappoint. It is the same fire stick but just try to imagine, or remember the fire stick before 4K, and before the power options and volume remote the IR features. It actually has the same power, and performance as the 4K Firestick, just 1080p HD. This was just a way for Amazon to corner the market by having the cheapest streaming device on the market ahead of all the new competition bringing out streaming devices. And again, it does not disappoint. It’s also faster than the standard 2nd gen Firestick, so if you have a 2nd gen this is a very economical upgrade.• With the lite there's no cheaper device this good on the market, and no reason to buy any other device on the market if you are just getting started, and now Amazon has a device for all price points, this is the economy Amazon package.Great job Amazon!

Spectrum's move to all-digital was my breaking point with my ever-increasing cable bill.  I have six televisions, only two of which were using boxes, and this change would mean that I would have to rent an additional four.  I have two Apple TV boxes and one Amazon Firestick, and can say that this is much speedier and more reliable than either of them.  I've been trying it out for about a week now, and am confident in dropping Spectrum at the end of this billing cycle.By the way - I see that some reviewers have complaints about customer service trying to charge them for setting up the Roku, or for adding or dropping channels, or for troubleshooting.  This is a scam perpetrated by someone with nothing at all to do with Roku.  An outside entity was able to create a fake Roku site that topped the list when googling "Roku."  The phone number you would call if you pulled it from this website was fake and, again, had nothing to do with Roku.  Roku was the main victim in this scheme, it's cost them negative feedback all over the internet.  Just DON'T google Roku and call any number you find at the site until this is straightened out.  Look for a number on the documentation sent with your device.  If anyone at the other end of the call tries to charge you for any of these things, you haven't reached the legitimate Roku support guys.

There is no volume but we bought the universal remote that the fire stick lite attaches to the back of for my parents. It was a WIN WIN!! They are tech challenged to the Nth degree and it was the best combination we could find. It created one remote. The universal remote controls the tv volume, input for devices, their hdtv antenna, and then they flip it over for the fire stick lite. It was the best combination we could find! The universal is made by Phillips and the fire stick attaches to the back. You have to try it if you need volume control and access to multiple devices.

I got this as Black Friday deal and am disappointed. Roku is still the industry standard and they will remain so as long as competitors like this put out subpar products.Likes:Easy setupAmazon integrated (obviously)AffordableDislikes:Long FW update out of the box on a device that was only released two months ago.UI - not intuitive and hard to tell what your cursor is highlighting.Slow response from remote compared to all other remotes ever used.Unstable apps. I've had to reset the device when a stream I was watching froze. It did this three times in the 6 hours I had been using the device.If you don't need this for a specific reason ( like twitch) then go with a Roku.

This specific model used up my entire wifi data for the month in just 5 days of use. I hadthe previous model for years and never experienced this problem. Be on the lookout if you don’t have unlimited wifi in your house!

Since most of my OTA viewing is on the sub channels that mostly broadcast in 4:3 aspect ratio. I am very disappointed that the Fire TV line does not allow for the native aspect ratio to come through. This is not an insignificant issue to a lover of the old TV shows. It causes the video to stretch to fit the screen and distort the image. This is the only product line like this I have ever heard of that does not let you get the native aspect ratio. I have many shows that I am going to have to continue to record and watch on the tuners of my PC instead of the new FireTV  Recast and Fire sticks I just purchased. The main purpose of the purchases was to save the PC from over work to just record TV. I never even thought to check on this issue before purchase since only an uneducated designer would even think to hamper a system in this matter. It makes me rethink all of the other Amazon Echo products I have on hand. Some of them still in the return window. I am going to give it two weeks in the hopes that somewhere I can find a solution, if not I will have to return it all.Update-12-18-2020: Lowered to one star. Latest software update changes the controls for Live TV which was a big mistake. Will say more on review if Fire TV recast.As for the FireStick the menu is now less responsive. Most things take longer to do. Once again Amazon shows the lack of understanding real people.

I have had a roku for 5 years almost and it was sooooooo slooooooow. as soon as I got the FIre stick it was a breath of fresh air. I love how fast this thing is. I Love watching anime but when My roku crapped out on me I had to use my smart tv but for some reason funimation would not work it would be so dang choppy. I'm so happy to be watching funimation again.CRITICAL UPDATE: so I'm not sure if anyone else is having this issue but it seems like if you use this product for too long a period of time it starts to freeze and lock up and then I have to restart it in the settings. I have a 300+ mbs download speed it shouldn't be doing this. I have to re-evaluate the stars i have it. I can't do 5 I can only do 3 not the best product amazon has made at all.
This fire stick has to be rebooted every time it's used (unplug, wait, reenergize) the other fire sticks I have (3) only need  the occasional rebooting. Smart tv here I come!
No sound, displays a black screen after 5 minutes, can't even open netflix. Im returning this.

I purchased this fire stick through Target as the one on amazon was sold out and I'm really hoping what I got was a lemon.The firestick constantly has to be unplugged and restarted for it to work and the remote has really poor connectivity - to the point where it's unusable.  Nothing is quite as frustrating as standing two inches away from a device and the remote still triggers no action.Super bummed about this product.

I bought this Firestick "LITE" thinking it would be easy for my 84 year old Mom to use. I personally have 2 old Roku boxes. I'm going to have to give her one of the Rokus and take the Firestick myself and see if I can get past the HEADACHE of not having all this unasked-for sh_t on it. It streams when I haven't chosen an APP, much less a show. It just won't shut up! I want to be silent and not MOVE while I choose my shows. But nooooo, it's constantly running previews or something, in the background while I try to obtain apps that should have come already on it! Why was PBS not on it already? Why is Netflix not already on it? Had to download both of those. The interface is just too busy, way too busy. Can't FIND the forest for the trees. God I wish I had just bought another ROKU. Going to see if I can return this.

Read this review if you care about if your ISP limits data use.A little background I am a long time cord cutter, used different devices over the years. Decided to switch due to new service only works on Roku. We use Comcast and have 1TB monthly data limit before fees hit. I also monitor using my routers traffic analyzer to see what is sucking up all my data. After using the Roku Streaming Stick+ for a few days noticed a spike in data use at AM hours and isolated the usage to my new Roku. This version of Roku has a power button to control your TV's power (very handy) Also the Roku can be powered via TV USB or external power supply if your TV's USB ports are too weak. My Roku is plugged into a power supply.**Heres the rub** So by force of habit when I finish watching TV I have been hitting the power button, TV goes off as expected, but the Roku continues to stream the streaming service I was accessing. (disclaimer only tested Prime and PSVUE so far) My router confirmed the damn thing streamed all night long (all night....all night long, dancin in the streets) with the TV off. Also confirmed by just turning the TV off and back on, what ever is being watched is still rolling.**the solution** To date I can't find a setting to time-out based on the Roku nor a method to automatically switch to standby when the TV shuts off without replacing a power strip. So my solution to date is  MAKE SURE TO HIT THE HOME BUTTON BEFORE POWERING DOWN THE TV.Other than wasting my internet data it seems like a solid device will post an update if another solution presents itself.

The Roku Streaming Stick + worked OK, but soon after installing it, other WiFi devices began to get kicked off the network.  I noticed in the android WiFI analyzer app that someone had brought up a WiFi access point on the same channel as mine. :(  It was also transmitting at a higher power than mine.  I soon realized that it was the Roku stick's WiFi Direct connection to its remote.  I tried changing my WAP to a different channel, but the Roku followed it there.  I tried changing from 2.4 to 5Ghz, but it also followed my access point to the new frequency/channel.  I reached out to Roku tech support, and they suggested that I change channels on my WAP...which I'd already done.  I informed them that I'd already been down that rabbit hole and they said to try a free HDMI extender?  The stick was on a 3 foot extender already.  Roku used to have an option in the firmware to try to correct this issue, but they've removed it.  I would have given 2 or 3 stars if they'd been more helpful.  But as it is, I must highly discourage anyone from purchasing this product until they fix the WiFi design/firmware.  I hope they do fix it.  If not, I'd probably go for an older Roku model with an infrared remote.

Immediately right out of the box I had nothing but problems with the Roku remote: the "UP" arrow on the scrolling cross only worked about half the time (it would make the "ding" sound when pushed but wouldn't move anything on the screen) which for a streaming device is completely unacceptable. Think about how much time a person spends scrolling through menus! So thinking this was simply a defective remote, I bought another brand new Roku Streaming Stick+ and took the remote out of the box and synced it with my system and guess what? This time the "Left" button on the scrolling cross only worked about half the time (again it would make a sound but wouldn't actually do anything on the screen) AND the power button did a "double tap" about 75% of the time: If the TV was on and I pushed the power button I would hear two "clicks" and the TV would turn off and then turn back on again! Same thing if the TV was off and I hit the power button- I would hear two clicks and the TV would turn on and then turn back off. Again- completely unacceptable.And the worst part about this is that Roku has known that their remotes are cheap and inferior quality and have done NOTHING to fix them! In reading older reviews on Amazon (something I should have done before purchasing) tons of other customers have complained about the low quality of Roku remotes for the last 18 months, and while Roku has commented on a few of these reviews offering only lame platitudes, they have done NOTHING to actually fix the problem.ATTENTION ROKU: It is clear that you're losing thousands of customers due to the shoddy quality of your remote controls...maybe that's something you should address??In the meantime I returned both my Roku Streaming Stick+ and bought the Amazon Fire TV Stick 4K and found it is FAR SUPERIOR!!!!! The remote is snappy and works flawlessly, and the interface is also FAR SUPERIOR, so thank you Roku for steering me away from your brand so I could discover that the Fire TV Stick 4K is a much better option.If you're considering purchasing a Roku product, do yourself a favor and read the incredible amount of negative reviews on here BEFORE you make a purchase decision and save yourself the hassle of having to go through what I did with their bottom-tier level, inferior quality junk. (Also note that Roku's "Customer Service" is non-responsive and non-helpful).

Extremely disappointed with this product. I have owned it for 4 months. About a month ago it began malfunctioning. Periodically the unit will turn on, work for about 30 seconds, then simply go dead. Usually when this happens it will occur at least two times in a row. I called support and their solution was to plug it into a different HDMI port. This did not solve the problem. So I have to make another call to hopefully get a 4 month old unit replaced because it is defective. Also, the remote drains the batteries every 3 weeks. I should have purchased a fire tv stick. Don’t waste your money.

Streaming stick was great at start - hooked up easily and worked well; good picture and sound.  Good remote that also handled TV power and sound volume.However, one day it just failed - wouldn't connect to WiFi.  A WiFi network with other devices and with the main hub just two feet from the Roku.  Signal quality was very high and speed tests on WiFi were strong (100Mb)Text to Amazon "Get Product Support" got a quick, polite chat started.  All the usual ideas: reboot, repower, reconnect, reset, redo password.  After 10 minutes, the advice was to contact Roku.Roku site was a set of videos on setup.  And, their policies on warranty/replacement only apply for 30 days.So I had a great 3 month product but now it is useless (not even large enough to function as a paperweight!)

I have had a bad history with 4K Roku devices. With my new 4K system I tried to use first the Premiere+, then the Ultra, and finally the Streaming Stick+, all played through the A/V receiver in my living room's 7.2 system. All three devices failed with HDCP 2.2 errors. Despite the fact that all components in my new system were 2.2 compatible, the Rokus would stop the entire system because its software apparently imagined that I had a recording device attached to my receiver. A Stick+ plugged directly into the 4K TV in my bedroom worked fine.I last sent Roku an email about the problem in April 2018. I had long since returned all the devices to Amazon for credit. Then in February 2019, ten months later, I received an email from Roku stating that the software problem had been corrected and that I should be able to use 4K devices. I decided to give it one last chance and bought a Stick+ for the living room. I've had it for about a week and it seems to be working fine.I gave it 4 stars rather than 5 because (a) it took Roku TEN MONTHS to fix this problem and I don't imagine that I'm the only person who experienced it and (b) they put these devices on the market before they were functioning properly.Not everyone plugs their devices directly into their TV, and Roku should have an effective way to correct problems in a timely fashion. None of the other 2.2 compatible devices I have has ever had any 2.2 problems.

The Roku Streaming Stick+ is simply awesome.  It's super easy to set up, it's powered by your TV, and the signal booster that is built in to the USB cable ensures a strong wireless connection.  This thing attaches entirely to the backside of your TV and is completely out of sight once it's installed.  I bought this for use with a bedroom TV because I didn't want any unnecessary electronics cluttering up the room, and I couldn't be happier.

I bought this Roku Streaming Stick+ in October 2018 to replace my old FireStick which was really slow and old and frustrating to use because it would suddenly stop in the middle of a show and go back to the home page.The Roku was easy to set up, and worked great for a couple of months. In December we had the first problem: it wouldn't work: just showed a bad picture with zigzagging lines. We reset it and couldn't get the picture to show up at the right size: it was enormous. Called tech support, and the guy helped us fix that problem. Then another problem presented: no audio and Roku remote won't control TV. I don't remember what I did to fix it, but it started working again. Good deal.We were gone for a week during the holidays. Came back and the Roku worked fine up until 2 weeks ago. Same problem as before. My husband was home, and he did what the technician had us do the first time: reset the unit and start over with setup. All good, but now the audio is not coming through again and we can't control the TV with the Roku remote. I couldn't remember what I did to fix it, so I called tech support. The guy had us try several things to get the remote to work and the sound to come through, but nothing worked. He said he could replace the unit, but we would have to return the one we have before they would send out the new one, and that I would get an email explaining how to ship it back and where to ship it. A day or two later, I got an email telling me that my case was "under review." Then I got another couple of emails asking me how they had done! I told them that I was not happy and explained about never getting an email with return merchandise information. That was 2 days ago.They sent another auto-reply. Today, I looked and they had send another "how did we do" email. I clicked on the link to let them know that my issue is still unresolved, and their web page says that they closed my ticket!!!

Don't normally write reviews unless they are extraordinarily good or extraordinarily bad.  For what it worth, here is a Two-in-One review to illustrate the opposite ends of the spectrum.The Extraordinarily Bad:  Roku Customer Service & Technical SupportIn an effort to cut the cord and start streaming, did my research to determine the best content (Amazon Prime Video, Netflix, DirecTV, Youtube TV, etc.) and hardware (Amazon Fire sticks, Apple TV, Google Chromecast, Roku's, etc.) required for the entire family to enjoy.  From the hardware perspective, settled on Roku sticks because Youtube TV did not (at the time) support Fire sticks for obvious reasons.  Started as a trial with a Roku stick against the some streaming providers listed above, and it worked quite well.  So ended up buying a total of 5 Roku streaming sticks (3 to keep and 2 to share) on various occasions in 2018 on Amazon.  One of them stopped working after a few months but still was under 1 year warranty.  Spent a few days troubleshooting by mixing and matching the configurations of the 3 sticks against 4 different TV sets under 2 different WIFI networks.  The results consistently showed that the stick in question (the stick itself and not the remote nor the TVs nor the WIFI networks) worked intermittently for a few minutes then the TV screens went blank.Contacted Roku as follow:1. Logged a ticket on Roku website indicating the problem as such.  No response for several days until after calling them in next step.2. Called technical support explaining the problem and the troubleshooting process above.  They said they'll send an HDMI extender.3. Received the extender 2 weeks later, but it did not work at all - no audio, no video, just blank screen.  The problem was actually worst since using the stick without the extender would at least work for a few minutes then stopped.4. Called them the following day. They admitted that they had sent a bad part and will make sure to send a "working" HDMI extender.  It never arrived.  Probably never send it.5. After 2 weeks of waiting, called them again and explained the troubleshooting process all over again (for the 4th time).  They said they will send a remote.  With patience running thin, asked the tech support rep why would she send a remote when the stick is the problem.  After a brief silence, she asked to wait for a few minutes then came back and said an email with instructions on how to return the stick for a replacement will be sent.6. Three days later, still no email.  And no, it's not in spam folder.  Simply put - they lied the second time.  Frustrated but decided to give them a final chance to rectify the problem and called one last time.  After 25 minutes, a rep finally answered then the line got cut off immediately.  Coincidence?Bottom line:  The problem had been reported for over a month and still no resolutions.  The average wait time for each call is 30+ minutes due to the so called "heavy call volume".  They sent bad part and lied their way out of honoring their warranty.The Extraordinarily Good:  Amazon Customer ServiceFrustrated and planned to just throw away the stick, but also decided to give Amazon a call to inform the type of service Roku had provided with the hope that if this is the norm, Amazon will think twice before selling Roku products on its site.  The Amazon CS rep apologized, offered a refund, and will work with Roku on the issue.  Didn't expect that!  After all, this is a Roku's problem not Amazon's.  The call took less than 5 minutes.  Problem solved.  Thank you Amazon.  This is another reason for being a Prime member.In the streaming war against giants like Amazon, Google, Apple, Disney, etc. and with the type of service Roku had provided, good luck Roku.  For your survival in this crowded space, you (Roku) should take a page out of Amazon's playbook and learn from it.  Otherwise, you will be crushed like a cockroach that you are.Update:Finally received the Warranty Swap email from Roku four days after the call in step 5 above (a few hours after posting this review). Decided to ignore it as so much time had already been wasted. It's unfortunate that the device worked quite well (when and if it worked), but the customer service is unbearable.

BUYER BEWARE - I've purchased Roku players in  August 2012, May 2015, and this new Stream Stick+ in 2018.  When I had a problem "activating" my new Streaming Stick+, I was given a number to "Contact Support Toll Free to Activate Instantly". I called the number and was told that since I had already registered 2 other Roku devices, in order to Activate this 3rd device, I would need to pay $70.00 to have a PREMIUM account. I told them that I didn't need nor want a PREMIUM account. I asked the customer service rep, to deactivate the first Roku I purchased in 2012 and then I would only have 2 registered devices on my account. I was told that - (1) Even if I deactivated a previous Roku player or (2  )if I opened a new account, I would still have to pay the $70.00 in order to register my Streaming Stick+ .So that is how Roku rewards it's returning long-time customer, by charging them a fee of $70.00 to activate more than 2 of their Roku devices!  So, in addition to paying for the device itself, you now have to pay an extra $70.00 to use it!!!I am hoping this review will alert other potential buyers to Roku's new policy of rewarding their repeat customers.Patti

We bought this Roku Streaming Stick+ thinking that all we had to do was plug it in and follow instructions. WELL NO! We have a Samsung Smart tv with numerous HDMI slots. We tried ALL of them and the update on the Stick would not load! We kept getting a 005 Network Error. I chatted online with "Ray". He stated that I would have to pay Technical support $69 to update the Stick+ . He explained that there have been too many errors updating their products so the company decided that the customer cannot update their new devices on their own and will now have to pay someone to do it for you! NOWHERE in the reviews I read did anyone state that I would be paying an additional $69 to use this device! So here I have a brand new device which costs $65 and now Roku wants to hold that item hostage and render it useless unless I fork over $69 for an update AND oh yes...that $69 would give me 6 months of free tech support! Yay!? Not gonna happen. I will NEVER purchase an item from this company again. They are way out of their league charging for technical support for an update to a brand new device.

I'm a long-time Roku user, having purchased devices from every generation throughout Roku's evolution. I've had the very original Roku N1100, Roku 2 XD, Roku 2 XS, Roku 3 (2013 version), Roku 4, a TCL Roku TV, Roku Ultra (2016 version)...and now this Stick +. While I've only had it for a couple of days now, this might be the best Roku I've seen from a value perspective.My house is a Roku house. We have 5 televisions but don't have a cable or satellite subscription.. One of the TV's is a Roku TV and the other 4 all have a Roku attached to them. Literally everything we watch is delivered via the Roku. Our OTA material is delivered from a Tablo DVR to our Rokus. Our local media is served up via a Plex server to the Rokus. We also have PS Vue, Netflix, Amazon video, etc. etc. Bottom line, we use Roku a lot, and I'm very familiar with them. I wouldn't consider myself to be a Roku "fan boy", though. While most of the Roku's I've had have been great...there have been some clunkers. The Roku 2XS was a turd that never got any better. The Roku 4 was a turd at the start, but gradually got better with each subsequent firmware update. Unfortunately, the cooling fan in one of my Roku 4s (The 4 was the only Roku model to ever have one) has begun to make the dreaded "grinding" noise in recent weeks, so I decided to try replace it with a stick+.I've generally been leery about all of the "stick" form-factor devices. They've generally lagged behind the more traditional "box" form-factor devices as far as specs go. The Stick+, with its quad-core processor, HEVC support, and 4K capabilities convinced me that the gap may have finally been closed.So, after a couple of days with the Stick+...here are my thoughts on this device- It's snappy and smooth. It's maybe not quite as quick as my Roku Ultras...but it's every bit as fast as the Roku 4.- The new remote is great.The ability to control the TV's power and volume without a second remote or a universal remote is loooong overdue.- Excellent wireless reception. I had two walls between the Stick+ and my router, but was easily streaming 16mbps local media through Plex.- Powering via the TV's USB isn't optimal. Assuming your TV stops providing power to the USB when turned-off, the Stick+ will have to go through the boot-up sequence and then connect to your wireless before you can do anything with it each time you turn on your TV. This can take ~30 seconds. I highly recommend plugging it directly into an outlet using the provided adapter.So, this is a great Roku device. It doesn't have the same bells-and-whistles that my Roku Ultra's have...but then again, I also paid nearly twice as much for those. This Stick+ is much cheaper, provides basically the same UI/playback performance, and also has a remote that will make having to juggle your Roku and TV remotes a thing of the past. That's why I say, absent some deal-breaker that I haven't encountered yet, this is the best dollar-for-dollar Roku yet.

I purchased the Streaming Stick+ after having repeated difficulties and problems with the Amazon Fire TV Stick.  The difference in quality between these two products is astounding. While the Fire TV Stick required constant reboots and had consistently poor network performance, the Roku has been flawless and completely without problems.  The addition of 4K support is a huge bonus.  I'm especially impressed with the connectivity.  My room, where I'm using the device, is on a different floor, on the other side of the house from our router, but I've never had an issue with connectivity or performance.The menu/interface is a little outdated, but I'd gladly sacrifice a flashy menu for good performance.  It's astounding to me what a bad product the Fire TV Stick was now that I've switched to Roku. I enjoy the wide selection of channels as well - every streaming service seems to be available through Roku.  The voice functionality on the remote works well, and I like that I can turn my TV on and off with the Roku remote as well as adjust the volume.  All in all it's an awesome product.

EARLIER REVIEW: Works just fine* and because our TV is not mounted, the length of the stick is not a problem at all. My husband enjoys the voice command feature and used it occasionally. At some point he was watching the TV and I don't know what he clicked on but the TV started talking--NONSTOP--reading everything on the screen. I was perplexed but, if this happens to you, go into "Accessibility" to turn it off. Apparently it's a feature for the sight-impaired.*LATER REVIEW (EDIT): THIS REMOTE IS A POS, It worked for about five months and then stopped working at all. If I hadn't read some other reviews where people had the same problem and discovered they had to change batteries way too frequently--one person had to remove the batteries every night and then put them back in the next night--I wouldn't have known that changing the batteries might work. We put in new batteries and it worked fine . . .  for a few days. Then it stopped again.THE COMPANY'S RETURN POLICY IS A JOKE.I wanted to return it but the company has made it sufficiently difficult and iffy to make most people give up on that idea, given the hoops you have to jump through, the resulting length of time it would take to have your TV viewing restored, and the fact that one of the major faults in this remote seems to be that it eats thought batteries. Also, if the remote's problem was its propensity to eat up the charge in your batteries, the company would likely try new batteries and then send it back saying, "You needed to change the batteries." So basically we have to eat the price of this thing and take a chance on some other model. Or maybe we'll just get some other system than Roku.RETURN AND WARRANTY SERVICE PROCESS [Sorry about spacing; it was in pdf format]Please  access  and  review  Roku  Support  online  help  resources  at  support.roku.com  before  seeking  warranty  service.  Returns  orwarranty  service  requests  for  your  new  Player  must  be  within  the  30-day  return  period,  or  within  the  original  product  warrantyperiod.You  must  first  obtain a  Return Merchandise Authorization (RMA) number from  Roku Customer Support.  RMA  numbers expire thirty days  from issuance. Roku may  attempt to  troubleshoot a  warranty-related problem prior to  issuing a  RMA number.Please be prepared to  provide additional information upon request.Once a  RMA  number is  obtained, you  must ship  your  Player, freight prepaid, together  with  proof  of  purchase  and  all  accessories,  in  either  the  original  packaging  or  packaging  affording  an  equal  degree  of  protection, to  the  Roku authorized distribution facility identified by  Roku Customer Support.Failure to  return any  of  the  accessories could result in a delay and/or result in an invoice to you or credit to Roku for the missing accessories. Important:When submitting a  RMA, please provide the  following information with  your  request: (a)  modelnumber, (b)  serial number,(c) problem description, (d) software version (located in the Settings menu), (e) date of purchase, (f) place of purchase (reseller or online place of purchase), and (g) return shipping address (P.O. boxes are not accepted).Additional Roku troubleshooting and online help resources can be found at support.roku.com

Folks something is wrong with the remote controls for the Roku sticks.  The remotes works and then all of the sudden they won't control the TV or talk to the stick anymore.  I bought another one and returned the first thinking I just got a bad unit.  Nope replacement unit had quit talking to the stick about 5 minutes after setting up all my passwords.  Stick with the big units until Roku figures this out.

Original title was: Perfect streaming stick with poor supporting (but mandatory) accessories… however, see updates belowI have bought three units. Two were installed successfully and are working great (with small adjustments described below)!The third one needed to be sent back to Amazon for replacement due to the poor quality and design of its unique power / antenna cable (you can’t find this cable anywhere and it cannot be bought separately). It easily snapped when installed on one of my wall-mounted televisions.In addition, I have a 65-Inch 4K Ultra HD television (Sony XBR-65X900A, a model from 2013) and my single 4K UHD HDCP 2.2 port is placed on the television’s back in an area that cannot fit this stick (due to its size and shape). I needed to add a small flexible extending cord to connect it. Finally, I also got an error message (from Roku) on that same television saying it is not getting enough power from the television’s USB port ... so I had to use the power adaptor that comes with this product. However, the power extender is also a very short cable ...Bottom line, once you get it installed and running (after one week of viewing) the product is great. The sound and picture quality are amazing. I loved the Roku user interface and speedy response. Its only Achilles’ heel is related to its poor proprietary power / antenna cable.UPDATE (November 10, 2017): Amazon quickly replaced the damaged cable and I was contacted by Roku. Roku team provided me with all the help I have needed (well, it should be on its way to me, so I will keep you updated once I'll get it). Thanks a lot Amazon and Roku!UPDATE (November 19, 2017): Today I have opened the door to my beloved FedEx delivery guy and look what I have got from Roku! The three (3) HDMI extenders (as promised) and an additional (and totally new) Roku Streaming Stick+ - all for FREE. Just as a reward for writing this review and adding my comments to it. To remind you, my original review had only four (4) stars (due to the issue with the product's accessory, as described above) – however, now I have updated it to five (5) stars. Because in my book - caring for customers and addressing their needs (and beyond) and making customers feel cared and important – it what makes a company (and its products) prefect. We all know, there are no real perfect products out there. For every product out there, we can always apply our hopes and wishful thinking ("I wish they have added that feature to it", “I wish the screen was bigger”, "I wish they have used that my preferred CPU " and so forth). But a company with a great product and a perfect customer care, how many can you find out there?So, once again - Thank You Roku so much! I really like your product and now admires your service!

***Quick note before reading numerous reviews! I research everything immensely before I buy it and one HUGE discrepancy I noticed when reading the top reviews for Roku devices is that they mostly date back to 2017-2018 and sometimes even before. Please take into account that THIS Roku is the 2019 release date and THAT is the device you will receive and the device that I purchased & reviewed :). I'm sure what other's wrote is valid for their particular Roku based on the release date but rest assured that a review from 2017 or 2018 can NOT cover a product released in 2019! Hope this proves helpful for anyone considering any streaming device (don't judge the newest model on old model reviews)!A little back story, I do own both Rokus (5 now 😂- mostly different generations but my two most recent ones are this one and the Ultra) and Amazon Fire Sticks (2 - various generations) and although I enjoy them all for the fact that we were able to cut our cable about 6 years ago thanks to them, I would say I am thoroughly enjoying this one and the Ultra the most. The technology is the most recent release dates and they stream absolutely flawlessly!I chose to purchase this particular Roku for my father because his bedroom is located on the top floor of our home while our modem is connected in our basement which is a concrete box of internet deadzone (the modem must be connected down there or the internet won't reach the entire house unfortunately, but we are in the process of getting booster Pods from Xfinity). We have the now 300 mb Xfinity internet (aka nerdy gaming speeds - was previously 250 mb) with our router/modem located in our basement for optimum connectivity and a WiFi range extender but our house still has connectivity issues with most devices. This Roku is not only 4K but it's supposed to be exceptionally good for connectivity which played a huge role in choosing this particular one.As soon as I plugged this Roku in, it was love at first home screen just as I had experienced with the Ultra that I had purchased several weeks prior. It recognized all my accounts, downloaded everything quickly, was extremely user friendly and the streaming quality is AMAZING. My father had become all too familiar with the loading screens on various streaming devices and we are ecstatic to be able to say goodbye to them for good thanks to the long-range wireless receiver in this bad boy. The picture quality is always exceptional whether streaming HD, HDR or 4K. This particular Roku stick is also so user friendly that my 70 year father (who generally avoids computers and technology like the plague) can even use it! I also believe this to be the best Roku for it's price point. The Ultra is amazing, but is not necessary in my opinion for most users although it too is highly impressive. We are very pleased with this Roku device and would definitely recommend it.***I took side by side photos of his new Roku (this one - the Roku Streaming Stick+) and his older model, the Roku 3. You can see based off the photos the difference in the remotes, particularly that the newer remote is much skinnier and more comfortable in your hand. The volume controls are the same with the exception of the mute button on the new remote. The Roku 3 remote is also shiny and has different channel buttons compared to the Roku Stick+ remote that is a matte black and features newer streaming channels. The new remote also has the on/off button that most Roku's feature and allows you to easily connect to your tv (it literally auto connects for you) and gives you the power to use your Roku remote on your TV as well. Last note, the picture quality is beautiful even on my Dad's older LG flat screen, but my phone only takes sub par pictures of it so don't mind that 😂.

This device, which should in theory need to know absolutely nothing about you, DEMANDS that you:- fill out multiple annoying Captcha screens during activation- full legal name (cannot opt out)- date of birth (cannot opt out)- gender (cannot opt out, male or female only, no allowance for the people who have ambiguous genders)- credit card information (cannot opt out), even if you never want to use it through their account- which room of the house it will be used in (cannot opt out)- which room of the house all your old Roku devices that you long ago threw out are located in (cannot opt out)I will never purchase anything through this Roku account.  It's invasive and I hate it.  For any content that I pay for, I will pay directly, like Amazon or Hulu or HBO.

The Roku devices are simple and easy to use. I have Roku, Apple TV, and Amazon Fire Stick. I love my Roku Streaming Sticks. These are truly simple to use that my 6yr old kid and 65yr old parents can use them. There are so many steaming app options to use it is great. My one issue is that it never shuts off. Now this might not seem that big of a deal, but if you have a limitation on internet usage, this will eat it right up. I recommend also getting an APC P8GT 8 Outlets Power Strip. This unit has a Parent/Child feature, so once you turn your TV off, the Roku, DVD Player, and another item will also power off until the TV turns back on.

I’m so annoyed with my Roku! I just received it a week ago and it has major issues. Every time I turn the TV on, it takes at least a few minutes for the Roku remote to work. I’m able to turn the volume up/down, but none of the other buttons work.I’ve also had an issue where the screen goes fuzzy (picture attached) and freezes when opening an app. I had to reset the stick.I’m using this with a new 4K LG smart tv so it can’t be an issue with compatibility. I’ve had amazon fire sticks in the past and they never had these issues!

Bought this Roku as I’m an Xfinity Stream customer. This seems to be the only solution for us that don’t want to watch/stream only on our phones or iPads but also on our TVs. I’m a die hard Amazon Fire TV/Stick customer, but Xfinity only allows their Beta app to be downloaded on Roku.Set up was easy. And I found the Xfinity app in the Roku store easily. From start to finish it took about 6 mins, from booting, to updating, to creating a Roku account, to loading my app and logging in.I like that it comes with the extension cable in case you don’t have a USB port on the back of the TV to power the device. I did splurge with this upgraded version, for 4K, but figured this was a long term investment.Very happy with my purchase!
Have had nothing but problems with this and only have it about 80 days. It works for a few days then I get errors. Takes HOURS on the phone and website. Don't waste your time or money.

I like the Roku stick but watch out for the SCAM when trying to activate.  Be sure to use your computer and NOT YOUR PHONE.  I first tried to activate on my phone and it would not work.  It said to not try the code a second time or it could ruin your device. Then there was a phone number to call.  Someone with the thickest accent answered and, OF COURSE, wanted more money to set it all up for a ONE TIME FEE.  I didn't really understand what he was saying, but I remember another review saying that they wanted to charge $70 to get set up.  I didn't even let the guy get that far.  I said I wasn't interested in paying for activation that was supposed to be FREE, and said I would be returning the Roku stick and hung up.  I then proceeded to try and activate again using my computer and I had NO PROBLEM AT ALL DOING IT BY MYSELF.  You do not have to put in any credit card information if you do it this way.  I would give the Roku stick 5 stars if there was not this scam out there.  Thank God, for the person that posted the review about the EXTRA FEE before I bought mine.  I just took the chance to order the stick because my sister has a couple and really loved it. SO, it really does work like it should, but DON'T FALL FOR THE SCAM!!!!! YOU CAN ACTIVATE YOUR DEVICE FOR FREE!!!!

I previously had an older Firestick and was having some issues with it so I thought I'd try the Roku.  I paid $50 for the Roku stick, thinking that was all I'd have to pay.  Boy was I wrong.When I received the Roku and went to set it up, I got to an activation screen that said "Roku does not charge for activation or support".  However, it then prompted me to go to a website and input a code, which then gave me an error message and directed me to call a phone number.Upon calling this phone number, I was told that I would have to pay a fee of either $90 or $140 to unlock my Roku device.  I told the man on the phone that it says right on my screen that "Roku does not charge for activation or support".  He said that's right, and my device is already activate.  However, I can't use it unless I pay this fee.We went round and round, but ultimately I paid the $90 and my device was instantly unlocked.  Had I known in advance of this extra charge, I never would have bought the Roku and would have bought another Firestick instead.With the Firestick, you just pay the one time charge and then you can use it.  There's no extra "activation" or "unlock" fee (or whatever word Roku wants to call it).  Buyer beware!!

I bought a few of these, cause we had tried all the media streamers and this one seemed to work the best of all of them.  Unfortunately if you use android (like millions of others do) Roku is only focused on iOS users.  The app is the only way to type on the screen that isnt the god-awful cursor based "hunt and peck".Well, search doesn't work on android and when I chatted with support, they just told me to use ios or to wait for possible further updates to see if that fixes my experience..THEN THEY JUST DISCONNECTED.  I tried contacting them back and they would read my previous transcript and immediately disconnect from me.  I wasn't rude or abrasive or anything.  they're simply finished trying to help I guess...  I tried talking to a supervisor "Escel" and he too would disconnect form me after saying hes reviewing my previous chat.I went to roku.com to get their phone number for support, but it was country code +44 (UK), and international calls cost big $, so Im stuck with chat.So I'm simply returning their half-baked sticks.  Amazon, Apple and Google will crush or acquire them soon anyway.  Bummer.

I bought this to replace a cable box which wasn't being used, so I could return the box. I have Charter Spectrum which is supported by Roku. I received my Roku + yesterday and hooked it up to my living room TV to test it out.Setting It up was easy. I have it plugged into my HDMI on the TV and you have a choice of powering it through a USB port on your TV, or using the included wall plug which you plug the USB end into then plug it into an outlet, which I did.Roku takes you step by step setting it up and you do have to put in a credit card, I used PayPal. That's only if you want to watch something that's not free.I loaded the spectrum app, logged into spectrum with my username and password and have all my channels. Live and on demand. I also love the fact that when I use the Spectrum guide with the app, it only shows the channels I'm signed up for, unlike the guide on my DVR box which makes you scroll through all the channels.The remote control has a voice button that you hold down and say what you are looking for, and it takes you to the Roku app with all the results. To test it out I searched Clint Eastwood and so many movies showed up, but most of them needed to be paid for.I was also very impressed with all the movies and shows that Roku offers. Not all are free, but I set up a pin to prevent any unauthorized charges.I can't comment on the range of the wifi yet, but will update once I do.When I read the directions, there was something about using it with a 4k and there's a free adapter they will send, incase something doesn't fit. I went right onto Roku site and ordered it just to have in case I ever need it.I love this so much, I'm seriously considering getting rid of my DVR service and box on my living room TV to save more money.

This is my second Roku in the house.  I bought this Streaming Stick + because of the flawless performance of my wired Roku device.My problem with the Streaming Stick + is the Remote and it's inability to pair.  After reading all the support pages and doing shutdowns, resets and fresh batteries it started to pair but then would stop responding.  The remote has some kind of a power problem and does not recognize the battery strength.  Half way through configuring the Roku the battery icon appears and shows "no power".  At that point the process stops.To prove it's the remote and not the device I paired my older remote with the Streaming Stick and it paired and configured properly and connected to my streaming accounts.Roku support first instructed me to contact Amazon for a new remote.  My response was "Really?  Amazon doesn't carry components within a product they sell.  I would have to return the product."  After 20 minutes of Chat with Roku support they finally agreed to ship me a new remote.

Our old Roku player quit working after about 3 years. It kept giving me a purple screen with error codes. I contacted support and they said that I would need to replace it. I didn't feel that a product working 3 years would need to be replaced, but apparently Roku products do. I figured I would replace it, because I like the Roku Interface and when it worked I didn't really have any issues. We got a new TV, so I figured I would buy the streaming stick+ now that we could enjoy 4k. After a few months the product said it couldn't connect to the internet. When I look at the status of the internet connection it says good. I moved the Roku Streaming Stick+  to the TV next to the WiFi router and still have issues connecting to the internet. When I run the check internet status it says it can't connect. So I had Roku forget the Wifi, and reconnected to the internet. It connected back to the internet and said the connection was good, but then it says I have a weak internet connection again. I contacted support again, and they sent me a HDMI extender, which makes zero sense, because I don't understand how or why a HDMI extender would help with my WiFi connection. I'm reaching out to Roku again, but I'm guessing they will suggest I purchase a new roku product. I will never recommend Roku to anyone, and will never purchase any products from them again.If they won't stand by their products why should I?

Nowhere does it say "If you buy this and you use it, we get to use 1/3th of the screen to advertise whatever we want."But that's what they do. As soon as you have configured the device 1/3 of the screen is showing you advertisements, trying to get you to buy whatever they are selling.You buy this for real money and then... They use you to get more money! That's now how it's supposed to work, now is it? No. I never agreed to that. Is that what it says on those really small letters that I can't read?"By using this you agree that you are the product and we just act as if you're the customer."

Got a new one yesterday and plugged it into my TV. Completed the initial setup steps like Language selection , Remote pairing and Wifi selection. The stick said it needed a software update and will reboot. Post the reboot, the stick would flash the initial startup logo and then just shutdown..Extremely disappointed with the purchase . Wish Roku had better QC in place.FINAL UPDATE 5/15/2019: Roku Support want me to ship this rubbish remote to them at my own cost and they will send a replacement. What these  ‘experts’ don’t seem to realize that the problem is inherent to the product and no amount of replacements is going to solve it. Maybe they should just look at Amazon reviews to see how many customers have had the same problem.UPDATE 12/12: I returned the stick for a replacement and had my fingers crossed hoping that this would just work but looks like Roku had other plans. The stick works (phew!) but the remote doesn't want to pair unless your 2 feet from the TV , which Roku should know, defeats the purpose of a remote control.UPDATE 12/18: Got in touch with Amazon who were wonderful in contacting Roku and ensuring that I got a replacement remote.Sadly the replacement remote worked fine the first day and had the same problem day two onwards.UPDATE 4/6 -  Multiple follow ups with Roku tech support has gone no where. Roku support keeps insisting I try and change the Wifi channel (non tech savy folks , if you are reading this, you should avoid this stick) and select one that is not congested. I tried doing that but the funny part is the Roku won't connect to those free channels (thanks for nothing Roku support!).I believe the product has inherent flaws which should have been fixed before the product was rolled out.The remote definitely has pairing issues , something which was not there in the older stick. Roku should acknowledge and fix this problem instead of sending replacement remotes.I really have lost all confidence in Roku now and will NOT buy anything from them ever again.

What an incredible little piece of equipment! Because the wifi pickup is in the wire that connects to the power, it balances on top of my TV, and because of that, I get my wifi through 3 walls of the house (wood frame house). The picture quality is, can I say, better than Cable? yes. The selection of endless movies, documentaries. I can scroll down through types of things I want to see. I am only paying for my PBS Passport station through a donation that amounts to $5/month that allows me into an amazing array of viewing. I get my local TV channel every evening for news. If I miss the news time, I can see it again at 9, 10pm, whenever.  We don't watch too much on broadcast tv, can't stand the 40 minutes of commercials sometimes and 20 minutes of show.  After checking out the Roku experience for 4 weeks, we are going to cancel all TV with Comcast. We do need them for internet, but we can use 55 mbps from them and it will accommodate all streaming.  I think we will save $100 to 140/month!!  So easy to use. The remote turns the TV on and off, one simple remote.  Nice.

I've never had a Roku before. This is well priced for what you get and the streaming is good quality. There are a few big caveats, though.The first is that Roku try to trick you into putting in a credit card. As you first sign up, the interface gives you no option to avoid this (!), but it actually isn't necessary to function. You have to stop your registration at the point they ask and restart the roku. Then, just log into the website. Works fine without the CC.  I guess marketing thought it was a good idea to force customers to give payment info.  It is kind of scummy.The second is that search is lousy.  Search within individual channels is awkward, and the main Roku search interface doesn't differentiate between movies on channels you already have, and movies on new channels they want you to subscribe to.  By mixing them all, they try to force you to sign up for more channels, I suppose, but it is at the cost of a easy to use search function.The third is that there is no general history or resume. If you stop in the middle of a movie there is no indication when you turn the machine back on of what you were watching or where you stopped. You have to remember to go back into whatever channel you were in, and look for the specific movie again.  Remembering current status is basic functionality, and the whole thing is made worse if you have more channels as Roku encourages.  Surely Roku could figure out how to resume properly. I purchased this for my elderly parents, all this lack of basic function makes their lives considerably more complicated. It is a shame, since those things would be so easy to do right and the streaming itself is fabulous.

Loved it until it stopped working normally. Now i have to restart it everytime to watch. It would have overlapping screens, no way to watch unless i restarted the system everytime. It has been over 30 days and cant get a replacement because roku says to contact whoever sold it on amazon, but those people cant be contacted.

Been using this for about a week now and overall I am really happy with it, but becareful of overheating and bandwidth use if your ISP is capped (mine is capped to 1.2TB per month which I need for other stuff too besides roku)Because of the overheating I had to add a fan near it and it dropped the temp from 82c to 66c in the secret screen (see pictures)to access the secret screen to see the temp hit this remote key combo:Home, Home, Home, Home, Home, Fast Forward, Pause, Rewind, Pause, Fast ForwardFor the bandwidth control you will want to go into your Router Settings (see last picture) and enable Traffic Management (QoS) and adjust the downstream to just enough for the Resolution you want to stream at, for me I use 1080p, and 3mbps down is just enough for 1080p streaming and I been able to stay around 15 to 20GB a day (0.5 to 0.8GB per hour) (450 to 600GB per month)Another thing you can do to save bandwidth is go into Roku Settings > Privacy > Advertising and check the box on "Limit Ad Tracking" and then restart the roku stick to apply the settingHave fun, hope this review was helpful

This Roku Streaming Stick + has been a royal PITA since I first got it. First of all was the multiple instances in which I had to log in with a username and password just to get access to the various apps. I could understand being required to do this perhaps once for each app (to register for each service), but not multiple times for the same app. I am in the comfort and security of my own home on a password protected (automatic entry for all my devices ALL DAY EVERY DAY) wifi system. I am not worried about hackers or otherwise unauthorized use of their streaming service. Nor should Roku.Undoubtedly, the Fast Forward and Rewind functions are the most aggravating and infurating things about the service, or lack thereof. Both are either too slow or way too fast. And the 10 second rewind function (why no 10 second FFWD option-ignorant!) no longer works. It will freeze the picture and after a 10 second delay or so, it will pick up right back where you left off, with no rewind. And ostensibly, it should be additive, such that if I press this button 5 times, it will go back 50 seconds. But it doesn't do so. And trying to find your way back to a scene you missed for whatever reason is maddening. It takes the patience of a monk to endure the slowest rewind speed. And there is no rational progression beyond that for the next increments of FFWD or REW speeds. It goes into hyper drive on the second push, what is typically reserved for the 3rd or 4th press of the button. Moreover, I have encountered too many disruptions of service where the picture freezes during buffering. To top it all off, customer service is a nightmarish merry-go-round to get through.Don't waste your money. The Amazon firestick does not put me/you through any of this mess, delivers consistent performance, offers both a 10 second rewind AND forwarding function, does not make you log in multiple times (only had to do so twice; one other for Sling subscription initiation), has only frozen in buffering once or twice for less than 10 seconds each time and has a better interface (which helps you find the shows you'd be interested in quicker). Moreover, Amazon customer service is excellent and readily available for help. I had one instance in which I allowed their technician active X remote control. He quickly, quietly and politely resolved the problem. I WILL NEVER BUY ANOTHER ROKU DEVICE AS LONG AS I LIVE!!! I AM GOING TO STICK THIS POS ON A TV I RARELY USE, OR SELL IT TO SOMEONE ELSE AND LET THEM DEAL WITH IT!

My first Roku I bought about a year ago. It just went out on me so I ordered a new 49.00 from amazon. When I went to set up on my Tv it gave an activation code and an error code when I tried to activate. A phone number popped up and I called it and it sounded like India. They said that there was a one time software update charge of 29.95 for her to activate my new device! And I would never have to do that again! I said absolutely not and took her name Tanya at Digistream I’m Tampa Fl.  Nothing in advertising about extra charges to activate! So I decided to get Roku customer service 816 272 8106. No longer working due to Covid! So I attempted to activate my device on tv again and this time I got someone who said they could activate but as of June they have to register new customers and it’s 200.00 for a year and 450.00 for 5 years!! I told her I’m returning this because it’s a scam and Roku is letting this happen. There is no customer support! DoNT BUY! This just happened to me on July 16 2020.  I'm still waiting to see my return is settled!

I can't tell you how much I love this Roku compared to Amazon Fire Stick. It is AWESOME and so easy to use and set up. Everything from the packaging to the contents of the box is quality and I love that I don't need 14 remotes to watch streaming tv. Roku even comes with instructions to set it up, but really, it is so simple. You can go online and watch tutorials from Roku and so much more.I had two Fire Sticks and neither one worked with Hulu and the stick got really, really HOT when streaming live tv. I wasn't crazy about the quality of Fire Stick either, Roku is night and day and with so many more features.I read the reviews on Amazon by the guys who I felt really know what they are talking about when it comes to streaming and comparisons. When I read that CNET also recommends this fire stick I was sold, especially after all the problems I had with Fire Stick. I LOVE Amazon and Prime but the Fire Stick was a bust for me in so many ways.I am so glad to be rid of cable and their hideous bills for getting nothing to watch and a ton of aggravation. Optimum raised my basic cable bill $30.00 after 4 years of loyalty and I was DONE!! Streaming is the future and the way to go.I have a 3 yr old Samsung Smart Tv 1080P and this Roku stick works great plus I am ready in the event I decide to get a 4K tv. Don't hesitate a minute. I don't think you can go wrong with any of the Roku sticks.

I'm SO glad I got this! 100x better than our fire stick. The picture quality is outstanding! We can get ALL the apps we were never able to before. The fire stick was so limited. We couldn't even get Vudu. And it's picture quality sucked. It would buffer too often. We have never, not once, had an issue with buffering with this Roku.(using the exact same internet and router) I only wish we would have made the switch much sooner! We love the free Roku channel on it.We will be getting another one now that we cut the cord on cable.I highly recommend!

I purchased this streaming stick because I was having trouble streaming content to my Sony Blu Ray player (Netflix and Amazon Prime).  It was so painful to try to watch streaming content and I was searching the internet to find some sort of solution.  I wondered if my internet provider was not giving me enough data speed and I also wondered if my wireless router was getting too old, etc.  Enter the Roku Streaming Stick+!  Now, I can stream anything and no problem.  I was absolutely shocked on how good my streaming is now.  I went with the plus model due to the fact that it claimed to have a better wireless reception than the regular streaming stick.  I don't know if I really needed the plus or if Roku is just that good, but I can report streaming content is not a problem anymore.  Now the Sony only play DVDs and BluRay discs.  Definitely recommend this.  The only thing negative to report is you cannot surf the internet with this or at least I haven't found a way to do that.  I have Firefox on my Android phone and on Roku and I can't seem to get that to work at all either.  I'm not worried about that because I usually don't surf the internet on my TV but it would have been nice to be able to stream shows from the websites of major networks like CBS (can't stream the free content you can stream on your laptop).

This is my third Firestick.  I bought it because it was the latest generation and my first generation had trouble with a couple of apps - dropping video, and audio not synced with video.  This corrected that problem (so far) but now every so often I get no audio.  The only way to fix this is to unplug the power to the transmitter for a couple of minutes to allow it to reboot.  Then, so far, the audio will come back on.  Not sure if this is a problem with just my device or if it might be inherent to all devices.  Other than that it works OK.Since my last review:Got two separate phone calls from Amazon.  The first was to verify that I had connected the device properly and to try different router settings.  This did not help.  But I did find that if I turned off the TV and then turned it back on most to the time the audio would then work.  On the second call from Amazon, they asked for all of the info regarding model of TV, etc., as they had similar concerns from other customers.A couple of days later another annoying problem came up.  During the playing of a video on the You Tube app, the video suddenly froze.  Tried turning on/off the TV with no success.  Tried other apps and they worked OK.  Opened You Tube on a different Firestick and a different TV and it worked OK.  Went back to this one and it still froze up.  Finally removed the power and unplugged from the HDMI port, let sit for about a minute, reconnected to the TV and then the You Tube app started playing again.  This is getting very annoying.  Hope Amazon can come up with a solution soon.1/27/21 - Amazon replaced this item with a "reconditioned firestick."  Within 4-5 days it started exhibiting the same problems.  Evidently this item was probably returned for the same problems, then marked "reconditioned" and sent to me as a replacement.  I've have spent countless hours on the phone with Amazon service reps, along with countless hours reconfiguring and then having to drive 70 miles to a UPS store to return the previous item.  Looks like I will be going through the same hassle again.  If Amazon would have just replaced this item with a new item possibly out of a better batch, I wouldn't continue having this problem.

I bought this Fire Stick on a whim -  it was on sale. My old one has been kind of slow lately so I thought, what do I have to lose? It was only $17.I honestly did not expect much from it, but apparently Amazon's R&D team has done its homework. I was very pleasantly surprised how quickly I was able to set it up. It took me virtually 5-7 minutes - and that included the most time-consuming part - downloading software updates and installing them.The new Fire Stick is definitely faster than the old one. It downloads the content much faster, and the remote makes it much more responsive and user-friendly (unlike the 2017 version). You can tell the difference right away. I've used it only 30 minutes, but I am excited to report that so far I am very happy with it. Best spent $17 lately.

Am called a technophile and tend to be an "early adopter". The idea of streaming TV has been around for a while the first I encountered (#6) was over a decade ago but the recent "stay at home" order combined with really inexpensive big screen TVs (have an advt for a 75" 4k for $228 from a big box) coupled with really high speed Internet (over 50 Mb/s) means all systems are go.Bought the Firestick lite to fill in a gap with my TCL tv in the guest bedroom: no HBO MAX. This is the main reason for a four star for the Firestick - no Charter/Spectrum app. Since I have the four biggies: Spectum, Amazon Prime, Disney +, and HBO MAX the fact is no one device I've found has all four here at the end of 2020.Other than that the Firestick is better than most. Like an Android TV it can attach a keyboard through BlueTooth something the #6 cannot. These small remotes make a search or even channel selection with a multichannel provider difficult.One other thing of note: it needs quite a bit of power. Some streaming sticks can be plugged into the TV USB for power. This Firestick would load but then constantly restart so almost nothing could complete.
