Once I connected it to the included wall wart everything was fine.One other note: the BR TV is about 60 feet and one floor from the wireless router. By itself the speed was around 8 Mb/s which should be fine for 1080 HD. For 4k I suspect a range extender might be needed but on a 43" is not an issue. Wrapping my hand around it tripled the download speed.So it is almost great and for many it would be but for now I still need two streaming devices to receive what is available.ps are a number of online workarounds for the Spectum/Charter issue. Ones I tried all wound up with the app bleating for an update that is not available.

I've had terrible luck with various previous models constantly disconnecting from my wifi (while no other devices had this issue) and showing the "Home is Currently Unavailable" error over and over. I couldn't even get through to movie without having to restart my Fire Sticks. I have since moved over to ROKU devices and all has been well. I took the chance at the Fire Stick again because of the sale and so far I haven't had any disconnects. This one seems to be working much better so far. I wish it had the controller the more expensive models do, but whatever, it works. The center "select" button is very wiggly and making a jiggling clicky noise when you barely touch it, so I'm expecting that to stop working eventually. Otherwise, the picture is fine and I don't have any other issues.

ordered 2 of these one for each of my kids room both were defected would go to a black screen the back button would stop working and would freeze then asked for a replacement which lately i Been having issues with either receiving my orders or with the workers not knowing what they’re doing and being on the phone for hours back and forth on hold etc. I don’t feel that this is appropriate being a prime member paying all that money for a year either to not receive your order as in it’s saying it’s out for delivery then all of a sudden is marked as undeliverable and being automatically sent back to the seller and being automatically refunded or having defective items and you’re on the phone for hours not happy never had these issues before always loved amazon but  then the replacement didn’t Work so yet again had to call Amazon to troubleshoot the replacement so I ended up having to send three fire sticks back yet again be on the phone for a long time frustrated aggravated hopefully this does not continue to happen because this was way too much aggravation and stress that was not necessary and thankfully the few people who I did get in contact with who actually did know what they were doing made it much more easier than dealing with the people who wasted my time and did not know anything

When I saw the fire stick lite available for only $18 I decided to grab one to pair with a video projector I recently purchased.  The lite version has all the features of my previous generation fire sticks (including Alexia voice control) so I had to do a little research to learn that it's called lite because it doesn't allow you to control your TV or stream 4K video.  Neither of those functions are a big deal to me so I was able to save $10-$20 relative to the higher tier fire sticks.  I've used it several times now and it does a great job of streaming Amazon Prime content.  I haven't had any performance issues at all relative to slow response times or buffering.  I can't comment on its WiFi performance, I bought an adapter that allows me to connect the fire stick directly into an Ethernet jack so network performance has been great.My only criticism is the fire sticks physical design.  Ever since the first generation the fire sticks usb port has been on the side.  When you plug the fire stick into the back of a TV or an A/V receiver the usb cord sticking out the side of the fire stick limits where you can put it and/or what you can plug in beside it.  It can sometimes end up eating 2 ports because you can't plug in anything beside it.  It would have made a lot more sense to me to put the usb port on the back of the fire stick so that the cord would be less in the way.To make matters worse the latest generation fire sticks are a bit wider than the old ones.  Now I don't know if there are any industry standards on HDMI port spacing but on my Yamaha receiver the width of the fire stick is great enough to block the HDMI ports on both sides so unless I use the fire stick in the right most port it ends up eating 3 ports.  Even when using the fire stick in the right most HDMI port it still makes the adjacent port unusable.

I am not tech savvy, but most of the reviews said this was so easy, that I took a chance.  All I wanted was access to Prime Video, but that did not show up as an option -- what did show up was channels I already have -- HBO and Starz.  After 2 days of messing around with this, I finally figured out I had to actually add the channels for which I already had subscriptions, and THEN it offered Prime Video.Also, I thought the Firestick would simply plug in like a thumb drive, but it actually has a black electric cord, so if you have a wall mounted TV, be prepared for a black cord to hang out the bottom of the TV.Finally, I have to use 3 different remotes to use Firestick.  One to switch the HDMI connection, one to adjust the volume, and the fire stick remote to move around the Firestick app.Now that I've worked out the issues, I am enjoying watching Prime Video on a large screen, rather than my laptop.

This review is for the "Fire TV Stick Lite with Alexa Voice Remote". I have 2 Roku 3s and have used them happily for years but their one downfall is that I can't stream facebook video with them. On black Friday this year, this product was on sale for 19.99. I figured at that price, why not give it a try? Lots of local musicians have been posting live video to facebook during the pandemic and I have been confined to watching them on my desktop - until now!The user interface for the Fire is intuitive and easy to use. It "fired" right up when I plugged it into my flat screen and as a welcome surprise, a lot of the apps I already had installed on my Kindle Fire tablet installed by default on the tv stick. Very slick! I opened Facebook on my phone, found a video, and was able to cast it to the Fire TV stick very easily. I did have to install the Facebook Watch app, but once installed, it made it even easier to watch videos from that platform. It also worked seamlessly with my Plex server (a must-have feature) and all the standard streaming services like Amazon video, Netflix, Hulu, and Youtube. I would recommend this as your central streaming device for sure!

Installed it almost as soon as I got it, turned it on had to do upda]te and connect to my WIFi, which it did but when I went to the home screen, NO NETFLIX was available, Well amazon called and got me through without a problem, then called Netflix to reset my password everything is great

The Lite version of Fire TV stick is only light on certain features. So, what’s missing?* TV/AVR control* Dolby Atmos Audio (HDMI pass-through)That’s it. In essence, we are talking convenience factor. You will need your TV remote for volume and input selection. These can be overcome using Alexa voice remote or a Fire TV blaster. I like the simplicity of a single remote, so the extra $15 is worth the convenience of the Fire TV stick over the Lite version.It operates the same as the other sticks, although the new UI/OS changes the way 3rd party apps are added (still allowed, just different). The new UI allows for individual customization of app selection and order. This is ideal for those who only watch a few channels/apps and for those easily frustrated hunting through endless rows of options.Use this product for TV in your RV, office, patio, or bathroom en-suite with an older model television. The picture is great and the stream reliable. Move up to the standard version to add TV/sound bar control.

I've never been a fan of the Fire TVs/Sticks compared to other streaming devices, but had started using one since HBO Max and other apps weren't available on the Roku.  I just ordered this FireStick for a downstairs to TV, but had been using a previous years model without too much issue on another TV.I set the new TV Stick is installed 3 feet from a large home router with high speed broadband.  It took several attempts to connect.  When restarting the FireStick it reports no connection on startup then finds the router about a minute later.  Tring to launch HBOMax takes 6 minutes for the main interface, another 5 minutes to start a program, then it freezes every 5 seconds.  I use the older model FireStick 50 feet away from the same router without this problem.Also can not use ESPN app on the FireStick, since it will not accept SlingTV provider login.  It looops back to a blank login page after  entering credentials (which is a painful process with the FireStick onscreen login page and remote).

I bought this solely so I could listen to audible on my tv, if I had known that I couldn't browse my library and that audible is controlled solely by voice command, I never would have bought it. Besides the audible issue, firestick tv really sucks, it's very chaotic, if you want access to everything, I would save up and get the nvidia shield pro, if you want something close to the best minus hbomax, buy a roku 4. Firestick tv misses the mark on everything.

You get what you pay for, in this case you get a 20$ piece of complete trash. Where do I start, how about the audio: I’ve never had a more incompatible device. Want to use Bluetooth headphones? Tough. Unless you want them blasting in your ears at full volume you need headphones with on board volume control. Now if you have headphones with on board volume control they will work but they will sound like utter crap and in my case the audio only comes out of the left channel (skullcandy wireless headphones). It also pops, cracks and cuts out every 10-30 seconds and has insane audio lag that constantly changes, so expect to mess with your TVs lip sync feature (if it has one) about 2-5 times and hour. I’ve also tried to connect a Bose Mini BT speaker. It connects but has the same pop/click issue. I tried using the aux-in on the Bose and my TVs audio out with zero sound. So enjoy your crappy tv speakers.The video: the video quality is pretty awful. I get weird red scan lines and all sorts of other glitches. It has major frame rate drops...I’m sorry why does this piece of crap exist from one of the biggest tech companies in the world? And every new version seems to be worse. I have an older version that does not have the same video problems but same with the audio issues. Save your money and buy something better. Or if you buy it don’t even open it. Just put it right in the trash.

The older similar device this one is replacing rarely had trouble with wifi/internet connections. This one never wants to launch Hulu. Or it will start and then give a message about "can't find" or "can't connect to that service at this time". Or it asks me to login to the services again. In both cases making it restart fixes it for a while. Sometimes Echo Dot can control it, sometimes it says I should go back to the Alexa app.This one is supposed to be the one without TV? Or maybe not replace the TV's remote. I don't know. I don't need either.It's the layout of the buttons. Logically the Home button should be at the top or the bottom (larger?) so you don't have to look to press it. No, they put it up from the bottom, between other buttons so I have to look each time. The one at the bottom, I don't know what that is. Something to do with live TV.It does feed a nice picture and clear audio to my old Sharp TV.

I've been using this a few months now.Pros (when it works):1. It streams some apps better and faster than the same apps via smart TV.2. Alexa's voice recognition has a pretty high accuracy, though there's room for improvement.3. The device is easy to set up.4. It's a good workaround for older TVs with specs too outdated for some channels, like iMDB TV.Cons (here we go):1. No disabling/adjusting sleep mode. Amazon refuses to add an option to turn OFF sleep mode, despite being given legit use cases for doing so in Amazon forums for the last couple of years. Want to leave it on for pets when you go out? Forget it. Have a business where the display needs to remain on? Nope. Or maybe you're like me and forget the TV is on because the screen is black. CAN I JUST SAY HOW ANNOYING THIS IS? You either have to root it, or install a 3rd party app (some of which also disable the screen saver).2. Interface text is SMALL. Like, really, REALLY unnecessarily, stupidly small. The last update did this, and there was no functional reason for it, just a designer decision of aesthetics over user need. So I guess older users, those with distance vision issues, or who have to place the TV a distance away don't matter.3. Given the brief time I've had it, I've had to restart it more often than I should have to. Captions will stop syncing up, audio will go out, or the video will freeze. This is while using Prime or Netflix, which BTW doesn't happen when I use the same apps installed on my Smart TV.4. The controller is small and very black, so it's super easy to lose, especially if you watch TV in low light or have dark furniture. I've had to add bits of fluorescent duct tape and glow tape so I can find them easier (or you can buy a brightly-colored silicone skin for it). And it's too curved to be able to stick any kind of location tag to it.I bought two, so obviously I didn't hate it. But this lack of responsiveness to good use cases and making changes nobody asked for that makes it less user- friendly are real issues.UPDATE: 4 months in and one is already broken. How convenient, when the warranty is 90 days.After about a minute, the screen freezes, and then the Fire Stick powers itself off completely! (Tried clearing the cache, soft reboot, hard reboot, restart the TV, even a factory reset - and problem persists.) Really, REALLY disappointing. Before this happened, I was seriously considering an Amazon Echo. Forget THAT.

I have a generation 1 FireStick. I didn't use it much, it was so sluggish to move from menu to menu. Since I'm now working from home, I decided to monitor my surveillance cameras with the Firestick.  I have 5 1 megapixel cameras, and have 2 different programs I can use: tinyCam Monitor PRO and Onvifer Pro.I use these 2 interchangeably on my Note 8 with no troubles.  The cameras are on my lan, so the internet is out of the picture.The Firestick (gen 1) was not up to the task, video sometimes would freeze, it was never smooth, and was pretty much always pixelating on any motion or just crashing, so I decided to upgrade to the latest gen of Firestick.  This device is MUCH smoother moving between menus, and is a much more enjoyable experience than the earlier version. The surveillance camera software is much better, its usable for the most part, still some choppiness and alot of lag, so I was disappointed with that, and they only crash once or twice in 8 hours.  The device sits 4 feet from the wireless source, and its a 5g link, checking the connection reveals no connection problems, and can't be the source of the lag, so that points to hardware.  Plex seems to work better on this one better than the original one.  Overall, its an improvement over gen 1, and perhaps I don't use it as intended, since I don't use it for entertainment, but I expected better performance.

Tv in living room. Had just got cable but didn’t have the channels I wanted without paying some outrageous price. Was recommended by a friend. The video we watch was horrible. Still don’t know all the features because it was hard to follow the video.

I'm still unsure. I haven't used it long, and consistently enough to know, howeverI started running a similar problem with this "lite" model that I had with my other Fire stick.APPARENTLY, your power adapters are faulty, as each one of them has run into the same issue, they don't produce enough power to power the unit consistently, so it either drops the programming or it goes into the "update" or "download" mode repeatedly.Once I replaced the adapter with a better quality power adapter the units worked fine.Here's the rub, I'd like to use my adapters for their specific device, so I have to swap it out for the stick when I want to watch Prime or any other app.I checked on AMAZON for a replacement and you want $20 for one. That's insane as the stick only cost me $18. No wonder so many people have reported issues with them, THE ADAPTERS DONT FUNCTION PROPERLY & $20 for a replacement is just wrong?Where's your quality control & customer service?

I have a very good surround system centered on a Denon AVR and multiple speakers.  All my surround sources go to the AVR which handles the surround audio and the video is sent to an LG OLED TV.  I want to be able to watch HBO Max movies in surround and initially bought a Chromecast which is supposed to be able to do surround but could not get it to work.  Saw many comments online having the same problems.  Spoke to their support but no joy.  Returned the Chromecast and bought this and it works PERFECTLY!!  I didn't want TV volume control as I have a universal remote to take care of that so this Fire Stick Lite is perfect.  The only down side is that the Fire Stick remote is not IR  so I cannot have my universal remote (which is IR only) control it.  But other than that it works very well.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED if you want surround audio.

Yep.  Keep getting the error 41 with anything viewable on Disney +.  I can get to the Disney + main screen and view all of the videos that are options - but as soon as I choose anything to watch I get the Error code 41.  Doing research, it lead me to believe that my wifi wasn't strong enough. Okay; possibility since my EA8300 is in the basement... bought an extender and installed/configured.  The extender is 15 feet away... Firestick states that wifi signal is very good.  Speedtests on my phone show 95mbs download.  Let's try Disney + again.  Nope.  Same freaking error.  Then I tried my 7 year old laptop.  Yep.  Disney + works just fine.  To any and all other peripherals = no problems at all.  Firestick?  Sucks.  Really... Disney + is the only reason I bought the Firestick.  Now what???Edit: through a massive internet search, I found the real problem with accessing Disney + via the Fire TV Stick... it has an issue with IPv6 on some routers. If you find yourself with the same issue I had, turn off the IPv6 or set it for pass-through. Viola!

Works Great and have been using Roku Products since 2010. There seams to be some confusion as to what all the unit comes with, so I have attached a picture. It does have a special power cord with a built in antenna, so you cannot a standard USB to Micro USB TV Adapter. That is why they use the older style mini USB Plug into the Stick instead of the more common Micro USB Plug like is used on the Amazon Fire Sticks and the other Roku Sticks.

1 year review update:Boy was I wrong about Roku being a solution. After a year now I can say with certainty that rokus own technology - hardware and especially software - are the very things youll be fighting with daily. This is horrible tech and theres no solutions here, just more problems than youve already got.Frequently dropping wifi, constant HDCP issues and settings that keep "forgetting" themselves, crashes all the time and all manner of streaming issues. Sometimes the picture is so pixelated I cant make it out, like it's a dying VCR tape or something - and Ive got 60M meg downstream cable internet service. Roku is the only platform that makes netlfix, hulu and sometimes Youtube an absolute chore to watch in comfort.My roku 4k plus Roku Streaming stick is garbage and a waste of time. I want to burn it, like in a fire. Thats how unhappy I am with Roku.Old review:Roku does a good job, and it kinda the Peacemaker of streaming platforms. Ok, yes the User Interface sucks and is pretty non-uniform/inconsistent in design, but the technology is GREAT and most importantly Roku is the only neutral ground for TV cable-cutter streaming services. Playstation has Vue so theyll never allow DirectTV Now or Sling or YouTube TV apps on PS4/PS5 etc, Amazon has their streaming services so they also ban certain direct competitors apps, same with Google TV devices and Apple TV etc...Most hardware manufacturers also have their own competing streaming services or have exclusive deals with one of them, and so they actively prevent and ban any competition from their platform, forcing the customer to use the one available option. Roku is like Switzerland - independent and neutral, without a directly competing service... And so EVERYONE makes a Roku app, and in that sense Roku is a fair free-trade zone, where quality and value of a given service is the only way to beat a competiting app... Roku is a neutral space where all the dirty tricks various companies use to force you to exist solely within their own software ecosystem don't have any reach. A pure free market, allowing the customer to win no matter how cutthroat the varied service providers want to be. Roku is the sherrif that keep Corporate greed at bay in a way. Worth dealing with the frustratingly poor UI design.

Just been using Roku stick plus for a week and need time to get use to it from cable remote.  The first day even plugged to wall outlet, I got insufficient power message. I chat with customer service and she was very helpful. I unplug from tv and let it charge for 15 mins. That was it and now it's charging through tv usb without the message. The stick is warm, but I think that's normal. For tv, I subscribe to Directv Now. I have to scroll through the channels and can't type in channel numbers like I use to. I can't use voice command to change channel either, Roku will take me out of live tv and open a corresponding App to that channel instead. Roku app doesn't allow me to change channels at all while watching tv. It would also be great if it has a mute button.My Roku came with remote with different short cut keys than shown: Netflix, Hulu, Sling, and Vue. I rather have one with NOW as shown.The good? Savings of 50% on cable, our household watches 16 channels but we need a package of 220 channels from Xfinity to get all the 16 that we watch regularly. On top of that no more equipment rental fees, except for modem/router...(next on shopping list).

I have owned this unbelievable piece of technology for about 10 days so please give my review the weight you deem appropriate.  So far,  I only have two complaints.  The mute button on the remote is poorly located and too easily accidentally pressed and occasionally the remote is a little sluggish in responding.  Easily connected, setup and activated, the device provides a mind-numbing number and variety of apps and channels with excellent picture and audio.  For those who choose to connect directly to av receivers I recommend you set the device audio to Dolby Digital plus. You will then enjoy multi-channel sound where available.  You may also need an hdmi extension cable. Although Roku will send one free of charge upon request it’s only about 4 inches long and practically useless. Amazon sells several and I purchased a 6ft one from UGreen that works perfectly.  I power my stick from a USB jack on the TV.  Roku recommends using the supplied adapter and connecting to an electric socket so it remains powered on at all times eliminating start up delay.  However, it only takes a few seconds to power on from the USB connection and this method also eliminates any heat build-up (however marginal) when the TV is off.  Some may argue that having the unit fire up every time the TV is turned on is likely to reduce longevity.  Of course this is the same argument advanced for computers and some other electronic devices.  I’ll leave that choice to you after noting that heat is a nemesis of electronic devices of virtually all kinds.  Use the power option that works for you.  Once set up you can literally spend hours just surfing through the staggering number of apps and channels.  Absolutely amazing device.  I’ll follow up if my opinion changes.

Had to update my review - every day - multiple times a day - my Roku disconnects from the wifi.When I IMMEDIATELY go through the prompts - it tells my wifi strength is either Good or Excellent and lets me reconnect.  Anywhere from 5 minutes to an hour later - it happens again. BEYOND frustrating.I should also note - when it happens - I'm pretty much sitting in front of TV with my laptop - connected to wifi - and my laptop connection is fine / untroubled.  This fact - coupled with the fact that it immediately allows me to reconnect leads me to believe that this is a Roku issue - not an issue with my ISP or wifi signal / strength.I even followed some steps on a YouTube tutorial (basically rebooting / refreshing via Settings) and that hasn't helped.Complete waste of my money.  I'm so angry with Roku right now.Like a lot of folks, I have Comcast, and I, therefore, have an insane monthly cable / internet bill.  So, of course, I'm always looking for ways to cut the cord OR save some money while I'm still cable bound.I'd read an article about how some enterprising folks were using Roku and the Comcast app - which is free, right now - but it's in beta stage - to save on cable rental fees.  I have 5 cable boxes (in addition to the DVR) - so I decided to give Roku a try - primarily to check out how it works as an option to get rid of my cable boxes.The set-up did NOT go off without a hitch.  When I entered my network password, initially, it accepted it, and a message appeared on the screen letting me know that the system needed to re-start to complete the installation. I was thinking, 'Wow! That was insanely quick!'But then . . . when it re-started, it kept telling me that my password was incorrect.  This went on for about 2.5 hours.  No exaggeration.  I knew my password was correct.  So I just continued working (I was parked on the couch with my laptop before starting the process) and re-tried the password every 15 minutes or so, and magically, all of a sudden it accepted the password and I finished the set-up.Ultimately, I think the product is 'Okay' - but I would never put on the two TV's we use for heaviest viewing.  That's because I'm not crazy about the actual interface. The TV I tried out with today is only a 42 inch - so the massive tiles (for channels) make it difficult to quickly scroll through and get to the channels you want.  I tried using the voice function to quickly navigate to the channel I wanted, but that, too, proved cumbersome.  For instance, (fictitious channel example - lol) let's say I searched for the 'SAL' channel.  It might return results of 'SAL Channel, 'Salads television show' and 'Sal and Andy Solve True Crimes show.'  So I scroll down to the 'SAL Channel', and click Ok, then it takes me another screen, where I have an option to Add the SAL Channel.  Even though I've already added it.  SO you click Add, then it opens.So after trying it out for a few days, I'll definitely keep it.  For my office, I got some inexpensive speakers for my computer and that TV is already hooked up as a second monitor so it was just a simple matter of logging into computer and viewing my line-up.So back to what I was saying - why I would never put the Roku on a TV I use heavily - because:1) no voice remote option - no way to manually enter a channel number - so you're scrolling to get to channels which can be kinda cumbersome*2) no way to schedule a recording - you can view recordings now (I guess they won that lawsuit sling TV had against them) - but not schedule them.3) You cannot pause or rewind Live TV and I do that (A LOT)So I plan to order a two more for the other TV's, and I'll wind up purchasing another Samsung TV for the fifth television - because unlike most Smart TV's - Samsung actually has a full-on browser - so you can surf / go to any website and just login / view.  It's pretty great - but that's another review . . .

Worked great for six weeks but suddenly unable to connect to my wireless internet. I have a number of other things hooked to wireless and it’s working great. Tried to get support from Roku and it is non-existent!!!  There are MANY Roku owners experiencing the same problem and nobody is able to get any answers!!!  My Roku streaming stick + is now a useless piece of junk!!!UPDATE:  I was never able to get through to Roku so called Amazon product support.  They were wonderful and patient as they guided me through trying to fix the problem. It became apparent the unit was defective. Amazon authorized a replacement unit be sent and I’m returning the defective one.  I so appreciate Amazon’s wonderful customer relations!!!

We plug in our Roku streaming stick plus into the USB port of the TV. So, when we put the TV off, the Roku stick also goes off power. When you power on the TV again, the Roku starts up, and now, suddenly the remote stops working. To get it to work,  we have to get up, walk close to the TV and point it at the stick just behind the TV. Now it starts working, and will continue to work until the next power cycle. This is unacceptable! What was wrong with the infra-red remote? Worked just fine!Another peeve. I tried plugging the Roku into the wall outlet. So, lets say you're watching an Amazon Prime video, or anything else. You power off the TV, but not the Roku. The Roku continues to stream. This is a no-no. What if you're on a limited internet plan? Also, the cable company is itching to meter our internet, it just needs a justification. Wasteful streaming will provide just such a justification. On the other hand, the Amazon fire stick is smart on this particular issue. It stops streaming, it senses the TV is off.

Roku streaming devices are wonderful in many ways. However, I’ve purchased two of these Streaming Stick-Plus’s, and I feel compelled to tell you about their less wonderful aspects: Both of the units I purchased failed pretty catastrophically. I needed their customer service to help me. And their customer service ranges from nightmarish to effectively non-existent.My first Stick+ failed after just nine days when the remote control just spontaneously completely died. I managed to get their so-called customer service to send me a replacement remote, but only after 7 completely solid, non-stop, super-ultra-nasty hours on text chat with them, including a lot of threats from me to send the whole thing back to Amazon for a refund (which is what I definitely actually should have done).My second Stick+ has overheating problems whenever the house warms up - despite good ventilation, added HDMI extender cable, etc., etc. I might possibly maybe be able to get it replaced under their supposed 1-year warranty, but, absolute best case, it would take many more hours of my time, and return shipping costs, and weeks without TV service, with no reason to expect any good outcome, just more very unpleasant, badly wasted time and money.Bottom line: You can be pretty sure you will have reliability problems and need service help with this product. But you should regard Roku’s warranty and support as non-existent, effectively just a scam, because it is. If you buy one of these units, be sure to try to flush out any problems within the first 30 days; and if you find any problems, just return it to Amazon, don’t waste your time with or expect any help from Roku.How badly can you treat your customers and still expect them to give you any credit?

Luckily the scam I'm talking about is in no way Roku's fault. When setting up my Roku I attempted to pull the Roku site on my phone and punch in the code. Apparently there's either a REALLY good spoof website, or the actual one is somewhat infiltrated, because I got a message that my Roku was "temporarily locked" and that I needed to call them. I've set up a few of these devices before, so I was already on alert. I called the number and was set up with "Roku customer service" who offered to fix the device and get me started, but said they'd need to charge me a one-time fee to access over 50 Roku channels. If you've used Roku before you know this is not the case. We went back and forth a bit. The Roku setup screen even states that there is no fee to set up. I asked the "technician" about this, and they gave some excuse about how charging me money to activate me was not an "activation" fee. I was getting more suspicious, and requested a supervisor, which I'm not sure wasn't the same person. The "supervisor" offered me a "supervisor's discount" of $10. It's interesting to note that the base activation fee kept changing from $49 to $69. I eventually got very suspicious, told them I was investigating further, and hung up on them. I then went my desktop computer upstairs (which I was too lazy to do before) and activated the Roku that way, and was streaming in a matter of minutes.I Googled it later, and apparently it's a fairly common scam. Don't believe me? Look for yourself.Roku makes a wonderful product. My original ones are still running okay, but I've been upgrading a bit this year. I've been consistently happy with their performance. I highly recommend them. Just be careful when you go to register.

This is important info. If you use a soundbar like I do, the Roku Streaming Stick, within 2 minutes of plugging in, with give a warning that it is overheating. If using a soundbar, please either get the free hdmi extender from Roku themselves or buy one that handles 4k. This is important info that I never saw in any reviews. The extender works fine, I just wish the product description would have mentioned it.

It pains me to give a bad review to Roku because I have another Roku TV and I love it!  This is not a ding on the product itself, but more on the product page.  The product page neglects to explain the importance of HDCP 2.2 standard.  It is some sort of copyright protection technology so that you can't make recordings of 4k HDR streams.  Older TV's that are only 1080p compliant (basically anything older that 2013-ish) won't have the proper copyright ability and the Roku device won't work with it AT ALL. I wish that it was more explicitly explained in the product page that if you want Roku on an older 1080p TV, you have to buy the ROKU EXPRESS device, instead.  I had a very bad experience trying to get this to work on my non-smart TV. After several hours searching the internet, i finally learned of the problem.  I knew that my TV was not 4K, but I just thought that the steaming stick would just dumb down the quality for my TV.  I didn't think it would completely not work.

We replaced our Firestick with one of these and we won't ever be going back. In the past few years, we've been through multiple Firesticks as they seem to only last a year or two for us before having problems and just failing. We would have connection issues constantly, dropping connection or just taking forever to load. Super slow loading of some apps, especially Amazon's own store (which doesn't make sense.. you'd think their product would load their own app quickly).Roku doesn't have any of these issues and the pre-programmed buttons on the front are great for us. Great streaming quality, never has slow load times, never lags, quickly cycles through applications and is a very smooth experience. The remote also controls turning our TV on/off and can control the volume. A really great, simple product that does exactly what it's meant to do.

I am satisfied with the performance of the Roku Stick+, though it did require the addition of a wifi ‘range extender’ to improve reception. The device converts my ‘dumb’ TV to a ‘smart’ TV, allowing access to a wide variety of viewing options, including Spectrum, Netflix, etc. I can now use my laptop exclusively for work, while watching a TV program. A nice addition.I am not sure why the Roku device needs a signal booster to perform properly since my laptop (used next to the TV) and all other device work fine. When first installed, the Roku Stick+ wifi screen reported “POOR” signal strength. After the addition of the range extender (purchased some time ago on Amazon for about $20) the signal strength is now “EXCELLENT”. A bit confusing since the extender is located next to the TV in what would be considered an ‘undesirable’ location: floor level, between appliances, and horizontal. But, it works!The “Roku Stick+” is a replacement for the less expensive “Roku Stick” which failed to reliably connect: poor picture quality and frequent “reloading . . .” (buffering).

Well I bought the device 60.00 dollars and set it up I needed a code to but in on the website so I did and yes it does not take it YOU have to call them to activate streaming. Okay on there own screen at the bottom stated no fees for activation or support! But then in the same breath they tell you - you have to pay them a one time fee of wait 130 dollars for 5 years 250 dollars for life time???? I just bought your product and you won’t let me stream anything without some kind of payment????? Then why does it say NO FEES for activation there is no trial period nothing they just want you’re money or No ROKU and customer service is horrible they told me to shut my mouth and hung up on me this went one for hours well if you can have to have this crap product so be it I’ll never buy one again FIRESTICK for me no hassle plug and play Hence I returned there scam stick HORRIBLE

Remote and Roku stick would not communicate. After reading several online troubleshooting guides, concluded this is a common problem with this version. Going back to the regular cheaper version, which has always worked like a charm.

Stuff I like:  Super Simple to use, supports 4K with HDR, much faster than previous models, can be plugged into a USB port on the television for power with the included cable, (preventing the need to buy the little $5 stick-to-USB cable to avoid using the AC cord), remote as always is so simple with only a few buttons and this one controls the TV on/off as well as the volume - though I still have four remotes for my TV!  :(Stuff I don't like:  Does not support Dolby Vision, remote has the sponsered one-touch pre-programmed buttons with channels most of us have no need whatsoever forI do use three streaming platforms on one television - Roku, Chromecast, and Fire Stick.Roku is by far the better of the three and this is my second Roku streamer.  The simplicity is what gives Roku the edge over the others.  Even though I've only used the iPhone app for my pre-existing Roku, the included remote is simple with only a few buttons and no clutter.  I do wish the "included pre-programmed"  buttons, like the one-touch Netflix, Sling, Hulu, and Vue, (what the heck is VUE???) buttons were not there and instead we were given the option to add our own one-touch favorites instead of letting those companies pay Roku for the privilege.  It's just wasted space on the remote, except maybe for Netflix. Roku could have used one of those buttons for a much needed mute button for the volume.My favorite for supporting Roku over the others, and I'm sure many agree, is the extremely simple home screen.  Many web review sites say it could be called "dated" but in this case, it's welcomed and Roku's biggest asset.  It's too simple and attractive.  My favorite positive Roku has over the others is there is little to no bias whatsoever on the home screen as the others can add so much clutter, advertising, and pushing their sponsored marketing stuff on you.  I also like the idea that I can plug the power for the stick directly into an unused USB port on the TV to avoid using the included AC power cord and adapter.  Our TVs today have enough unsightly wires in the back from stuff as it is!My personal biggest negative with the Roku Streaming Stick + is it does not support Dolby Vision, only HDR10.  I can't figure Roku out on this, the days of regular 4K are far behind us and a televison without both HDR10 and Dolby Vision should ** never ** be considered if you're really into televison specs and display quality.  Thankfully my Vizio supports both Dolby Vison and HDR10 on Chromecast.  The lack of Dolby Vision is why I gave this review 4 stars instead of 5.  It would be nice if the remote would control my Vizio's input options in addition to the volume and power on/off buttons allowing me to put my Vizio remote away.Overall, for the price, quality, and features, this is an excellent streamer I highly recommend.

I thought I would give Roku a try.  Should have stuck with Amazon Fire Stick, they are great and I have 3 already, and a Cube. The issue is..Before you can even use Roku, you have to go through so many steps to set it up, one of the bullets in the info states "Setup is a cinch: Plug it in, connect to the internet, and start streaming--it's that simple"........IT IS NOT THAT SIMPLE !!! you have to use your phone or PC, you have to give personal information, gender, birthday, email, address,  AND.....you have to set this up with a credit card. You have to give all of this information during set up before you can even stream, you can not go any further without all of this personal information.  I did not feel comfortable with doing this. I should have read all of the reviews first. Lesson learned.  Read all of the reviews  with a 1 and 2 stars, these customers are not exaggerating. I reported this to Amazon as misleading product information.

First, the bad. It took me forever to figure out why the unit wouldn't connect at 5 GHz - it can't see "DFS" channels. In plain english, you need to select channels 37-48 or 149-161; it can't see any channels between.Now the good, this thing is awesome! It boots quickly, can run off of USB power from the TV, and the addition of volume control and TV power are fantastic. We cut the cord and only use Roku for content - now we have only one remote that can do everything, including search for content using voice. The user interface is significantly improved from previous generations. It is very simple to use, even my four-year-old has no problems.Overall, I get it 4.5 stars. The 5 GHz channel issue is easily compensated. Otherwise, is perfect.

I moved my Samsung smart tv where there was no cable outlet, and where it would have been to expensive and messy to install one. Then I downloaded the Spectrum streaming app. I experienced annoying buffering. I tried various solutions without success. I was almost to the point where I was ready to give up. When I read that Roku long-range wireless receiver gave you extended range and a stronger signal for smooth streaming even in rooms farther from your router I thought I would give it a try. My router was upstairs, and far from my tv. My extender didn't solve the problem. I downloaded the Spectrum app on the Roku and I experienced immediate success. It's been about two weeks and I haven't experienced any buffering on Spectrum.

Recently decided to try and ditch the cable bill and use a tv streaming service (yttv). One big thing to note is that the power button only turns the tv on/off (via IR). If you've got a 1080p stream going and push that power button, you will continue to eat up your internet bandwidth to the tune of up to 50GB/night. I came to this realization a bit too late. All you have to do is be sure to hit the "home" button before shutting off the tv. Easy to remember, extremely difficult to put into practice with a revolving door of toddlers and guests accessing the tv.A second option would be to power the device via USB power from the tv, but this means a reboot of the device every time the tv is power cycled - this is far from ideal when considering boot time plus remote pairing time. Far too long for my taste.I much prefer this unit to the fire stick that has screen after screen of Amazon content and no (official) yttv support. The interface is the best I've used on a streaming device (fire stick, roku, shield tv).I'm removing a star based on two things:1) the remote interface for a consumer looking to stream tv. An option to trigger a "home" button push with every power button push would be super... or hold the home button for some time to trigger the IR to shut off the tv... Just something to couple those two buttons somehow. Maybe even put the device into a standby mode/home screen based on HDMI CEC when the tv shuts off. I just hate that a tv power button was included on the remote that doesn't function the way a traditional tv power button functions.2) no sound bar volume support. Tvs get flatter, speakers get worse necessitating external sound, and this remote cannot support it. Boo. Fire stick does.Regarding #1, Sure, the tv streaming app could include a timeout option, but the ideal scenario to me is to stop all streaming when I command the display off. Certainly music streamers would not prefer such a feature, so to me, the ingredients lead me to believe this should be an option.Very good product, just not very good for me.I literally cannot afford to use this device to stream tv due to this functionality combined with the occupants of my home.

This is a reliable steaming device that seems to be compatible with any TV that has HDMI ports.  It is a rather bulky stick that does not fit into HDMI slots that are close together (as on many TV's).  A short "dongle" cable is included in the package, so the stick then dangles on the back of the TV.  However, this seems not to be much of a problem.  Like the current ROKU streaming sticks, this stick also requires a separate power cable and power brick, so you'll need an available AC socket.  Unfortunately, plugging the power cable (without the brick) into my TV's USB socket produced an error message, so I was not able to simplify the wiring in that way.  This "lite" version of the Firestick does not have audio control buttons.  I think that is both an advantage and a limitation, in that it avoids compatibility problems with your soundbar (a problem I had with another version of the Firestick).  Bottom line is you'll need to use your TV remote to control the audio volume.The user interface is pretty easy to navigate, though I think not as elegant as the interface for TV's having built-in Fire support.  The voice commands generally work well, and this seems like a definite plus for a device in this price range.  The Firestick Lite also integrates with Echo Dot devices.  This is not really useful if the Dot is in the same room as the TV but could be valuable if the Dot is in another part of the house.I think it is useful to compare the Firestick Lite to the ROKU Express (the comparable non-4K ROKU streaming device).  The available streaming platforms for both devices seem pretty much the same (HBO Max, Showtime Anytime, Netflix, Amazon Prime, Hulu, etc.), though it looks like ROKU may have a few more of the obscure platforms.  I was able to download the Criterion Channel on both a ROKU Express and the Firestick.  On the day Discovery Plus launched in January 2021, ROKU had it available, but the Firestick did not.  However, a week later, the Firestick did have it. The ROKU user interface is simpler and I think easier to use than the Firestick interface.  Both devices have a search function, though ROKU's seems to work a bit better.The bottom line is that the Firestick is a very reasonable alternative to ROKU devices.  I would not pick either the Firestick or ROKU on the basis of channel availability, since both are excellent in this regard.  If voice control is important for you, the Firestick is a good choice.  If you are a big fan of the Amazon Prime channel, you may also prefer the Firestick, because its user interface focuses on that channel's content.  If you don't use Amazon Prime, then you may find that the ROKU user interface is a better fit for you.

THIS IS THE SMARTEST MOVE I'VE MADE IN MONTHS! The Firestick Lite bears a bit of comparison to the 4K Firestick ...A year ago, I agonized over which Firestick product would be best for me.  I decided that forward-thinking would be best and went with the 4K Firestick, even though nothing is broadcast or streamed in 4K YET.  It turns out that embracing the newest technology is a huge trade-off.  Sound, picture quality, bells and whistles are great, BUT ... FYI:  4K IS A BANDWIDTH HOG!!!!!!!!  It doesn't matter what your speed is.  It could be 200 Mb and you'd still have buffering and dropped connectivity issues. What matters is how many connected devices you have along with other wireless connections near you.  HARD LESSON LEARNED: THE RING DOORBELL is a signal thief and only before and after the one nearest me was installed/uninstalled could I watch anything on the 4K Stick for more than a few seconds or minutes at a time.So, when Amazon offered this Lite version of Firestick at an unbeatable sale price, I was torn about whether to even bother with it or just  bite the bullet and buy  a second 4K Stick.  I mean, if the 4K is an issue, the Lite version had no hope.  Right?  WRONG!  I figured the Lite version might just be less of a drag on bandwidth and speed, and it is.  I've been running it straight for almost 24 hours hours I've been live steaming TV and playing movies and shows on Prime, Netflix, Starz, Pluto, CBS All Access, etc.  NOTHING HAS BUFFERED, STOPPED, STUTTERED, DROPPED THE CONNECTION.  It reminds me of the old days when I stayed at 3 Mb when everyone else topped out at 15 and I streamed everything smoothly because I was the only car on the slower freeway so to speak, while everyone else was crammed into the newest, fastest highway.Well, the Lite is pure DELIGHT.  The same pieces as the other sticks:  the stick, the extender, the adapter connector to the outlet, and the Alexa-enabled remote.  This remote won't control the TV but it does everything I need.  I prefer individual remotes anyway, and it's in the bedroom so any shortcomings won't matter.  I never pre-link my Amazon devices, but setup is an easy snap.  Just  manually input the wireless Network key and you're set.  Add the desired standalone apps you want and start streaming.Some reviewers also complained about the unavailability of YouTube.  It's on there. I'm not missing anything that I have with the 4K Stick, but I have gained the luxury of nonstop streaming which has been a setback for the 4K stick.  Now I'm comparing the streaming on the 4K stick and any interruptions to the flawless run I've had on the Lite Stick.  If it goes down as expected, I just may buy another Lite Stick and use it in the living room as well.  the difference in sound and picture is negligible to me at this point without full 4K, and I want smooth streaming now more than a future benefit.  HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS STICK.

UPDATE:After writing the original, negative review Amazon tried to shame me via text, voice-mail, and email -- 'cause it must be my fault, right? Thing is, after the negative experience with the Fire stick, I bought a Roku stick and it works really well: no lag on the controller and a good UI/UX -- just like the old FireTV.Sorry Amazon, it isn't your consumer's responsibility to fix your product.ORIGINAL REVIEW:Loved my old Fire TV. I only upgraded because an app I wanted wasn't supported on the old one.WTF happened?The controller lag is ridiculous -- it can take a second or more for it to respond. Lot's of fun to enter a username or password, let alone just trying to navigate menus.Then, there's the whole UI/UX. Tedious and painful are the two words that come to mind.Run away. Run away.Lab126 has definitely jumped the digital shark.

****I am editing my review after initially, I wrote this review and got call from Amazon customer support person again to get some issues fixed.****1. Unable to install Sling Tv app : This issue was resolved as initially my account was set to different country than USA and issues fixed when I login using USA account.2. Support guys told this is 1st generation device. This is ok as it's 1st gen (lite) among other varients.3. Unlike other versions of fire stick support guy is unable to take remote contol of fire stick to troubleshoot issues. This was resolved after I update my account to USA.

I received this item and had no trouble setting it up. But the next day it started occasionally freezing up and not responding to the remote. On the third day the stick was completely unresponsive and would not even power on.I tried to get a replacement, thinking it would be easy and straightforward but kept getting directed to a useless customer service bot that I'm sure eliminated lots of jobs. It kept getting stuck in a loop and could not even establish what product I had an issue with so I called and after more than 20 minutes of being put on hold repeatedly while they "looked into the options" I was able to finally convince someone to just refund my order. I don't even want a replacement at this point. The customer service strategy seems to be to try and prevent returns and exchanges as much as possible even by way of frustrating the user to the point they give up.

Update 12/2/2020 - After using this for a couple weeks i went and disconnected both the Roku and Chromecasts for good. i've even stopped using the smart tv apps and only use this unless i happen to be watching something in 4K or 8K only then do i use the built in TV apps. i didn't expect much from a $17 dollar stick let alone that i would prefer it to all our other streaming media devices.We already had a Roku premiere plus 4K unit however we get dozens of OTA channels with our antenna and wanted something that could put all our media in one spot, using one device. should also note we had a couple chromecast dongles as well.The stick comes with what you need to get started. Batteries, charger, cable, hdmi connection and an hdmi extender for those who need one. If unsure how it all connects I included photos showing that. Ours was linked to our existing amazon account when it arrived. It was as simple to install as you could hope for, no rocket scientist needed so to speak.We have streaming services like YouTube TV, Amazon Prime, Netflix, CBS all access, etc. As said we also get a lot of OTA channels using our antenna thanks to our signal amplifier. Once setup is complete by pressing the ‘tv with rabbit ears’ you will go to the channel guide section. There it starts out with the OTA channels, then YouTube TV and so on.Also you have the ‘home’ button. That takes you to the main page showing all your media sources and recently used channels. There is a menu across the top with viewing options. On the far right as we have a recast device, there is DVR. So again everything all in one spot using one device, just what we wanted.The remote response is fast, much more than expected. Compared to the Roku premiere plus 4K response times it is blazing fast which honestly that surprised me. that considering the Roku cost 6X what I paid for this stick. Picture quality to my eyes is no different than if viewing using the stock smart TV apps or Roku device.Plenty of useful options and settings with the device. As mentioned we have the amazon recast and paired with this stick the two together are a wonderful. The first one worked so well I ordered a second for our mom. I only bring that up because she still cannot set the clock on her old VCR. Anything even remotely tech related means I get to do it for her.This fire stick and the remote are so well designed I was able to give her one. It took me all of ten minutes to show her how to use it. since she not only can use the fire device, tv how she wants and when she wants but it also gave her a little positive, confidence boost being able to use tech that before was always too complicated for her to use.The only minor negative is voice control. Sometimes it gets it right other times it doesn't but does get to the 'general neighborhood' so to speak.We got both of ours when they were priced at seventeen bucks. Well worth it and then some in all of our opinions in this household. I wouldn’t hesitate to recommend this to anyone. Those intimidated by tech or those like myself who simply want everything in one spot with one remote to access it all from.

It was easy to install to my monitor HDMI port using the extender cable that was included with the kit. I needed the extender cable because the HDMI ports on my monitor are inset. So I'm glad that the extender cable was included. The instructions that came with it were easy to follow. And for good measure Amazon sent me more instructions via email after I ordered. I have an older gen1 Fire system that connect via cable that I use on our HTS where we have CAT6 installed. But wanted to add Prime video to another set. This works just fine for that, so I gave it 5 stars.  I understand that it doesn't have all the bells and whistles, but for what I needed it works just fine.

Got the first fire stick - no picture. Followed Amazon support steps - no dice. They sent a second stick - this one was filled with static and the screen flashed in and out. I managed to complete the setup and got a clear screen by limiting the stick to 720p output.This is ridiculous. My older 2nd gen fire stick had no trouble outputting 1080p and there’s no reason this one shouldn’t either. Truly annoyed with Amazon and their “support”

I was apprehensive when I bought this, simply due to the fact that the 'regular' version is so much more expensive.  I was almost convinced that, in purchasing this one, I would be missing some sort of critical feature, and would regret 'getting what I paid for'.I haven't.I'm now wondering why anyone would choose to pay double the price for the original version, when the only thing you are missing is the ability to power and adjust the volume on your television; this is something that I do with the proprietary TV remote anyway, as I would think most people would.  I still get every streaming feature, apps that I couldn't normally access on my Smart TV, e.g., Disney+, ease of use with the remote, and the voice command feature (which is something I did NOT have in my old FireStick).  I am missing nothing, and was able to save some cash while doing so.Amazon devices are always an easy 11/10 for me, and this one is no exception. It's a great, affordable option for those of us that don't sweat the extremely minor inconveniences of life.

I've owned two other fire sticks and they've worked great. My daughter and granddaughter got them as well which I set up for them and they worked great for them as well. I purchased the new Firestick Lite and had it for awhile before I switched out my old one for this one that I installed just two days ago. When I opened the package, it wasn't sealed, the batteries were already in the remote, while all the others were separate in the box, and the protective plastic on the remote was missing which leads me to believe this item had been returned because someone definitely got into it before I did. I've had to restart it multiple times because it kept saying I didn't have an internet connection...which I did have each time. I restart the Firestick and it works for awhile but then does it again. It's definitely not my internet because all my other devices work. I don't know how this item was allowed to go out when it was obviously opened but I will be return this one.

UPDATE: After writing the review, shortly thereafter I received a call from Amazon. Awesome BUT Creepy.  They wanted to offer a solution to my problem.  What?!! I couldn't speak at the moment and requested they email me.  I received the email and followed their instructions. It worked!!!  Great Customer Service!ORIGINAL REVIEW: Let's be honest.  Who doesn't like the price?  But, the issues I am experiencing is crazy.  Not sure if it matters, but when I am done watching TV, I normally turn off the TV.  I know--what a phenomenon! When I go to watch TV again, I will turn on the TV (Lite does not have power button) and wake the Fire TV Lite.  Sometime it will not wake (gray screen).  Most times, it will wake and function BUT without sound/audio!!!!!!!  No SOUND!!!I then have to reboot the Fire TV Lite in order for the sound to come back! This is GARBAGE!

I have several Fire Sticks, Roku TVs, and a Roku Express.  I don't have a need for 4K so that feature, found on the more expensive models, is not important to me.  Price and basic performance are what counts.  The new FireTV Stick Lite delivers--especially at the current promotional price.All three of my basic Fire Sticks are standard models and identical in appearance with slightly different remote controls.  The oldest standard stick has the most basic features and no volume or power button.  The newer standard model has the same controls but with the addition of a power button, mute button and volume controls.  The newest Lite model removes the power and sound buttons, but adds a guide button, not on the other two.They removed the power and sound buttons on the Lite model.  With these buttons, I pretty much don't have to use the TV remote control at all.  For a few dollars more, you may want to consider the basic FireTV stick, just to get the power and sound buttons.  Just make sure that you are getting a newer model with these features, and not the original stick without these buttons.UPDATE 12/13/2020:  I discovered that you CAN control the TV Power ON/OFF with the Fire Stick Lite if your TV is CEC capable (most are.)  Pressing the HOME button on the Fire remote should turn the TV on and switch to the Fire input.  If the TV is already on, pressing the HOME button will switch to the correct input.  To turn the TV off, press the MIC button and say "TV POWER OFF" and it should turn the TV off.  Make sure that your TV HDMI settings have CEC control turned on for this hidden feature to work.  So far, I haven't been able to control the volume this way.All of the remote controls use RF (radio frequencies) to control the stick, rather than the usual infra-red (IR) controls found on TV remotes.  That means that they don't have to be pointed at the TV to work.  In fact, they wouldn't work with the Fire Sticks if they were IR remotes since the Stick sits behind the TV.  The downside to the RF remote is that they are specific to the individual stick.  The menu allows you to pair a new remote to the Fire Stick if you replace one.  You can also access the Fire Stick with your cell phone with the FireTV app.  This has come in handy when I've misplaced the remote control, or worn down the battery and not had a replacement.  By comparison, the Roku Express (and my Roku TVs)  use IR remotes that you have to point.  They are interchangeable, and the batteries seem to last longer than the RF remotes used with the Sticks.Performance, picture quality and speed are good on all three Fire Stick models.  The Lite model is the newest of the basic models and should have the fastest speed, but I haven't detected any difference.  To save on network bandwidth, I force all of my devices to operate at 720P.  The picture quality is quite good on my TVs (up to 50") and pushing higher resolutions just wastes bandwidth, in my opinion.  However, picture quality is heavily dependent on the particular app and type of content being watched, so I can't really make any predictions how it will work for you.The FireTV Sticks plug directly into the HDMI connector on your TV.  A short extension cable is provided if there is not enough space for the Stick to be plugged directly in.  The unit is provided with a 5V  1.0 amp AC adapter and a short USB cable.  Amazon recommends plugging the stick in to a separate outlet, rather than using the USB jack on many TVs.  In fact, if the unit detects that the TV USB connector doesn't have enough amperage, you'll get a message telling you not to use it.  It's more convenient to use the TV to power the Stick but there are drawbacks aside from the lack of power.  The TV often turns off the USB connector when powered down, meaning that when you turn on the TV, the Fire Stick will have to reboot and reconnect to your network, slowing down your start-up.  It would also be possible, in rare instances, to accidentally power down your stick with the TV when an upgrade is being performed, which could cause problems.  All that said, I still use the Fire Stick with a smaller 24" Vizio that I carry out to the patio, and power it with the TV's USB connector.All of the FireTV Sticks have the ability to talk to Alexa by pressing the microphone button.  Because they are directly linked to the FireTV stick, you can also tell it to search for and pull up apps.  Before using the FireTV products, I was accustomed to selecting a search box and keying in what I was looking for.  With the FireTV Sticks, I can press the mic button and say what app I'm looking for and install it.  Or, I can tell it what program I am looking for and it may search and find it on YouTube, then start playing it.  Neat feature and habit forming.  The voice remote has many other features, like being able to answer my Ring doorbells, view my CloudCams, and other Alexa related skills.  However, for most Alexa related activities, I usually have an Echo in the same room and use that, rather than the Fire Stick.How does the FireTV Stick Lite compare with the Roku Express?  Because they are similarly priced,  you'd expect them to be very similar, but they are actually quite different.  I've always liked Roku's and the Express is a very fast and capable unit.  It doesn't hang from the HDMI connector, but instead connects with a short cable and sits under or on top of the TV, positioned so the remote's IR beam can control it.  The Roku Express seems to respond faster, and with some apps, performs much faster.  Again, that could be and app thing, and not the performance of the unit.  With CEC compatible TVs, the Express is able to turn the TV power on and off with the basic remote.  One BIG difference (and one that's hard to find in the literature) is that the FireTV Stick works on Wi-Fi at 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz.  The Roku Express only works at 2.4GHz.  If your network is heavily dependent on 5GHz, the Roku Express won't be a good choice.  Fortunately, in my situation I am able to use both.Finally, with any smart TV adapter, make sure that you get one that will run the program apps that you want.  They are mostly the same on the Roku and Fire devices but there are differences.  For example, on the FireTV Stick, I can view my Amazon Photo library, including videos that I've shot with my cel phone.  I can't do that (at present) with the Roku.  You may find that the Roku has apps that are not available on the FireTV products.  Ultimately, it's the apps that make these things work.

I admit that the thought of cutting off cable caused me actual emotion pain lol.  But so did paying that cable bill.  The Amazon firestick delivers everything I need for TV viewing.  I am not missing cable at all!  I am so happy that this technology is available and delivers television viewing in a remarkably easy and painless way at such an affordable cost.  Now... what to do with that $120 extra per month... :)  I'm a happy girl!

I wrote a review giving this three stars. After another couple of weeks I have lowered it. This is a piece of crap. It hardly works and it of poor quality. Buy the regular fire stick. This is garbage.

This device is not compatible with my Insignia television. Every other device requiring an HDMI connection works great.  Fire TV Stick Lite does not, I've been delivered 3 in a week all failed to work.

We were previously using a game console to stream video content to our TV. This was fine for the gamers in the house (me) but everyone else struggled with using the controls to watch streaming programs. I picked up the Fire TV Stick Lite and was amazed and how easy it was to to setup. Installing apps for streaming was like you would do on a phone or tablet and the remote is simple to use. My daughter really likes the built in Alexa to the remote. With this we are getting much better use of our streaming services. We have even figured out how to get HBO Max on it so there is no need to go back to the game console for anything other than games.

I have been a long time Fire Stick user since 2015.  I have 3 - and all of them are gen 1s.  Yes, the upgrade has been long overdue.  And wow, gen 3 is incredibly fast.Some thoughts and tips:1) The out of the box experience was very smooth.  If you are familiar with Fire Stick of any generation, then everything will be very familiar to you.  It checked for new software update which took a few minutes, but I was up and running in no time.2) (Coming from gen 1), the remote feels more "premium".  The buttons are rubber on gen 3, as opposed to hard plastic on gen 1.3) I bought the "lite" because a) I don't have a 4K TV (and therefore no need for a Fire Stick 4K) and b) didn't really care for the additional features of "standard" compared to "lite'.  As far as I can tell, there are only 2 differences: 1 TV controls (on/off and volume) and 2. Dolby Atmos.  Neither of these mattered to me.4) If your wifi connection is dodgy, do yourself a big favor and get an ethernet connector.  It tremendously improves the experience.  In this regard, you don't have to buy the Amazon branded one.  Search for "KOOPAO Micro USB to RJ45 Ethernet Adapter" on Amazon and save yourself $5.This is so worth the upgrade - especially those who are still running gen 1.

This is the first product I've reviewed on Amazon.  I had a first-generation Fire TV Stick that lasted 5 years, but my wife lost the remote when we moved.  I bought this because I don't have a 4K TV, so I didn't need the nicest version.  It is a complete piece of crap.  With the first one I received, Netflix worked well, but other apps (Hulu, ESPN, FOX Sports, HGTVGO, etc.) experienced issues.  I thought I got a lemon, so I requested a replacement.  The second one had the same problems.  Amazon must have spent no time developing or troubleshooting this device.  I'm super disappointed and annoyed.

11.13.2020 - I have Apple TV, Roku, and Roku Stick in my home and have used them for years. I decided to give the Fire Stick Lite a try because (1) it was compact, (2) it would connect with a speaker setup I have with two Echo Dots and an Echo Subwoofer, and (3) I love Amazon's products.Setting it up wasn't too difficult, but I can't always get the sound actually to come through my Echo Dots. Sometimes it will do it automatically; other times it won't. When the sound doesn't come through the Echo speakers, it also doesn't come through my TV itself. And no matter what I tell Alexa, it won't get the sound going. I need to restart or unplug the device to get it to work.When the sound does work through my Echo speakers, the volume is quite low -- even when it is turned up all the way. Now, I am not expecting home-theater quality, but I would expect them to be at least as loud as they are when I listen to music on Amazon Music Unlimited, which is completely sufficient. Just to make sure it wasn't my imagination, I measured the sound using the Main Title on the Star Wars Episode IV soundtrack on Amazon Music and the Main Title on the movie itself on Prime Video; the Prime Video is ten decibels lower than the Amazon Music. When the sound is relatively loud on a program, it's not a problem, but when it is somewhat quiet, any ambient noise in the room can easily drown it out. (This may be more of a limitation with the Echo Dots than with the Fire Stick, but it is something I thought I'd note for those who need the volume louder.)I've only had it for two weeks now, and I've used it maybe five days so far. Two times, after watching for about an hour, suddenly there was white noise coming from the Echo Dots and the subwoofer. I backed out and opened the app again but then there was no sound at all. I restarted the device, and still no sound. I unplugged it and plugged it back in, and this seemed to fix it. The second time this happened, I went through the same steps, but unplugging it didn't work this time.Twice so far the video has completely frozen, forcing me to unplug the device and restart it.It also seems to have some WiFi connectivity issues or at least some communication issues. For example, I attempted to open one app, but the device said it couldn't open it because it is not connected to WiFi. So I checked the settings, and it said that I AM connected to WiFi with a "very strong signal." I go back to the app again, and it says I'm not connected to WiFi. I try a different app, and it opens right up.The verbal commands also don't seem to work all the time. When I say, "Open Disney+,"  Alexa wants to open something else Disney-related. So I say, "Open Disney+ on Fire TV," and Alexa replies, "You have How Many Days enabled. Do you want to open it?" OK? I have found that I have a better chance if I switch the sentence around and say, "On Fire TV open Disney +."  Still, only one out of five times when I say this does it actually work. The other four times, Alexa responds with, "I couldn't find Disney." It's really frustrating.One other small issue I have is the "enter" button on the remote. When I press it, it feels and sounds like it has cellophane stuck underneath it. Not a show-stopper, but a little annoying.It seems to be a very temperamental device, and I am very disappointed. I am going to work with it some more and see if some of these bugs just go away. I'll update this review, if they do.UPDATE 12.02.2020 - Upon submitting my review, I immediately was contacted by Amazon's tech support inviting me to get in touch with them to resolve the issues I was having. When I had time, I arranged for a call with them. The first individual with whom I spoke for about 30 minutes went over some very basic things -- most of which I had already tried. She transferred me to another tech rep, who was more knowledgeable about the system.After trying a few things with no success, the second rep suggested that I should do a complete reset of the device. He said he could call me back at a designated time to follow up and make sure things were working correctly. I asked if he could call back in two hours. He called back about three hours later, which was fine, but the device was still downloading information, so we couldn't test it. He suggested that I give it 12 full hours and then give it a try.I waited until the next day, which was well over 12 hours, and the device said it was still downloading - although the progress bar was completely full (as it was the previous evening). I took a chance figuring that maybe the downloads had completed and set up my Fire Stick anew. Everything seemed to be working alright, so I then connected it to my Echo speakers (two Echo Dots and an Echo subwoofer). It worked well for a while but then it ended up doing the same white noise for about a minute and then cut off the sound completely. I disabled the Echo speakers, and the Fire Stick worked fine again. I have not reconnected my Echo speakers to it and just used the TV's sound instead. I have used it for several days, and I have had no further problems.So, long story short, it seems that the issue is somehow caused by connecting it with my Echo speakers, which is unfortunate, as this is the whole reason I decided to go with a Fire Stick rather than a Roku. If I had it to do over, I would definitely have gone with a Roku device, as it has access to apps that the Fire Stick doesn't - such as VUDU.Still, the device works okay on its own, so I am upgrading my review to two stars.

I am writing this from the perpective of a device addition or upgrade from a pervious Firestick owner. I ordered this because technology keep improving and Amazon does use fast processors as they become less expensive. They also increased the WiFi speed and memory over the old version that I have, and you can really feel the difference. So, from an improved hardware perspective I am happy.Unfortunately, this time they are trying to upgrade the interface again... and planning to port it to my older Fire TV devices. The new interface is clunky like the old one, just in a different way. Each time the device wakes up, it asks which profile you want to use. This might be okay if you rarely leave your device for the few minutes that it requires to go to sleep, but it often affects me. The other issue with the profiles feature is that it rarely does not do much. It does not automatically select your profiles in your apps... it seems to only work for Amazon Prime, which I watch but not as much as Hulu, Netflix and other apps. This profile feature is only a part of the user interface changes. There is now no means to scroll through more than your first five apps... and there is no longer a recent app menu which was very convenient if you use some apps more than others. Often the remote shortcuts fail to function, as the  OS seems to have a new bug where it ignores your button presses when it is low on memory or busy... sometimes making you think your remote batteries have drained. Also, low memory seems to make Hulu loop back to the beginning after playing for a bit...Another unfortunate concern is that they have not resolved the existing issues with functionality, The first is that when you leave an app, either by choice or by the amazingly short timeout happening, the app still continues to run in the background using up memory. This is neither easily resolvable manually, nor do they do it automatically in the background. This is the reason that the devices run out of memory! The second issue is that when you leave the device for a bit and come back to a blank screen, it does not resume where you left it... you still need to go and reopen your app and select your app's user profile... and now you get the extra step of choosing your Amazon profile before all of this.I am hopeful that they can and will resolve these issues if enough users complain, but the mainstream website reviewers seem to never notice nor mention issues with the products. I have opened issues with Amazon about other Amazon products and I have not seen any changes... so if you want these fixed, you need to write them in your reviews and contact them.The voice recognition is still the same, just as spotty as always. Alexa integration is also unchanged. Stream quality in apps is still extremely clear on a 1080p TV.Overall, the device is fast and if you are streaming TV without any pauses, it is a good deal. For me though, it seems to be getting worse with each new iteration... because like most modern people, I like to pause my TV when life happens. Amazon should be making this easier not harder -- they should fix issues before adding more issues.  Until these are fixed, I would recommend going with the other mainstream brand... as it does not have any of these issues. I am giving this device three stars (rounded from 2.5stars) average as it deserves five stars for the hardware and two stars for the new software bugs and still existing software glitches.

Love it! However I have issues with it. Apps do crash from time to time, it goes into sleep mode too quickly when paused (probably need to find where to adjust that in the settings or something), and I don’t like not having the most recent whatever showing up on the home page (only Amazon content will show there, maybe another setting? Doubtful). Aside from these minor complaints, it works great! I have Hulu, Netflix, Disney, Prime (of course), and Apple TV accounts. They all work great.
