Very happy...but....I probably stared at the specs for the lite and regular one for no less than four hours before making the purchase. I knew everything was the same, but the difference between the two is clear: the lite requires you to use two separate remotes for volume and power for the TV, and is it worth $10 to have all that on the very sleek nice Firestick remote. Here is a break down of me living out my decision of trying out the lite:Day 1. I’m not that picky. I can have two remotes. Plus it’s in my home office, not a big room. No big deal.Day 2. Yep, I did lay the firestick remote by the tv and somehow left the other remote on the coach on the other side of the room. It’s just habit. I need to get used to putting them in the same place.Day 3. Why is this so hard to remember. This old remote for my TV doesn’t work very well. Maybe I should have went with the one with everything I need in one remote. It could have solved two problems, because of the aging TV remote. Hmmm.Day 4. Maybe I can duct tape the remotes together. There has to be some way to make this less painful. I’m really starting to regret this decision.Day 5. I’m not sure about any of the decisions I have ever made in my life if this is the type of decisions I am making. I have kids that were planned, maybe I’ve made all kinds of bad decisions that I have just been forcing myself to live with! How could I have not realized how much of a pain it is to keep these two remotes together. Why is that so hard, but now every time I have to hunt for one or the other it is like someone is punching me in the face with a $10 bill pasted to their knuckles. It’s the volume changing from all the office calls (or pausing or needing to do both or one of the other quickly) and sometimes it’s the boss so I can’t be running around the room trying to kill the sound before answering the call. This was a mistake, and I can solve it for $10. I’d pay $20 if I can escape the pain and suffering I have caused myself these five days which feels like five years!Day 6. Return initiated, extra $10 engaged, regular Firestick arrives tomorrow. It can’t get here fast enough! Now I’m cool with not having 4K because the only TVs I would use this on aren’t 4K and the one tv that is had its own apps (its smart like that, and it got a 1300 on the GRE, which is respectable). Let’s just breath and relax with the epiphany of one remote to rule them all, one remote to find them, one remote to bring them all and in the darkness bind them.Day 7. The one remote has become precious to me.So pay the $10. What do you need, ulcers?

Apart from the price savings, there isn't much to like about the Fire TV Stick Lite.I have a full fledged Fire TV 4k stick, as well as a Chromecast.I bought this Lite version as a sort of spare for screen mirroring (sometimes the screen mirroring function on the Chromecast can be persnickety).I thought the only features the Lite Stick would lack would be volume/power and as I am fine using two remotes, I thought, why not?Here's why -- the Fire TV Stick 4K with onboard on and off seems to "remember" which HDMI port it was connected to and to maintain the audio/video connection.Whereas the Lite Version "forgets." I often have to turn the TV on or off, or reboot the stick. It's a nuisance.To be honestly, I use both of my Fire TV sticks mostly for mirroring, rather than the onboard Fire TV interface, which I find isn't nearly as responsible and intuitive as using the Amazon Prime Video app on my phone or PC, then mirroring that app to the Fire TV stick.Also, I noticed there were more ads on the Fire TV Stick than there used to be. Yes, I know Prime has ads for paid video content, but since when do we see ads for completely unrelated products like insurance policies?  Very obnoxious.Anyhow, in terms of being able to maintain a mirrored connection, both Fire TV sticks are better at it than my Chromecast, which connects more easily, but occasionally has to be reconnected when the connection drops.However, the Fire TV sticks are much more troublesome in terms of establishing the initial screencast link. For starters, there isn't a shortcut. You have to use the remote to maneuver to the settings menu, select display, select screen mirroring or screen sharing, and then select screen mirroring or sharing on your phone.Really, the  best way by far to use Prime Video is via a hard-wired cable connection from your pc/ipad/iphone/android, if you have the appropriate cable and provided the device you are linking supports MHL video output (which fewer and fewer Android devices support these days).All that said, if wireless casting is your only option and if you absolutely need a solution that is ultra-cheap when it is on sale, the Fire TV Stick Lite does work, provided you have the patience to reconnect it and perhaps reboot it once in a while.Nevertheless, if you can spare a few bucks more, I recommend buying the fully-fledged Fire Stick 4k rather than the lite version.

First off, I want to point out how much I love the UI of Firestick. I have owned Apple TVs, Rokus, and Firesticks and for me, the Firesticks are far and away the best experience. They have the most apps, the most enjoyable UI, the easiest navigation, etc. (Plus they are customizable)Not only that, but they integrate with Alexa, so you're able to ask Alexa to play something and she will! I have it programmed into my Routines on Alexa to "Shut off Shannon's Fire TV" when I tell her goodnight! The remote is sturdy and has been dropped a number of times and still works like a charm. I would like the back battery cover to be able to stay in place a little better, but all in all, nice piece of machine!If you are trying to decide between a firestick, Roku, or Apple TV GET A FIRESTICK!If this review helped you - please leave a thumbs-up!(I was not paid or incentivized in any way to give this review. I purchased this product with my own hard-earned money!)

I bought this to replace an old Roku that was giving me trouble, thought this would be an upgrade. Unfortunately, this is way more of a pain than the Roku has ever been. It almost never wants to play sound, which is incredibly irritating. I have to unplug it and plug it back in constantly, though that doesn’t even work most of the time unless I leave it unplugged for several hours or even days. It’s also a big pain to go back to a show you were watching. You have to click through all the channels, find the show, then try to figure out which one you were watching. It looks like you’ve already watched shows you didn’t see, the line across the bottom shows up on ones you never watched. If you were watching a series, most of the time it will jump several shows ahead so you have to go back and fast fwd through a bunch of episodes to figure out where you were. Sometimes it will randomly start playing in the middle of an episode you haven’t watched when you turn it on. I bought Discovery+ through this and can’t access it through my Roku, so it’s annoying when I want to finish a show but can’t get any sound. With everything technology is capable of these days, it’s amazing that not even the most basic things (like sound) will work. Too late to return it. Glad I at least bought it on sale since it’ll likely end up in the garbage. For now I’m back to using the old Roku as even that works way better than this thing. Extremely disappointing! I will just buy another Roku in the future. The idea and ability to get many different channels is great, if they could only get it to work consistently and fix some of the annoyances. Not worth having to keep unplugging it and plugging it back in several times just to hear the sound. Today I’ve done that 6 times and it still won’t work. At least my Roku plays sound.

This is my first streaming Stick, I've previously used Roku stand alone devices. I did not need TV on/off or volume control etc so I went with the Lite. The main reasons for buying the Stick are: to evaluate the Fire user interface and try the Silk browser (Roku does not support a browser).The Stick was connected at the back of my AV receiver (using the supplied extension cord) within an AV cabinet, a less than ideal situation. Despite the Stick being surrounded by a jumble of receiver wires, that you might expect to effect RF signal strength, the remote worked fine and I obtained a Very Good WiFi signal indication.Stick setup was easy. The Fire homepage is arranged differently to Roku but is no less usable. The only omission is a complete lack of time & date info on the homepage or screensaver, something I'm used to with the Roku. The speed of operation is similar to Roku.The Silk browser works great. I use it to navigate to radio station homepages and bookmark the URL. While on the subject of radio stations, the Fire TV TuneIn app is not as comprehensive as either the Roku or Kindle tablet versions, with a lack of Recents and Favorites. However, the Fire TV iHeart Radio app is better than the Roku or Kindle tablet (go figure?) versions but it still lacks several local major stations. So between using Silk and iHeart I'm able get all the stations I need.The ESPN app took two attempts to load (load, fail-to-start, uninstall, re-load) but eventually worked fine. So far I'm impressed with the hardware and I've managed to overcome any software imitations.

After evaluating several streaming devices, I’ve determined the Firestick is my best option with the most features and performance for a reasonable price. Especially with this new 2020 release, it performs faster and with fewer glitches than previous gens. I recently focused on the TiVo Stream 4K because I liked the way their search engine would aggregate content from all streaming sources, so you wouldn’t have to search individually through Netflix, Hulu, Apple+, Amazon Prime, etc. to try to find a movie.But guess what? Amazon has incorporated a new search that will do the same thing with this new release! If you notice, TiVo is so nervous about this they quickly dropped the price on their Stream 4K from $49 down to $39.....for BROKEN hardware. Read on.The main focus of my testing is surround sound capabilities. I use an OTG (On The Go) micro USB cable to plug in my thumb drives to the Firestick. I am then able to play my 5.1 audio files encoded as Dolby Digital AC3, DTS, FLAC, WAV, SACD-DST etc. Firestick DOES PLAY and properly decode all of these via the terrific “Kodi” player app. TiVo’s Stream 4K also plays these files, but even though it DISPLAYS a 5.1 Dolby Digital+ decode it is REALLY only playing in just TWO CHANNELS! Even a standard stereo two channel mp3 shows being played back as full Dolby Digital+ 5.1....FAIL!But the problem with the Amazon Firestick is its inability to read anything other than FAT32 formatted drives natively. EVERY other streaming device I’ve tested can read NTFS drives natively. Yes, there is a workaround by playing files through the “ES File Explorer” app that then plays through Kodi, but you can’t sequence playlists, and for each file you need to hit the home button to get back to the ES app to then load another file....NO GOOD!The other big issue with FAT32: files are limited to 4.2 gigs in size. FAT32 cannot read anything larger. So if you have a movie larger than 4.2GB you’re out of luck. So outdated.Amazon crew members, get on the “Stick” and add native NTFS support!

I bought this to replace an old, 1st gen fire stick. It's only used on a small unsmart tv in our bedroom so I didn't need all the extra tv controls or 4k. The 1st gen has just gotten too slow and unreliable as it has aged, even after resetting it, so when the "birthday sale" came along I stepped up. WOW! What a difference in speed! I also have a 4k stick for the main living room tv and this actually seems a little quicker than it. Setup was easy, though you do have to be patient while it first downloads and updates during the setup process. There were a couple of times I thought it gave up, only to have it suddenly continue on. Anyone that's still using an old 1st gen I strongly suggest upgrading. You won't be sorry!

Now have three fire sticks set up in our house. For the most part set up is quite easy. Stations come in clear. Don't use the Alexa feature. Still don;'t trust that technology. Internet hook up though is slow. Transitioning between cable and fire stick is not real smooth. Biggest criticism is setting up internet viewing locations in a convenient way to access. Have worked at this, and can't find a way to set up the stations I want. Also downloading Apps is problematical. At times just not making the connections. Will work at these items over time and hopefully figure out how set up. For now use the fire stick for a couple of internet stations, otherwise still using cable. That should change soon. Still not confident enough to cut the cord with fire stick, but getting closer.

(Clarified on 2/15/21 due to the 4 emails I received from Amazon, Notifications on my Alexa, and CALL I RECEIVED AT WORK FROM SOMEONE AT AMAZON Cus Care - I am grateful but it says to me you already are aware of this product)No one explained to me in the store (Purchased at Staples where it was marked down to 21.50 as the prices are fixed to mirror Amazon.com) so that this could not actually control the volume of the monitor in my bedroom, only that it did not have advanced connectivity for sound and only HDMI (I am not sure if this device is any different at all, or it just comes with a less feature filled remote.) -- which I thought would be fine as that is all the Gen2 Firestick that I had did.  I needed a secondary device to my AppleTV and I thought that this would be worth the money. It is worth the 21$ to just add a tv easily BUT THERE IS NO INTEGRATION AT ALL, so it is a bit of a disappointment. This model is a bit underwhelming overall. Wish I had spent the extra 10$ on a standard fire stick so I could lower and raise the HDMI volume without having to get out of bed as this monitor has no remote.PS. Dear Amazon, WHY WOULD YOU THINK 6 months of "food TV" videos free, is a selling point. Get it together Amazon. This is like a bargain basement product, and you sold It like one. I already have Prime and Cable, and I dont cook so that is useless to me as I would imagine it is to 98% of the other users, which I HOPE you are paying for per activation, not some huge volume license, as again, WHO WOULD EVEN WATCH IT!

I bought this to have Spectrum streaming service since Spectrum does not support Amazon Fire TV. So I end up with both Amazon Fire and Roku.While Fire TV device responses instantly, I cannot switch from Fire TV to Roku. I have to reboot every time and wait at least 2-3 min to have a response to the remote controller. It has been a month but I had to replace the remote controller battery 3 times! It is a very slow device with a bad remote controller design with useless buttons. For example, you do not need Netflix, Hulu, Vue, Sling buttons. Home page sofware keys should be more than enough. The 'return' button (round arrow key) does not have any function. It drains batteries like a coarse sieve while being not in use.I do not understand how they do possibly market this thing! Sad since I cannot find minus five star rating.

I gave this stick 4 stars on the basis of it working with 4K.  My Vizio 65" screen had to small of a indentation where HDMI1 was located for the Roku to fit, so I was temporarily forced to use a side port HDMI4, which only supports HDCP1.4.  No matter how hard I tried, or what I set the Roku to for display (tried auto, 720 and 1080) it would bring up everything fine, menus, channels, etc....until it tried play video, in which case, it would purple screen with an HDCP error and emit a loud tone from the TV requiring reboot.  This was tried several times, in various ways.  Never could get it to work.  Once I received my 1.5" 4K compatable HDMI extension cable, and plugged the Roku into the 4K HDCP2.2 port, then it finally worked after about two attempts with a purple screen.  If you are looking for 4K, and have the time to spend tinkering and trying different things, then you may like this.  If you have no interest in 4K, or do not have a 4K TV, avoid this one.Added: 7/2018 - After buying a Marantz 4K HDCP2.2 AVR and plugging this into it, along with a 4K Tivo Bolt, everything worked fine and it streamed 4K video from the internet just fine.  I attempted to stream a 4K Atmos file from my computer server (i7 with Gig ethernet), and the flle would play about 2 minutes and then fail with an bandwidth error.  The file was 12Mb/s video, plus audio.  Tried 5GHz and 2.4GHz with same results using the Plex App.  Switched to the Tivo, which also has  the Plex app, but is hooked up through ethernet, and the file played fine.  So apparently, the wireless speed of this device isnt quite up to streaming 4K blu ray quality video (the signal was excellent and the Roku was 2 ft from the router).  If I had to do it over, I think I would pay the extra and get the external non-stick HD version, with ethernet connectivity.  All in all though, Roku is still the best platform for streaming I have experienced.Update: Unit was only used one or two hours, a couple times a month.  Lasted until today, and will now not accept remote control commands from original or new remote.  Hitting the trash bin.  Save your money and get the better version with a fan.  This one overheats badly.

Recently we decided to cut the cord and as long-time Roku users we discovered that our old Roku would not be capable of doing the live streaming we would need to access services like Hulu Live or DirecTV Now.  After doing some research and based on Amazon customer and outside reviews we decided to upgrade to the Roku Streaming Stick+.  After a rocky installation process that took a couple of days we finally got it to work.  It was faster than our old Roku and the picture quality was superior.  Unfortunately, this did not last long.  Like many other reviewers, after about two months (a month past the return window date), we began to have issues.  At first we began to experience constant buffering every time we tried to watch a program.  And eventually we could not get the programming to start at all and got messages about our connection to the internet and about "weak signal strength."And of course whatever the trouble was it always came back to assigning the blame to OUR router, OUR SmartTV, and/or OUR internet provider.  We tried everything we could think of including restarting everything, reinstalling everything, and checking the status of our router and our signal (according to the Roku itself, our wifi and internet signals were good to excellent).  We went through this over and over again to no avail.  One of Roku's recommendations was to mitigate the interference between our router and the Roku stick by having them in close proximity to each other with no walls in between.  While our router and Roku were not in the same room, they were in sight of each other.  And if that were the problem, why did this arrangement work fine with our old Roku and with this one for the first two months?  On the other hand, one of the selling points of the Stick+ was that it would work with a less-than-ideal signal.Finally, after several days of trying and failing to get access to any programming using the stick, we put the unit back in the box and reinstalled our old Roku (which worked just fine).Some avenues of exploration that Roku might consider concern the Stick itself.  Our old Roku box is relatively cool to the touch.  On the other hand, when the Stick's power cord is plugged into the wall the unit gets extremely hot (even when it is not plugged into the TV).  Also, on our Samsung SmartTV the HDMI socket is relatively high on the back of the set and even though the Stick "clicked" into place the downward stress with the added weight of the USB power cable pulling on it might have had the effect of weakening the connection.  The old expression "it hangs like a dog's ear" comes to mind.  At one point I even used tape to affix the cables to the back of the TV in an effort to relieve the stress, but like everything else we tried it only worked briefly.  As a last resort we requested the free HDMI extender cable that Roku offers in case the Stick+ does not fit your HDMI socket and it did strengthen the connection, but it did not solve the overall problem.  We still kept getting messages about signal strength and we still could not successfully access programming.  It's as though we had come full circle from the early days of TV when someone in the family had to hold the rabbit ears to get a clear signal.  Nowadays you need a volunteer from the audience to hold the Stick in place while wearing an oven mitt.Maybe there just some inherent problems with the Stick+.  Six hundred negative reviews (as of this review) should not be ignored.

In 2015 I ordered a Roku streaming stick. It worked fine for a while, but after a year, it quit working. In the meantime, I had purchased a newer tv and was able to access Amazon Prime and Netflix directly through the TV, so I never pursued repairing or replacing the Roku. I was never charged anything for my Roku other than the initial purchase price.I recently acquired Disney +, which I can access directly on my living room tv, but wanted to access it on my granddaughters older tv. I ordered a newer Roku streaming stick to install on her tv. In the process of installing it, I was told to call Customer Service to get technical assistance for my installation. When I called Customer Service they told me that the original Roku was still linked to my account and could not be unlinked. Because this was the second Roku on my account, I would be charged $129.00 for a 5 year basic account. I don't know what a basic account includes, but he said I would not be able to access Disney+ with the basic account. I didn't ask what the other options were, because the $129 was already more than I was willing to pay for an account that I had never been charged for in the past 5 years. I could probably buy her a newer tv and access the Disney+ and it wouldn't cost much more than the Roku.

Love my Roku!! But I almost sent it back shortly after trying to install it. When I went to the Roku website to connect and put in the code to activate, the first link says ‘link and connect easy com link activation’.  Because it was a Roku link or so I thought, I called the number. They were going to charge me $69.99 to connect. Then I found the “real” Roku link down on the list and activated my account. The scammers argued with me, got nasty, hung up on my when I refused them the fee. They said we will activate it for 10 minutes and give you a chance to think it over. Somehow they were able to do this. PLEASE BEWARE!! They are scammers and probably identity thieves. The Roku was easy to install and has worked perfectly. I would definitely purchase another for the other tv.

Update 1/13/2020:So, it's been close to 5 months since I received the replacement. It's been working almost issue free (a few hard restarts here and there). I've updated my rating to 3 stars (from 1 star) just for Roku's horrible customer service and I feel longevity is still unclear.I wouldn't buy it again unless it's $15 or less and wouldn't recommend buying it for its current price.Original review 8/2019:This is my 5th Roku. I also have 2 fire sticks but Roku always seems faster and the UI is more intuitive.The Roku Streaming Stick+ is my favorite so far (when it comes to responsiveness) and it was working flawlessly for over 2 months before I started having remote connection issues and a few days later wifi connectivity issues.Roku customer service is horrendous.I've spent over an hour (after 30 minutes wait) chatting with CS representative. He kept saying to call my ISP to resolve the wifi issues even though it was working flawlessly before and that this is the only device in my house that has connection issues. It took him forever to respond and he kept asking the same questions basically ignoring my answers.Only after I told him this chat was going nowhere he offered a replacement.I had to pay to ship it back to Roku. I received the replacement 14 days after they received the defective one, no communication from them whatsoever.Calling them is just a waste of time. No matter what options you make, you never get to speak with anyone and it will end in an abrupt hang up.I wouldn't get again or recommend getting any Roku with a "point anywhere" remote. I have 5 Roku devices, 2 of them with "point anywhere" remote and both remotes stopped working.Roku really do make great media devices and I was always happy with their products but if you do have a problem, you will need to deal with their very unhelpful customer service or simply trash your Roku if warranty has expired.Also 90 day warranty is not enough.I can't give a 5-star rating to a product that is not 100% backed by its manufacturer.I think it's just a matter of time before the replacement will break too.

I purchased the Roku Streaming Stick+ for two reasons:1. To attach it to my TV that is not a smart TV.  Without built-in streaming apps or W-Fi capability, my TV needed a streaming device to view alternate programming.2.  To replace an Infinity cable box that I've been paying a monthly rental fee to use.I read the descriptions and customer reviews of multiple Roku devices to find one that might meet my goals at a reasonable price.  This device really fits the bill.  I ran it through testing before disconnecting the cable box.  I can still see all of the Xfinity channels in my package (I was skeptical about this).  I had to get used to a different menu and user interface, but most of the features are available including recording, searching, and voice commands.  One thing that is missing vs. the Xfinity remote is that the Roku remote does not have an Info button to see program descriptions.The picture quality is excellent.  Once a link is established the Roku remote can be used to power on the TV, but there is a slight delay in response time compared to the Xfinity remote or the TV's manufacturer's remote.If you select this model you should add a USB extension cable to your order:  You'll be glad that you did.  The USB extension cable provided in the box is too short unless your TV is within two feet of the wall socket.All in all, I recommend this product.  I will be sending in the Xfinity cable box to lower my monthly bill.

Roku streaming stick plus is a great add-on to a non-smart TV. Very easy to set up even detected my TV in set up the remote code so I can turn the TV on and off with Roku remote the voice command on the remote works well it was able to look up the app says I ask for them but the only downside I can see is the stick is very long and uncertain TV's it looks like it might stick out the side or not fit into the area where you're supposed to plug in HDMI so you might wanna double check if you have the space for this stick.You need 3 3/8 "clearance.This effectively replaced both my old Sony SMP-N200 streamer and my Microsoft Wireless Display Adapter for Miracast.Also ROKU has a Windows Phone App! Works great in my 950.The menu navigation is fast as is app launching (The quad-core really helps), I also this weekend brought the Sharp - 43" Class (42.5" Diag.) - LED - 2160p - Smart - 4K Ultra HD TV Roku TV SKU: 5746801 at BB that also has Roku TV built in.  Both support Miracast which means I can easily hook up my Surface Pro's in out family.The assigned one-touch app buttons: Netflix, Sling, hulu, PSVueAt $48 on BF  this is awesome.

I have to say that I am disappointed in this purchase.  I did fairly extensive research before deciding to buy the Roku Streaming Stick+, comparing it to Apple TV, Playstation Vue, Amazon Fire and others.  I even read the Roku website and blog that says the following:BackgroundJust like your smartphone has an “app store” for installing new applications, you can access the Roku Channel Store on your Roku streaming player or Roku TV™ to add new “channels”. Channels are applications for your television, popular channels include Netflix, YouTube, Hulu, VUDU and HBO GO. Additionally, current generation Roku devices include access to The Roku Channel, which features hit movies and TV at no cost to you.Do I have to pay for channels?Although some channels must be purchased or require a paid subscription, many others allow you to watch movies and TV shows for free.Which channels allow me to watch movies and TV shows?There are many channels that offer movies and TV shows including popular choices like Netflix, Google Play, Vudu, FandangoNOW and Hulu.Search Movies & TV shows in the Roku Channel Store.Are there channels that allow me to watch live or local TV?Yes, there are live broadcast channels like ABC, NBC, CBS, HGTV and Fox. In addition, some cable/satellite companies are creating Roku streaming channels that allow you to access all or most of the channels you get through your cable subscription without having a separate cable box (e.g. Spectrum TV, Comcast Xfinity, DIRECTV NOW).If you have Roku TV, you can also connect an antenna to access live and local broadcast TV over the air.I got the distinct impression that I'd be able to watch my live and local broadcast TV via the Roku system.  Wrong.  Turns out that the Roku stick does not have an antenna slot, and the Roku channels provide "live" news that is actually not live.  It's an amalgam of news recorded throughout the day and then recycled throughout the day on various channels.  Further, when I tried to watch Saturday Night Live, I could only access archived Saturday Night Live episodes, or buy a separate subscription for the show.  Hey, I'm used to watching it live, for free, over my HDTV antenna.  So, I ended up switching back to my antenna.  The only way to actually get what was advertised is to not buy the Roku stick, but, rather, to buy a Roku TV with an antenna slot that allows live and local broadcast TV to be processed via the Roku TV system, including pause and replay.  Ya gotta read the fine-print!The only reason I'm still giving Roku 2 stars is because, in its own right, with all the caveats I've mentioned, it's not too bad.  I'm hoping I can get used to having both the Roku stick and the HDTV antenna to serve my needs.Update May 27, 2018:  my Roku stick stopped working.  Not sure what happened.  Power surge?  Really don't know.  But, after calling customer support and going through the usual "Is it plugged in?... Have you tried a different outlet?..." they finally gave me a return authorization, so now I'm waiting for a replacement.  Sheesh.

We bought this to replace an old streaming stick with a different kind of remote (I think the old one was radio and this is infrared but I'm not a techie). The old one had so many issues with the remote not being recognized, something to do with wifi interference or something. It was so frustrating we hardly ever used it. I finally went ahead and got this since it seemed to be different. And it is! No remote issues whatsoever, it seems to load and do everything faster. I did have to plug it into separate power since the usb output of the TV apparently didn't have enough power. But that's not too big of a deal. The voice recognition works amazingly well. My wife has a bit of an accent and it hasn't misinterpreted anything so far. Overall this is super nice!

Really like the user interface of this Roku but it’s proved to be a real inconsistent pain in the arse every time I turn it on. Often times it’ll show that no device is plugged in. This requires that I unplug it and replug it in, often multiple times. Customer service has been ZERO help suggesting that I “try to use it on a different TV” as if I had a spare TV lying around my living room. This is a brand new LG OLED TV, so it’s not like I’m using a TV that’s a decade old. How about you, Roku, work on fixing your product rather than blaming it on someone else’s! Really disappointed for the money I spent on this thing.

I've know for years that the Roku Stick was a superior product than the Amazon Stick but I already had an Amazon stick and figured how bad could it be?Well after frustratingly suffering through Amazon Stick for years, I had enough and purchase this Roku Stick. I should have done this month if not weeks after getting my Amazon Stick but I was too lazy and stubborn.I've only had it three days and it's never crashed. The Amazon Stick crashes or freezes on a daily basis.The Roku remote works perfectly and with my TV while the Amazon Stick remote never works, doesn't work with my TV, and their phone app remote is just as bad.The Roku wifi signal has never dropped while The Amazon Stick looses the wifi signal while it's sitting right next to the Router.This review will probably get deleted at some point for trashing an Amazon product but here you go.

The concept is fine. The execution is horrid. It is all about the remote, not the stick. I found out, like others, that this remote design eats batteries about every 2 weeks depending on how much you use it. I finally put an ammeter on it and I found that the remote draws 30-150mA for about 45seconds after touching any button. If the remote is used on any reasonable frequency, that is far too much to be supplied by 2-AAA batteries.On the chance it was a defective remote, I got a replacement. Sorry, it is the design of the remote that is the problem. I will be returning the replacement also and getting a Roku with only an IR remote. It is really sad that Roku would hoist this "long-range RF design" without a warning. Most people expect 6-12 months life from remote batteries, not 2 weeks.

The unit quit working after 6 months. Could not sync the remote to the stick. After troubleshooting with the tech by phone it was determined the unit was bad and an RMA warranty was issued.  The unit was returned by Express Mail and arrived within four days of the RMA being issued. Then a whole series of canned emails began, most ending with the question had this been resolved. I kept answer4ing no, not until a replacement unit was shipped. More canned emails. After about 10 days of this I was able to locate a customer service phone number (not on Roku’s website) and called them. I was told the status was they have the RMA, it takes about 10-14 days to ship a replacement depending on the warehouse but that I would b e getting a replacement soon. This seems to be ridiculous amount of time for a warranty replacement. A week later I get an email requesting a tracking number for the original return. Well I had been in temporary quarters for several weeks and had now  relocated and frankly did not store the USPS receipt safely as Roku said they had received the unit. Called Roku again and explained all of this to an agent who spoke poor English. Said he would do nothing without a tracking number. Asked to speak to someone who could resolve issue or to a supervisor. The agent just kept repeating without the tracking number he would do nothing and would not allow me to speak with anyone else. I finally gave up. I will now go with Amazon Fire-stick. This is the worst customer service I have ever encountered in either my professional or consumer roles.

Love it on my little Office TV. The TV is HD w HDMI port. But it is not a smart TV. I wanted to watch maybe my Prime or NF w/o commercials. I just cut the cord and tried a few antennas. But the $40 spent there was mostly a waste of $ on the little older TVs. I have no clue what is on the 20-40 channels I get in there. I only watch that TV after work during my treadmill or exer bike time. I’m thrilled w the pic quality. Plus I can watch so many old TV show if I want on many Roku channels w commercials. I immediately ordered a 2nd for my Bed/Liv smart TV. The Smart TV’s USB port is powerful enough to power the Roku. The office non-smart required the included USB extension and included wall plug. I ordered the HDMI extender that you can order from Roku for free. I don’t need it at home, but I plan to take it w me when I travel, because you don’t know what may be at your hotel, etc.  I like that the extender was offered for free w free 3 day shipping

I bought this in 2/2018. Six months later the remote stopped working properly. I contacted customer support, and through troubleshooting, the problem was fixed. A while after the remote stopped working again. This time I was told to get an adapter to fix the problem, which did nothing. I contacted roku again today about this problem but because it’s been over a year they will no longer pay for a new remote. For paying $60, I am very disappointed with the quality and with the customer service. My device is no longer usable at this point and I refuse to pay for another remote when I did nothing to break it in the first place. Would not recommend this product to anyone.

TLDR Buy an AppleTV.The first thing you notice after installing your new Roku is the large ad on the side of the screen – on the thing you paid for. It can not be turned off. I tried. Hard. Even if you never connect to a network, and the Roku won't do anything since there's no media player installed, the space will be used. You'll need to install a media player via yet another account on their website.So you go to the fugly website, disable some security so the login works, and jump through hoops to find something to sort of work. Oh look Netflix... hmm that doesn't look right... Sometimes the Roku can't hold a connection no matter what you do. Fine. Maybe tomorrow. I'll just shut it off... You can't. It keeps running 24/7. If you put in a USB stick or memory card adapter you'll discover it's constantly warm. The Roku never stops accessing it. What it's doing I have no idea, but it creeps me out.The Roku is pretty bad at everything it does. There's really very little the Roku can do that you can't do with a Raspberry Pi, if you're technically inclined. If it's too much trouble to do that, you can buy an AppleTV. Apple's heavy handed controls are only slightly less cumbersome than Android's privacy and security woes. Seriously, I've spent more time trying to get this thing to do what it's supposed to... that's why I'm on my machine today, again... at least the ads work...

This is a great streaming device and the third Roku that I have so far (still using all 3 just fine) Let me start by first saying that there is a very popular highly trending negative rating from Nov 2018 here on Amazon warning people that if you try to add more than 2 Roku devices onto your account, Roku will insist on starting to charge you for a Premium account (or something.) This is false. The first photo I included here is my account showing all 3 of my Roku devices on my one account, zero charged, still free. So don't believe that review. The only thing i can think of is that maybe the author of the negative review got scammed and clicked on a spoofing/phishing website that tried to scam her out of money. Either way, rest easy, it's false, you don't get charged for having 3 devices and here's your proof. The second picture is my connection to the TV. I used the direct to TV method (powered by TV, not using electrical outlet.) You can see that the Roku itself is plugged in to the HDMI-3 port and the short black power wire is going into the USB port labeled "USB (HDD 5V 1A)" just above it. That's it. Easy-peasey. If you have a TV with connections that can support this set-up, it doesn't get much easier. It fired right up, linked right up to the Wi-Fi extender I already had right in the same room. Signal rating is "excellent." The third and final picture is the home screen after a few minutes of churning away adding/installing all the apps. All fired up and ready to go now. Very fast and robust navigation from app to app and using the apps. Way faster than my two older ones (Roku-3 from 2013, and Roku Express from 2017) I don't have a big body of work using the voice command remote. It's my first one, the older ones don't have that. I tried it once, I said something like "Open Netflix app" and it did just that, brought me right to the Netflix app and opened it. Pretty cool I guess. Granted it's only been a couple days but so far it's been great, as have the other two other Roku units in the house. Overall great deal. Very happy and would not hesitate to recommend it.

Oct 10, 2020Like (what's better than the Amazon Fire stick):You can customize the home page (move things around)!You can remove apps you don't use!Freaking faster! It's not just faster...it's FASTER. Loads apps fast! Fast! FAST!My Samsung TV remote doesn't disconnect every other day because the Roku remote controls EVERYTHING.So far, it's only locked up once (thus the 4 stars) as the Fire stick needs to be rebooted (or power disconnected)  every other 5 days or so. (I have 5 Fire sticks and they all do that. My boss at work has a few also and he reports the same thing)What I don't like about it (compared to the Fire Stick):More expensive (about $20 more if the Fire Stick is on sale at $29).This review will be updated should anything change.

Roku Streaming Stick+ | HD/4K/HDR Streaming Device with Long-range Wireless and Voice Remote with TV ControlsI finally made the leap.I evaluated Fire and Roku.  (I looked at the original Chromecast who wants to need their phone to watch TV?)I chose Roku because it didn't have a goofy "modern" interface like the Fire (and Amazon Prime Video) does.The Roku is so easy to use!I bought my first one in July 2020.  This is my third one...for a third TV!It is so fast.  I used to torture myself trying to watch Netflix with the App built into the FIOS box.  The Roku is SOOOO much faster and easier to use and doesn't cost me $12 a month!  And Smart TVs?  Can they get any slower?  The Roku is so fast!The Roku is awesome!I haven't found any streaming channels that I can't watch using the Roku (YMMV).It even displays content from my phone.Good quality build.  Fast.  Easy to use.It's just a matter of time before I buy a 4th one!

So overall this thing is great, easily portable, gets all the apps we couldn’t on our TVs BUT, I don’t know who decided the cord length but it’s not even close to long enough for most applications. If you have your tv wall mounted you’re probably going to need an extension cord. Major annoyance and downfall.

I bought this 3 weeks ago my son finally installed it kids they take forever to do something lol so we had a very old roku box and it started acting up so I got this to replace it. We've always used roku but decided to go with the firestick. It was easy to set up and boy let me tell ya this thing is super fast compared to our old roku box. I had to tell my son to slow down so I could see what's on the screen lol he was jumping around to different screens and apps so fast. The picture quality is real good also and our tv is about 6 years old. I'm thinking about getting another one for my tv upstairs it's a roku tv and works great but it's not as fast as the firestick and doesn't have the voice activated remote which my son really likes with the firestick.

My fire stick light didn't work it kept powering off I thought it was the remote or maybe the power wires that came with it so I hooked my other fire stick up to it the old one and it worked perfectly fine with the new power wires and remote so it was the fire stick itself I've tried calling Amazon but haven't got in touch with them to do a return and I have been too busy this month and with being hospitalized to put that return fire stick at the top of my priorities list.
I love it

Updated from 2 to 4 stars.  I kept the product as I was able to download almost all the TV stations via the app catalog and along with my internet package i can login.Just have to open each app independently depending what i want....end of update Love the product and picture and speed is better than my old roku....HOWEVER it does NOT support Spectrum TV app...so now I either return the fire stick or xcl my Spectrum TV add on service....so aggravated.

I have tried other Android TV Boxes.  None of them are compatible with Disney+.  They may say they are.. But they're not.I finally gave up and bought the Amazon Fire Stick Lite.  We bought it at a local store.  Not here on Amazon.  We were in a hurry and didn't want to wait for shipping.  However, Amazon asked for a review.  So here it is.We stream mostly Amazon Prime and Disney+. There are other 3rd party streaming sites, but we don't use them as much.  Like I said before, we have been using a "generic" Android TV box.  That one replaced a different one.  Neither were compatible with Disney+.  The newer one claimed it was.  NOT!!The Fire Stick is much easier to use than the other TV boxes.  There was no real set-up required.  Just plug it in, Log-in to Amazon & the other apps we're using, and go.  Easy peasy.We haven't tried the voice search yet.  But I'm sure we'll get around to it.  We don't have any Alexa devices in our home, so we don't use that feature.This Amazon Fire Stick came with an HDMI extender, and remote.Forget the knock-offs.  Get the Fire Stick.  You'll be glad you did.***Please note:  I Did Not receive any discount for my review.  This was purchased at the retail price.***

I really wanted to like this, and in some ways I do. I got it for an older flat screen in my bedroom to make it a bit "smarter" and give me some more viewing options. But it has been a nightmare in many ways. First, the sound keeps dropping out. No sound at all on any viewing option or even the menu navigation sounds. Only reliable fix is to reboot the device - and it happens all the time. Amazon tech support couldn't really help me. It also has a cord which is far too short when you are trying to adjust to get a Wi-FI signal. I had to buy a longer one - about 3 feet vs 3 inches. It still didn't solve my problem. The signal fluctuates from good to marginal. Amazon tech support recommended a "signal booster" which wasn't a booster at all - it was just a longer cable. I did end up having to buy a real Wi-Fi booster - and it has a direct line of sight about 20 feet away from the Firestick. Now my signal strength fluctuates between very good and, wait for it - marginal. There is no option for hard wired ethernet built in - so now a have paid for a $25 piece of hardware, had to add extension cables, Wi-Fi boosters and now another add-on which will let me plug in an ethernet cable. Which I also have to buy and run under and through me house. $25 turned into $500. I could have got a real smart TV for a lot less. It doesn't have nearly enough storage - 8 GB? Really? In 2021? I can get 8 times that much on a thumb drive for under $10, or a 2 TB drive for around $50. It would have been so easy for them to make this product so much better right out of the box (for pennies more) and they didn't. Also, Amazon tech support told me adding wired ethernet won't help, but the Firestick on-screen messages when the signal drops off tells me it should help. (Too bad there is no ethernet port!) I pray that it does help, and that I don't have to reboot this thing every day for the rest of my life just to hear the sound.BTW, my real smart TV in the den receives the Wi-Fi signal from my router with excellent signal strength - and it passes through more wall than the Firestick signal did. The Wi-Fi booster I had to buy gets a strong signal. And the Firestick still keeps losing the signal even now when I have a direct line of sight with the booster. The Firestick itself is the problem.

I bought the Fire Stick Lite to take advantage of a free year of Apple TV+. My 2018 Sony TV has all the other apps but Apple TV. The FS lite was easy to connect using the supplied HDMI extender cable and USB cable with power adapter. The Alexa  Voice remote lite came with AAA batteries. Installation was a breeze as the unit did almost all the work with my only input of a single password. The product description was accurate to what the remote does, just Alexa voice, select, home, back, menu, rewind, play/pause fast forward and guide buttons. I only use the FS lite for Apple TV; my Sony TV handles everything else. I have found the FS lite to be a bit quirky as it sometimes doesn't select what show I want, indicates I have already finished a series even though I have more episodes to view, and takes some time to start or continue a show when paused. I can either put it to sleep or let it sleep on its own when switching back to the Sony TV for other streaming services.20/12/31 update - still behaves strangely, sometimes restarts an episode after a pause. Software update allowed me to place Apple TV+ to front of menu choices. Noticed the recent price increase to $29.99 from $17.99 in just a month.

I had ordered this to replace an old Fire Stick that I got back in 2016.  Decided that for the price point, I could upgrade.The Fire Stick I currently have is a replacement.  The initial one lost audio every time I tuned it on.  Then, it would not stream anything.  Since it had been less than a week since I got it, Amazon swapped it out for free.The one I currently have still has audio issues.  But, those issues are only after it starts up.  After doing a web search, I found a lot of others also complaining about this and suggesting to switch to another of the TV's inputs and back to the input with the Fire Stick.  So, I do that now and it solves that issue.The next issue is that the unit does not power on with the remote or phone app.  I have to unplug the power to the unit and plug it back in to wake it up.  I would connect the power to the TV, but I get a message that the TV's USB power may not be sufficient.  Never had that issue with the 2016 Fire Stick.The only upside to this Fire Stick vs the one from 2016 is that this one is much faster.  I'm hoping that Amazon will send out a patch that will fix the audio and power issues.  If they don't within the next few months, maybe it is time to look at other devices from other companies.

I needed a way to access HBO Max, Discovery+ and a few other apps I couldn't get on my LG tv. This is great. It's easy to search with. I can ask Alexa to find a movie or series and it'll search all of my apps for what I'm looking for. Only negative.. the Amazon batteries that came with it for the remote didn't last a month. Seriously Amazon, your batteries won't last in a remote for a month. Even the crap batteries that come in any other tv or dvd player, last a couple years in a remote. This tells me I have always made the right decision in never buying amazon batteries. Otherwise the firestick itself works great. Application is great. Since switching everything to the firestick from my tv, the viewing over the internet has been 1000xs better. I no longer have to reboot my router, or reboot the connection on my tv daily. And having gotten rid of my satellite TV and using the internet for all our TV, this is a huge deal. So getting the firestick before getting rid of satellite was a must. Happy to say, it made a huge difference.

My wife had enjoyed our original Roku unit for several years but had to start unplugging then plugging it in to get it to work. I looked online and thought I would "upgrade" to the Roku stick. It showed up promptly (thanks Amazon!) and the installation should have been a piece of cake. It wasn't. The software kept getting stuck on the installation. After power the unit and the tv down and up several times it finally went through. Now we're getting to the sad part.All remotes now a days have 4 directional navigation buttons and the right arrow on this unit wouldn't work unless you pushed REAL hard and repeatedly. Is it too much to ask for a new product to work like its supposed to? This new remote also has a cheaper, thinner non-ergonomic feel to it and is designed to be operated with your thumb. If you have to use your index finger, for instance, when lifting pointing the unit then one of your other fingers will always press the volume mute button. This is simply a bad design.When I use a service or product I think the provider should excel at what they do: a burger joint should make amazing burgers and stop chasing chicken n shrimp, a lamp should light when I press the button and a remote control should be intuitive, easy to hold and operate. Sorry Roku, you struck out on this one.

I will begin by saying ROKU has the worst customer service I have ever experienced.  It is Saturday, I wanted to watch the NFL channel on my ROKU attached to the TV.  I downloaded the NFL app.  I followed the instructions.  I connected to my local TV provider but never once did I see "the activation code box prompt" so I could connect.  I have tried now at least four times.  Ironically, I have been able to turn the NFL onto my IPAD, IPHONE, and computer, but simply not ROKU.  Customer service has disconnected be twice, the phone line is impossible. and I have missed the game.  this is not the only time i have faced this frustration.  I have APPLE TV and an AMAZON fire stick but thought I would try Roku to compare.  Customer service is what makes or breaks a company.  Spending 60 minutes on a Saturday dealing with your unqualified service is wrong.  Your basically a gimmick for NETFLIX and AMAZON and in truth people should just get a smart tv.  But before you buy this device, pretend you own a ROKU and go to trouble shooting and see what happens.  Nothing.

I've had Apple TVs from the first gen to the latest 4k one. For around $50 this Roku Streaming Stick+ is the best option for your money and this supports all current video and audio formats (4k, UHD, HDR, Dolby Atmos etc.). I added this to a Denon AVR-X4400H and it switches on the AVR and TV (Samsung UN65JU7500FXZA) and controls the volume as well. The only 1 remote I need and the only 1 streaming stick I use, although I have Apple TV 4th gen and Samsung Smart interface as well. This has way more apps and choices compared to Apple TV and the only thing this doesn't have is games (which I don't play it on Apple TV anyway).Another reason to get this in a bedroom or guest room is that you can access the Xfinity Stream app and all your subscriptions plus live TV through it rather than paying $10/month for a cable box to Comcast. That's ROI within 5 months. I have this in my main TV set in the living room and in the master bedroom. Also have a cheap TCL Roku TV in the guest bedroom. No issues activating unlike some reviews that mentioned it here while owning multiple Roku devices.Only cons I can think of -1) The voice recognition and search functionality needs major enhancement and doesn't work all that well.2) The remote acts up sometimes and doesn't control the TV/AVR and I have to reset the Roku device (others have mentioned this as well)Overall - I really want to give this 5 stars, 5 stars for the price, 5 stars for the app store, 5 stars for the functionality,  5 stars for formats supported, etc. etc. I'm just taking 1 star away for the minor niggles with remote and universal / voice search.

This was my first Roku device. I was searching for a way to stream my Comcast to my outdoor backyard tv and this gets the job done.  There is some buffering that occurs but that is more of a function of my wifi environment.  The interface is easy to learn and use.  The HD/4k streaming is awesome. My only concern is that the stick gets really hot.  I've gotten a few on screen warnings. The TV is outside in a very open environment and it still gets really hot. This would not be a good device to put in some type of cabin. It works great but make sure you have great ventilation...even then it might be questionable. We'll see how long it last before it literally burns out.

I'm going to go straight into pros and cons:PROS- Super Easy to install.- Voice recognition is very accurate.- Great design and I like the home screen.- Price is fair given alternatives.- Remote programmed on its own to my TV controls.CONS- The voice controls are just MEH! They don't really work within individual applications. For instance, you can't search for a certain show on Netflix while you are in Netflix. It will just search all applications for that show and then make you exit to the home screen in order to select it. It also doesn't automatically recognize whether you own the movie (say on VUDU) or not even when the account is linked.- Parental Controls are not available on the TV home screen or in settings. In fact they are VERY limited and the ONLY way to block purchases is to set up a pin on your Roku website account. I mean c'mon man, its hard enough as it is to keep my 3 year old from ordering accidentally, don't make it harder! *This is the prime reason for the 3-star rating (no pun intended).SUMMARYI am not impressed. I want to like it, but find myself just a little annoyed. Now that I have it all set up, I will most likely keep it, but who knows. I certainly like my friend's Firestick better. I'm only 1 person, but that's my $.02!

Warning  this device power and sound control  does not work with Vizio M series tv. You pay an extra $20 for something you can't use so you might as well buy the $30 unit because ROKU doesn't tell you that ,you just have have to waste an extra $20 to find that out. Wonderful! Also , their support,LOL, emailed me back and 4 times to refer me to their website on  how to setup the remote when I described to them the trouble . Then they tell that my tv is not compatible with their device after playing email tag.In all the system does work on my other tv and I do like it but I don't appreciate being taken advantage.

Honestly do yourself a favor and ditch all the other streaming sticks for this one!I’ve used an Amazon fire stick for years. I love Amazon and I’ve always thought their products were great- except for the fire stick.At first I thought it was my internet disconnecting and reconnecting constantly causing my apps to load slowly or just shut off. But when I would do stuff on my laptop/phone everything loaded perfect. (I had the latest stick too)Then I got the idea to just try to Roku and see if it’s any different.Well I’m here to tell you it’s well worth the switch. Roku’s program and layout is 100% better and faster. I’ve yet to have an issue (and being at home constantly right now-thanks COVID- I’ve had a lot of experience) and everything works just as I need it too.If I had to name a con- it would be that there isn’t a web browser like Amazon has. So that’s slightly inconvenient. Sorry Amazon- I’m still a loyal customer just with a Roku stick now.

We have a Samsung HD 4K TV, but I bought this streaming stick to use primarily with a 10-year-old Samsung flat screen with 1080i / 720p resolution. It didn't work with the old TV: pink pixelated display with faintly visible menu. It worked perfectly with the HD 4K. So 5 stars for new HD TVs, 0 stars for older models.. If I were rating this just on support, I would give ROKU 1 star. The tech person I reached by phone didn't know what she was talking about. I gave her detailed specs for the old TV and she kept insisting that the HDMI port on my TV was defective even though I kept telling her that the port worked perfectly when I used it for other devices. I also submitted a ticket, which ROKU responded to several times, but only to say they were still looking into it. Finally, three or four days later, a response to the ticket, with an apology for the delay, recommended getting the ROKU EXPRESS PLUS. I did. The HDMI connection worked perfectly so I didn't need to use the RCA cable - the "Plus" - that was included in the package. So maybe the ROKU EXPRESS would have worked just as well.

I love Roku. I get a ton of free channels and pay channels like Disney, Hulu, Netflix, Amazon Prime, Youtube, music channels and more. Even international TV channels. I bought Roku sticks for my sons and can share log- ins on some streaming services so they have access too, cutting down on costs.  The Roku channel itself has tons of great shows and movies. So easy to set up and I'm saving over $100/month vs. cable TV.  Should have done this years ago. I got it for my 80 year old mother. It took her a bit to get used too, but now she's flying through the streaming services like a pro. She's delighted with the expanded options and huge cost savings vs her previous cable bill. She has so many program choices, she has spent an hour just looking at what her options are. Never again will she say "I have all these channels, but there's nothing interesting to watch" like she did with traditional cable. Great investment, and you can take it anywhere.

When you go to activate it fails and tells you to call a phone number. They then tell you you can't activate unless you have a registration code which costs 99.00.It is a scam do not pay to activate, try to activate on a computer not a phone.
Fue fácil instalar y tiene un amplio grado de apps para tener en la TV, es super rápido. Lo que no me gusta es que muchas de las app no están disponibles para mi país Panamá.

I had one of the very early FireTVstick's (CV89LM). I was very happy with it, but the latest firmware/software upgrade slowed it down - a lot. I decided to try a new one (for under $20) and am VERY pleased with the purchase. It is much faster reacting to the remote and has some nice, new features. Alexa works great. Never had that, so it's fun to use. I will use the old one in my RV for occasional use, but love the new one at home. It's better than the Smart TV app on the television. You cannot beat it for the price. Especially if you have Amazon Prime for tons of free movie streaming. Get it.

Wow! I never knew watching TV could be this easy. I don't have to jump out of one App to go to another thanks to the awesomeness that is the Firestick Lite. Having everything in one place is what I dreamed of but never thought would be a possibility. I can search for a movie or show easily. For example, In Plain Sight, and be shown which app has it (Imbd) instantly. I don't have to search every app individually any longer. Do you get what  blessing that is??? No more typing in the title 4 or 10 times. Just type it once and POOF its displayed, and with options to purchase it if so desired. Complete game changer here people! Less jumping from App to App means more time for binge watching. Who of us doesn't want more time to enjoy our shows?!If you have more than one TV, buy one for each!!! You won't experience the supreme let down of going from one truly awe inspiring viewing experience back to the mundane experience of having all your apps open and still not finding what you're looking for. I'm kicking myself in the butt for not ordering a 2nd one on Cyber Monday.I've seen the future and it is beyond what I ever dreamed it could be. Join me as a fellow firestick owner and you, too, can enjoy the fruits of their labor making our binge watching endeavors delightfully easier!!

Works well. As I have another Fire TV Stick, it read that set-up and duplicated it on the new Fire TV Stick. Everything works as described. Good processor speed. Plenty of memory for my needs.A review that I read here before purchasing the Fire TV Stick Lite suggested you purchase the lite stick, save $10 and upgrade your remote with the savings. That didn't work for me. An upgraded Fire TV Stick costs about the same as the whole Fire TV Stick does. I have one of the newer Fire TV Stick remotes and paying $10 more for the 4K Fire Stick with more features and a better remote is a bargain.You need to think about how you want to use your system before choosing the right model Fire TV Stick. For example, the volume control on the better Fire TV Stick is worth a lot to me. Also, the 4K has support for my Fire Recast. If all you want is access to a couple of streaming apps, the lite model may be a good choice.  I am happy with what I got for the price I paid. I could have chosen better.

Yay, HBOMAX is now on Fire Stick, and can be accessed by, well, I pressed the 'sponsored' app link, bright purple, hard to miss. This app has a glorious amount of Criterion movies from TCM, HBO movies, original HBO series, old and new, brand new original HBOMAX series, and lots more. Account registered on one device can be used on all devices.The fire stick lite has so many apps I can't imagine what the one that's not lite has.But as I bought it expressly for HBOMAX, I've not tried anything else yet. Though all my Amazon Prime TV and movies are easily accessible too now.

I had gotten an Amazon Fire tablet, which I despised, so was never thinking about a Fire stickThe price on this made me consider it for my mom. I had another streaming device I really liked so I was keeping that.I set it up and used it trial run and was very pleasantly surprisedI t works well, setup was just as easy as the other and after a week of using it, I use it now and gave elderly mom the other because of the home screen. It confuses herSo the only complaint I have is the home screen is too busy. WAY too busyToo many Strips to navigate, so much going back and forth, even for the channels I installedI like a homepage I can see my channels, most of them I use often anywayThe Fire you have to scroll sideways on a strip of apps and can only see the first 5Irritating!But it has voice so I can save some time if I use itJust really don't like all the recommendations and side scrolling...Otherwise for the price it's a gem

For 21 bucks and change I was able to turn a very nice flat screen tv into a Smart TV! No cable required. Just plug the TV in, plug the firestick into the wall/TV, and BOOM, I now have all of my APPS on this TV! The set up was crazy easy. I used my laptop to help with set up and the Firestick literally told me where to go, I plugged in a code, and everything was registered. I did not want to buy another Smart TV, knowing I had this great (older) TV in the basement. I mean, it's kind of a great way to recycle, in my opinion! I even got a free year of Food Network TV (make sure you change the option to bill you monthly at 4.99 at the end of the free year instead of the yearly cost (there are 2 options)--that way if you want and forget to cancel, you'll only be charged a month). Great Price! Comes with BATTERIES! Was able to utilize a TV I already owned. Oh, and Alexa is pretty cool. My kids like the games included. There's Jeopardy and trivia built into the device. Just ask Alexa to play a game.

honestly, I dont know the difference between the fire stick and the fire stick light.  This one works just as good as the other ones I have seen...with the only difference being the cube since you can talk to it more.  This works perfectly and give us everything we need so we never need to pay for cable.  It is so easy to find everything we are looking for.  Plus it is super cheap.  We own both fire sticks and Rokus...They are so similar... I think the Roku is a little easier to use... especially since it took me a bit to know how to lock purchases!  But it is nice to see shows right away on the screen and not really have to search.  This is a must have!

The Fire Stick Lite is a lower cost, solution to streaming needs on the go! Although it doesn't have volume control or channel control it is still much faster than old previous generation firesticks and is relatively easy to set up and use, and even is Alexa enabled.  I used this one on my projector to watch outdoor movies and it works great without alot of additional gadgetry.Just get a nice outdoor extension cord and an outdoor rated powerstrip, hook up some speakers and make a nice afternoon with friends outdoors. My streaming functions worked fine with my network.  Just ensure your router is good enough to cast a bit outdoors. Do NOT attempt to use this setup in the rain. But it worked great on a nice dry cool fall afternoon outside by the firepit.  Best of luck and I hope you enjoy your firestick lite as much as I have so far. I liked it so much I've bought one for my parents,  and another for a guest bedroom! They've all worked great!

I have purchased 2 other fire sticks and had no problems. I got this one for my child’s room, and it’s complete trash. I have to unplug and replug the fire stick every time I cut the tv on to get it to turn on. The remote only worked the first 2 days and then was almost unresponsive. I use the fire stick remote app on my phone instead, which I shouldn’t have to do with a new purchase. Buy a more expensive one, this one is not worth it!!

I purchased this because a TCL Roku TV all of a sudden refused to connect to WiFi after being moved to a different room (while everything else was fine)  and NO ONE was able to help. Yes, I did all the customer service turn this on, turn this off, reconnect this, etc. etc., etc., ad nauseam. This did exactly what I was hoping and restored Roku capability to the TV. Loses a star because not able to get to live TV button or add it on the Roku stick evidently so now have to use two remotes, but oh, well. Better than having to buy another TV.

I purchased the Roku for the sole purpose of adding my spectrum cable app to my television and all my other tv apps to have all in one place due to our fire stick doesn’t allow the cable app we have, however when trying to hook it up my husband ran into an issue with the codes that are needed to enter to set it up. We call support, they say we need a subscription for support and if we enter the codes 3 times then the Roku is useless unless we purchase a subscription for him to reset it. I went back and looked at my Amazon order and it didn’t say anything about needing a subscription and paying more money so I call the Roku number for myself and sure enough, I can get it fixed for a year, 3 year or lifetime subscription 😳 (lifetime subscription is like 299) and I told the gentleman Absolutely NOT and have a good day sir! Now I’m out 50 bucks! FYI we thought we were setting up wrong and not following instructions and yes we know how to read but we had already entered the codes more than we should have and rendered it useless before we called the support number so just read as much as you can before purchasing this or go to a store like we’re going to now. We’re not tech savvy people and it could’ve been our error but at the end of the day, I felt like it was a scam considering we got the same representative both times we called. 🤷🏼‍♀️

All I wanted to do was stream my cable tv content to a 3rd tv 25' away.  No reason to have to open a Roku account, agree that they can track your viewing habits, and have your credit card on file...ridiculous!!Had I known this going in would have never purchased this device!

My Roku is connected to my Google WiFi system (mesh). At least several times a week, we'll be watching something on TV, but at some random point, the remote stops responding. I'm only able to adjust the volume on my (Samsung) TV and turn the TV's power on/off since it is using the infrared. Most of the time, I have to wait a period anywhere between 10 - 20 seconds, before the remote responds again. Other times, I have to unplug the Roku's power entirely, and wait for everything to turn back on for the remote to work normally again. It's very annoying - especially when you have two toddlers where a quick distraction is needed.I even adjusted my router to have the Roku unit on a static IP address, yet the issue still remains. Based on researching other reviews, it seems no one has able to figure out a solution for this problem. When the remote is working as normal, everything is great with the sound and picture. However, because of the common remote freezing issue, I would NOT recommend buying this Roku model.

To patti s response on Roku requiring a premium account.  It is a fake website you went to.  I fell into the same trap.  Roku warns you about this in the doc provided.  I still fell into the trap.  During installation Roku tells you to go to specific website.  If you google that website the first entry is the fake website.  Installation will appear to fail and they give you a phone number to call.  Those India guys will hit you up for 99$ for premium.  If you type in the www address you will get the right activation code and the install will succeed  Mark b

The stick was already activated when I tried to activate it. I had to factory reset in order to activate it to my account. As well, the remote was all scratched and had a blob of white paint on the rear cover, I suppose meaning it was used. In this day and age of Covid, I'm terribly disappointed in Amazon and Roku. ...and it kept hanging up. I had to disconnect the power cord to get it to reboot and respond. I have already ordered a replacement and am returning the original.The picture of the two sticks shows this purchased item on the left, which I am returning. The stick on the right is the replacement. Hmmm. Two different models.The picture of the remotes shows the original purchased remote on the right and the replacement order on the left. Notice the difference? One has a power button the other does not. The quick streaming service buttons are different.The pictures of the USB connector shows a micro-usb connector on the original purchased stick while the other shows a mini-USB connector.So, it appears a previous buyer had a Streaming Stick, purchased a Streaming Stick + then placed the non + model in the + box and returned it to Amazon.If anyone from Amazon is listening, I'd like a response on how that return made to your inventory and into my hands. You've wasted my time.

Bad model device where previous models worked & work great.  Only two months after first use, it started getting hot &  losing the video voice tracks intermittently. I changed the outlet but it didn’t change the hotness.  I changed the micro-USB-B but that did nothing to the hotness nor voice track losses.  Turning everything off and unplugging the roku streaming stick from the electricity then plugging in again returned voice tracks but intermittently.  Now the stick remotes aren’t recognized at all.  That’s $85 down the toilet including the second remote.

I got a Roku Streaming Stick+ last year, and it was great for a while. But despite years of calling itself a "neutral platform," Roku has recently dropped support for HBO, and has declined to add support for HBO Max or Peacock, despite the fact that its customers have been asking for it. The entire reason I bought a Roku device in the first place was that it supported all the major streaming services, but that's no longer the case, so I definitely would not buy this device again.

When I first purchased the Roku Streaming Stick+, I thought it was a nice improvement over my 1st Gen Amazon FireTV Stick with the Roku being able to search multiple apps for specific movies and television while the Firestick pushed Amazon products. Others have complained that the Roku interface looks dated but I found it to be familar and easy to navigate with a quick response time and very little lag. But that is where the positives end for the Roku.I connected the Roku Streaming Stick+ to my Yamaha RX-679 surround sound receiver via HDMI and it played fine at first. But then I started getting frequent, sporadic audio drops where the center channel would simply fade out and the volume would drop so low that it became inaudible. It would stay low for several minutes and then return to normal before repeating the audio issue. I tried numerous app updates, system restarts, system resets, updated the firmware on the Roku and the Yamaha receiver, switched HDMI ports and HDMI cables but nothing resolved the issue.Out of desperation, I returned the Roku Streaming Stick+ to Amazon and purchased a Roku Ultra hoping that would resolve the issue but it didn't. I contacted the Roku support team and listed all of the pertinent details in my original message before receiving a response that seemed to indicate most of my original message had went unread because I was being asked questions that I had already answered. I answered those same questions again and Roku support told me to disconnect the Roku from my AVR and connect it directly to the television, completely bypassing my surround sound system and just using the built-in television speakers.A quick internet search shows that Roku has had audio issues with surround sound systems as far back as Roku 3 and as recently as the Roku Premiere+ so I told the Roku support team to address the issues with their audio coding instead of asking customers to find subpar workarounds. After doing so, the Roku support team claimed that my Yamaha receiver was to blame, marked the claim as being "resolved" and closed the ticket.I had the FireTV Stick, a PS4 and an Xbox One all connected to the Yamaha receiver via HDMI and all of those devices played through my 7.1 surround sound system flawlessly. So it is obvious that Roku would rather place the fault within  other components instead of taking responsibility for its own faulty software.My advice is to stay away from Roku if you have any kind of surround sound system. A sound bar may work with the Roku but it seems that audio systems with multiple audio channels will have problems with the Roku software and the Roku support team is completely useless in resolving these issues.

Amazon stopped supporting Prime Video on my Panasonic Plasma and my Sony Blueray player. I needed a new way to stream. Roku looked like the answer.Roku did not work for me. I purchased three of these in a month. The first one activated in minutes and streamed perfectly for about three weeks. Didn't understand the bad reviews. Then it stopped streaming completely after three weeks. Network was fine. Sent back two days before return window closed.The second one hung up for hours trying to activate. It logged on to my network fine, but It would not finish the activation screen. It gave me the activation code to finish, but before I could enter it, Roku kept giving me a new code. Returned it also.Third one, same as the second one. I've had it with Roku.The first one streamed fine for three weeks, then died. It seems it's hit or miss with Roku.Guess I'll have to try a Fire Stick.Update: Purchased a FireStick 4k after sending back the third Roku.The FireStick was up and running in about ten minutes. It's fast and so far no issues. Also, it's nice to be able to skip intros and ads with the firestick. Sorry I wasted so much time on Roku.

I'll always be a fan of the fire stick is my first introduction to a different way of watching TV after the antenna was taken outta the picture I'm still not used to this even after all these years but think of all the years I watched with an antenna way more years That than this way but yes Amazon is on it with this the difference between the lite and the regular fire stick besides there's a live TV button to press instead in I'm not sure yet. The smart TV we had died and this temporary old TV we have well this temporary TV think died because of the fire stick LOL  THE temporary TV was 5 years old and not a smart TV so until tax season I'm using my phone because I mean disability only goes so far but my honesty doesn't don't hook up to non smart TV's or to TV's 5 years of age or older LOL.. but yes Amazon fire stick is the only way to go. No extra anything for this either unless you want it. Other than that good good to go

This is a nice item to have but the upgraded version with volume control it much better.
