I'm giving this a 3-star rating only because I think Amazon is ripping off its customers by not offering a remote sold separately in case something happens to the remote.Unbeknown to me, my daughters remote got tangled in bedding and ended up going through the washer .There was absolutely nothing wrong with the fire stick itself, on the remote was fried. Buying a new remote by itself cost just as much as a new fire stick with remote so it made sense to buy all new everything. I was forced to buy an entirely new fire stick with remote.and am now stuck with a useless fire stick all because I can't pair another remote with it and it's cheaper to just buy a new fire stick remote.Come on Amazon!!!! you can do better than that with your customers!

I had an old Roku that started giving me fits recently. I knew it was connected to WIFI, but when I went to load an app it told me I wasn't online. Apparently, this is an old issue with Rokus that hasn't been resolved. I did a factory reset and that fixed the problem, but I saw this Fire Stick Lite was on sale for Black Friday and I decided to give it a try. After using it just for a little while, I don't think I'm ever going back to Roku. I find the user interface to be a lot less clunky, though it probably helps that I've been using Prime Video for years and I'm used to the layout. Aside from Prime Video, adding other streaming services like Netflix, Hulu, Disney+ and YouTube was very simple, as was rearranging them as I desired. The stick itself is very thin, but I still needed to use the short extension they included to make it work with the HDMI port I wanted to use, so it's great that it comes with that. Finally, the remote is very nice. I don't use Alexa or voice searches, but the remote has the buttons I need to easily navigate the interface, play, pause, rewind and fast forward videos, which is basically all I need. So, all said and done, I'm super happy with this Fire Stick Lite. My only regret is that I didn't get a Fire Stick sooner.

I was not able to determine the difference between the Fire TV Stick and the Fire TV Stick Lite by reading the packaging. You can’t open the boxes so there was no way to visually determine the difference either. I purchase the Fire Tv Stick Lite based on price.  I was disappointed toFind out that there were no TV controls on the Lite so I have to use 2 remotes to stream TV. I need the TV remote to turn on the TV, toadjust the volume or use the mute setting. That is certainly an inconvenience and not what I expected. The device itself works just fine....so I have no complaints.  Just wish Amazon was more clear in their marketing of these products.

What took me so long to buy this! I bought this and the next one up. Haven't even opened the other one (may give it to my son for Christmas)  but we have been using a blue ray player that has Netflix, prime and youtube for years and it locks up and you can not afd other channels at all. This is exactly what we needed!  And am so happy, from purflex to cbs/abc we can download as many other apps as we pay for or that are free. I love that it hooks to my prime and I can search for a show/movie and it will show me where Its available for me to watch on my channels. (That's probably my favorite thing) I'm not sure I like that it connects to my Alexa because now my Alexa is always running and blinking. And I don't use the voice control because it,  my alexa dot and my phone all try to do what I'm asking even if the for is in the living room it picks up on my request. Trying to figure that out.

So I recently bought a 2021 Yukon with the Rear Entertainment system.  There are 2 HDMI ports as for some reason GM did not want to integrate roku or fire tv into the system....  but to solve this problem and make it look as clean as I could without having to take the fire stick in and out  I paired this with Fire TV Stick Lite with AmazonBasics USB Type-C to Micro-B 2.0 Cable and Cable Matters Right Angle HDMI Adapter. This was to point the stick down so it does not stick out and get broken off or knocked down by kids getting in and out..  I have had great success since install and the kids really enjoy it.  photos coming soon

I have been using the 1st generation Fire TV Stick for 6 years now.  It is miserably slow!!!!  Decided to buy the newest generation of the Fire TV Stick Lite version.  I don't have a 4K TV, so this version is fine for my purposes.  And, I'm not so lazy that I have to have all my TV controls on the same remote either.  The Fire TV Stick Lite is fast and works wonderfully!  Am still getting used to the new UI somewhat, but that won't take long.  There was 1 issue of adding an app (EWTN) that I have on my other Fire TV devices .... Amazon kept saying it was incompatible with all of my devices .... even the ones that were currently running the App.  But, I think enough of us complained about the issue and it has been resolved.  I'm as happy as a clam with this new Fire TV Stick Lite.  Price was great too at my local Home Depot .... only $17.99.

Got specifically to use for Apple TV, because if you have a subscription, you can’t view it on a big screen unless you have one of the specific TVs that Apple tells you will work, and I didn’t.  In my Fire Lite version, it is not on the list of apps that come up, and on my journey to try to find out how to get it, became quite frustrated with the Amazon support chat, and in fact had 4 separate individuals come on to try to help.  3 said “too bad”. #4 finally told me to go “purchase” the app from Amazon App Store. I was so mad! But then realized by “purchase”, they meant FREE.  So it was a frustrating journey that ended well. 1.5 stars for Amazon support :-(TL,DR: if you are already subscribed to Apple TV, and the app does not appear after setting up your FireStick, get the app from Amazon App Store and it will automatically download, and then you just follow the usual steps of logging in via the Stick.

It's pretty cool to have everything in one place on my TV. I like the various searching tools. It's been good EXCEPT (I don't know if anyone else has this problem) but mine randomly looses sound. There is no reason that I have found why this happens. When that happens I am forced to restart the Fire stick by unplugging it from the power source then plugging it back in. Not sure what else to do.

Repeatedly failed while trying to add appletv+ app to our (obsolete) “travel” Firestick and after contacting amazon support, we discovered that we had an original edition Firestick that was not compatible with the appletv+ App.  We saw the bonus one year access to the Food Network where we could learn new kitchen skills and purchased this new Fire TV Stick Lite.  We were immediately awestruck with the speed of the light stick.  Apps we had on our old stick were automatically downloaded onto the new light Firestick.Signing into channel apps was easy because we only needed to aim our phone camera at the QR code and the Light Firestick was activated in an instant.  We are so impressed, we may upgrade another older Firestick merely for the speed.Overall, this was a fantastic purchase.Well done Amazon!

It has many problems. The biggest problem is that it disconnects from the wifi when I am not using it and then wont reconnect until I reboot it. Forums recommended changing the channel of my wifi so I did that twice and it still loses connectivity. It has full wifi bars.The remote is terribly unresponsive. Sometimes you click a button and it works after a few seconds and sometimes it doesn't. I changed the batteries and it didn't help.It recently started turning off momentarily when I walk around as if something is loose and shorting out.Apps occasionally lock up and it remains unresponsive for minutes.I really want to like this thing but it feels like it was developed by Microsoft in 1997. Yes it eventually does what you want but it seems pretty weird to have such an awful user experience in such a cutthroat competitive market.

I purchased this to hopefully bring order to chaos. I have a smart tv. I stream several streaming services, 1 premium pay, and several free. Each streaming service uses my remote differently, and I was hoping the Roku remote would standardize maneuvering the various menus. No such luck. Really, it added another layer of complexity and confusion to what I already have. I have found myself not even using it. That's on me, I should have researched more carefully. The good news is, the Roku Stick + is fast, works every time without glitches. If you have a nice non-smart tv, this can be a huge help. If you already have a smart tv, not so much. I wish all TV manufacturers and streaming services would collaborate to make a more functional remote with universal functions. I guess that won't happen. Recommended, with caveats.

I've been using this Roku stick since November 2017 and it is mediocre at best. First the remote goes through batteries like a RC car. Once it gets about 50% battery left i constantly have to remove the cover and take out the batteries and put them back in and it finally works. The biggest problem I have is connectivity. The roku stick is literally 4ft away from my router and it constantly buffers on Playstation vue, Hulu, Netflix you name it. I've went into the secret menus changed things, put the roku on a different channel. I disconnected every single device from using the router and tried still buffering issues. My internet is very consistent at 150mbps. I have no other issues when using Hulu or Netflix via Xbox one. Plus my 12 year old son has a TCL Roku tv and his bedroom is on the other side of the house he doesn't have any buffering issues. I wouldn't recommend this product. Gave it two stars because its easy to use and the menu browsing is quick.Update: Down to 1 star - This remote is absolutely garbage. I contacted support and they said to reconnect the remote. I have to do this multiple times a month. In addition, to the remote i continue to have connectivity issues. The stick is literally a few feet from the router. My son's roku TV has no issues and we also have an older Samsung smart TV with no issues.

I can't tell you what I like about it because I can't use it.The HDMI port on my TV doesn't allow for the long Roku stick to plug in directly and Roku doesn't include the small wire adapter that allows this as part of the standard packaging. You have to go online to order a free adapter that'll make it work. Ok, so that's a bit irritating. I have this device that I already waited on and now I need to wait for snail-mail to deliver an adapter. Fine! I guess I have no choice.So online I go and fill out my name, email address, shipping address and super long serial number. Press submit and wait for my confirmation. NOPE! Sorry! they're temporarily out of stock on this 3 penny item. I mean, really? You don't a bazillion of these laying in piles since they cost nothing and are a critical component to many customers? But that's not irritating enough, do you think they'd take your order and ship it whenever it becomes available again? NOPE! They simply trash your order (after saving your email for marketing I bet) and expect you to come back day after day after day, fill in ALL your information again, re-submit your order and just to hope that Roku has gotten around to replenishing the critical 3 penny Item.Ridiculous!Utter lack of customer service and lack of respect for end users time.They can 'stick' it (get it? :-) I'm sending it back!

Good things first: this Roku does a fantastic job with streaming. I've never had network connection issues and the availability of apps is unrivaled.Now the bad: the remote is basically unusable. Unlike most of its competitors using Bluetooth, Roku went with a Wifi-driven remote.  Every single day the remote loses its pairing. The only way to get it to reconnect is to place the remote right next to the device and mash buttons until it finally picks it back up.  And then it'll routinely lose its connection to the remote as you are watching.  Nothing more frustrating than trying to pause a show and having to wait 3 min before it will actually register your button presses!  This is apparently a known problem and is compounded by the fact that our media console and wifi router are near one another.While I loved the device, I can't deal with the completely useless remote.

I've been using the Wii for about ten years, but they got rid of YouTube a few months ago, and now are getting rid of Netflix, so it's useless technology unless you have old games. The Roku is great for streaming, and no, you do not need to add a credit card as others have mentioned. You only need to add steaming services that you already have, OR use the free channels, as there are several.The Talk to Search is really awesome on the remote control, but it doesn't always recognize what you are saying. The downside is that it only searches all of Roku, not specific channels. For example, if you search YouTube for "90's Music," it will search the Roku channels for it. You can't search within the channel itself using the voice option. It also doesn't always understand very well, even when you're speaking clearly. You can keep repeating it and nothing will populate, but then when you type to search, what the Roku just said was not there by voice, suddenly appears. Very glitchy.There are times that it will freeze on the home welcome screen as well, but turning it off and on helps. Overall, those are the only complaints I've encountered. Setting it up was easy.

It works really well for an older TV that is ‘smart’ in name only, no more waiting forever for apps to load! I haven’t tested the 4K capability as my other 4K TV already has Roku built-in, but all other features of this Roku stick work like a charm. I actually use the Roku app on my phone to control all my TVs so I don’t mix the little remotes mixed up (roku TV remote is exactly the same as the stick+ but has some different app buttons at the bottom - the Netflix and HBO ones). The stick+ is very fast to start once plugged into the USB service port on my TV for power and of course the stick has to be plugged in HDMI to work. Initial setup was a breeze because I already have a roku account. I got this to fix the apps crashing on my old Sony TV that has YouTube and Netflix but is a couple years old so has trouble loading the apps and buffering streams. The stick+ has no problem with any content I throw at it. The voice control function is neat for the remote, but I prefer the app anyway for the easy text input when I’m searching. The remote is also small so it easy to misplace (especially if you have little ones). I only use the Netflix, Prime, Viki, Plex, and YouTube apps, but roku has a large store of apps available for download. I’d say most people with 4K TVs will already have smart features built-in to their set so you might be able to save with the non-plus version. I only got the stick+ because it had a great sale, making it cheaper than the regular stick.

I have been using Roku devices for years but this one has 3 issues:1- Remote takes a long time to start working. I thought that the long range controller was an advantage but its actually not as the controller deactivates after sometime and to reconnected at take up to 10 seconds to reconnect which is very annoying.2- If you are using this device outdoor it will just keeps going to the main menu: sometime 4G connection even though  its fast disconnects for a very short time and while in other devices you will not feel a thing as there is a good buffer and it will continue working normally or maybe pause the stream for a short time or until your connection is back. The roku will close your application and bring you to the setting menu to select network and you have to set it up all over again after that u will have to go back to the application, wait for it to load, select your user, search again for the video and forward until the point where its stopped working.3- Voice controls are not compatible with netflix or youtube.

Roku device is good at streaming, lots of free options if you don't have cable or other subscriptions. Picture quality is good most of the time, sometimes looks poor but eventually clears up. My biggest complaint would be the REMOTE. YOU NEED THE REMOTE FOR THE ROKU DEVICE TO FUNCTION!!! but the design is poor. I have to reconnect the remote EVERY DAY and often it will not connect at all. I have contacted Roku about this but they never responded. They have many problems with this and all they offer is a "how to" for connecting your remote. Unplug tv, unplug roku stick, remove batteries from remote, plug back in, turn on, put in batteries, press button...AND IT STILL DOES NOT WORK! You can use the Roku app on your phone as a remote but this wears down your battery and monopolizes your phone if you want to use it for anything else. You know, to make a phone call or something... Roku should be a great product but with a defective remote it is really frustrating and annoying to use. I wouldn't want to have to deal with this on more than one TV, reconnecting them all EVERY SINGLE DAY, something that is integral to the function of the device!

The set-up was a breeze and the only minor issue is the sales pitches for numerous "pay station" apps you have to navigate through before you activate the roku.  I have no idea where the one customer called to have someone ask for $70 because they had multiple rokus on one account. The instructions clearly point out roku does NOT charge for activating devices so beware of scams.  It appears someone tried to scam the customer.  Wifi reception was strong and 4K streaming is breath taking.  This replaced an older roku device that finally bit the dust.  A plus is the ability to control tv power and volume with the roku remote, which automatically sync to our Samsung tv.  Well worth the sale price paid.

This is my third Roku.  I have it on three two different sets.  First problem I had was after months of using the Roku, it went from 5.1 to stereo PCM 2.0.  I don’t understand how this happened when there is only my wife and I at home and she never touches the receiver or any of its features.  When home she watches cable.I purchased another, this one, which I am reviewing, in December.  It is now March 16, 2019, and while watching Hunter Killer it didn’t sound right.  I noticed it’s playing in 2.0 PCM.  I checked the settings on the Roku, also on my Anthem receiver.  They are correct.  So this is another device that has given me this problem.  I’m through with Roku and will next purchase a Fire Stick and hope that it’s better than this POS which is very annoying to say the least.

I returned the Roku Streaming Stick+ that I bought in 2018  because it would not connect.  This 2020 Roku Streaming Stick+ connected to my dumb TV quickly, and the wi-fi is fast.  The included wi-fi extended might be the difference.  I am not seeing the lag that I noticed with the Roku Ultra over wi-fi.  I also got three months of CBS All Access commercial free to binge Picard etc..  The Ultra draw was that I could connect it to the ethernet and improve my signal, future proof the device with options such as an SD card, and have a headphone jack backup to my Bluetooth earbuds.  However, the streaming stick cost, speedy operation, and CBS deal beats the Ultra advantages.The only problem that I have had so far is that YouTube would not connect to the profile I wanted, leading me to delete an obsolete profile that used the same e-mail address.

Roku Streaming Stick+ is useful if your TV is set far enough to cause lag or connection problem using other streaming stick.  Previously, I used Amazon Firestick.  Over time I started having lag where it took long time if I switch between programs or even lost signal completely.I searched the web and I was intrigued by Roku's claim of improved Wifi reception of Streaming Stick+.  I was dubious at first because while checking for other reviews on internet, I read articles where the reviewer didn't seem to notice any improvement in Wifi reception of their test unit.Set up was pretty straight forward.  You will have to set up Roku account if this is your first Roku.  I found Roku remote superior to Amazon's Firestick remote because it also double as TV remote.Of course, you don't need Streaming Stick+ version if you have no lag issues on Wifi reception.Update:  I still have some lag issues but compared to my old Amazon stick lag is shorter duration and recovery is quick once I get out and get back in.

I've owned them since the very first "roku netflix player".  I've had boxes, sticks, ultras, etc.  Maybe 10-12 of them in total over the years.I bought this stick+ for an advertised 3 month CBS all access deal for free, which wasn't much less than I paid for the stick.  Humorously, I needed another remote control and the stick+ with remote was $10 more than just the remote.The deal had to be activated by 4/5.  Its now 3/31.  Won't work.  Roku advertised this special offer for months, and still has it on their site, but now it says you have to click through their site to a retailer to get it.  It didn't say that last month when I bought it.  They refuse to budge.Along the way, I've found their tech support to be bad when it used to be pretty good.  I've also had their top of the line Ultra's simply not work properly with my off brand Sony and Samsung tv's (sorry, had to toss out a pun) giving me errors, the remotes stopping working altogether, various streaming issues where I could literally unplug the roku and plug a fire tv 4k box into the same cable and it'd work fine."Its a problem with your network, cables or tv".No Roku, you simply make some problematic products these days, have made the activation process onerous (MUST provide name, credit card, address, phone number, birthdate and gender), and you don't honor your deals.Fun part is, those early roku's I bought still worked fine, as did their remotes, albeit very slowly when I checked them out and factory reset them before recycling them a few years ago.

Let me start out by saying that I am fine with the picture and audio quality, but I am not all about that to begin with, so I may not be the best judge of it.  I installed this on a TV we don't used very often.  My issue is that when I turn it on, it freezes at the screen saver, the volume up and down works, but I can't get to the TV, Netflix or anything.  I have to turn it off and on, sometimes unplug it because it is frozen and won't do anything.  I just turned the sound off for the button because I read that could cause it, but I just did that, so not sure if that is a good fix. When it works, it is great.  I will update in a few weeks.I was going to wait to update, but I just got so frustrated trying to get this thing to work I had to downgrade my rating.  I have tried everything to get this thing to work.  I restarted it, unplugged and restarted it multiple times, and no luck.  There are a lot of people having issues like I am having, just do an internet search on Roku freezing.Okay, after trying for 45 minutes to get this to work I found a website that said to refresh the remote.  I had no clue I would have to wipe the remote clear and then pair it again with the stick.  Finally working, but it will be interesting to see how often I will have to do this.Absolute junk!!!!!!!!

Not happy with my second Roku purchase. This time I purchased this item in july 2020Over a month ago I started to have problems with batteries getting drained ever 3- 4 daysAt first I thought the problem was with the quality of my batteries. I tried new AAA Energizer batteries,  no difference!Do Not Buy !

There is a whole lot to like about the Roku and the features and services provided.  Unfortunately, that is all overshadowed by  ongoing hardware issues.  I have two Roku Streaming Sticks+.  So far, one has not given me any problems.  The other one does not maintain a pairing between the Streaming Stick and the remote.  I have had to re-pair multiple times, and unless I use a precise order of steps, I can't even get the re-pairing to work.  That is just waaaay too much hassle for a product that should have worked out the bugs by now.  If I cannot find a more permanent solution, my wife will force me back to cable or satellite TV, because she just will not deal with the problems of this hardware.The steps I have found to work best to re-pair my remote with the Roku Streaming Stick+, should you wish to stay with a product this buggy.Unplug Roku - just pull the plug that goes into the stick.Take batteries out of remote.Put batteries back into the remote (leave the back off).Green light should be flashing.  If not, try pressing reset button for 3 seconds.Plug power back into the Roku - with the remote nearby.The pairing process should begin.Good luck.  I'm losing my patience.Edit:  I contacted the seller and asked for a replacement.  The seller quickly responded and replaced my unit.  Thus, I have zero issues with the seller.  Well guess what?  The new Roku does exactly the same thing as the last one.  Overnight, the remote loses pairing with the stick and I have to go through setup all over again.  To add to my frustration, one of the steps required is to remove the batteries from the remote.  The battery case is so poorly designed it is very difficult to remove the batteries and requires some type of tool.  Fingernails just won't do it.I have tried an experiment that seems to reduce the incidence of lost pairings.  I place the remote very close to the Roku stick.  Distance seems to be a factor.  My couch is about 15' from my TV.  But seriously, 15 feet is too far to maintain pairing?  I have Bluetooth devices that never lose connection at considerably more distance.Bottom line:  I am very sorry I went with Roku.  The service is great, the hardware sucks.

So, for whatever reason, Roku did not include the wireless component of the unit in the actual stick. Roku decided to add it to the USB cable that gives the unit power (the "Advanced Wireless Receiver"). Unfortunately, that cable is the weak link in the system. Having now owned three of these, I can tell you that if your TV is mounted on a wall and you need to extend the USB cable longer than the included extension, you are out of luck- regular USB cable extensions that you buy won't have the wireless component, so your stick won't see the remote or your wi-fi. Likewise, if your HMDI ports are mounted vertically, when you plug the cable into the unit all of the strain is on the connector which will eventually fail. It will still pass power (sometimes), but you won't get any wireless connections. And if you get a great idea to buy a 90 deg adapter for the cable, you're SOL there, too- just like extensions, no adapters work with the USB/ AWR cable in the box.As I stated, I have owned three of these units in the past year. I will not be owning a fourth. I don't know what I'll do, but it won't be this.TL:DR- Because Roku made its failure-prone proprietary USB cable essential to the unit with no ability to adapt, extend, or replace it, these units are not worth your time or money.

I've had previous generations of Roku products. I've had AppleTVs. I have a FireTV stick. My TV has crappy online streaming features. After trying pretty much all the options for streaming TV I keep coming back to Roku products. They're reasonably priced and are almost constantly on sale. They're platform agnostic and support any subscription service you can throw at it. Setup is easy and consistent. I rarely have had a Roku product software crash or misperform. I don't yet have a 4K TV nor do I use the voice search function much, but I still got this model just to future proof myself. I tend to use the physical remote instead of the phone remote, but the mobile app works in an emergency and is intuitive and available for iOS and Android.

Let me preface this with I have owned every single Roku since the initial model (over a decade ago now). Roku as a platform has grown exponentially since then, and I am proud to use them on all of my TVs. This Roku stick is almost indistinguishable from its full size counter part in terms of speed and quality. I went with the stick form because it was for a projector and I did not want to run another HDMI cable through the ceiling.For those who are posting about a scam or being held “hostage” by support, make sure you actually go to Roku’s website, and check the SSL certificate. (This is why we don’t google URLs when they’re presented to you on the screen...). Roku does not force any fee to activate and they don’t cap the number of devices (they don’t even require a payment method on file to use, unlike another streaming stick I know). If you were told otherwise, you were made a fool of by a scammer who took advantage of you not checking the URL.The new remote with this stick is so light and thin, a major improvement over the older generations! My only complaint is that the library of remote commands (TV power, volume and mute) is restricted to TVs- not AVRs and Projectors. You can usually google it and find a brand that uses the same code to map it to get it to work- just not as simple.While I’m a firm believer in always wiring streaming devices to your network (I.e. Ethernet port), this stick does a great job streaming 4K over WiFi regardless of the fact that it’s in a terrible spot for WiFi coverage (behind a projector with a lot of interference and hanging off the ceiling).

I purchased this, simply because it does not control the TV. I control it with it's own remote. This gives tons of options for watching TV. You don't have to be stuck with Network TV or only a couple of streaming sites. This offers so many and it does the job I bought it for. I have no complaints. It was easy to set up, and connect to the internet. I may purchase the Ethernet Adapter to connect with a wired connection so I don't have to use Wi-Fi. Makes us dizzy and grouchy. I highly recommend this for anyone needing a new streaming device without spending a ton of money on a device. (Like a new Blu-Ray Player). Prime Video, Netflix, Pluto TV and so many other options. Your local TV station may have an app to allow you to watch their newscast live. This is great for those of us who cut the cord years ago.

Been using ROKU's (3) for years. They have become somewhat unreliable. Remotes often go bad and unit also begins to malfunction. BUT it was simple to use as long as it worked. Fire is overwhelmingly complicated compared. Offerings are confusing. Has an universal search that implies somethings are free but they are not - only the app have to pay for a "provider". Still learning but wastes a lot of time. Not very intuitive. As you scroll for apps it starts a preview they are pushing right away. Very irritating

No tv controls sounds like a minor inconvenience but this also means NO power button for the Fire Stick. Always running means it does not clear it cache etc (Refresh its self)  unless restarted in the setting (Very inconvenient w/ multiple clicks) or unplugging the device. We have now sent back ever single fire stick lite due to consistent customer issues. All complaints were consistent with it not responding correctly, loss of sound, & loss of Ch if using the Fire Recast. Customers would have to unplug and plug back in ever day to get sound to work, For the recast issue factory resting would make it work for a day or two. All customer were upgraded to a Fire Stick 4k and have had no issues.

Your browser does not support HTML5 video.










  
  
    
   I love my new fire stick! Ive had it for just about 2 weeks and it works great! I included a picture of the box that looked a little beat up when I opened the package, but everything inside was perfectly fine.I purchased this after returning a Google chromecast on Amazon and leaving a pretty bad review. Thankfully, the purchase of the Amazon Fire TV Stick Lite worked out much better.I purchased the Lite option for a few dollars less than the price of the original Fire TV Stick option. The only difference is that the Lite does NOT have a power button or a volume control. I don't think this is too inconvenient, but it might have been worth the extra few dollars just to have everything in one.Keep in mind that there are a lot of different streaming services offered on the Fire TV (netflix, Disney+, CBS all access, YouTube, etc) but while most of the available apps are free to download, most of them require a subscription to actually use. With that being said, there is a "free" tab on the home screen that gives options to watch for free WITH ads. If you don't subscribe to any streaming services though, and don't like ads/commercials, this device probably won't be of much use to you.I have an Amazon Echo 1st generation, and was easily able to connect it to my new fire stick in the Alexa app. As you can see in the video, there is a few seconds delay, but it works pretty well (and I rested the remote on the TV so you can see that it really is the Alexa taking control)Although there is no power button on the remote, the TV did shut off when I said "Alexa turn off my TV" but it did not turn back on when I said "Alexa turn on my TV". The Echo did not respond to volume commands pertaining to the TV. It's not a total loophole, but being able to turn the TV off is a little extra since I expected to exclusively need my TV remote to control power and volume. Either way, it was easy set up and provides convinient handsfree watching. Pressing and holding the microphone button on the remote while speaking allows all of the same voice commands as the Echo, without needing to say "Alexa", and the delay is significantly LESS than when using the Echo. The commands that I have discovered and used so far are: open an app; play a movie/show/song (if you don't specify which app, it will give you your options, or you can specify which app in the original command); turn off the TV; play/pause; skip/rewind; what time is it?; What's the news?; Home; open settings. There are also suggested voice commands that pop up at the bottom of the home screen every now and then if you just leave the home screen open.The remote takes 2 AAA batteries, and 2 were included, so that was nice to not have to go get any separately.A small extension cord is included incase things are cramped around your HDMI port and you can't have the Fire Stick pointing straight out. I did not need this, but it seems like an important feature to make sure noone has any trouble setting the device up.Overall, this is a great device and has made streaming very easy. It works well and I would highly recommend it.

I can't even get it set up. When trying to connect to my wifi I almost always get the same error message. "Could not contact Amazon.com..." I returned it and got a replacement that did the same thing. I have 15 wifi devices in this house and all of them worked without any hassle. I've spent hours with Amazon technical support trying to get this to work. It worked for about a day and then stopped again. It is not worth all the trouble. Google "Could not contact Amazon.com..." Lots of people have this problem. Then when I tried to return the second one, I was faced with yet another hassle. They wanted to troubleshoot it again. I didn't want to do that. I was fed up with this thing and just wanted it out of my life forever. It took a while to convince them that I would only accept a refund.

****Review edited****I was originally super disappointed in my fire stick and it not working. I was having the issue with it going to sleep then not turning back on. After being frustrated and talking with tech support online I received a phone call. The person from Amazon was extremely helpful. Walked through some trouble shooting things. Looked up the book for my TV as of course I didn't have it. Helped find if there were settings off in my TV and factory re set the fire stick. Got my fire stick to work like it should and even called back the next day to be sure it was still working well. Wonderful customer service and of course love the fire stick. Especially love the extener on this one so I am able to use both home cords and don't have to switch between 2 devices at the plug.

I love the Amazon Fire Stick, it works so much better than the Roku (in my opinion). I have been using this product for many yrs and I have always found it quite enjoyable. I had to upgrade my Fire Stick when my old one finally kicked the bucket. I chose this one because of the price as I needed one in a hurry and I was strapped for cash at the time. It is a handy device to have and mine worked well at first, but now it is freezing a lot. I do believe that I got a defective one. That can happen when things are mass-produced like these are. Overall the device is great and I can stream all sorts of channels at the touch of a button. Alexis is quite good at finding what I ask for, and I have never had any real trouble with my stick before. This is the first fluke that I have ever experienced while using this product. I do recommend giving it a try (if you already haven't) as it is a great companion for your TV...

I snagged this on black Friday special for $17.99 just to add streaming capabilities to the TV in my room at my parents house. I was visiting for a month and didn't want to break the bank. It was totally worth the price, even for just the month. It was a little glitchy but to be honest my TV is old. I had the Alexa fire cube 2nd generation and this worked just as well for a fraction of the price, it just doesn't have as many features. I ended up purchasing two more of these little babies before the deal ended to leave at a condo I visit a couple times a year. I have all google devices in my home now, which I actually prefer, but this was a steal (Chomecasts are $30!)If you found this review even the least bit helpful please smash that 'helpful' button below! Thanks :)

I purchased the Fire Stick Lite for a Sony Smart TV which has limited streaming apps. The only way to access more apps was to connect another device. I already purchased a previous model Fire stick for an older television so I purchased one for the Smart TV. The set up is very easy through the prompts on the TV. The only problem was that the AAA batteries that were included for the remote control were not good. This is why I had problems with the set up initially. Once I swapped those out for new batteries, set up was simple. I recommend the Fire Stick Lite for anyone who wants a simple set up and does not want or need the remote to control the TV.  The main menu lists all the available apps and it was easy to find what I needed. Setting up Alexa remote control is very easy as well although I do not use the voice feature frequently. You can also set up different profiles on the home page for each user which is nice.

With broadcast TV so messed up with series not being done due to Corvid, We brought our first Fire Stick.  I'm impressed with all the movies and series you can watch.  Wish I would have checked this out years ago, but was discouraged with my Vizio smart TV and what little I saw, was not working well.  The Fire stick works great with using 5gh on my router that I never used before.  My error.  Bought one from Amazon for $21.00 and now want a second for my wife's TV.  Now priced $8.00 higher than my first purchase.  What a rip off.  Found another vendor that was selling same product for $22.00 and ordered from them.  Amazon ordering direct is just screwing you at an additional $8.00 over the first sale.  Also have to delay another Amazon order to meet free shipping.

This version of the Fire TV stick is an absolutely amazing upgrade over the previous generation. My original stick was still working, but I was never 100% happy with its processing speed. Read the reviews for this version and decided to give it a go and am so glad that I did!The processing speed for all features is great! Moving between apps and menus is super-smooth and there is no noticeable lag time at all. The difference between this version and the original stick really is like the difference between dial-up and cable internet.Set-up was effortless, as with all of the Amazon products that I've bought. Literally plug it in and go!If you have the original and are thinking about upgrading; I highly recommend doing so.

I purchased this item about 18 months ago but didn't take it out of the box until two weeks ago.  I encountered problems in set up which, upon investigation, was not a unique event- it wouldn't finish set-up, got caught in a loop, etc.  I contacted customer support, admitting the "old" nature of the device.  It took 3 days for any response.  The first response told me to try some things which I did with no success and contacted them again.  2 days later they said it was out of warranty.  After a few back-and-forths they offered me a 30% discount on buying 2 devices.  That was fine but when I put in the discount codes it would only give me 15% on one device (and the 2nd device could have been bought for the same discounted price directly.  We are now 17 days into the process with their last non-automated response telling me the matter is settled.  Obviously it is not.  Maybe most of the devices are good but customer service is sadly lacking.

We have purchased 4 over the course of the past month.  The first one wouldn't connect to the TV.  We thought it was odd but eventually got it to work (after unplugging and plugging back in several times).  After about a week, there was no sound.  We resolved this by unplugging and plugging.  This happened several more times, so we tried a different (NEW) fire stick.  That one would not connect at all.  We tried different TVs - nothing.  Not only that, the remote became incredibly hot to the touch.The third one connected without a problem, but has also had the volume problem.  I don't know if this is just a bad batch, but this is a bit ridiculous.  The fourth was intended to be a gift, but I don't know if that is a good idea, knowing that the other 3 we bought are terrible.

I have completely enjoyed my Fire Stick Lite very much. My husband doesn’t do well with installing anything with WIFI, but with this he didn’t have any problems. I keep my Fire Stick in our bedroom on a TV bought in 2013, therefore, it isn’t able to do EVERYTHING that is advertised about it, but it still does quite many things that have been advertised! I fully enjoy the Fire Stick Light! I would, have, and do recommend this for everyone!

I have used several fire sticks and even bought some for friends and family.  When the less then 6 month old one quit working, I went to customer service to see if they could help me figure out why it wasn't working.  After leading me through steps I told the customer agent I had already done (so it ended up being done twice) All he could say to me is my warranty is expired.  I spend around 100 a month on amazon if the customer service continues to be poor I will have to find a new online realtor.

I decided to purchase this because I didn't have the option to watch Amazon Prime through my blu-ray player (it's an older version with only a few apps like Netflix and Hulu).  I wish I had purchased this sooner.  I only had to plug it in and there are so many options.  Plus, my Netflix is so much more responsive through the fire stick.  I also like the microphone which makes it so much easier to find my shows.  The best part was downloading the Silk internet app so I can watch certain performances etc on a large scale as opposed to watching on my laptop.  The lite version works just fine for me as I really don't care if I have to use the cable remote for the volume etc.  Such and affordable solution.  Very happy.

This product came shipped with a half baked OS. I have a Recast and it works for both live and recorded content on my other 4k sticks and my previous fire stick 1st generation fine. The first generation fire stick was getting too slow and I thought it would be a good idea to get this Lite. Boy was I wrong! I can't watch both live and recorded content from CBS, ABC, NBC, AND FOX local affiliates. The weird thing is the other public channels and PBS work fine. I spent 2 hours on the phone with 2 reps since I got disconnected with the first one and I am waiting on a resolution. I just do not understand how something that works fine with the same display and a 4k and OG stick are fine and not with this Lite product.

I bought it on the Prime Day. I am glad that I did it. For under $20, I got everything I wanted for an old LED TV. It was very easy to set up - less than 5 minutes and very easy to use (same as the previous version - this is my third Fire Stick). With my recent purchased Fire Recast, I can see all OTA TV channels on this old TV that I cannot get good reception in downstair. Provided, I can see all the Prime Video in this TV plus these extra free channels. I highly recommend it - especially for Prime Members.

This is a Roku house - but there's no HBO MAX app for Roku, and I like to run "SmartYouTubeTV" to watch YouTube without commercials, which Roku doesn't allow.  When this tiny Fire Stick went on sale for $18, I grabbed one.  It runs MAX and a couple of ad-free YouTube Android APKs flawlessly.  You'll have to side-load the needed Android apps, which Google will tell you how to do.  The small Fire Stick Lite and its accessories seem solid and well-built.  The finish and packaging suggest it's being sold at a loss.It took a couple of hours to install the apps and launcher necessary to get rid of Amazon's home screen commercials - but it was worth the trouble.  This Fire Stick is as snappy in operation as a $40 Android TV Box.  See the picture for the clean and uncluttered home screen you can get with a custom launcher.

I was skeptical of the Fire TV Stick and if I would use it. It's engineering marvel, why? You can download hundreds of apps which vary depending on your use. I currently use it to view movies, news, weather and access music via YouTube. The remote is easy to use with a quick on-screen menu. The setup was relatively easy, but I'm computer guy. The only drawback it, does NOT interface with your TV. So if you want access to hundreds of movies, news, weather and also search the web all for FREE. The exception is the cost of internet (recommend 50 megabits or more) and the Fire TV Stick. I currently pay about $65 a month for internet at 50 megabits. Drop your $250 a month cable bill and use the money to buy new wardrobe, car, vacation fund, bitcoin or start college fund for the kids. I almost forgot to mentioned it comes with ALEXA voice, which works as advertised. 4 stars

There is no volume control on this version, but ots not something I was looking for. The video quality is great and it now streams HBO Max, which was the selling point for me. The remote is easy to use l, and the voice control is a huge plus l, specially if you have kiddos. My toddler loves it, because she can open her Netflix or Disney+ without help.The only downside is the set up. It's a little more complicated than the Roku, but I guess the voice command compensates for that.

I am old, old, old "school" and do not use the voice recognition feature.  I'm a button-kind-of-guy, but the fewer the better, and this one is just right, EXCEPT for a couple of features.  First, of course, you need a good quality (does not mean expensive) streaming TV and Internet.  Quality of ours (Roku) is pretty good.  The features I do NOT like are:The size of the remote/stick might be OK for a child's hand but it is difficult for man hands.  It is also super slick, like slide-out-of-my-hand slick.  Lastly from me, the volume control on the side is awkward to use, and there is an echo/feedback situation competing with our sound bar unless I put this remote on mute.  Even then, I or someone else sometimes inadvertently touch the up/down volume buttons and have to hit mute again if I notice the interference with the TV sound bar.  Functionally, the device works great (and there are a lot of programming choices), but the design of the handheld REALLY needs improvement.

I have a Vizio M55-D0.The only port this device fits in is the Side HDMI as the shape of the TV back prevents a direct plug in. Using the side HDMI port I get HDCP error immediately upon playing any video, the menus work fine, but zero content will play.I overcame this by purchasing a 90" elbow to plug this into the rear HDMI port (there is no flex connector or adapter in the package for compatibility issues fyi). Now most video plays... Strangely when I purchase explicit content (PPV, ESPN+ non-prime, non-netflix) I get HDCP errors that come up every few minutes show for a few seconds and then disappear - this pains me because I'm trying to enjoy purchased content, and usually hosting guests when doing so.Thought I could work through this will ROKU support. They send you instructions similar to the initial step 1 of calling the your internet provided in the early 2000s. Have you tried turning it off and on, then also unplugging and then plugging it back in again (to each HDMI port on the TV) - yup.Maybe I have older tech or something, but it plain doesn't work consistently for copyright issues, not necessarily the device not working - which is painful because it seems the device is nice, but the content cannot be delivered.2016 year model TV and 2018/19 Roku just won't play well together

This is my third Roku, and it's the first one with a remote problem.  Presumably it's because it's now a stick instead of a box, so it's plugged into the back of my stereo receiver.  The remote was unreliable out of the box, and when I checked on the Roku website I was told to order a free "extension cord" for the Roku, to get it away from the HDMI ports.  That has only helped a bit. Every time I turn on the stereo and Roku, the remote is unworkable for a while.  I keep pushing buttons and then all of a sudden it's good.  But then later on it might stop working again.  I checked the batteries in case they sent me some that were nearly dead, but the meter says they are good.Why is Roku selling a device that supposedly has a long-distance RF remote when the RF signal apparently isn't strong enough to overcome interference?  The Fire TV stick plugged in next to it has no remote problems at all.  I may return this.

Last month we finally cut the cord and went with Roku.  For the most part we are happy with Roku and I really like the voice command function.  Also, it's very easy to add new channels such as Disney+ and HBOMAX, but after a full month of use here are my not-so-good impressions.  1.) The controller does the job but I wish it had additional features such as switching back to the previous channel with the touch of a button.  Performing this task is a bit awkward and requires several button clicks.  2.)  Thus far we've already replaced the  batteries after one month.  3.)  For some reason the volume control will suddenly cease to function.  I found that if I unplugged the fob in the TV, thus rebooting it, the volume function returned.  Weird.  That said, I would still make the same purchase.  It just takes some getting used to.

The Roku SS+ was easy to pair to my TV and could power it on and off, and adjust the TV speaker volume. However, I was disappointed that I was not able to get the Roku remote to control my Sonos playbar which is hooked up to my LG TV via optical out. Prior to purchase I called Roku to make sure the remote could control my TV and Sonos. They told me that if my TV supported Consumer Electronics Control (CEC), I'd be fine. But they were wrong. My hours of googling suggested that If you use ARC over HDMI to connect your sound bar to your TV, Roku TV can use CEC to control the sound bar’s volume (maybe). But, if you're hooked up by optical out - you are going to have to buy a logitech smart hub to get one controller.But, all my gripes are about the remote and lack of control. As expected, the Roku device itself is great and the user interface is way better than my lame LG WbOS smart TV.

I purchased this on May 2, and it was delivered on May 11.  As of yesterday, it is no longer eligible for return to Amazon.It was great when it worked, for all of 4 weeks, or approx 40 hours.  Then is start freezing up and none of the buttons on the remote would function at all.  I changed the batteries, but that made no difference.  The streaming stick is plugged into an electrical socket, not a USB port.  Freeze, reboot, freeze, repeat.Today, it does absolutely nothing.  No off/on function...completely dead.  This remote is as useless as the rest of this Roku Streaming Stick +.

Same issue as many others apparently... out of the blue, six months in, nothing talks to the device anymore.  Runs red hot within only a couple minutes too.I'm honestly now convinced that Roku streaming devices, and their remotes, are too flimsy and janky to justify buying, and that the "savvy consumer" would be well advised to spring for something a little more sound.Had to replace the remote that came with it to see if that was the issue, and then of course had to return the replacement after that TOO failed to pair... at which point I walked into an amazing discussion with an Amazon rep trying to "solve my issue" by teaching me how to use the Roku app. as a remote instead  -___-  at which point it HAD been made clear that I was trying to return this thing for a refund after it out-of-the-box failed to function...So if you're following, the rep. was trying to prevent a refund for a defective item by teaching a customer how to use a different item instead.  Brilliant.After 30 min. the refund was agreed to WITHOUT requiring a USPS pick-up, which was odd, and when they agreed to the refund they also said something to the effect of "because you're a valued customer...", which was ALSO odd hahaha shouldn't it just be "because that thing you bought no work..." ?Ultimately it was fun watching AdultSwim on this cheap toy while it lasted, but now I'll probably have to purchase a more solid competing device and toss this thing altogether :(

I have very high expectations for my audio/video gear. When streaming audio or video, I am used to using a home theater PC connected to my TV via a receiver. This is fantastic for most things, but it isn't very convenient or easy to use. Additionally and unfortunately, many streaming apps for Windows don't support the highest level of audio or video quality, which is very frustrating.To solve the convenience, ease of use, and quality problems, I purchased one of these. And the Roku Streaming Stick+ is very convenient (small, easy WiFi connectivity), easy to use (great interface), and allows me to stream high quality from apps like Netflix and Disney+.However, there are a few major problems with this piece of gear:1. Ads. I hate that there are ads littered about the Roku interface. Come on.2. No advanced features such as A/V sync offset. For some reason, audio in certain Roku apps is out of sync from the video. Neither my receiver nor my TV have options for modifying this sync - usually, I just change that setting per-application on my HTPC, and I'm happy. But there exists no such setting on Roku, which makes certain content unwatchable.3. The first copy of this piece of hardware I got from Amazon was dead on arrival and wouldn't turn on. I returned that Stick and purchased a replacement.

After having Directv satellite for 18 years at my house (which I loved despite the breaks during storms), I called customer service because monthly price has gone from $92 to $163 in the past year, but they refused to discount any further so time to say goodbye to Directv.  After some research I decided on Youtube TV.  Next it was looking for a streaming device.  I am a channel surfer so quickness navigating between apps and programs to stream was of high importance.  I have an Asus RT-N66U router and Spectrum 100MB cable internet so bandwidth shouldn't limit me.  I first tried the streaming Stick + from Roku which gets glowing reviews.  I connected it via my 5G wireless (in the next room about 8' away from the TV) and it was very sluggish and reported a slow internet connection.  Doing a connection test in the ROKU reported 1Mb/s though the laptop on speedtest on the same wireless reported 54Mb/s.  I've had spotty coverage in the house with the 5G wireless so I switched to the slower and Roku was then happy with the porformance showing nearly what the laptop did.Pros - I like the Roku menus, DVR setup, layout, and the simple remote... Using a Panasonic Plasma 1080P, the picture is excellent with absolutely no complaints.  I didn't test anything with soundCons - What I don't like is the latency when switching among apps or when kicking off a stream.  Seems to buffer for about 8-10 seconds before the program starts playing.  I'm guessing this is buffering because if I compare what is streaming for a local channel to antenna input on the TV for the same channel, the Roku was about 8-10 seconds behind.  I have Youtube TV, Amazon Prime Video, and Netflix with the slowness the worst with Youtube TV.  I also don't like that you can't set a particular app to automatically run on startup.At less than one third the cost of Directv, I'll stick with it but it feels like going backwards in performance... like if you had to get rid of the SSD in your Core-I7 laptop for a slow hard drive.Note that I moved the streaming stick + to the bedroom TV and got a Roku Ultra for the main TV.  This time connected to ethernet and Roku reporting 78 Mb/s or better.  While the performance is slightly better, it still doesn't have the quickness I'd like.  I'll keep watching reviews for something better...

I have replaced my Fire Stick with a Roku as this device seems to handle weak Wi-Fi signal much better.  The other big issue I has was having amazon.com and amazon.co.uk accounts.  For reasons unexplained the .co.uk account had become the "default" when setting up the Fire Sticks I had purchased,  basically locked me out from viewing US content.  Amazon customer service fixed this promptly when I figured out how to talk to a human but it was an inconvenient and confusing issue.  The Fire Stick is cheap and works but the inferior ability to handle poor wi-fi signal in my use case meant it was not fit for purpose.  Also pairing hand controller with Stick after battery replacement is not obvious.  Need to press the Home button for 30-90 seconds to get it pair sometimes.

This is more of an FYI than a review.I have a TV mounted pretty high up on the wall so the power cord included does not reach the closest outlet. I did not have a power extension cord but I did have a USB extension.  Little did I know that it would cause my fire stick to constantly reboot. I thought there was something wrong with my fire stick so I exchanged it for another with the same problem. The only common denominator was that USB extension. The extension worked well with other products but not with the fire stick. So if you are having problems with the fire stick constantly rebooting check your power source. I ended using the USB from the TV for the power source. Even though it said that it was not sufficient power it still works fine. Even when playing Amazon's Luna. Or just buy a traditional power extension cord.

I have reached a point in life where the TV commercials are getting so annoying that I literally avoid watching commercial TV. So Netflix, Amazon, Acorn, Discovery+ are my go to places. The Firestick adds internet connectivity to  any TV without it and improves connectivity for a smart TV.  I can pay for those services I like. Watch better quality programming in HD, without annoying commercials. After trying out one unit I have now bought 5 for every TV in our house and vacation house. With my subscription services I get programming I like for about 1/3 of the cost of satellite service.

All I'm going to say is worth every penny... not sure why i didn't invest in one of these a long time ago... I'd highly recommend it, even without the deal, it's still worth $29.99. I'm in love already. 😍 I've been using my note 10/ Samsung dex with an hdmi cable to stream TV/ movies from my phone to the TV, & it's a pain in the a$$! The wire would get bumped & id lose what I was watching, have to get up to change to different apps, etc. Plus, my phone was always hooked up to my TV & then when I'd unplug it to use my phone, my 16 month old daughter would flip out because her Disney Channel was no longer on... no more worries 😌 it's a win win for mommy, & my daughter. BUY THIS! My first time using 1 & I love it. My next purchase will be a echo dot.

The Fire TV Stick Lite is a huge improvement over my First Generation Fire TV Stick.I had recently started having problems with the remote with my first generation draining batteries in less than a week and a new remote for the old one cost more than the new Fire TV stick lite did. I got a deal on it too for Superbowl special pricing.I also have a second generation Fire TV stick and this new one is so much better than the old ones.It loads the interface immediately and there is zero buffering or lag like I sometimes had with the old one. The old one would reset without warning and was annoying when watching a live show.Also all my favorites and watchlist were saved only had to register the device and all was there.

I have used Apple TV for many years, but then they altered me that Apple TV will no longer support the YouTube app starting in March, I had to ditch Apple and get something else.  Didn't need anything fancy, and the Fire TV Lite with Alexa remote was the most logical choice at under $30.It was a breeze to set up, add to my WiFi network and everything else was pretty much automatic.  Much easier to use than the old Apple TV I had, with quicker response and better interface as well.  The Alexa enabled remote is great too, even though I don't have Alexa at home (I use Google).  Just tell the remote to go to the app then tell name the movie you want to watch and there it is!Should have switched to this a long time ago.

I love the Fire stick and this is my second.  But this one is a little glitchy as there are times when I use it in the morning where the volume won't work unless I unplug the power cord from the stick and plug it back in again.  Frustrating, but it works.  I contacted Amazon support about it and they told me to reset it.  I don't think that I should have to reset it every few days.  I don't have to do that on my other one and don't feel that I should have to do it for this one.

The stick worked fine for about a week.  It’s a little less user friendly than the Roku, but it’s easy enough.  All of a sudden it’s telling us there’s a network connection error.  After going through all the troubleshooting tricks, except resetting our wifi-that’s not going to happen, it was still giving us an error.  Then, about 10 minutes into searching for solutions, it started working again.  I’m not sending it back yet.  I’ll wait to see if it does this again.

I just contacted Amazon I purchased three for Christmas from my home two out of the three are not working. One stopped working two weeks prior to today’s date and the other one stopped working three weeks prior to today’s date. I was told today that the cut off date was 30 days and it was too late to return I don’t wanna return I just want to exchange. Now they’re telling me I can’t do that either I am not happy! I don’t buy products to have them break down in less than 40 days. Is that why we buy things to replace them every 40 days? Once again I don’t want my money back I just want an exchange for a new one that works. I already had to replace one when I first ordered them because I got sent the wrong parts. Someone who packaged the item did not supply me with everything that went with it. I am not happy with this product!

Easy to install.  Some apps such as Rumble don't work well.  Voice doesn't always work or understand what you want.  I was sent the promo code for a discount on Hulu to be included with this product on Dec. 20, 2020 and the code didn't work.  I emailed with amazon and was told give them 3 days to correct and send a new code.  Nothing, so sent them and email Jan. 11, 2021 and they replied give them 1-2 days.  Still waiting.  Very poor customer service for this issue.  Spoke to customer service again and they transferred me to Hulu; according to Hulu they do not have any promos with amazon for a discount for 6 months service and the code is invalid.  I've sent a reply to amazon AGAIN and STILL no reply!!!!!!!  Is Amazon now a SCAM?

Our son got the Amazon Fire Stick for us as a gift.  We have a "dumb" TV set.  Now, it's "smart"!The Fire Stick was pretty easy to install, although we had to remove the wall-hung set to plug in the Firestick's power cord.  Once installed, the setup was pretty easy, and we were watching our first streaming program within an hour.  Since setup we have watched several movies, and one series.  All excellent.However, it's important to know that in order to watch certain programs, you have to pay for the corresponding program upgrades, such as HBO.  Only then can you watch the premium streaming HBO programs.  Still, even without subscribing to any premium services, there is a huge amount of free streaming programming available once the Fire Stick is installed.The sound and image quality are excellent - as good as the direct broadcast cable we watch.The Fire Stick is an excellent way to get streaming on a non-smart TV.  It's an excellent value.

We were tired of our "Smart TV" not having the apps we needed.  We weren't able to add the apps needed either.  So off to the Fire Stick we went.  Has every app that we needed plus so many more.  They stay up to date and add any apps that you may need for your situation.  I have a home theater system, so the Satellite, DVD player, and everything else goes through the sound system first and then only (1) HDMI cable comes out of the sound system to the TV (for whatever video source is playing through the sound system).  So, I decided to plug in the fire stick on an available HDMI input on our sound system, instead of the TV's HDMI input.  It works flawlessly like this as well.  When I want to watch Fire Stick stuff, I just click "HDMI #3" on my particular sound system, and then that output goes to the TV.  We chose the "non-volume control" model because our sound system has all of that control.  Works great and I highly recommend!

we all love to give amazon the business. addmit it. its a guilty pleasure. BUTi have to say. This has been one of my BEST purchases Ever. if you ha e prime and other amazon things...the FireStick Lite and a decent internet connection. And BANG everything to entertain yourself is right there....it Even remembered my Old amazon music playlist from long ago. You can Connect amazon Luna to it and stream (wirelessly or using ehternet connection) with ubisoft+ linked to your Luna account? Hulu? There. Amazon Video? There. This is a Pocket studio of fun.I even tested it to see How Far i coupd push this little thing, in the picture, the firestick lite is connected to a junk VGA monitor streaming watchdogs legion wirelessly....like dude....you can take this little thing ANYWHERE...if youve been on the fence, dont, get an amazon firestick lite, amazon prime, and luna. This is the Best Investment ive made for my personal fun in a hit minute

My ability to stream content was rather limited before I got this. I had a 1st gen Chromecast that was less than useful, and a Blu-ray player that could stream, but it enjoyed crashing and was limited in what it could do with modern streaming platforms.I decided on this streaming stick since it seemed simple, provided a lot of features, was a good price, and worked with a simple USB power interface.It was incredibly simple to install and setup. I think it would be extremely difficult to not make the Fire Stick not work correctly as long as you follow the steps it provides.I found the navigation to be very easy and logical. It was easily to get it working with my various streaming services. The quality of the streaming is excellent.I have yet to encounter a fault or problem. I would highly recommend this to anyone that wants to do simple multi-service HD streaming.

We bought this as a replacement to our 1st generation Fire Stick that was just getting to where it wasn’t able to keep up and required cache dumps often just to function and was becoming progressively slower.I know this is a “lite” but it’s functioning power definitely isn’t. It’s amazingly quick and works well with all of our streaming services.Though slightly cumbersome to navigate with the remote the Amazon Silk web browser is also very quick and responsive.We have definitely been happy with this much needed Fire Stick upgrade.Apps we have tried:NetflixHuluDisney+LesMills OnDemandYouTubeSilk BrowserCrunchy rollPrime VideoAll of the above apps have worked seamlessly with this streaming device.Definitely a great investment for any television that does not have built in “smart” capabilities.

O bought this item as My streaming  Blue Ray DVD player had very few apps it could access in case I wanted Disney+ or something more popular than Hulu and Pandora.  There was also the problem of running an attached wired cable to the back of the Blue Ray DVD  that ran along the floor of my office and constantly being tripped uponThe Firestick was easy to set up and within 15 minutes I was all ready to go and logged into my Prime Steaming service and Netflix .Although I had wanted this product, I also wanted to make myself familiar with the item soI can help some friends who also wish to get a Amazon Firestick They may go with the more expensive HD model but I now have some knowledge of how to set one up when the time comes.Pluses:  A short while after installing the device I get an email with tips and links to use to learn more about it.Cons:  Nothing to tell me how to shut it off.  I had to go online for the answers as I could not find anything in the small foldout instructionsAlexa commands must be exact,  For somne reason the word "return" did nothing and I had to instead use "Home"I woulkd reccommend this item to a friend and I already have

Every time I turn it on I have to unplug the power and plug it in again to reboot in order to get sound on my tv. I have 5-6 other sticks that function with no problem. This is the only Lite one I have. Poor. Also I hate the new UI.Works ok after rebooting until the next time you use it. So I guess that’s worth some star. I’m going to ditch this one.Update: I was impressed. Within minutes of submitting this review Amazon called. They are gathering info to track down the problem some people are having with audio or video issues. So I upped my rating.

Alexa? Who needs Alexa? "She" misinterprets everything I say.I have a Samsung Smart TV.  I like the features on the Firestick better.I I have Sling TV. Sling works a LOT better on the Firestick than the Samsung.I also have Pluto. They work the same.I have no connection issues, and I like the ability to set the bandwidth, and also the captioning.It's a neat little unit, much easier to navigate than the Samsung TV,and works very well with my network setup.For what I paid, I'm extremely happy!If you can grab "Firestick Downloader", you can add THOUSANDS of channels, from all over the world.As it stands now, with Sling (Hollywood and Starz options), and a couple of free "sideloads", I have more TV than I can handle.  And I am a TV freak.Sure comes in handy in times like these. You can find something for everyone.Enjoy!

Whoa.Firstly,  I am an Amazon/Alexa/Firestick fan. I have had MULTIPLE firesticks in the past 5 years, mostly due to adding TVs and needing the portability for summer camps etc.Secondly,  this is BY FAR the easiest setup of a firestick!! Holy Cow! Because I had a Firestick in the living room,  it recognized it, connected to the wifi (um....Without having to enter the $##@%% password) and used the other Firestick to add apps etc. A much loved (on my part) feature.Cons? Well. I knew what I was buying (this is stick #6 or 7),so no surprises qith the base features. However (and I'm not sure this is merely a "lite" feature) the Home screen has changed. No biggie, just an acclimation necessary.As for the "no tv controls"....that was never an issue.My only [ONLY] issue? The extra tv button on the remote....I am such a creature of habit with muscle memory for remote controls...so I keep hitting the tv button when I mean to play/pause. Seriously,  thats a user thing, I shall adapt!All in all...if you have multiple Firesticks (like me), you plug it in, accept the cloning of the other settings and.....Bob's your uncle.Its the simple things!!

After two weeks of use, it began to fail over a period of three days.  When I tried moving ports, restarting the TV, restarting the Fire Stick, etc. it would not boot up.  It was quite obviously dead.  I had heard how easy it is to return items to Amazon.  Not this item.It was very confusing to the very patient support person that *I* bought this, but someone *else* registered the device - my wife.  After 31 minutes on the phone, he agreed to send a new one.  Which works fine.  So far.  But I was instructed to send the defective item back, for refurbishment or quality control purposes.  When the replacement item came, I did not find a return envelope or an address label.A few days later, I asked my wife if she had seen the return label.  She had not, so I tried to get one without the hassle of the phone.  I gave up on that and called Support.  They called right back, were also (patiently) confused by the user not being the same as the buyer, and after 23 minutes, agreed to send (or re-send) the return label.  To the user, not the purchaser.  Tomorrow, the dead one goes back.So if *you* buy it, make sure *you* register it.  Perhaps the more expensive version of the Stick is also more robust.

What have I been doing without this Fire Stick? I cannot believe that I didn't get this sooner. This is the best invention since sliced bread. It works with my cheap TV and I don't need an expensive TV in order to get quality movies and shows. This thing works like a charm. I cannot believe how impressive it is and especially at this price point. $22.00 with a remote and Alexa? Come on. I ordered another one right after setting up the first one. If you're considering purchasing it, don't hesitate. Get it. All the apps in one place at my fingertips. I like my Chromecast too, but the difference is your cell phone is your remote for Chromecast and for Fire stick they come with a personalized remote.

I have 5 of these, one of them I lost the remote.  Think I left it up at Whistler.  Although your phone works fine as a remote with the Fire TV Stick App.  You can reprogram a remote to a different stick by holding down the Home Key for a few seconds.  Anyway, I don’t have any smart TV’s but I love how easy the TV fire stick makes the TV smart.  I can view all my cameras one at a time by just pushing the microphone button and saying, “Show Driveway Camera,” etc.  It will also work with on the TV with an Alexa device.  It does everything I need and I can project YouTube etc out of my Ipad through the Firestick onto the TV screen.  There are so many ways you can use this stick it is mind boggling.

This is my first Amazon streaming device and I would say I'm decently satisfied with it... I had a Roku stick that I used for my living room TV and was planning on buying another to put in my bedroom but my work ended up giving me an Amazon fire TV stick lite as a Christmas gift. So I moved my Roku stick to my bedroom TV and set up the fire stick in my living room since it was newer. The design and set up of it is obviously different than my Roku but it's still easy to figure out and I like some of the features like the "Find" function that lets you search for free movies and shows. One downside is that I don't have an Alexa device so that's a whole function of it that I don't use. The only other downsides I've found is that you have to actually "turn on" the fire stick after your turn on your TV which is a very minor thing but something that I had to adjust to with switching from a Roku stick. I also have a problem with using Amazon prime video on it because I don't have prime.... I use a family members prime account which was what I was logged into on my Roku, but since I set up the Fire stick with my Amazon account I don't have access to prime.... Other than that, it's a really nice streaming device and I do really like the voice recognition function. I might have to buy an Alexa just so I can hook that up to it as well... Thank you work for the amazing Christmas present.

I had a 2017 fire stick that has slowed down continuously over the years, and decided to buy an updated one for our downstairs TV. Typically we use an Xbox One for streaming services, but Microsoft does not have a CNN app and I very specifically wanted a CNN app that I could log into with a cable provider.Unfortunately, the CNN go app for the fire stick will not launch no matter what I do. Clear cache, clear data, restart, etc. I’m 23 and very handy with technology and cannot make it work.This device is excellent in most ways: extraordinarily easy to set up, alexa controls are way improved from my old fire TV stick, and I love that you can search across platforms unlike Roku. Unfortunately, it seems like a number of the streaming apps that aren’t the “bigger streaming services” are underdeveloped and are either quite buggy or don’t work altogether. If you’re looking to stream mostly apps like Netflix, Hulu, and YouTube, you should be in the clear.

The firestivk lite runs just as well as the firestick 4K , while it does not have tv controls or 4K capability , the apps run just as well as they do on the more expensive Firestick . I do not think that most users will be able to tell the difference in the Firestick lite and the more expensive Firestick 4K .  The same cpu is used in both . If you do not need t.v. on-off and tv volume controls on your firestick ,then save yourself some money and go with the Firestick Lite .

The device I received work initially when I set it up. However, about a week or so later it was no longer connected to my account and I couldn’t get it reconnected. I called costumer assistance and after about 45 min they told me that for some unknown reason my device had the same serial number as another device. This second device was reported lost and so my device was now no longer functional. No one at Amazon could tell me how there were duplicate serial numbers on two devices or if there were not other devices out there which also had duplicate serial numbers. Beware!!!

Since we both wanted Disney+ (big kids at heart) the only way we could get it was to purchase a Fire Stick. It's relatively easy to use, love the Alexa integration. HOWEVER, we thought our first First Stick purchase was defective, so we ordered a second - and thought that, too, was defective (the 'menu' button didn't work). After calling Amazon (yeah, I know - should have done that in the beginning), we were told that the menu button wasn't functional for us - we would have to 'upgrade' for it to work. Okay, now we know. Still, it's nice to have the voice activation feature. Even though we don't have the menu feature, I would still recommend it for owners of 'older' smart tvs.
