Edited :: Well ...I figured something out ... every time I turn the TV on I have to re-boot the Firestick ...I mean EVERYTIME!!  I get picture but no sound .... if the person from Amazon wants to call me back and help me through this I am all ears.. otherwise we stay at one starThis device is terrible .. drops programming and more so the volume gets lost.  Have to turn off and back on in the middle of live broadcasts ... and to think I was stupid enough to order another one ... will see how this works ...if it doesn't work any better  I will definitly go back to Roku

The product isn’t all bad; it isn’t all good either. I firstly did my research, prior to purchasing. Everything I saw or read made the claim that the only differences between the Lite and Standard fire sticks were found in the remotes and something having to do with Dolby audio settings (not important to me). That turned out to NOT be entirely true. Although slight, the Home page looks different. The panels are set up differently than what we’ve grown accustomed to expect from previous fire sticks. However, they’ve maintained the user-friendliness of the device, making the learning curve manageable. Also, the device has maintained the ability to side load apps from unknown sources. However, although everything works as expected, a couple of the apps fail to display the panel art and therefore remain blank in appearance. To me, these slight variances aren’t much of a big deal. However, if you’re like I am, you appreciate knowing the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, prior to purchasing any product. In my opinion, Amazon fell a bit short, this time, in doing that. Besides the aforementioned, the product serves my purposes. It gets the job done but depending on your personal preferences, you may want to stick to what’s familiar. Besides the lower price, the Lite appears to be void of any advantage over the Standard fire stick we’ve all grown to love.

I am so glad I bought this. It was very easy to set up. It almost seemed easier than the more expensive models. I have the 4k model from 2019.  It is very fast and a lot less buffering. It seems to work better than my 4k model.  I bought this so I'd be able to stream HBO Max on a non-smart tv that I already had a Roku stick on. I didn't need the option to control the tv because I can do that with the Roku remote so this was a very good option. I'd buy again.

I owned a previous-generation Roku and needed to add a couple more as we moved from cable to streaming via SlingTV.  I was skeptical of the stick, thinking it would be slow and limited.  But I've had these now for almost a year and they are great.  This is the 2017 version of the Roku Streaming Stick (the + indicates it supports 4K video.)  It's a good device, and this and its non + twin both feature a wonderful remote control that can turn your TV off or on -- and adjust the volume.  This means that most of the time you'll only need one remote control -- a great feature.  You also get voice commands.If you haven't used streaming video before, you may be confused by the options such as Roku, Amazon's Fire, Google's Chromecast and Android TV, and Apple TV.  You choose a device and then there are available apps for various pay- and free streaming services.  Services such as SlingTV, youtube TV, Direct TV Now, Hulu Live, and Playstation Vue all provide selections of cable and broadcast channels live -- basically cable without the cable.  There are literally hundreds of other free services on Roku, with wide ranges of content AND quality.Having used this product for the better part of a year, I can easily recommend it, unless you need a hard-wired solution such as the Roku Ultra.

WILL NOT WORK ON A LOT OF OLDER TV'S.  Will connect to WIFI internet but won't go any further to download application.ONLY "support" is on-line---NO WAY TO CONTACT ROKU BY TELEPHONE.I also have a basic Roku streaming device that came with my SLING subscription.  Keeps dropping my internet connection (only about 25 ft from my WIFI router) which requires a device "re-set".  The re-set is VERY DIFFICULT as my TV is wall mounted requiring a step-stool to reach as the device is connected on the top rear of the TV,  and the re-set button is quite tiny.My suggestion is:  DO NOT BUY ANY ROKU PRODUCTS!!!!!!

I purchased this unit solely on the promise of long range wifi.  I have been using a 4k Firestick which has a less than stellar wifi range.  I have the 2 hooked up side by side in hdmi 2 and 3.  There is absolutely no difference in wifi connectivity range between the two.  Tech support from Amazon and Roku are handled by folks in the Philippines.  While they are all very polite and try hard, they are very little help do to language barriers and the fact that they don't actually know much of what they're talking about.  They simply lookup questions on the computer and give canned answers.  They don't know enough about the product they're supporting to actually think logically about their answers.  That is just such an incredible disservice to their customers.  After using the Firestick for several months I found using the Roku kind of clunky.  The Firestick reacts more quickly when you make channel selections and switching wifi networks like I need to do from time to time takes fewer commands with the Firestick.  When using the Roku and watching multiple episodes of a series, it will sometimes freeze right when the new episode is about to play.  I then am forced to press the home button and go back into it again.  This never happens with the Firestick.  Maybe the Roku is just defective but Tech Support being as described was no help in determining this.  If the wifi range was as good as advertised then I could deal with the other issues but since it isn't in this case, I'll be returning the unit.  At least Amazon makes that part very easy.

Overall, this is a very nice streaming system. The setup is pretty easy, although not nearly as quick and easy as the Fire TV since you have to register an account on Roku and give them a credit card (it is not charged unless you buy something).I have it connected to an AV receiver and it's working great in terms of both picture and sound. The stick is slim enough to plug into an HDMI port on the back of the receiver without blocking anything.  Wireless speed and connectivity is excellent.What I don't like:1. The four one-click buttons on the remote for Netflix, etc. can't be re-programmed. While the Netflix button is great since I have that service, the other 3 are useless. It would have been great to be able to reprogram them to work with an app of my choice.2. The power and volume controls do NOT work with an AV receiver, only a TV. Since I have the stick plugged into my receiver, neither button is functional. Disappointing.I also have a Fire TV box attached to the system. In comparison, the Roku menus are pretty dated looking as is the overall navigation. The remote is more clunky and doesn't respond as quickly at times. But, the Roku has apps that the Fire TV does not, so having both gives me more choices.

Bought a few of these and really wish I hadn’t in the end.  They work but lack a lot compared to a fire stick.  The Firestick is android based and will allow you to do a lot more with a side load capability.  Roku doesn’t even have a browser that be loaded so you limited only to the available apps that you can download through Roku.  Now that Firestick has volume and TV control there’s really no reason to use a Roku compared to Firestick.  I’m in the process of getting rid of all these Roku devices.  Additionally something they don’t mention is that they frequently stop working due to heat.  They will send you and extension if requested to try and get the device away from the TV and give it some air flow but that doesn’t alway work.

Laggy equipment - I expected this to be more responsive.  I hate any sort of lag and this was noticeable to me.Remote doesn’t work all the time.  Started after the 30 day amazon return.  This is my biggest beef.I like it better than the fire, but I HATED the fire interface.My new tv has a faster os and the same interface as the roku... so I no longer use this.I switched over because my roku also wasn’t showing 4K content when I upgraded my tv.  I don’t know if I needed to tweak a setting or not but it wasn’t automatic.One good thing... YouTube didn’t have commercials.  That could bring me back to the roku as the tv does have commercials for YouTube, but I’d only use it for you tube content.

I have owned several Roku streaming devices during the past and have never had any issues with the devices.  However, the Streaming Stick+ is a different story.  Very often, the stick freezes up and is totally unresponsive.  The only way I have found to get it working again is to unplug it and wait 60 seconds.  I contacted customer support via Chat and the representative was of no help.  He told me he would send troubleshooting steps to correct the problem via my email but I never received them.  I then called customer service's phone number and waited almost an hour but was never able to speak with a representative.  I was unable to find any troubleshooting solutions to this problem on line.  If this is the best Roku can do, I'm switching to Fire Stick.Update:  After communicating with Roku's Technical Support via emails for two weeks, I still have not resolved the problem with my Streaming Stick+.  It still freezes up several times a day and I have to unplug it for 60 seconds and then restore power to reboot.  Even then, it does not always work and I must reboot several more times to get it going again.  Customer Service is TERRIBLE.  It appears that the Tech may be overseas and using a language program to translate based on the tech's poor grammar and misspelled words.  Also, you can forget about the one year warranty!  They are quick to blame the problem on everything except their device and will not consider replacing the device.  My advice is to avoid purchasing the Roku Streaming Stick+.

We bought this on Prime day to replace an old Roku. It freezes, buffers, crashes and shows so many errors.... it's unusable. We are returning. The old Roku from 4 years ago works much better than this one. Very disappointed and would not recommend it. We restarted, reset, tried everything. No avail.Upon researching, many others have these issues (i.e. open up Netflix and it plays for 2 minutes, then buffers for 5 minutes, plays for 3 seconds, buffers for 5 minutes......). It's a glitch with this device.

This thing is junk, spend your money on anything else.What sucks you might ask:Roku will make you create an account and provide a CC just to use your device.Roku will add you to their SPAM lists and their unsubscribe is non-functional - Violating the 2003 CAN-SPAM actThe included power cord and "extension" is a joke, be prepared to buy a USB extension to plug this in.The remote, with brand new batteries, barely works.  Be prepared to walk around the side of the TV to get the remote to work.Even with a reported "Excellent" Wi-Fi signal (AC - 1400 15 feet away) it will still have dropoutsApparently, you can't turn it off.You have to use another device to add "channels" (you can add some, but not all, from the device itself).Like I said, buy anything else.  I'm going to stick with the Nvidia shields that I have on the other TV's (highly recommended) and put this junk on the guest room tv (or in the trash).If you don't want to spend the loot for the shield, which is far superior to Apple 4K and Dune 4K, maybe try the Amazon stick - I don't have one of those but it's unlikely to be worse, or anywhere near as awful as this.  I suspect anyone who recommends this crap has never used anything else.1 star is too much.

I tried Amazon Fire's new model, and several others.  This is the one to buy!  Super easy setup.  Best of the Best as far as the user interface goes.  Adding new apps/channels is a breeze and they support nearly everything, including my DS Video from Synology for accessing my NAS.  Also, if you have a USB port on your TV, then you don't need a power adapter at all, just plug it into the HDMI for your video input and Pigtail the included USB cable into the USB port on your TV and i that will power the device.  Very feature rich and in my opinion, the best streaming device on the market.  Roku has come a LONG way since they started. Stop looking further and buy this today!

I have one of these Streaming Stick + that works. It’s stays “on” all the time; it is powered on all the time.I bought a second one and the tv powers the USB port off when it turns off.The batteries die in the remote in about 5-6 days. I have been through 5 or 6 pairs of batteries in a couple of months. It’s awful.Roku support is unhelpful. They followed up twice with a long questionnaire about the issue but they don’t follow up any more after this, and I answered their questions in detail.I have had made 4 attempts through chat and email to resolve the issue, and have now given up. And I never leave bad reviews. Others should be warned about this situation, though.Roku told me to keep the device plugged in, basically, and never responded again even though I have reached out three more times.IMHO they don’t have an answer and blew me off.The issue is documented on a Reddit thread I found so there are others with this issue even though Roku denies it.I believe other units will work in this situation (needing the roku to be powered off when not in use), so you can get other Rokus. Skip the streaming Stick + with the voice remote. It’s not good unless you want to use your phone as a remote or love buying or recharging batteries every week!

When this was <$20 on sale, it's a great deal. Otherwise, it's just "Meh" with compeition being good options. The reason I say this is for tow reasons: 1st, the included remotes are not great and 2nd, it's just buggy. I'd be willing to pay more to get an alumum clad remote that has better feel, something more like what comes with Apple TV.  As far as "buggy", it constantly drops sound and get's glitchy. No matter the software update, we're lucky to get through a week without having to unplug the power to it and do a clean reboot.  Sometimes it's nearly every day. My kids use Prime a lot and I'm constantly having to intervene to make it work right is annoying.

WILL NOT WORK UNLESS YOU AGREE TO PAY $80-100 OVER THE COST OF THE STREAMING DEVICE ($50)..THEY TELL ME THEY WON'T ACTIVATE IT....WHAT THE ?????THE CUSTOMER SERVICE REPRESENTATIVE ADVISED ME TO THROW IT IN THE GARBAGE AND THEN HUNG UP ON ME.  ROKU THINKS THAT LITTLE OF ITS PRODUCT AND ITS CUSTOMERS.....WOW!!!!!

Great little gadget; I've been using Roku for many years.  I was blown away, though, when I bought this device, plugged it in, got ready to retire all my other remotes, only to learn there's no mute button on this remote.  There are mute bottons on other Roku remotes I own - but not the 4K stick model.  I had to buy a SideClick (with programmable buttons) to resolve the problem.  Also - the voice recognition?  Doesn't work inside other apps, which is really too bad. Finally - to avoid the very slow boot time, don't plug your stick into the USB port on your TV.  Plug it into the wall, and you won't have to wait for the reboot (TV's often power down the USB ports when you turn them off).April 29 2019 Update:  I've been using this device for several weeks, and have a growing list of gripes:  Powering up the TV with the power button this the remote doesn't always work.  It's not just "press the button".  It's "PRESS THE BUTTON A VERY CERTAIN WAY".  Lots of casual users (visitors & guests) struggle with this.  The stick needs regular rebooting.  It crashes..... ALOT.  The power plug (USB-B) isn't tight, and making matters worse, is on the bottom side of the stick when plugged into my LG HDMI port.  Fixed with electrical tape - but when the device needs to be physically rebooted (which is turning out to be about 2-3 times per week) this has become an unacceptable problem.I'm going to contact Roku and ask for either a replacement or an upgrade.  This is not an acceptable user experience.

I've been a Roku user for years,including several different models. Roku has recently released The Roku Channel,which has hundreds of free movies.It is ad supported.And now Locast app gives you free local broadcast stations CBS,NBC,FOX,ABC and PBS.Locast now offers local TV network broadcasts for New York,Boston,Chicago,Houston,Dallas,Denver areas and plans to add many more cities.This means many folks will no longer need antennas to watch local networks for free. Roku has just about every app you can imagine (YouTube/Pandora/Netflix/Amazon/Hulu/HBO Now) and thousands of more apps in many different categories.This Roku Streaming Stick PLUS does have more advanced WiFi antenna than the regular Streaming Stick.Here are some points to consider when deciding on which model of Roku to buy:1)If you need to connect by WiFi in a room far away from your WiFi router,I would recommend the Roku Streaming Stick PLUS or Roku Ultra.2)If you have a 4K TV,I would recommend the Roku Ultra or Roku Streaming Stick PLUS.The Premiere 2018 model also plays 4K.3)To search for content using your voice,go with either the Streaming Stick,Streaming Stick PLUS or Ultra.All 3 of these models also have a remote that can control the power and volume on a TV.There is also a Roku app for Android & iPhone/iPad that lets you use your smartphone/tablet to control any Roku device and use your phone/tablet on-screen keyboard for searches.4)If you want a wired ethernet connection,go with the Roku Ultra.5)If you want to connect to an old TV with RCA/Composite audio/video jacks,you will need the Express PLUS6)The Express & Premiere 2018 models have a remote where it has to be pointed at the device,unlike the other Roku models.7)If you are only going to buy one Roku device,I would recommend the Roku Ultra.The Ultra has many unique features that the other Roku models don't such as:-Gaming buttons to play video games-Remote finder to find a lost remote control-Ethernet port for a wired connection-Micro SD card slot-USB Port-Night listening mode (this lowers the volume of loud,explosive sounds and raises the volume of soft sounds like whispers.Very useful!)-Headphone jack on the remote for listening without disturbing othersBottom Line:You can now get a Roku device to replace your cable TV box & service or to replace an antenna for free local network TV.And of course you can create your own custom TV experience that simply is not possible with cable or antenna TV.
Get a roku and cut the cable!We are so glad we did.There is so much content to stream!!! click the helpful button below if youre cutting cable toooo!

Since I work for Amazon, I won a Fire Stick a few years ago.  I was very disappointed in the performance, and when it fried, I picked up this Roku stick, and I'm happy I did.  The options and menu worked fantastically, the buffering was reduced tremendously, and the interface was fantastic.That was just over a year ago.  So a few months ago, the remote continuously drained the batteries to corpses overnight every time we didn't take the batteries out (which we shouldn't have to do . . .).  So of course things got worse.  Yesterday I was watching something and friends dropped off something for me, so I hit pause, and when I came back several minutes later, realized that the play function was not working, so I went through the several annoying steps to re-pair the remote and once it was, hit rewind, then play.  The rewind worked, the play and pause and stop -- literally 1/2 second later -- did not.  The show rewound to the beginning.I re-paired it again and even went to the online manual, tried everything, forwarded to the point where my show was initially paused, then the play wouldn't work.  It went all the way to the end and to the next episode, so once again I had to unplug the USB power to the device and re-pair.  This activity has been happening, worse and worse, for over a week.So I checked the order, it's out of support.  I am buying it again and this time getting the danged 3-year extended warranty for less than 5 bucks.Great item, mine died fast, so get it with a warranty.Peace.

Love my  product upgradeGot this instead of Alexa Stick. Looked at a lot of YouTube informative videos.Made my mind up to stick with Roku Vioce Streaming Stick. Never lost my old channels , upgraded right along. If thats a concern. Not to worry. Roku tutorials will aide those in need of tweaks like  getting sound from being loud from pic to commercials. Eady as pie to add to my Smart TV.  Love all the channels. Movies From the 20s to present all are avaiable. To Concerts, Videos, radio, all types of music n sounds. So much at no cost. Have low cost internet. No high cable bills.No issues and no problems .Very happy to have this diverse Roku TV viewing.The best is the remote.  No more going to tv remote for volume control. You have All control buttons at a touch of yr finger tips .Am enjoying my smart tv more with my upgradedRoku voice stick with all its perks. NO REGRETS  8  )Ps  remote is sturdy not cheap n feels good in yr hands

Interested in "cutting the cord", I researched the best streaming devices, and found that the Roku Streaming Stick+ was consistently in the top 5 and was the best value for the money for our particular family.  I was able to choose same-day delivery, and received them in the late afternoon.  They were contained in a larger box, so no one could see what was in the package, and the delivery person thoughtfully put them behind a half-wall in our entry court, rather than right in front of the door where they could be seen from the street, which I appreciated!When removed from the box, the items were just as described, in unopened, original packaging.  The quick start guide takes you step-by-step through attaching the Roku to your TV and syncing it to the remote, and from that point on, you simply follow the on-screen directions as it walks you through setting up your Roku account (free - but keep in mind that you will need a laptop, desk computer, or phone present in order to access the Roku website to do this), linking your device to it, and starting to use it.  It was easy to add the streaming services we already had, such as Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon Prime, and interesting to browse the many free options available and add the ones we wanted - the Western TV & Movie Classics" channel is a big hit with my husband and his dad.  Once set up, there are links on the home page to a "Getting Started" with Roku page, and a "Tips and Tricks" to Using Roku page for more information regarding your Roku, in addition to tiles for whatever channels you chose during your set-up.We have been using these (we installed two in our home, and one in my 90-year-old father-in-law's home) for a month now, and have had no issues whatsoever.  We have not had any problems with lag, and pictures are clear and bright (any fuzziness in the photos I've provided are the fault of the camera operator!).  The user interface is pretty standard for this type of thing - the biggest learning curve we faced was figuring out exactly which apps the shows we normally watched were on.  However, between being able to customize which streaming apps appear on your home page, and the two ways to search - you can either type in the name in the search bar, or you can hold down a microphone-iconed button on the remote and, for example, say "Search Criminal Minds", it is fairly easy to get to where you want to be without having to flounder around in the interface.  Even dad-in-law, who is somewhat electronically challenged, got the hang of it fairly quickly, and is very comfortable with using the interface at this point.  We are all very happy with the device and service.  Highly recommended!NOTE: Regarding the stick being at the side of the TV  in our photo, in case anyone is concerned about the aesthetics of having this sticking out of your TV - there were other HDMI ports we could have used at the back of the TV, where the stick would have been hidden and only the Roku power cord coming down next to the TV power cord would have been visible.  However, these were difficult for me to reach, and since my husband is not very technologically savvy, I am the one who usually deals with the electronics and troubleshoots when there are problems, so I was more concerned with the device being easily accessible that I was about how it looked.  Rest assured, if you want a neater look, it is certainly available if you choose to use an HDMI port at the back of your TV.  :- )

Bought this back in October 2020. It drains remote control batteries in 2 weeks or less. Several online “chats” with Roku support yielded a replacement remote that suffered the same fate.  Given all of the time consumed trying to troubleshoot this through multiple chat sessions and money spent on batteries, I asked them to replace the entire unit and they refused. I will be tossing this in the garbage and switching to a Fire Stick or TiVo Streaming device. Stay away from Roku. Poor products and poor customer service.

I bought a total of 7 of these sticks to use between our home and our condo  later summer/early fall of 2019.  The sticks are now about 7 months old, but any particular stick will have only been used for a maximum of 4 months.  While initially pleased with the purchase, recent issues have changed my thoughts.  I am now very concerned with long term longevity with these units.  Of the 7, I now have pretty serious issues with 2 sticks.  One has intermittent wifi connection issues that essentially began over nite.  I've moved it around, rebooted, changed feeds, rebooted the router and wifi all to no avail.  The second stick seems to have a problem with the HDMI plug on the stick itself.  I started seeing some kind of copy protection warnings the requires a repower to clear.  Both sticks are in our condo and have been used for roughly 4 months.  To top it off, the 3rd condo stick is also now beginning to act it little odd while booting up - strange screen messages, etc.  Again, a reboot seems to clear things out.  I contacted Roku customer service and am getting a bit of run around.  Before you buy this, be aware that there seems to be hardware issues that will arise.

I bought this for my brother and when he tried to set it up a phone number flashed on the screen to call and when he called some guy in India wanted him to pay $200 to activate his account.  THIS IS A SCAM!  i don't know how the scammer got involved with this Roku device, he probably supplied it to the Amazon seller at a discount if he would add the scam, but NEVER pay anything for Roku, it's always absolutely free!  I have no problem with the Roku device they work great, but I'm giving it one star because the seller somehow sold a scam with the device.

I choosen the lite version because I needed to connect it to a projector and audio via blutooth to a receiver in another room.  Nice interface, blutooth connected 90% of the time, but I was very deceived that this system does not control its own output volume.  One thing is being able to do it via IR to your tv, and other is controlling the output on the same device.  with this flaw, this item is restricted to be used in the same room with tv and receiver.  According to what I`m researching, more advanced fire tv has volume controls, but only via IR too.  Additional software can be added to control output volume, but you can not link it to your fire tv remote.

I bought this Fire TV stick with Alexa voice control for my parents who are in their late 60’s and not tech savvy. It is very user friendly. The voice recognition is very convenient especially when they know exactly what they want to watch. The smart features are easy to navigate and they were sitting on the couch using it with ease within minutes.The setup itself was simple. I just plugged it in downloaded all apps like Disney +, Netflix, Hulu, HBO Max, etc and logged in.Now all the grandkids can have synced watch parties with their grandparents (since sleep overs are canceled right now) and everyone is once again laughing/talking/joking happily together during movie nights with Nonie & Popie.

My favorite feature is being able to search for titles across streaming services. My second favorite is Alexa voice search. Typing on the on screen keyboard is a huge pain. Voice command is very accurate and easy. I also like that you have to push a button on the remote to invoke Alexa. I do not like having Alexa listening to everything.The streaming quality is significantly better than the default that comes through our Samsung tv.I bought a second FireStick for my bicycle training because Zwift runs on FireStick but it does not run on Android TV.I will recommend considering whether a tv has FireStick built in when buying my next tv.

This digital antenna is the best I've ever purchased.  Excellent quality and easy to install but need to gave an HD TV to install port.  Extra long cable making it easy to move around for best reception.  Best place us up high on window itself.  Gives you 200 mile radius switching from short to long distance radius.  Incredible clarity.  Just move cable cord as needed if pix begins to scramble.  Pulls in most local stations, 2, 4,5,7,9,11?,13,21,25, and many more.  Take note each main channel gives you additional sub-channels within that channel so you're getting even more stations.  Worth every penny then paying those high cable bills.  Terrific price for quality assurance and more.

I had to replace my original firestick that was about 4 years old, because it kept overheating and one day everything just froze!  I received the new "lite" version today and set up was easy.  The only difficulty I had was getting the battery cover off the remote, but after continuous trying, it just suddenly popped off!  I found everything I expected and the bonus is the Alexa voice option.  I'm a happy camper now!

When I moved into this house, the internet was through DSL. I didn't think it would have sufficient bandwidth for streaming so I bought dumb TVs. Since then we've got fiber optic so I got Firestick to access digital stuff.I had one of the early Firesticks on one TV and a newer one on the other. I noticed the newer one seemed much faster so I replaced the old one. I was right--the new ones are faster.

I have the original FireTV (2014) and like it a lot. I saw this, for under $20.00 (sale), and like Fry yelled, "Shut Up And Take My Money!". This is a good version for a secondary TV (bedroom, playroom, etc...). The functions are easy to understand and adding apps or services are simple. The only reason I recommend this for secondary TVs is this unit/interface is notably slower than my original FireTV. Some button clicks take "a while" to react. Other than the lower CPU power, this plays content largely without issue (few buffering prompts) and sound is crisp and clear. I'm liking this little guy (don't miss/need the "tv controls") and can easily recommend.

Bought this on Black Friday, wrapped it up so “Santa” could gift it to my wife and I. After Christmas, I plugged it up- set everything up and kept getting this error. Called support and talked for over a hour, doing troubleshooting- the result was a defective device. She overnighted me a replacement, got it a couple of days later. Thought all was good, got everything set back. Same errors. Sat on phone again, Trouble shooting. They couldn’t get it to work. End result, 10$ off a new stick. Obviously, was not happy about that, so I asked for a supervisor. She is sending a second replacement. She explained that if this second (or third stick) does not work, to let them know and they would come up with a resolution.

Overall, a great streaming device, but that said, never tried Roku/Apple TV/ChromecastWould be great if this could in the future pull broadcast local stations if your TV has an antenna attached - and would appreciate airplay support - we love the Amazon smart ecosystem, but are also iPhone users - also would be great to remove options to rent & buy titles or at least separate into another sub menu - was hard to find what stuff was included with prime so canceled primeUpdate 3/19/2021 - have used for a few months now and have noticed multiple issues which were never present in the second generation firestick - at times will freeze and/or lose audio and need to reboot the stick (never had that issue in the past) - also certain apps will not play (paramount plus) or show will keep playing a loop (hulu) - when going to other tv (samsung smart with built in apps) paramount plus and hulu cannot replicate the issue

So disappointed. I have the static/snow bug.  Hooked up the new stick today and every five minutes the screen goes to snow, you can still hear sound and it will stay that way for a little while and then the picture will come back.  If you unplug the HDMI and plug it back in it will bring back the picture. To troubleshoot I plugged in my old Roku 3 and it has been playing for two hours now on YouTube TV without any issues, changed nothing except for the devices. Update:  Roku did respond to me on Twitter. The problem for me appears to be that the new devices do not work through either an HDMI splitter or my particular Samsung receiver. Plugged directly into my TVs they work. In the room where I have a projector I have multiple devices and I need a splitter so I will use the older Roku three. Kind of lousy that the $35 fire stick works with the splitter and receiver no problem but not the Roku streaming stick plus with newer and supposedly more advanced technology-but at least I got everything working.  They seem to work pretty well now that I can actually use them, but big negative that I have to use older tech with my projector because of the snow bug.

Solution/Work around.I  have a ROKU Stick+ on an LG 49UH6030. The LG software 05.30.90 is up to date.This LG TV  does not handle Amazon Prime HDR properly.  The images are way too dark and no settings tweaking makes them acceptable.   The LG TV displays Disney+ and Apple TV HDR content just fine, so the problem is probably with the Prime Video app.This problem is apparent on Prime Video via HDMI as well as on the Prime Video app installed on the LG OS.  My specific test video is the Amazon-produced Chi-Raq by Spike Lee.  I used a DVD of the same content on my upscaling Sony BD player as a control and the DVD disc displayed properly and far better than the 4K HDR streaming on this TV.ROKU reports that the LG TV HDMI port is 4K, HDR, 60 Hz, HDCP 2.2 via the auto-detect in ROKU/Settings/Display_Type.My solution is to choose the 4K, 60 Hz setting without HDR.  Now 4K videos that were detected by the TV as having HDR play properly. The LG TV has HDR-effect display settings for non-HDR items to compensate.This LG-TV/Prime Video HDR issue does not appear to be exclusive to the ROKU Stick+ but ROKU's settings flexibility provided the work around that was needed for this TV.

Let me say that I have 2 other Roku's that are fantastic and have never had any issues with them.  Bought a new TV in July and was excited about the fact that Roku makes this stick that can handle 4K and HDR.  Over the past 5 months my excitement has faded.  I, like several others, get the HDCP warning on a regular basis and the worst part is that it happens when I'm trying to load non-4K apps.  After calling Roku customer service in November they sent me an HDMI extender, which did absolutely nothing.  Recently there is a new issue...the remote keeps un-pairing from the Roku.  Customer service has finally agreed to replace it since it's still under warranty but I must pay shipping to return the defective one to them.  The two stars applies to the device and their customer service.UPDATE 6/5/19 - downgraded to one star due to the fact that the replacement Roku is just as bad as the original.  It also has a whole new set of issues including constantly losing connection with my network, unpairing from the remote which doesn't work half the time, audio issues, and failing for no apparent reason...and once in bright red letters on the screen was a message saying the Roku was overheating...unplug it!  I have come to know not to wait until the show I want to watch is starting because it can take up to 20 minutes of restarting/repairing to get the thing to work.  I'll be throwing this out & replacing with something else.  It's junk & I do not want to deal with Roku "customer service" again.

We've had an older Roku for over 10 years and it was fine for the most part. A few years ago we bought a Roku TV so this device went in the basement for that older TV. Until recently, we haven't spent much time in the basement but lately the wife has gotten hooked on an app with free movies when she was in the basement exercising. She was starting to grumble about the picture freezing occasionally. I then checked the available Rokus to see if there was any that would work better. This one, in the description, mentioned for basements so I decided for the price, it might be worth a try. What a difference! With this stick there is no more freezing or buffering. My wife is happy and you know what they say, a happy wife is a happy life. I found the set up easy enough. Since I already had a Roku account, once I logged in, all my apps preloaded. Well worth the money.

Before I begin, let me say that I have 1GB internet speed package, and that when I experienced issues with this device, I had our internet provider come out and test all the lines in the house, going to and coming from the house, and test the download and upload speeds.  Everything checked out. I also installed the Speedtest app on this device and confirmed that my speeds were plenty fast enought (avg 40-60 during peak hours) for streaming tv. If you stream movies, it works with no issues. But if you intend to watch live football, or any other live tv event, it buffered constantly. We experienced this on Hulu and DirecTvNow, during peak hours and off hours and across multiple channels like CBS, ABC, ESPN, and Fox AND plugged in via ethernet (side note - I've read that most devices including this one and the Fire stick are not capable of anything more than 10/100 even with ethernet so having 1GB speeds was a mute point). We tried everything and I mean everything, including buying a different Roku (Ultra), changing router settings, ethernet vs wi-fi, etc and had the same issues no matter what. Out of desperation, I ordered a Fire  TV Stick (v2) and have experienced buffering only twice, for fraction of a second. All I know is this doesn't work and the Fire TV stick does for live tv.

This is my second Roku.  The first one came with a service I purchased and quit working after 3 months.  I kept seeing the great reviews and got a good price, so decided to try it again.  What a mistake!  At first, I couldn't get any channels because it was confusing my new device with the old one that was FOUR YEARS OLD!  They told me I would have to use a different email account to set up the device.  After about 30 minutes of telling them this was ridiculous, I will just return it, they finally got a supervisor to intervene to fix my account.  Bad luck on my end, because I should have just returned it.  About four days ago, all my channels just randomly disappeared except for Netflix.  I can't add any channels either through the device or on my computer.  Tech support said they would contact me but it has been four days and nothing.  Going back to using the Firestick.  See photo above for the dead link you get after you select the product to get customer support.  Do you see a way to proceed?  Neither do I.

The unit seems to be fine. This is the second round unit we've purchased.  We hooked it up in our bedroom.  But we can't stream  our it through it. Apparently there's a bit of a conflict between Roku and spectrum.  As of December 15th 2020... you cannot stream Your Spectrum through your Roku.  You can have other streaming.  Disney plus, Netflix,  Hulu, video and others. We have do have our spectrum through our previous Roku. But. For now. If you purchase a new Roku? And you are a spectrum customer? You will not be able to stream through Roku. I sure hope they fix this issue soon...

WAY TOO MUCH back and forth from computer to tv and back. Registration is obtuse. Would not allow registration to complete unless I added CC. I do NOT make purchases, so this is useless and just another way for ROKU to intrusively capture your information. Also added channels I did NOT want: DISNEY, HULU, HBO, SHOWTIME, etc.The only reason I purchased was for viewing YouTube. That's it. I have been using a Samsung DVD/BluRay device, the the YouTube performance was VERY BAD. Continuously stalls for YouTube but works good for NF and AP. This device works VERY well for YT, but the setup is a turn off. The juice is just not worth the squeeze. If I had it to do again, I would not buy this.One more thing... the extender cable I needed had to be ordered thru Roku. BACK ORDERED for ONE FULL MONTH. I went out and purchased one retail. Another poor selling point. For the price, it should be included. ROKU is just "Cheaping Out".Do Not Buy... or do so at your own peril.UPDATE: The EXTENDER CABLE is NOT A CABLE, BUT A CHEAP CHEAP CHEAP "dongle" appx 3 inches long. AND IT DOES NOT, I REPEAT, IT DOES NOT WORK. I plugged it into my SAMSUNG TV, and the screen does not display correctly... looks like lines on the screen. DO NOT COUNT ON ROKU any time soon to fix this. THIS FEATURE IS A JOKE!!!

An excellent upgrade to Roku streaming devices.  I've used Roku streaming devices for years and I've never had one fail.  This streamer provides true 4K output and slightly improves wireless signal reception in areas where your wireless router signal may not be full strength.  Roku's remotes get slightly better with each generation and this one is no exception.  Buttons are crisper and presets for various streaming services work well.Roku's User Interface (UI)  has evolved.  It works well but as I test it against Apple TV's latest version and Amazon's latest UI I find Apple's UI to now be the most useful.  Roku in my view still beats Amazon's latest convoluted UI.  Roku should look at Apple TV's UI for the future.  Unfortunately, Apple has failed to produce a streaming stick and Roku fills this void nicely.I like Roku devices because they work well all the time.  They are like the Toyota of streaming devices.  They compete well pricewise.  They set up easily, are easy to use, stream well and are reliable.

I like everything about this product as far as functionality, but it smells so badly that it smells up the whole room. I bought it and returned it , bought it again and the second one still reaked of mold and mildew like it had been stored in a damp place for ages. Since all the parts are plastic I doubt if it will ever get better. I washed the remote with bleach but it did not take the smell away. I think it's just permanently imbedded in the plastic. I'm afraid to return it again since the next one might just be the same problem; and it's so inconvenient to have to keep signing in to everything over and over again with a new one. I haven't even received the refund for the first one I sent back yet either so I'm kind of waiting to see what happens with that before I return this one again to avoid any confusion. I'm not sure what to do about this now..has anyone else had this happen?

I usually do not write reviews, good or bad, but this time I am extremely disappointed. I have owned Roku for years. Unfortunately the quality of the operating system has been deteriorating slowly but surely. I recently purchased two Roku sticks + in order to upgrade from previous models which do not really support 4K - even though they say they do. The sticks worked fine for about 2 months. The last update Roku sent has made them pretty much worthless. Despite my fairly fast internet speed (I get speeds of just over  340 Mbps next to the router where the stick is placed) the stick takes forever to load any App. When I "check the internet connection via the Roku App, I get little more than 25 Mbps - pitiful!. Amazon has stopped working altogether. Even YouTube is slow and when it finally loads the sound lags behind. I contacted Support and after they could not figure it out the problem (45 minutes) the guy told me to wait a couple of minutes while he "check on it" and just disconnected me. I'm switching to Apple TVI have put up with the slowing/deteriorating operating system because the Roku has been always easy to navigate but I feel that they have not cared to keep up with the streaming technology and feel that if I continue to stick with them (no pun intended) I will just continue to feel frustrated and will just waste my money. Time to switch.

I bought this to replace a ROKU 2.  Amazon videos play some things.  CBS all access, ROKU site, PBS, most all of streaming stations  play nothing for more than 5 seconds without buffering.  After 3 or 4 buffers, it freezes.  Remote also is slow and frequently freezes.  I have uninstalled and reinstalled stations, rebooted ROKU,  move my router, cut off all devices that share the net,, used a wall outlet for power, disconnected Alexa,  My old ROKU 3 had no problems, but was heating up. Connection is rated as fair and speed is rated as good.  I have contacted the Amazon support line who offered a new device.  I have ordered the extender.  If that does not work I will send back.  A new device should work better that an old one that cost less.  I am afraid that this device is inherently  flawed.

Worked great for first 9 months. Now I have dealing with customer service for last 3 months because of failures, lockups, freezes. They are totally incompetent, disorganized,  lacks any signs of customer satisfaction. Buy this with a throw away expectation when it fails.

I think the ROKU system is awesome, but the Streaming Sticks interface to the remote control is horrible with useless voice command capability. I have had the Streaming stick for almost a year. When the remote works it is good, but that is rare. The original remote control started going bad after about 4 months. I asked ROKU to send me another one and they did.  And it is going bad also, or I thought. And then I looked up REMOTE CONTROL ISSUES on Streaming Stick and found there was an extender HDMI cable they will send you for free to fix the remote response lagging issues supposedly caused by the Streaming stick being plugged directly into your HDMI port. I though awesome, maybe now I won't have to wait up to 5 minutes for the remote control to respond to a button push. The cable came after about 4 or 5 days, and I tried it right away. IT MADE IT WORSE!!!!!.  I gave it three days and it did not get better. Worst remote control I have ever had on any TV. And I am 60 and have used countless TV's and remote controls. I had to start using the ROKU remote control app on my Samsung Smart Phone. Response is great on the app, but a remote without buttons that you have to look at every time you want to change the Channel or fast forward past commercials sucks.  SO.... I am sending it back before my year warranty is up.  I am going to try the top of the line Roku ULTRA. If that doesn't work, I think I will be going back to Dish Network. Best remote I have ever used on the Dish system.
Awesome product. Picks up WiFi signal much better than cheaper models. Love it for the Spectrum app

Great little device to ad Roku to TV without it.Couple of modification I did  to make it even better us this device.Just stick in to the TV HDMI port may work fine may not. I have the TV on the bedroom and the WI FI in the living room. The HDMI port on the back on the TV and when I inserted it was close to the back panel  of the TV therefore was not the best to get the fastest signal and heated up.I moved to the wall by using a high speed HDMI extension cable,find the best sweet spot  also used stud finder so the stud in the wall will not interfere with the signal.Also I got lucky to be attach to the wall just over the Xfinity Cable Box and on the top the box already I had a Xfinirty S 1 fan to coll the box. This way I got the two for one "deal" so the fan cooling both unite.Now I get the highest possible speed and bot the cable box and the Roku stick nice and cool so perform better and longer.Hop this help you to enjoy it trouble free the sticks.p.s the 4 star for the countless advertising even when you reduce the advertising by using the menu of the Roku.Free channels feel like you watching advertising with movie breaks.

Had it on a second TV.  Worked ok for a while, not very snappy or responsive.  Started to die just before the one year warranty was up.  Have been dealing with Roku customer service.  They are impossible.  They aren't willing to stand by their product.  I've spent a month on the phone with them,"try this, try that"  over and over.  Clearly the item was detective and not working, but they really didn't want to replace it. I could send it back to them, at my expense, to see if they could get it working.

This was not easy to set up. Ultimately I did not ditch my cable service like I thought I was going to. But I did downgrade it which saved me some money. We have multiple TV’s in the household, and it is to much of a drain on the internet to be watching at once. It was constantly buffering and it was annoying.Setting up: It took me almost 6 hours. It kept giving me error codes. I had to reach out to support multiple times to get it to work (also if you have to call support they charge you money). Thankfully I was able to sort this one out looking at their common problems. It was just frustrating.They don’t have long enough cords to plug into the wall. My second TV I still haven’t set up because I haven’t purchased extensions to use the Roku. They need to come with longer cords. My gaming devices has longer cords than this. Come on Roku.The voice recognition only works maybe 50% of the time. It is more frustrating than Siri. But when it does work I love this feature, it is something every cable/satellite service should have.I love all the TV channels and most of them are free. It is great. I down graded my TV package to the lowest level but I don’t feel I am missing out. There is so much to choose from. The application is basic, but I don’t mind if it has the channels I like. I love that it even has YouTube. Something Amazon fire doesn’t have.UPDATE: The life of the product doesn’t look hopeful. In less than two weeks my Roku has died. I am sending I back to Amazon for a refund. I am wondering if I should do the same with the other as well. For a $60 product you expect it to last. I’m hoping it was a fluke but this has me worried.

Regarding the 1-star reviews about:“Roku Tech Support made me pay $$$$ to set up a Roku account“....these are from people that fell from a WELL KNOWN SCAM!Please Google “Roku scam” and you will see thousands of articles about FAKE ROKU TECH SUPPORT that tricks people into paying money for support and setting up an account.To avoid potential troubles, make sure your order is sold and shipped by Amazon, not a third-party seller.  Ordering from a third-party seller to save $5 is not worth the potential hassles you may encounter.Go to the official Roku website for questions, not some similar looking “help page” that pops up on Google or is listed on a fake owners manual that a shady third-party seller put inside your box.Long story short, do your homework!Regarding the actual product:5-stars all-around!  Stream quality, user-interface is excellent, voice recognition is great, and Alexa and HomeKit integration is outstanding.

It works fine, runs much faster than my previous Fire Stick (menus, thumbnails and apps load faster).The battery cover runs nearly the entire length of the remote. Every time I push a button the battery cover flexes considerably, and it feels like I've inadvertantly opened the battery compartment. Very unnerving.I don't want Alexa in my house. This Fire Stick comes with Alexa, but the product description (or maybe questions/answers?) says that there's a setting to disable Alexa. I could not find that setting. I am now seeing commercials encouraging me to speak into Alexa. So the commercials know that I've got an Alexa-capable device even though Alexa is supposedly not enabled. I'm also now seeing an Alexa "app" in my suggested apps list. I have no idea what this app might be for. Is it needed for Alexa to work? Does it augment Alexa? Just a lot of sketchy info about a feature I don't want.When I am done watching for the day I put the Fire Stick into sleep mode. I did this with my previous Fire Stick, and it seemed to work as expected. But this new Fire Stick is up and running as soon as I turn my TV on, which makes me wonder if it ever does go to sleep.

Very disappointed in the lackluster technology, and lack of communication. The fire TV stick light apparently lacks the ability to transfer multichannel audio output when using an optical connection. My current setup is where my TV transfers audio signals to my surrounded receiver via optical output, and the TV stick lite does not have the ability to send the proper audio to my TV, only allowing for 2 channel audio. Very disappointing to have a streaming device that can't send out multichannel audio signals, and even more disappointed to have that left out of the product information. Users may not have this problem with HDMI only connections, but this should caution anyone using an optical connection.

I like the program options.  I have a smart TV and thought this would be rather redundant.  I also do not have Amazon Prime.  But there are enough nice features, like the ability to have the HGTV Go app and the DIY Go app and some of the Amazon free programming.  There is also some on demand programming that just isn't available on UVerse for some reason.It is a little difficult to navigate and find things at first but, I got accustomed to it.If you are looking to ditch cable, this is a good option.  Lots of programming available, especially if you have Prime.  Be aware, you still need internet service.

After about 2 years of paying cable bills, that started under $100 p/month, and without really realizing it, the bill had quickly risen to over $250 p/month! Thing was, that wasn't even the cap! I was still getting some of the hardware at an introductory price that took a few dollars off per box, and some of the movie channels for free as a trial, but that would all be ending in 2 or 3 months. I'm sure when that happened, I would be hovering around $300 p/month for WATCHING TELEVISION!!!Uhhh.... no! So, I decided to cut the cord and get all my home's TVs on the Amazon ecosystem. I bought the Fire TV Recast and 6 Fire TV Stick Lites. I must say that the last time I had a Fire Stick it was the GEN 1 and it was OK but not as good as I would have liked it to be. That's why I was so pleasantly surprised by the Fire TV Stick Lite. They are fast and responsive (much, much more than the Gen 1s), easy to set up and get started, and seams effortlessly with Plex, Pluto TV, YouTube, and of course, the Fire TV Recast, and Netflix, which I plan to be the only monthly subscription that I will be paying for. Overall, I'm very pleased with the Fire TV Stick Lite. Alexa is installed and using voice commands to change the TV is so wonderful! I can also turn the lights off from my remote control when it's time to movie watch. I love it! Let's see the cable companies let me do that! I figure I'll be saving about $230 p/month now and all for an investment that was less than paying for 1 month of paying a cable bill. Not bad at all, Amazon.

Overall I like this product.  If you are fanatic about volume, get the other fire stick as the lite stick does not have volume control.  I had to set this product up for my parent who is not technologically inclined.  Set up was not the issue.  Those who have lived 8+ decades with  channels and simple on/off features on a television have a hard time understanding apps and the "timing" of programs -- scheduling.  We need it for one program, but then we have to switch back to regular fios/cable for programs/channels that are on television.  It would be easier if there was a set channel function within the fire stick of the most watched channels/programs for ease and convenience-- especially for those not app oriented.

Works great and is great for my non-Fire Smart TVs. However, I could not get signed in using my tv provider info for the History Channel app (Spectrum credentials) whereas on my older regular fire stick I was able to sign in fine. I purchased them recently for multiple TVs. The new ones just kick me out and back to Home. Some comments said to do a factory reset but these are brand new so I don't think that is the solution. So I just can't use that particular app on the TVs with the new lite fire sticks. My Fire Remote app on my phone works great with both the old Fire Stick and the new Fire Stick Lites, which is a plus!

I bought 2 of these. One to upgrade the one in my son's room for xmas and one to upgrade  the one on my new smart TV in my room. I hooked mine up last night, fell asleep while it took forever to update itself or whatever. This morning I attempted to watch a program on Philo. This thing keeps shutting itself off and buffering for several minutes at a time. I turn Philo off and switch to Netflix, same thing.  Try Hulu, Disney and even Small Axe on Prime. Same thing! I unplug it and hook up my old Gen 2 Firestick... works like a charm with no shutting off or buffering at all. I am so disappointed in myself for wanting and thinking I could do better.

So I have a fairly old TV that my sister gave me a few years back. It's not by any means a bad tv just not a "smart" tv so I wasn't ever able to watch any of the streaming services on it. I've been debating getting a new TV just so that I could watch my shows. This guy was on sale recently and I figured I'd give it a shot, glad I did! I downloaded EVERYTHING (Prime Video, Netflix, CBS, HBOMax, Hulu, Disney+.. EVERYTHING) and everything works so great! Also, you're able to speak into the remote what you want to watch and it pulls it from everywhere you have linked to show you how you can watch something. I'm so glad I didn't have to get rid of my TV just so I could watch my shows. Absolutely recommend!

I can't say I'm a huge fan of the new layout for the home screen. They should at least give us a CHOICE where the navigation buttons are located. Top and left side good, middle.... ugh.And the TV button needing their blaster device... I'd rather not have that button there at all.Otherwise, though, no complaints. Setup was easy, apps and streaming works as well as on any of their other Fire TV products. New user profiles for Prime features is nice, my fiancé can stop burying my few selections added to my watch list with a her hundred at a time now. That's one new feature I'm stoked to have.

I love fire stick lite it doesn’t have controls like volume and stuff but that’s ok I just wanted to try this cheaper version and I’m happy with it and like it even better than my ROKU I didn’t think that was possible!! All this free TV especially Pluto TV makes you feel like you have cable minus the monthly bills!! Pretty easy to set up takes just a few minutes. Try this you won’t be sorry!!!

If you get one but already have another, whatever you do don't 'Add' the new one to your account.  Use another email address and user name.I've bought several and on one of the units I wanted to remove Hulu from an older unit that no longer was compatible with Hulu.  After I had done that I discovered that Roku had removed Hulu from ALL the other units, including one at the vacation house.I've found that even if you are directed to remove a misbehaving App before installing it, it also wipes the app off any other Roku's that didn't need to reinstall.Roku customer service is useless, no way to reach them and emails go unanswered.  To even get into your account you are forced to deal with the most annoying machination of the computer age, reCaptcha!  I have dropped blog accounts that require it.Why are all the streaming device companies worse than the cable companies we are trying to escape?

I've had several Roku's and the stick is the best so far.  It typically streams very well, but streaming isn't flawless.  Having said that, I cannot confirm that it is a Roku issue.  We are on GigaBit service, but it is not perfect.  Hulu isn't perfect and we're pretty sure the service has gone down for a few minutes, but it's rare.  Netflix occasionally doesn't stream, but by the time we check using another device the Roku is streaming again, so it tough to tell.  There are a lot of variables.  The Roku stick seems to be more reliable than earlier Roku devices, but still has moments of confusion and it self-reboots, but it seems like this happens less than once a month and it's only down a minute or so.  When we had cable, it went out more often and for longer periods.  Never had a dish, but friends who do complain about it not working and not available in every room.Yes, if you don't want to move the stick from room to room and reboot it, every TV has to have one, but our cable company made us have a box on every TV and they charged us rent for them every month (3 months was about the cost of a Roku stick).  Some TVs now have apps built in, but the Roku allows us to add (and remove) channels and services our TV didn't come with and keeps them all in one easy place.

So at first I did get the purple screen saying error, but after about a half hour of troubleshooting, I figured out I just needed to use a different hdmi port. It was very frustrating, but my new Sony 4k hdr TV will only work with this roku in the 2nd hdmi port. (I thought it would be the first, who knew...)  Then I had experienced how some people are saying their remotes just stop working. This had happened and it was an overall easy fix. It just needed to be paired with my roku once again. Also frustrating, but it's working again. Due to these two issues I would give it 3 stars, but when I finally got everything working, the quality is amazing! And the roku stick works very well. This was my first experience with Roku. Definitely make sure you have a 4k HDR ultra HD tv when buying this, otherwise I think you should stick with the cheaper one. So overall, I say 4 stars because the quality is so good, but i think the start up guide could be a little better with detailed instructions and trouble shooting for the remote and start up. Just my thoughts.

I have been very pleased with each Roku product and here updated from Roku3 for my primary TV stations while having RokuTV sets on other TVs for bedroom and office. In WV where signal strength even with good routers and an extender remains neanderthal,  Roku + is definitely a plus.  And I love being able to load Hulu or Network rapidly and control volume at the Roku device itself. The reliability and innovation of all Roku products is a welcome change from the difficulties of Windows and most computer hard/software. All I would ask is ability to type my email on screen with a single click for choice of x.com, x.net, etc. instead of typing in each character.

So far this year, we've ordered four streaming + sticks for 4 in-house and one RV usage.  The sticks work great. Long range RF remotes mean I can irritate the Wife Unit by changing streaming channels from two rooms away. These are our first streamers and they are light years ahead of the two Samsung "smart" TVs. Near instantaneous response to channel changes as measured against our zzzz response to channel changes from DISH TV. The voice recognition works about 80% of the time. That is good since I search for some weird stuff when going down the you tube video rabbit hole. They are all 4 happy with our regular 50 MB AT&T wifi and work even down to <13 MB/sec on 2.4/5 GHz after the signal goes through a wifi extender which isn't really needed (used for jamming neighbor's way-over-powered wifi). No pausing and plenty of buffering. They struggle a little (intermittant signal loss outrunning the buffering) with the campground wifi since it is always overloaded but it is not really a current problem since CA "science" says the virus can jump, from one campsite 150' to another, and has closed our campgrounds. We really like being able to get real news and grand-punkin programming in higher res than the compressed DISH signals. If there are any minuses, it would be that I accidentally keep hitting the 4 direct-tune buttons on the bottom two rows of the remote. We don't subscribe to any of the pay-to-streamers there. After the warranty is gone maybe I'll open up the remotes and disable the buttons. We were not able to get a ROKU streaming channel to work through ROKU even with their help once. They tried but couldn't get it to work even through the designers of the channel. We recommend the ROKU streaming stick+. So far, no stick failures amongst four of them. Be sure to order the free little HDMI extension asap from the site in the instructions with your serial #. It is great stress relief for the HDMI connection to the TV. We power two of the sticks off of the USBs on the TVs and two of the sticks with their USB wall wart power supply. No diff except for about 30 second ROKU reset after turning on TV if using TV USB connection for power. No, nobody compensated me for this spew. We like our ROKUs!

I used to be a huge fan of Roku until they decided to act as badly as cable companies do. Roku decides which apps you can and cannot get. The latest two examples are HBO MAX and NBC Peacock networks. I PAY for HBO Max, but Roku refuses to allow the app because they hold the content providers hostage to pay them more money. To be clear, I didn't sign up for HBO Max through or because of Roku. I was already a subscriber with Spectrum and simply switched from HBO Go to Now. I should now have access to HBO Max but don't because the jerks at Roku decided they should get a cut to provide me the service I pay for.If you're thinking of cutting the cord to get away from your cable company, be aware that Roku apparently wants to be your cable company not release you from their grip.I have 3 Rokus in my house now and am now replacing them with Android TV. Fortunately, you can side load Android apps with Android TV to break your grip from this idiocy.

Cable cutters!This Roku Streaming Stick+ works with YouTubeTV, Amazon, Netflix, Disney+, and CBS All Access.  I bought a similar Roku streaming stick from BestBuy several months ago and returned it because it did not support YouTube TV.  I made do with casting from my phone to my Chromecast for a while but missed the user interface of our other Roku TV.  I received this on July 23, 2020.  It was easy to set up, connected to my WiFi with ease, and I was watching my shows in less than 15 minutes.  By the way, the packaging says Copyright 2020 Roku, Inc.  Would buy again.  Would recommend to a frined.

The best thing about this is the format. The USB stick shaped device is one , more device not cluttering up the TV area or unhidden wire running to the electrical socket. The worst thing about this device is the remote. It doesn't always work in a timely manner. You point it at the device, push a button and nothing happens for 15 - 60+ seconds (not an exaggeration for me). I've had instances where I have found my phone, pulled up the Roku app there, and made the same selection ... And then had the original function finally work leading to unnecessary interruptions. It's the worst! I've actually considered going back to my old Roku box because the remote always works. The only reason I don't is because I can't get some apps to work on my older box due to the software. What should also be mentioned is for some reason, Roku doesn't supply you with a connector you may need for charging the stick through USB. The connector is free, but you have to request it first. It should already be in the box. They even cover the shipping. Makes no sense and not good customer service because it was either use an extension cord (which I don't have) to plug it in (the original cord was to short for the height of my wall-mounted) or wait.

Was thrilled to set up my 2 TVs with these streaming sticks in late November.But after a couple of weeks each remote failed to do anything on the Roku home page. Hmmmm....Turns out it was the batteries. So I installed new batteries.  Rinse, repeat.After going through 4 set of batteries in each device over a 6 week time period--and I don't use the Roku remote everyday. nor do I play a headset through the remote or do any video games--I got on Google and discovered there are thousands and thousands of complaints about these remotes gobbling batteries like candy. Roku IS aware of this issue. They will honor their warranty but want me to pay for return postage. Really? For their defect?So I am returning through Amazon, thanks to THEIR great return policy.

I recently switched to Comcast for TV service, and the rep told me I could add additional TVs for free with a Roku. I looked at the options and picked this one.  I hooked it up to my Samsung TV and added all my streaming apps. It's perfect to have all my options on one input, on one device. I can stream my Comcast content, and access all my streaming services.  The voice control works fine, but it doesn't work as an input method for every app.  I also need to get used to how to FF and RWD with the remote, since it's so basic, it acts a little different that I am used to.  Lastly, the interface once it first turns on is a little slow for my taste, but nothing to make a big deal out of. I have Fire Sticks on my other TVs, but the Roku is quite nice!

OK...with trepidation I'm cutting the cord with C-x cable for SO MANY reasons!!!! But Cost is the major one. By adding this Roku and a streaming service and DSL provider modem I've reduced my cable bill by 110%. I may regret it but the bundle scam was putting me into the red. Had to return this  Roku  because it overheated and replaced it with Firestick. I've added YouTubeTV so I can still have storage DVR  and 110 local channels. Add a Voip phone option (OOMA)  and voila!!! cord cut. Had to return as the stick overheated with warning messages frequently...major fire risk I suspect.Also with YouTubeTV app , Roku was redundant with the apps I have on my SmartTv and Amzon site subscriptions.FYI I love my breakup with C-x Cable. I now have the channels I WANT for 1/3 the bill, with better internet speed, and free phone service after my initial OOMA  Telo purchase. Love performance of Cent--y Link DSL. Now my so-called strongarm cable bundle is gone. I've  replaced it with my own bundle of Never changing DSL monthly cost, never paying for phone with free US longdistance and all the needed TV I chose [ broadcast (90 channels), subscriptions and DVR] and a faster internet connection! What's not to celebrate!!!!

I bought this for the wireless strength extension.  It had gotten to the point that we could not watch TV in our family room, with download speeds fluctuations continuously between 0 and 45, but more and more often, we got ‘No Internet connection’ messages. Our serviced came out and speed tests were fine. He said, ‘You need a new ROKU!’  Did not believe it since old ones worked fine in bedrooms but when I saw this I had to try.We had purchased an extender two years ago and it did nothing.So far, I have not had one instance of buffering or outage, the system is working beautifully. Considering the cost ifv’extenders,’ getting a fully loaded ROKU that gives me consistent and strong WiFi/internet to our main television, I would recommend this to everyone.

Somehow, a company called Caligeeks hijacked my Roku. On 2/8/2020 during the setup of this Roku the screen wouldn't allow me to continue setup unless I called the listed phone # on screen. It took me to a company called Caligeeks who said Roku had changed their policy as Jan 1. Now you had to pay a fee of $79.99 to set up a five year account with them, or $129+ for a lifetime account. They made me believe I couldn't work my Roku without them and that all Roku customers would have to pay this fee each time they bought a Roku. I don't know how their phone # appeared on my Roku, but I argued with them for an hour (since I already had a Roku and knew it was free to set up an account). They had thick accents and were hard to understand on top of it.If Roku is going through a 3rd party for weekend support, there should be information about it upfront instead of lying to customers telling them it's MANDATORY. It's not mandatory. It left a bad taste in my mouth for Roku.Also, the Roku remote was faulty. I messed with it forever and followed all the troubleshooting multiple times and it still didn't work. I was fed up and returned the whole thing, but the device itself seemed to work fine.

Update 01/14: HDMI Extension cable showed up, once plugged into the correct port on the TV everything seems to working fine thus far. The instructions Roku provides does state something about making sure your HDMI port is 2.0 or something like that so the frustration was more my POS Vizio "4k" Smart TV and not so much the Roku. Just wished I would've seen a review of someone having a similar problem or the seller mentioning this as possibly being a problem on the product page. Either way it works now.I haven't even gotten much past the setup of this stick as for some reason it is throwing an HDCP error on the TV. I assume it something between the Vizio smart TV and this stick not talking to each other correctly through the HDMI port I plugged it into (Odd as I can plug anything else in that port and it works). Unfortunately given the length of this stick I am not able to plug it into any other HDMI port except the side, so in order to try and use a different port I had to shell out an additional $10 for an HDMI extension cable. That cable has not shown up yet, but if it does not work by switching ports I am returning this. The voice remote will also not work with the Vizio TV and the only "support" Roku gives you through the error link is how to repair the remote to the Roku itself. Funny cause I got this model specifically to use for Volume and power on the TV also and that doesn't even work. Hoping that has to do with the HDCP error as well but we will see. All in all thus far I am highly disappointed.

This is a great little gadget if you don’t have a smart TV and/or are an Xfinity customer with a TV that doesn't have a cable box. I've been able to ditch the useless little free receiver that Comcast supplied after I exceeded the number of cableboxes that were included with my plan. The Comcast receiver only picked up non-HD channels. With Roku and the new Xfinity app, I not only have all of my HD channels, but I've also got Netfix, Amazon Prime, Tubi, etc. On top of that, the little Roku remote allows me to control the TV volume and power, so I don't need to hassle with multiple remotes. Some people have complained that the Roku remote is not friendly since it doesn't have a keypad, but the settings button will open a virtual keypad and allow you to enter a TV channel. It takes an extra step, but that is a minor inconvenience and, for me, not worth the loss of a star when you consider all that you get. Setup was a breeze, picture quality is excellent, and operation is responsive and easy. My only regret is that I didn’t buy this sooner.

I've previously purchased and installed about 7 of these streaming stick +s, all without a problem.  I purchased this one in January for my home, and the remote didn't work out of the box.  I did all the troubleshooting, replaced batteries with new (which it drained in one day), searched Roku community boards, and it was clear this is a faulty remote.  (I used the iPhone Roku app to control the stick and that worked perfectly, so we know it was the remote itself.)  I reported all of this on the community boards with no reply from Roku.  I tried customer service.  No phone number was available to call, and email correspondence was broken, so I used the chat feature.  I spent about 40 minutes on the chat explaining all the troubleshooting I did, providing serial and model numbers, etc, etc.  I just asked for them to replace the remote, not the entire device.  Well, as of today, they have yet to respond with any resolution (the device was purchased in early January, it's a month later as of this writing).  By the way, did I mention that according to the Roku community, this is a known issue?I returned the entire device to Amazon, after speaking to Amazon customer service, and they supported that return.  I purchased a new one (for $10 less!) but when it arrived, the box had already been torn open, so given my recent experience, I returned it to Amazon the same day.I know everything is crazy regarding the pandemic, but this was a simple issue they could have easily resolved and kept a happy customer.  I may purchase an Apple TV instead (yes, it's more expensive, but I have an older one and it works great--and Apple customer service is excellent)  Not sure what I'm going to do with the others, but if they begin to have issues, they may be going back as well.  Sorry Roku, I was your biggest fan before this recent experience.  Please fix your customer service.When they work, they're great.  Good luck if they don't.

It was GREAT while it worked...until it didn't. It would randomly reboot in the middle of streaming. The situation quickly got worse and it would do it every couple minutes. Then the remote stopped working.Roku support was HORRENDOUS and is limited to email correspondence...about once a day.Google just came out with a chromecast with a remote. I highly recommend it instead.

We've loved Roku for a long time. This year we decided to upgrade our TV to a 4k HDR Samsung. To provide the streaming services, we got this Roku Streaming Stick +. Unfortunately, the picture quality through the Roku was terrible - washed out colors, contrast too high, everything too dark, and lost clarity. This was universal, but especially bad in some Disney Plus titles like the Mandalorian, which was unwatchable.I still had the old LED TV with a Roku 3, and I compared them side by side. The old setup looked perfect. So I plugged in my Roku 3 to the new TV - and the issues all disappeared. It was crisp, bright, and colorful. So the issues were with the new Roku Streaming Stick+.To make a long story short, after much experimentation and research, I was able to get the new Roku to look as good as the old. Here's how you do it:• Go to Settings > Display type and set it to just 4k -  WITHOUT the HDR. It turns out that there are some issues with Samsung TV's HDR settings and 4k Rokus. Upon changing this setting, I found my picture through the new Roku Streaming Stick+ was once again clear and bright.• The other issue was all the "smart" features on the Samsung were messing things up. Turning them all off and setting the TV to "Game mode: On" for the Roku brought back the intended brightness, contrast, and color range.As an aside, when these issues appeared, I also bought a Chromecast with Google TV.
