It had the same issues as the  new Roku, but did NOT have the ability to turn off HDR, so it wasn't able to solve all the display issues like the Roku.I hope this helps someone!

I will start off by saying, that we are on Apple family and use 4 AppleTV 4K's in our house.  We needed a fifth streaming device that will get the least amount of use and did not wish to pay the Apple prices.  After some research, I decide to try this affordable Roku Streaming Stick+ and I am glad that I did.The Roku Streaming Stick+ was very simple to setup with an HDTV & the directions were were clear and concise.  Once I typed in my Wifi information it immediately connected on the 5 GHz band.  After a quick software update, I put our apps that we mainly use onto the Roku and I was streaming.  The streaming quality was no different then the AppleTV's quality.  The main apps we are using were all available on Roku, which includes:  FuboTV, Netflix, Amazon Prime, & HBO Max.  Also, the remote works very well and I was happy that it came with batteries.After one week of use, we have had no issues streaming on the Roku and we watched in all formats including:  SDR, 4K, HDR10.  This is a good price considering you get all these formats.My gripe's about the Roku include:  The menu UI.  My 15 year old son commented that the graphs & layout looked "old" and "not high tech."  Those comments made me laugh, but I absolutely agree with him.  Perhaps Roku could do an update to the IU now that it is 2021.My second gripe, but I knew this going in:  No Dolby Vision.  At least the Roku is able to process Dolby Vision movies as HDR10.

TLDR:  worth it, buy it.Over the years of the streaming revolution, Roku decided to toss their hat into the ring.  They were absolutely garbage.  Delayed remote input, latency issues on wifi, and limited streaming options were just some of the reasons I despised Roku, ESPECIALLY the sticks.It's been YEARS since I've given them a chance though.  My son received a Roku TV from his grandmother.  She got my wife and I a Roku TV and she upgraded her own TV with this exact Roku stick.I was blown away by how well it works.  There's plenty of features but the two I enjoy most are the voice control though the App and being able to toggle between Roku devices on the same network.  These features didnt really exist back in the day so I was utterly amazed by them.  Not only were they available, but they work VERY well.For streaming options, you've got just about anything you'd want.  I've got my cable on there, Netflix, Hulu, Disney+, YouTube, Minno, and BabyFirstTV.  It's serves me well for doing just about everything I could want out of a streaming stick.It ALSO has screen mirroring capabilities!  Not really an option people seem to use a lot, but definitely worth mentioning.  I used to swear by chromecast devices for streaming and screen mirroring, but since being turned onto Roku (again) I was more than eager to get this stick!

I’m not an Alexa-type person so I don’t use it. I have no problems using the remote. One day I’ll use Alexa (but not today). This was my first experience with a Fire Stick so I made some mistakes. This is a ‘lite’ Fire Stick. The remote only works with the Fire Stick. The TV had to be turned off and on manually. I couldn’t figure out how to install the Fire Stick. My friend did the entire installment. There are dozens of movies, TV shows, sports, news etc. This needs internet service. No other  service is needed- that alone saves hundreds of dollars. My new TV has the Fire Stick built in. That’s the way to go!

I'm confused. Works great on my other Element TVs. Just not this one. Amazon tech worked with me on my "no source found" issue with the HDMI. Unplugging the TV. Recycling the power on the Fire stick. Finally decided to send another under warranty. Same issue. Soon as I turn the TV off and back on, the TV just cant find it.  Had to settle with putting the old one back in, which works fine, just slow and I miss out on the updates.

I got this on sale and decided for the price what the heck. I was surprised at the quality of the voice recognition. It was easy to set up the actual unit to the TV. Adding each app took a while to do so set aside some time. You can choose to set up watchlist or libraries. It shows what is currently airing that you may like. It is definitely geared towards Amazon Prime Video consumers but I have multiple apps that I stream quite easily with my fire stick. As a Prime Member you do have access to a lot of included apps. One con is that Sometimes the apps get stuck and no matter what you push on the remote you are dead in the water until the system refreshes. It is not a long time but it is irritating.  Otherwise, The remote generally is fast, responsive and easy to use. Yes you can watch local news, most prime time TV shows and then so many other streaming apps are available! Some apps have in ad commercials that you cannot skip but you had to watch commercials paying your internet provider anyway. This fire stick  Makes going to bed very hard when you can binge watch about anything you want.

I bought this stick to replace my much older Fire Sticks. I had noticed that shows and apps were taking longer to start. I was constantly getting "no internet connection" and "Home not available". Apps I listen to, especially Iheart, would cut off while streaming. I decided to replace my Firestick hoping newer technology would help.I just unplugged the old one, plugged in the new one, set it to my internet and it updated itself (took about 5 minutes).This Firestick is so much faster than the old stick. Much faster downloads and no interruptions on streaming. I should have done this long ago.

I couldn't not get this for $17.99  I want an Apple TV, but money is tight these days.  So even $18 was a stretch but hey its pretty amazing what kind of tech you can get for that these days.It does YouTube, Netflix, and Prime Video which is all I really use, and my TV's are only 1080p so its perfect.  Playback is smooth as long as internet holds up, and works fine at non peak hours from my apartment buildings public wifi.  I expect it to work perfectly when I get my own internet account.  When I eventually upgrade to a better streaming device I will use it on my bedroom TV.

Finally Amazon is making is much easier to discover new shows and movies to watch.  This has a better menu than the older models and is pretty easy to navigate.  If I could change one thing is the TV feature a the bottom of the controls.  It's right below the play button and I've been accidentally hitting it.  It's easy to get back to what I was watching before so maybe I'll get used to it.  This Fire seems to be so much more responsive than the older ones so I've updated all but one of my Fire Sticks.  I love Amazon's integration and compatibility with all my other Amazon electronics.  I'm hooked.

I originally gave it one star because I couldn’t get it to update the fire stick. I am so happy with it because I plan on dropping U-verse and going strictly with just Internet and streaming.

We had an extra tv but no coaxial cable to hook up another cable box and since we stream a few services like Netflix and hbo so we bought this so our 67-year old dad can watch his shows. It’s connected to our 5G and it’s maybe 10 ft away from the router, maybe that’s the issue. I’ll switch it back to our 2G and see if that might solve the issue for a steady connection since 2G is convenient for devices that are long range. Aside from this issue it’s been very simple and easy to manage.

This Fire stick is my first foray into a streaming service and it did not disappoint. Setup was fairly easy, howevernewbies need to read the instructions and follow the steps to connect to their WiFi.  If you are not a mega TVwatcher and don't care to pay for extra apps the Free tab gives you lots of choices and saves your budget. I ama huge youtuber so that alone is reason enough to like this gadget. As a recent cord-cutter from cable I am onlysorry it took me so long to try this. So far I'm totally enjoying  using it and I'm like a kid in a candy store just having so many options. One of the best purchases I've ever made. If you're new to streaming I think this is a great "gateway" tool.

You get to watch TV without cable.  Easy to install.  Just plug it in.  Plug into HDMI, and plug into power. I already have an older version of this but decided to give this one a try and I'm very pleased.  It's so easy to search using Alexa so I'm actually using Fire TV much more often than I had been. I purchased this to replace an original Fire TV box (2016), as it was slow and required rebooting often to work properly. I have it installed into the HDMI port on my home theater receiver, not directly to the TV, and it is working perfectly.I am completely satisfied with this purchase. Losing WiFi connection4.  Remote stops workingWe enjoy using our Fire TV Stick Lite and eagerly awaiting future updates to eradicate some bugs we have encountered.

easy to set up BUT.....It took me a 65 yr and 2 U tube video to open up the  remote for the batteries !! Very easy to set up and use, this little device is basically plug and play. There are many apps to choose from and easily log into. My frustration is the function of the device itself, I am tech savvy so I am pretty sure it's not user error.The device requires a restart each time I switch apps or the sound does not work. For example: I can start off in Hulu, great sound. But if I switch to Netflix, Prime, Disney+, Vudu...etc... goodbye sound. Adjusting the sound in the Settings is no use. It doesn't matter the selection, I tried them all just to be sure. The only thing that resolves the sound issue is restarting the Firestick itself (I am not the only one with this issue; thanks YouTube!). This is super annoying. I can watch a show on one app, my daughter wants to watch a show on a different app...restart... I want to continue watching my show on the first app...restart... and so on. You should not have to restart in-between apps. I guess I expected to much from this little device. My smart blu-ray DVD player we use in another room workes better with multiple app use/sound. I may have to break down and buy another. I had only paid $8 for this at BestBuy through a holiday promo they had going on so I am not out a large about which makes me happy.

A great deal for $18. I now have 4 of these (2 with TV volume & power controls). Have had a "new-in-box" 21 inch monitor collecting dust for years.  The Fire Stick appears to function with any monitor that has an HDMI INPUT (not output, such as a laptop.) The most labor intensive part of the install was removing the monitor and the Fire Stick from their boxes and hooking up the cables.  The monitor came to life instantly, Fire Stick attached to WiFi, downloaded latest firmware, and was ready to use. Other than my existing (over-priced) 300MB Internet connection, I can watch thousands of shows, You-Tubes, News channels, etc basically for free.  The abundance of ads is extremely annoying, and I'm constantly reminded that if I paid for subscription services, there would be far fewer ads. (Ain't no free lunch.)Makes an excellent portable or garage "TV", especially if you can get local TV reception with rabbit ears, or high-tech equivalent.I have no other Alexa devices, so I can't comment on integration. And per the item description: "Fire TV Stick Lite with Alexa Voice Remote Lite (no TV controls)", there is no volume control to rate.

Edit: When I left this review, I received a call from Amazon Customer Support. I bumped the rating up to a 3 from a 2, since this only shows how good the support for this device is. I can't give it a 4 or 5 until Twitch stops freezing for streaming too long; However, definitely better then I first thought.Original review: Twitch is a property of Amazon, and yet, if I stream Twitch for too long, it freezes. The only way to fix it is to go all the way into the settings to force stop Twitch. Restarting it fixes it, but it's a pain to do it literally every single time. I figured that the Fire Stick would be the way to go since Amazon owns Twitch, but it was not.If you only run the Fire Stick for bursts, it seems to work fine; However, running it for any length of time (such as overnight or most of the day) will cause it to freeze and you'll have to restart it.Wouldn't recommend this unless you're just looking for something cheap. It gets the job done, but not without it's fair share of bugs and inconveniences.

This product is terrific! Like many others I wish I had cut the cable out a long time ago. The set up was super simple. I did purchase the Paramount app through Amazon so I could watch alot of CBS programming but outside of that I'm seeing all I want to just like before it's just in a different way. Most of what I watch I can get through my Hulu subscription,  like ABC and NBC and Fox shows it just means waiting a day. If a show I want to see is on Monday night then I wait until Tuesday to watch which is no big deal to me as I recorded most things on my DVR unit anyway for watching later. I'll be saving about $100 a month and that is big to me. There is so much programming out there. And all the old old shows I watched like NYPD Blue, Hill Street Blues, ER, The Practice....you can watch from the beginning. Hulu is a great resource for ALOT of things. My Hulu plan does have commercials but they are brief and knowing the money I'm saving I can deal with it. Same with alot of streaming stuff, you might need to sit through commercials but I say give it a try. You can always go back to cable if you don't like it so you don't have anything to lose. Remote is easy to use too. You should give it a shot!

I've been threatening to "cut the cord" for years.  When the cable bill hit nearly 50% of my property tax bill, I realized it was time. It works good enough i suppose. The speed is great. Functionality is fine, however everytime my TV is turned off the firestick loses audio. Have to reset the firestick every single time. This was my 1st Roku device, and my 2nd streaming "stick" (the other one being a Fire TV stick 2019 generation).  I had read articles comparing the 2 and thought Roku might be better.  It was nicer in some ways, but lacking in one important feature area - data saving and data monitoring.Pros:-Easy setup (about the same as my Fire TV Stick)-Clean interface (less ads and overall easier than Fire TV Stick)-Lots of apps/channels (about the same as Fire)-Xfinity Stream beta app works better on Roku than on Fire right nowCons:-Had to find special link to signup for Roku without giving them a credit card. I pay for my streaming services by signing up directly with Netflix, Disney+ etc and didn't want Roku in the middle of that, especially just to get started and try it out.  But if you like to buy a single movie "on demand" thru any Roku channel, you'd want to have a credit card on file, so maybe this wouldn't be a big deal to some.-Volume & especially the Mute buttons located on side of remote are easily clicked by accident while holding the remote in your hand-Couldn't get the Roku remote to control my TV to change the input to the right one for watching the roku-Can't install Firefox web browser for full surfing (can do this on Fire, its clunky but a nice option to have)-Can't put it into Sleep mode for low power and no data usage (Fire stick does have this)-Can't see any data usage by app/channel...Fire TV Stick allows this under Settings>Preferences>Data Monitoring.  It is a nice way to see how much a particular app is using so that you can attempt to control data usage in that app's settings (or choose to watch things in the lower usage apps).  i.e., Disney+ defaults to a very high streaming quality using 3-4Gb per hour.  At least you can change that quality within their app to save data.  But having the Fire stick show you the usage per app is a handy way to evaluate which apps are data hogs.  Roku doesn't have this feature.-Can't limit the streaming quality (aka data usage) in the Roku Stick settings - there was a hidden option at one time that may have done this (Bit Rate Override).  You can still get into that setting but it doesn't appear to work anymore and the Roku support forum reply is basically saying "sorry, too bad" because hidden/developer features are not intended to be supported so this isn't a bug.  Jeez, that's lousy - fair point in the software world, but this was a hidden feature discussed all over the internet and used by many prior to 2019.  Roku forum also suggests you should set your home router to limit the data used by the device - not all routers can do that by device, not all users can do that.So, look, I'm sure some of you will think the data usage issue isn't Roku's fault, blame your ISP for putting caps, use the features within your channels/apps to limit usage, etc.  A few of our streaming svc apps/channels give you the ability to throttle the data usage with quality/bit rate settings, but most do not.  I don't think its too much to ask a long-established streaming device maker to include a feature for this.  And since the Amazon Fire TV Stick does this, I'm going to return this Roku and get a 2nd Fire stick when they go on sale.I did really like the cleaner interface on the Roku and wanted to like it enough that I could give one to my 70+ yr old parents, but not if I can't easily limit their data usage at the stick.  Sorry Roku, you didn't earn my business.

My family has owned 2 other Roku Sticks and have gotten a huge amount of use out of each one.  One of the sticks we use everyday, many hours a day, with our streaming service, making the roku stick is our primary way of watching TV.  By and large, the sticks have worked really well for many years.But recently, as the quality/quantity of TV streaming increased, we found that having a Roku stick that was quite a few years old, wasn't performing as well as would like.  It still worked, but we found it dragged when trying to search or trying to scroll through the, seemingly, hundreds of channels/options that are available.So, it was time for an upgrade.  We choose the Streaming Stick Plus and, after using for a few months now, we wish we had upgraded far sooner.The new stick is easily able to handle the demands that streaming puts on it .  Each channel we choose comes up much faster than with the old sticks.  I think, though i don't know i can prove it, that the new stick is able to receive/utilize a stronger wifi signal, especially as compared to the older model.The on-screens controls that come with the newer, upgraded version of the roku are much easier to use.  the new remote, with built-in controls to turn the tv on/off, to control the volume of the tv and to mute the volume of the tv means that having a seperate, tv only, remote isn't needed.And, we've have not only been having fun using the voice controls on the remote, we've found the voice controls to be an extremely helpful shortcut for many different sites.I haven't yet tried hooking the roku up to Alexa, as that isn't a major plus for me, but I might try doing that in the future.so now i'm thinking that it might be a good time to go ahead and upgrade that one remaining, older roku that we have.  yep, that sounds like a good idea to me.

Recently we got just sick and tired of paying $140 a month to be forced to watch endless commercials and ten-year-old reruns. I have been an Amazon Prime member and a real fan of the Fire TV Stick I've been using in addition to my cable service for years now, so when we decided to cut the cable bill and upgrade to a newer version of the Firestick we became interested in the ROKU Streaming Stick as well because we have heard a lot of great things about ROKU too. So I got one of each. I don't regret either. And I DONT miss the cable bill either!The ROKU streams beautifully, rarely ever an issue, EVER, with pausing to buffer; Loss of signal NEVER happens, and the picture is crisp and clear--actually as good as if not better than what I experienced with paid-for cable TV. My only real complaint is the sound: I have to crank-up the volume on my TV to get enough volume to understand what is going on.I enjoy the flexibility that ROKU offers in-that I can sign-on to Prime, HULU, or any channel available, including the ROKU Channel (Which I've come to enjoy immensely). I love that I have control to watch what I want, when I want it, without having to spend 40% of the time I've PAID for being force-fed ad after ad after ad,  ad-nauseum. On most free Channel Apps I find they only show two to four commercials per break, and there are fewer breaks making the advertising tolerable. I don't mind watching a few ads to compensate for watching TV for free. I just HATE watching endless commercials on a service that I'm paying for!I also like that you can purchase or rent movies right from your TV and that there are so many new releases available.Sure! The move to ROKU has taken some adjustment, but it's soooooo much better than cable TV! And I'm putting that 140 bucks a month I used to spend on cable TV to much better use.

First off, I want to be clear that activation of the Roku device is free. Purchasing the device is the only money you pay to Roku. If you have somehow end up on a website claiming that you have to pay them an activation fee or an upgrade fee just to be able to use your Roku device then you have navigated to the wrong address and it is a scam. What you do have to pay for, if you choose to do so, is any of the paid subscription streaming services you want. Some services require a paid subscription and some don't. To name a few:  Watching basic YouTube (the same ones you watch for free on your phone, tablet, or computer), Tubi TV, Pluto TV, and hoopla (if available through your public library) are all free of charge. Netflix, Amazon Video, CBS All Access, YouTube TV, and Apple TV+ charge a monthly fee, but that has nothing to do with whether or not you use a Roku device to access their content.We bought a TCL Roku TV a couple years ago and, between Netflix and Prime, found that we weren't watching cable television anymore.  So we downgraded to internet-only service through our cable provider and got this stick for our bedroom TV.Unlike some of the less expensive Roku offerings, the remote that comes with this one does both TV power and volume, so as long as you're getting all your content through Roku (and never need to switch inputs to, say, cable/satellite/antenna service or a DVD player) you don't need to have a separate TV remote.  I was surprised the remote doesn't have a mute button, though.  Our TCL Roku TV's remote had such a button.  So if you're a heavy user of the mute button you may find that this does not in fact save you from needing a separate TV remote. I'm also a little troubled that our Roku TV, which we bought new only about two years ago, doesn't support Apple TV+. This particular streaming stick does support it. But it seems like a couple years is way too early for a streaming device to be even starting to creep into obsolescence. I have no interest in buying a new Roku stick every few years, and hope this isn't a sign of what's to come.It's also clear that the Roku stick has no idea whether the TV is on or off.  This means that if you just push the power button in the middle of watching something, it will keep playing--and perhaps even advance automatically to the next show.  This means you'll lose your place in a series and, perhaps more importantly, will consume more power and data.  So remember to stop playback when you turn off the TV.  Or get one of those power strips that automatically turns off accessories when the master device turns off. (Or buy a Roku TV instead of a separate TV and Roku stick--but remember my comment above about sliding into obscelescence.)If you're looking for free entertainment, there are some options but you probably won't find them up to par with paid cable TV or perhaps even with free over-the-air TV.  Tubi has some content, including a "Not on Netflix" section.  Pluto TV is okay--it has a lot of channels, but they're largely underwhelming.  There's a local news "channel" that in our case gives us content for the nearest big city, an hour away, rather than our actual local news stations.  The Roku Channel occasionally has a movie worth watching.  Your public library may offer some content through Hoopla as well. So there are some free options, but you're unlikely to be completely satisfied without some form of paid entertainment.

I'm not buying any more Roku devices. Not after how things have gone with HBO Max and Twitch.The ONLY draw that Roku had was supporting ALL the apps i use slightly better than the built-in apps of my TV. And now theyre not doing that because in their greed theyre trying to double-dip by charging me a premium for the device AND the content providers for a piece of their action.  You dont need this.  Just use the apps on your TV.

This roku streaming stick its nice, you'll stream in 4 if it's available from streaming services, the one little problem I encountered was that I was trying to power it with a different cable that did power it but I couldn't pair the remote, after switching to the included cable everything worked fine, so yeah use the cable included to power it it looks like it's designed that way to work the two together, other that that little issue everything works great, the one thing I didn't like was roku customer service you can't call anyone they send you to the website that is extremely useless and they take forever to reply any emails and that's why I rated this product 4 stars

Overall this was a great upgrade from our Apple TV 3rd gen. We are only using for 1080p content at the moment.Super small & portable.If you're already a Roku user, the interface is identical, at least to my 2018 TCL TV. The remote automatically paired with the IR on my 2012 LG Plasma, which I didn't want at first, but this meant that it works also with my Vizio soundbar for volume control, so that works well too.One gripe: every time you power off the TV, the Roku must start up again each time you turn it back on. This sometimes takes 30 seconds to fully become functional. Maybe this is just me, but worth noting if you turn your TV on and off several times per day.Another thing to mention, especially if you're coming from an Apple TV: the interface for each app is different, so it takes some getting-used-to.

I was going through the setup procedure and it came time to enter the code for activation. It said my account was BLOCKED and I had to call the number on the screen to get activation.  I called the number and they want a "REGISTRATION FEE" .....there was no activation fee .....It was a new policy by Roku put in effect in May. They wanted $80. I said this sounds like a scam and hung up.They had  information on my Roku account ...email, phone number, other Roku products that I had.I later got a text form Debbie the "account manager" who said if my Roku is still not working to answer "yes" to the text and she would get me the cheapest option, she sent the same text the following day. the numbers she called from were 914-334-6824 & 201-500-6506

Very disappointed horrible customer service I returned all the Roku Streaming Stick+ | HD/4K/HDR Streaming Devicethe units keep freezing and the remote become unresponsive.  Roku in it great wisdom has NO phone support unlike other companies like Amazon who offer great support including phone. support NOT roku they seem not to care in future I will recommend the fire stick it works not like  Roku Streaming Stick+ | HD/4K/HDR Streaming Device  .  I went through 4 of these units and returned all.The  Roku Premiere  I have been using has none of the issues all 6 of the Roku Streaming Stick+ I have had and all six of the Roku Streaming Stick+ I have returned would not buy again

I have 3 televisions and 4 different Roku units. TV #1 is used the most and is 50' from the router. TV 2 is in a bedroom about 20' from the router. TV3 is in the computer room and only 5' from the router.  The Roku 1 was our first streaming adventure on TV 1 (50'down the hallway). Our first viewing experience was a success, although Roku 1 was slow and not a great experience. Roku 1 was replaced by Roku Premier. Premier was a huge step forward with no complaints on TV1.Next up was Roku Streaming Stick for TV #2 (20' from the router). No problems at all.Feeling good about myself, I put Roku 1 on TV3 in the computer room (5' from the router). Disaster! If another TV was on, it slowed to a crawl or even a dead stop. No more reprieves - --into the trash. I took Roku Premier from TV 1 and put it on TV 3, where it's performing admirably.I put the much touted Streaming Stick Plus (fabulous reviews right?) on TV 1 (50' from the router). When it works, it is fine, but it can't seem to work for more than a few hours. Then it will drop words, stop dead, the remote may stop working, picture may to fuzzy, etc. Usually these symptoms get worse rapidly. Seldom, it returns to proper programming. If I unplug the Roku device and then plug it back in,  it will usually perform well for quite awhile.Assuming the Streaming Stick Plus couldn't be at fault (remember those great reviews?) I though about replacing my aging router. But not being a total moron, I had been checking connections, signal strength, etc all during this process. According to WIFI analyzer, my signal at TV 1 is usually around minus 62-64, which is OK. Roku settings/network is consistently 'good'. My speed test results were generally 17-25 upload and 8-11 download, which is good 'nuff. So, unless I really am missing the boat, the router signal isn't to blame.Next step will be putting Streaming Stick Plus with it's great reviews on TV3 (5' from the router) and putting Roku Premier back on TV 1. Roku 1 will sadly stay in the trash where it truly belongs. Hopefully, life will go merrily on with three functioning TVs and three different Roku units. I really love Roku for what it does - - - when it works.

For years I was using my laptop with a HDMI cable to watch Netflix and You Tube. Recently the laptop has really been lagging or the wifi would shut off and I would have to turn the laptop off and on again (it wouldn't just let me reconnect to wifi for some wierd reason). So I finally broke down and spent $30 for this. One of the best decisions of my life!!!  (except maybe getting divorced from my ex..😁). What a life changer..plus now I have so much more to watch. Also Alexa will play music for free etc. How can you beat it?? Easy to set up and start streaming. PS my TV is 10 years old and still works with it..

I own a Fire Stick 4K, which I like, but the UI is confusing.  The Roku stick, piece of cake.  It's super easy to set up and use.  From there, it goes downhill.I have an LG C9 OLED TV that supports all the latest and greatest video technologies.  The Fire Stick supports Dolby Vision, which looks AMAZING on my TV.  The Roku does not, and even though it supports HDR, the picture is much too bright.  Whites hurt my eyes and everything looks artificial.  Ok, so I could change my TV settings I'm sure....but that won't fix the next problem with the Roku......which is constant freezing.  My router is about 3 feet from the TV, so there's no way the signal is too weak.  No matter the app, the picture on the Roku constantly freezes.  I can watch a stream for 8-10 mins, then freeze.  Then another 8-10 mins, then freeze again.  Not to mention the remote will become unresponsive within apps, causing me to have to exit back to the home screen and restart the app.I'll keep the Roku and put on a spare TV for now, but next time Amazon has a sale on Fire Sticks, it's getting replaced.  It's a bummer because the UI is drop dead simple....but if I can't actually stream anything, what's the point?

I have a Firestick on all my TVs. I can't find much to watch on TV from my regular provider. I shop and watch a few news programs but not much more. On my Firestick, I can download my apps and watch whatever I choose. I have many choices now. I watch Martha Stewart, YouTube, Hulu, Netflix and Amazon Prime so I have lots to watch when I want and where I want. I can even take my FireStick on vacation and plug it into the TV and feel like I am at home.I love the convenience of a FireStick and they only get better. Using Alexa to find the program I want to watch is wonderful.Happy viewing!

Okay. I am 50 and not the most tech literate person.  I will say that I had a ROKU, and the difference is HUGE, to me. ROKU was much less brand centered, as you can imagine. IT is JUST a streaming stick, and I found the display format to be much simpler and easier to navigate. The Amazon stick, on the other hand, is very AMAZON-centered. And, for me, the format is much harder to navigate and understand. On Roku, Amazon had it's own separate menu like all the other streaming sites. On the Fire stick, all streaming is on an AMAZON based menu, so it is harder for me to navigate, like between the subscription sites I have purchased on Amazon and the other streaming subscription sites like Hulu or Netflix that I purchase independently.  I am sure the stick is working as it is meant to. I am just not a fan of the formatting.
I'm confused, I'm login, trying to get it set-up and is asking me to login and don't recognize my password, not on tv or on my either devices, can't install the stupid device.

Ordered the Fire TV Stick Lite as a "work-around" for older VISIO smart TV.  TV's streaming capabilities were pretty limited, and had issues trying to add apps required for internet TV services.  Fire Stick solved all those problems instantly.  Device was easy to set up and is simple to use.  Set up took about 10 minutes.  Just follow concise, step-by-step instructions included in the package.  Now enjoying all Amazon Prime content (plus tons more) on primary flat screen TV.  Bargain at $30.  Recommended it to a tech-challenged neighbor couple and helped them set theirs up in minutes.  Very pleased.

The Amazon Fire Stick works great; however, be careful where you plug this in on the surge protector since it does not provide shielding against EMI. If you plug it in next to the plug to your TV, you may notice a seizure inducing flickering. Make sure you save at least one plugin of space between your Fire Stick and TV and it should work fine. I actually bought this because I thought my other Fire Stick was broken, but on the positive side, I have a new Fire Stick. I would have given it 5 stars if it provided good shielding but it doesn't.Edit 12/26/2020 - Turns out the only way to use this device is to plug it directly into the HDMI port without the extender. The extender was the problem.

I'm glad I purchased this. I don't have cable tv and this was able to expand the amount of tv shows and movies I can watch. The setup was easy and the controls are simple, which I am happy about because it makes it easy for my mom to use. My tv is a bit older, so I don't have apps built in. Glad I can watch stuff like Netflix on my tv now. Thinking I should've bought a fire stick sooner. I also bought a fire stick 4k, but I'm not as pleased with that one because sometimes the video freezes or it gets stuck on the menue screen. I bought the 4k, after the lite. But I wish I just bought another fire stick lite instead. The fire stick lite runs more smoothly. Also I think the remotes are too light in weight and could easily break if you drop it just once by mistake . I handle mines with extra care because I'm not trying to find out if it can easily break. But that's a minor detail

I tried to use a 6 ft. USB extension cord to reach the wall and it just kept restarting at the opening screen over and over. Works fine without the extension. I don't know why this is the only device that has ever had a problem with a USB extension. After finding that out it's been a great addition to the entertainment set up. It brings all your streaming services under one device and even plays some fairly good games if you have a fire controller. Without a fire controller I wouldn't say it's much of a gaming device though.

Best, user-friendly option to stream content on the market, especially for the price. Without much research, I’ve tried a half dozen products to cast or relay from my phone & this is its own stand-alone entity to convert a HDTV into a smart TV without buying another screen, when your original one fits the space & application. Couldn’t be happier, so I bought another one for the bedroom TV set. Only thing that is even remotely negative is that the back cover on the remote doesn’t lock in place very well; if you’re listening AMZN. But not enough to take away a star... maybe a 4.8 star rating.

I couldn't get the fire stick to connect to my wifi for two days with it brand new out of the box. Did all the troubleshooting I could find on Amazon. Several resets on both the fire stick and router. I use the same wifi with my smart TV and a roku. No problems at all with my router. I contacted the support for the product. Worst "help" I have ever received through Amazon. The person I was dealing with had no idea what they were doing. I can understand when they have to go through all the prompts before turning it over to a tech support. But when none of it is working and I'm asking to speak to someone else, just send me on over to tech. They just had no clue at all. So frustrating when I have to repeat myself so many times over and over again in the same conversation. I did one last reset before I sent it back or just ate the money for it. It finally decided to connect to the wifi and it is working so far. I'm not liking it at all though.

I have had several Roku's over the years.  Thought I would try a Fire Stick.  Went to down load Xfinity app.  But had to install a Down loader then make setting changes etc etc.  Finally got it installed.  Life appeared to be good.  But like all Amazon specific products you get a constant commercial on their products and then see your last visited sites then the third line is your apps.I leaned to live with this for a few weeks.  Then it said I had to up date my xfinity app and it all started over again.  Down loader etc.Stick the Fire Stick.  Ordered this Roku device. Had it up and running in 20 minutes. It even asked if I was an Xfinity Customer and downloaded the app as part of its start up, up date.  The hardest part for me was to sign in to my previously purchased apps as I had forgotten several passwords that I had chosen some years ago when I first signed up for the Apps.Roku is the best.  I am not compensated for this in any way.  I love the Roku. I must admit I did get scammed once setting up a device where I got directed to a scamer site who required a setup fee for Roku.  I paid.  This was not Roku but some scamer I got directed to.  Roku does not  charge a fee.  Remember that.

Product worked fine, until mid-movie the other day. I have 3 Rokus, all purchased at different times. This latest one I purchased in February 2020. It lasted until August. I swapped with older Rokus on other TVs to confirm that it was this one, and not the internet connection, that was bad. I'm disappointed that the 6-month Roku support ended about 2 weeks before this issue. I would like to Roku support before buying another unit.Follow up: I could not easily navigate to follow up via Amazon on this. However, I did follow up with Roku. They said that I should do a factory reset, then send in for a replacement. I did the factory reset, then tested it and it worked, so I am not sending it in for replacement.I had originally put a 3-star, but since contacting Roku via my Roku account and getting a quick response and direction, and a willingness to replace, I have changed the rating to 5-star.  Good follow-up and service.

WARNING!!! BUYER BEWARE!!!I bought this as a gift and my friend was scammed during set up! Instead of allowing him to set up his own account, he was told to call support since the code he logged in “didn’t work”. Not being familiar with roku he did exactly as he was told and ended up paying over $100 to be able to use the roku. The person on the other end basically held his roku hostage until he paid money, then his roku was all set up for him. He called to tell me what happened and I knew something was wrong since roku never charges to activate and set up! I did a factory reset and everything went normally after that. Now he has to watch for the charge on his credit card! Someone has preinstalled software on the roku stick to scam people. I don’t know else this would’ve gotten on the device!!!

This device will drain batteries in a matter of days. We have replaced the batteries several times. The battery drain ranged from a few days to a few weeks. This device is not used daily, so there is no movement, nor anyone pressing buttons (Support has sent us 2 additional replacements remotes, which did not solve the problem).Buyer beware this is a faulty product. We have owned numerous Roku devices over the years, and they have been great. However, this device is faulty by design and drains batteries. We paid $50 for this. It's worthless.

I wish I’d purchased any other streaming device. The remote is absolutely awful! It eats through batteries super quick, the batter warning flashes non-stop on the tv screen, and goes to sleep constantly. It has literally taken me 10 minutes to type in a 2 word movie title because it would go to sleep after every letter! I have tried every ‘fix’ I can find online and nothing works. Do your homework! Buy anything else! Never have I been more disappointed in an electronics purchase.

*update*I ended up keeping this since I got it to work and... I wish I hadn't*It occasionally causes the TV to tell me that the HDMI connection isn't HDCP 2.2 so it won't play some 4K content (note that this stick plugs directly into the HDMI port so there's no cable involved. Also, it's started simply shutting down randomly and using the power button on the remote doesn't turn it back on. I need to pull the power cable and reattach it.Sure, this is only $50... but that shouldn't mean it's trash. If it was slower, fine. But random shutdowns and disconnects just means they screwed this up. Do not buy._____Original Review:Utter trash. Tried to setup apps and, since I use complex passwords, I grabbed the iOS remote app and copied and pasted the passwords. Or tried to. Although the app showed the password as having been pasted correctly, the entry on the Roku was garbled beyond recovery. Could I have just typed in these 18 digit passwords? Sure, it's tedious but you only do it once, right. And then... my TV told me the Roku was not putting out a signal anymore. Unplugged the stick, put it back in the HDMI port... it worked... for a while.Sure, this could be defective, a lemon. But this is a solid state device and it should test itself when it boots. If something is wrong, tell me. As it is, this is going in the return bag to Amazon tomorrow.

I had the original Roku and that worked fine but didn't like using 2 remotes to still have the ability to change the volume, etc..  This new one solves that problem but the sensor is behind the TV as its part of the HDMI connection.  So sometimes I need to "aim" it just right.  It also takes a few minutes to load for some reason.  Same WiFi as my old set and that was quick-- this one can be spotty at times.  Jury is still out on this one.I will say-- Why can't Roku make a remote that lights up?  very annoying that in this day and age the remote doesn't simply illuminate so when watching with the lights out you can quickly find the pause button.

ROKU makes lots of streaming devices. I have the larger ones for my home system where I want multiple input/output options.I needed one for a simple bedroom TV and decided it was time to try the stick.It plugged directly into the HDMI port. It does need a USB power supply. My TV has a USB port, but only has power when the TV is one. So, if you use the TV port, the ROKU will need to power up each time you turn on the TV. That takes about 30 seconds.It's better to use the included USB power supply, which powers the stick at all times and avoids the ROKU power up issue.Reception and streaming is great. I have had no issues. It connects to the WIFI and has every option I need.My only grief is that ROKU seems to keep adding stations to my viewing options that I have to delete. It is almost like the cell phone with all those apps you don't need, don't want, and didn't ask for.The good news is that they are easy to remove....but they seem to keep on adding more and more apps that have to be deleted.Overall, I'm very happy. Easy integration and good quality.

Can't believe I didn't buy this years ago and was still using a Roku 1 box.I love this thing. The quality of my picture on my TV screen is a million times better and clearer. I love that it has a power button on it to turn both stick and TV off. Love having volume buttons on the remote also. And the microphone option is so much better then not having voice activity. Now I don't have to type all this nonsense anymore when I want to search for a movie. I just push the little microphone button and speak into it. I actually whispered into the other day and it still worked lol.My most favorite thing about this streaming stick is that when you scroll across a TV show or movie and stop there, it starts playing previews of that show. No more sitting through crap that I don't like anymore. I can always tell if I'll like something from a preview. So thank God for that.Worth the price and I just bought a second one for my mom.

Recently purchased a small size projector with a small size screen projection size.  It was clunky using the cell phone to play various types of content.  This Fire Stick lite is great for the projector.  We don't need the TV controls, nor 4k quality.  Already having numerous Fire Sticks, We are very familiar with the remote control.  Nothing new to learn.Turned out a great inexpensive way to make a small inexpensive projector, a wonderful experience!  All the components are light weight, easy to carry in a bag.  Perfect for traveling!

You have access to some free movies, and old weekly shows like Bewitched, Dennis the Menace, Johnny Carson, etc. There is a fee for all the other shows.You have to set-up a network on your your computer for WIFI for the Fire Stick to connect too unless youalready have WIFI.Images are nice and sharp.Only problem I had was that the HDMI cable would not connect properly to one of my TV's, cable end was lose fitting and I could not get a signal. I ordered a new cable male to female HDMI and will try it as soon as its delivered.

Cut cable & saving $55 monthly eventhough YouTubeTV costs $65 monthly. Using AMZ FireTV stick is functioning well..still getting accustomed to user interface as I select local TV & streaming. TV list by time & alpha sorted stations takes some adjusting to vs. SEARCHing for TV program name. It works...just like in the ocean - which way to go - up, down or sideways.  ImDB TV offering clunky - so opting NOT to use it. AMZ FirestickTV (w/ TV button only) was/is my choice. I want to use My Samsung TV remote for other TV & peripheral equipment controls.

This was a replacement for my first generation Fire Stick and I was disappointed with it.  I decided to upgrade as my first generation would lose connectivity.  I received the new Fire Stick Lite and for some reason it would need to be restarted every time I turned on the TV due to there being no sound.  I called and spoke to an Amazon Customer Service person who helped by sending me a replacement.  That service was amazing!  Unfortunately the second one was inconsistent too and I found the same issue.  Perhaps it didn't work with my tv?  I am returning it.

I ordered this yesterday and it said it would come this weekend and it came today like I’m so happy . I love it !! And how fast it came when it told me it would be delivered today I’m like nah it’s not .. it comes in a perfect little box it’s fast no volume control but I’m cool with that don’t need it .. I used to have one of these years ago but then got smart TVs for the bedrooms and a PS4 for my living room tv which is the only tv in the house that isn’t a smart one and me and my kids only eat in the living room my PlayStation broke yesterday swear... so I ordered this right away (can’t afford the ps5 right now lol) and it’s here don’t have to wait until the weekend !!! Comes with batteries and everything

This is my fifth fire stick we have them throughout the house. I wanted to return this and get one replaced but they kept making me talk to tech-support so I just gave up. Usually the fire sticks are amazing! But this one for some reason will not stream Hulu or Netflix it will start to and then it will cut off about a minute into it and then start the program over I don’t know what the problem is. My only other option was to return it and get a refund but I got it on sale and I’m not gonna pay 10 or 15 more dollars for the same thing that I got.

We've been using a Roku for over a year in order to stay away from cable but decided to try out the Fire TV Stick after a lot of research. It's been about a month we started using it and we love it. It can be a little overwhelming at first due to having so many options and settings when you first set it up, but everything is very easy to figure out and gets you right into the action as soon as you are ready to watch. The picture is perfect clarity, the sound is awesome, and the connection has been perfect with no lagging. Everything you need for streaming entertainment is right at your fingertips with this inexpensive Fire Stick and we would recommend it to anyone. As far as using the remote to control the tv for on/off and volume, we have a fairly new Insignia 40" HD tv and the remote that comes with the tv actually controls the Fire Stick as well so no need to buy the next step up.

My husband and I got this to replace our roku that was having issues (couldn’t connect to WiFi, even though the WiFi was fine). This has been great for us with only a few things I’m not fond of.1) I’m a weirdo and I like subtitles on at all times despite not being hearing impaired - this feature in some apps doesn’t seem to stick, and I have to turn them on every time I watch something (first world problems, but inconvenient nonetheless)2) when the device “goes to sleep” it takes you all the way back to the initial page, rather than where you left off. Again, first world problems, but inconvenient.Otherwise this thing is great! And we will likely be buying another for our other tv!

I bought this firestick to replace one that I purchased in 2017. The 2017 firestick was slow and glitchy, no matter how often I updated it and restarted it. I was about to completely give up on firestick, but thought I'd give this one a shot first. And viola, it works perfectly. I also have an Nvidia Shield that I paid $150 for. I don't play video games so the shield was way overkill. A techy friend told me to get the shield and that the firestick is crap. My techy friend was 100% incorrect. This firestick is perfect if all you are doing is watching Netflix, Hulu, Prime, YouTube, etc.

My remote went bad. I tried new batteries and re programming. The remote would work about 5 minutes and get real hot. I had to take the batteries out. It has never been wet. It has been dropped a few times. I downloaded the fire stick app for my iPhone so I could still use the fire stick. I went to buy a new remote and the fire stick lite was cheaper than a used remote with voice. I bought a used remote without voice control for $8. I have had a Roku stick much longer than the Fire TV Stick. The remote is made much stronger. It doesn’t have voice but it still works. I bought both brands to see which one I would like. I really don’t see a big difference but the design of the remote.

Shame on me for letting this product sit around for a couple of months before I got around to installing it.  Decided to do this on Dec 6th, 2020 on a rainy day.  Instructions make it look easy.  And it was at first.....long story short, when going through the setup of the product you enter an e-mail address that sends you an activation link.  First time failed?  Second time was a success.  Went through the process and got the congratulations page.  Sitting on the TV was the page that simply showed my e-mail th link would be sent to and a * option that gave yo the option to reset the device.  Also, it stated the link would expire in 15 minutes.  Ok. Great.  I completed the process as stated above and finished out.........now what?  Page is still shown on the TV stating it would send me a link.  Do I turn it on and turn it off.  The * option, just gave me options to reset the deive to factory defaults or restart the device.  So, I cut it off vis the power button on the remote and upon starting back up it either goes back to the page showing a link will be sent or starts the process all over again.  It's stuck in a loop.  What's worse is the website sucks too.  Go to the roku support website and it asks for the category of support needed and then the model number and...........no continue button, no page refresh for that model, nothing.  Page just looks like it was not finished by the developers.  How could it suck this bad?  Oh, and if you finally find the Roku support number you get a recording saying they no longer offer phone support due to Covid-19.  They don't offer chat support either.  Looks like I will have to choose another product to cut the cord.  Obviously for Roku to be aorund as long as they have they have got to have some good products......or just nose dived and started sucking hard on Dec 5th 2020 or somewhere around that time frame.  Anyway, that is my experience.  Still going to try a few things.  I'll post if I make progress.

i am not new to Roku,i have several.i wanted this one "streaming stick plus" because i have a tv that is far away from my router ,this stick has an amplified antenna booster on the power cable,did it work ? yes.the Roku Premier that was there said signal strength good,now the new Roku stick signal strength says Excellent,but all is not well,when i open Netflix and watch a movie all is good, plays very well,it's when i exit the movie there is NO sound,i can exit Netflix and go to Roku home page open another App to watch something else and still NO sound,i found if i disconnect the power from the Roku stick and plug it back in all is ok sound is back,i can open ALL App's and sound is ok,but if i open Netflix sound is ok it's only when i watch a movie on Netflix then exit the movie i loose the sound.I called Roku and they have no answer.Other than that works perfect even the movies and videos that are in 4K and 5.1 audio "surround sound " play very well ,,my tv is 4K and i am hooked up to my Sony theater system.

Update.  This is the the ultimate piece of garbage I ever bought.  DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS PRODUCT.  SENDING BACK TO ROKU IN PIECES.  YES PIECES.  THEY CAN KEEP THE MONEY I PAID FOR IT FOR THIS PIECE OF GARBAGE.  GOING BACK TO MY ROKU EXPRESS THAT NEVER EVER LOST CONNECTION, FROZE UP OR EVER HAD ANY ISSUES WITH.  THIS ROKU STICK DOES NOT EVEN GET ONE STAR.  BUT STUPID AMAZON WANTS AL LEAST 1 STAR.  GET REAL AMAZON. IF A PRODUCT DOES NOT DESERVE EVEN ONE STAR THAN MAYBE AMAZON DOES NOT DESERVE ONE STAR.

1. Bad design: the stick’s form makes it impossible to connect directly to the hdmi port on my tv (which is a brand new, latest model Vizio) since the stick is too big to fit in/around  the two different locations behind the tv that have hdmi ports ......the stick is too long to get into the port/connection well behind the tv.2. Overheating : the device overheats and becomes unusable. I don’t have it in an enclosed space or on top of any other electronics....I had to get an hdmi extender and the device is  laying out in the open with plenty of air around it. Even then it becomes hot and unusable after a few days.  I have to unplug it after using it.  Also the power cord is ridiculously short - so either have to use a power cord extension or have to have it laying down/hanging near the power outlet/strip.I am very frustrated with this device. Who designed this junk?!? I’m very surprised by the absolute lack of effort and intelligence that went into this product. Don't they do any FMEA on design and alpha/beta testing?? My earlier roku was way better and well designed.

This is the third Roku device I have bought to add to TVs in my house. They all still work and were easy to set up, however this device is unlike any other I have purchased. Although it is supposedly the same as the original Roku stick I purchased on Amazon, this one interrupts my TV streaming with Roku pop-up ads or suddenly forcing me to download a new app/channel that I don't want. Both of these interruptions close the app/channel I was using, and make me manually go back, as if I just turned it on. I don't know why this one is different, but I can't recommend it.

That the cable they include did not fit my older TV was less of a problem than not being able to speak with customer support for two major problems. The set-up kept failing by not recognizing my WIFI, the router for which, in perfect health, sat in the same room. This went on for days while the Roku team sent me condescending emails with long lists of what I had to do to make their unreliable hardware work. I eventually solved the problem by ignoring it and trying again seven days later without doing any of the things on their long list.  As I relaxed with Netflix, the Roku CS team kept sending me emails and finally called me. Do any of you answer calls  from unknown numbers? Not enough time in the day. More email tag ensued, during which time the Roku stick again malfunctioned. Out of the blue - no one bumped into the TV stand or jostled the stick. There were no electrical surges or WIFI problems. Just cut out in the middle of a movie. Bad engineering or poor quality control, take your pick. Do they think this will motivate me to update my TV? Certainly not with one of theirs.

I bought four of these for the various TVs in the house. Three of the four eat batteries within one or two days. I've had to resort to removing the batteries after each use.  Customer support has given me the runaround after multiple calls and chats. Last contact, they said they would escalate the problem, tech dept. would monitor my account and get back to me with a solution. Roku will not exchange the remotes or actually do anything but wear you out. I will never buy or recommend another Roku product for as long as I live. Absolute waste of money. If you get the 1 in 4 good unit, you're lucky and might actually enjoy the product.

Beware of this Roku's remote. I brought a Roku Streaming stick Plus last year. The remote is cheaply made and stopped voice recognition after 5 months of usage and stopped working completely in less than an year. I called the Roku customer service to resolve about the remote issue and since i passed the 1 year warranty, they said they cant help me with it and asked me to buy a new remote for which i will have to shell another $30 ? If the Roku device is reset and God forbid the remote stopped working the whole unit becomes useless, as in my case.I would never trust another Roku device and will never buy one either when they can't even get their remote work properly, which malfunction within a year !

I bought 3 of these to replace Xfinity DTA boxes that I was being charged a monthly fee to use.  I love that it is so small and plugs directly into my TV's HDMI input, and is neatly concealed behind the set.  I've been using this for a month now, and on one of them, about once a week, I turn on my TV and the screen is blank.  The ROKU device does not boot up as normal.  So, I need to unplug the device and then re-insert it, which then leads me into the process of the original setup, which requires selecting the wifi network, entering the wifi password, entering my email address, retrieving a passcode, name the device, and then the device uploads all of the services.  Then,  to get the Xfinity beta stream to work again, I need to go tot their website and re-authorize the device.  This whole process takes about 15 minutes.  This doesn't seem normal, and I think there is something wrong with the device. I will reach out to ROKU and see if they can address the issue.  The others seem to be working just fine.  If Roku can address this for me, I will revise my rating.

I have had this device since black friday nov 2017.  The stick works well for streaming 4k content... but someone explain to me why their are ads on the landing page?  About 4 months ago the remote started chewing through batteries. I tried the HDMI extender.  No good.  Looks like the remote has a short.  They will not replace the remote because the warranty has expired.  Except they won't tell me how long the warranty lasts.Shrug.  So now i have a stick but no remote.short version is this is made extremely cheaply.  Expect to buy a new one every year or two.  Not a bad deal for $45 on black Friday.When it was working it worked well enough.  The voice search only works for paid channels and not for Plex.  The Alexa integration was only okay.

This is my fourth Roku (the oldest one finally died after many (8?) years, and this one is an upgrade from a conventional 1080 Roku Stick).  Didn't have any of the problems with registration highlighted by another reviewer.  My old Roku Stick connected just fine through the streaming box HDMI input of my Onkyo 4K capable AV receiver to my old Sharp 1080 TV, but when I upgraded to a Samsung 4K TV,  the new TV didn't recognize the video signal from the old Roku Stick when it passed through the AV receiver.  (Note:  the old Stick worked fine connected directly to a HDMI port on the new TV).  Anyway, I decided to get a 4K Roku Stick+ to match the resolution of the new TV.  As a bonus, the Stick+ works fine passing the video signal through the AV receiver to the new TV.  Unfortunately, with this configuration, the Stick+ remote control does NOT control the TV power and volume (no surprise there), but I'm confident it would work if I connected the Stick+ directly to a HDMI port on the new TV.  However, in my set-up, the TV is wall-mounted so it's "cleaner" to use the AV receiver as the "command center" for all the HDMI video inputs by placing peripherals (AV receiver, blu-ray, boxes, etc.) on an adjacent shelf/table and use a single cable from the AV receiver to send the selected video signal to the TV.Bottom line, the Roku Stick+ provides an upgrade in video resolution to match my new TV, and also solves the problem of passing the Roku video signal through the AV receiver to the TV.  5 stars.

In my experience, based on two different Roku models, the Ultra and this one the Streaming Stick +,  The Ultra is fine, no problems, but this one, Streaming Stick +, is a different experience. The problem is with the Remote Control. This Remote Control drain the batteries extremely fast, brand new they last a week with less than a week of use, it is unbelievable, and this happens with Duracell batteries.. DO NOT BUY this Stick

I got this Roku Streaming Stick+ to replace my Fire TV Stick 4K as I have a lot of friends who swear by Roku and it's collection of apps. Well, bottom line up top here is that The Fire TV Stick 4K is a superior device. So just buy it instead unless you really love Roku.The Roku does seem to have lots of additional things you can add such as obscure channels and things, but I mainly use these things:Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, HBO GO/MAX, Apple TV App, CNN, NBC News, and YouTubeBoth Roku and Amazon Fire TV have all of these apps and they work essentially the same on both so as far as actual content is concerned it's pretty much the same.Things I noticed about the Roku that I did not like:- Roku requires you to signup with a separate "Roku Account" in order to use the device. I assume this is so they can target ads to you across multiple streaming platforms. This isn't much different from having to login to the Fire TV with your Amazon account, but in this case Roku doesn't really provide you any content (compared to Amazon where you are logging in so you can access Prime Video).- The Roku HDMI control and remote had a lot of issues controlling my TV. Many times things would end up in a state of the Roku being on but the TV being off, or vice versa. With the Fire TV Stick the HDMI control seems perfect and the remote always turns the TV on and off properly.- The Roku interface seems a little dated and kludgy. I am not a fan of the way the menus wrap back to the beginning but that will vary by person. The Fire TV interface just seems a lot cleaner and better organized.- Roku seems to insert a lot more ads into shows. I wasn't aware that this was a thing until I compared the two devices. For instance, if I watch the NBC Nightly News on my Fire TV Stick 4K I see one commercial at the very beginning of the news and that's it. When the anchor says "We'll be right back" there is no commercial and it just fades right back in to the next news segment. On the Roku watching the exact same NBC Nightly News I get a commercial at the beginning, but then during every commercial break segment ("We'll be right back") I get 4-6 commercials which adds a significant amount of time to watching the news. This alone is worth going with the Fire TV in my book.- Remote - The Roku remote places the volume controls along the right edge of the remote instead of on the main face of the remote like most other remotes. I much prefer having the volume on the main portion of the remote instead of on the side.- Boot up time - Every time I turn on the Roku it takes maybe 15-30 seconds to turn on while a Roku logo animation plays on the screen. The Fire TV Stick 4K starts up much faster.- Dolby Vision - With the Fire TV Stick 4K it seems that the output is always locked to Dolby Vision as my TV displays the Dolby Vision logo as soon as the Fire TV turns on. With the Roku it seems that maybe Dolby Vision is only output when necessary and I've noticed that sometimes this results in the Roku menu appearing either bright or dark depending on what the last output mode was. I like the consistency of the Fire TV Stick 4K output better.All in all the Roku is not a "bad" device per se, but I think for the price you are much better off with the Amazon Fire TV Stick 4K. I ended up selling my Roku and buying another Fire TV Stick 4K.

Update... I went and bought my own HDMI male-female cord because Roku was so backordered. Went and got it all set up and it's a nightmare to stream from my iPhone (with audio and video). My son has a Chromecast on his projector and it's so much easier. In retrospect, that's what I should have gotten. So I gave 1 star before, and they deserve another reduction in stars but I can't go below 1 star. Definitely recommend against Roku... (And I used to be a fan from the Roku 3 that I bought many, many years ago...)Here's my prior review:This thing can't fit into the space of my Vizio TV. It's nuts that they design this hard plastic item that is fairly big to fit into the tight space behind my TV. They offer a free extender which is backordered until April 30. My Amazon window for returns expires April 28, so I'm going to have to return it because I won't know if it works until after the return window. Can't begin to explain how frustrated and disappointed I am.Awful design.

I purchased this item a year ago and gave it 5 stars at the time--mainly for picture quality and improvements over their original model. But Roku has now lost me as a customer. After a year of their ridiculous channel selection system (about a dozen clicks to get from start screen to a program), I tried to watch a program tonight on CBS All Access (now Paramount+) and found Roku had logged me out of that channel. The device/system would not accept my account and password for that channel, even though it works on the new Paramount+ website. I went to Roku.com to advise them of the problem, and I hit the wall they'd built to avoid their customers. After selecting the closest non-relevant option they offered, I got this message--for a device I bought just a year ago! "Agent-assisted support is not available for your issue and/or model." Roku offers no online support other than "ask the community," no option to e-mail them--just nothing. How do they expect to learn about problems with their system if they close their door to communication from customers?

I got this because even though my TV has built-in Netflix and some other things, it doesn't have YouTube or Funimation, so I had been using the PS4 apps for those, and they're not good. The Roku version of the Funimation app is much better. If you only need the biggest streaming services (Netflix, Amazon Prime, etc.) then most TVs seem to come with those already these days. But Roku is pretty good for smaller channels.My main gripe is the fact that they sell positions on the quick buttons to various companies/channels, and you as the consumer have zero control over which buttons you get. Mine came with Disney Plus, Netflix, Sling, and Hulu. If you don't actually use the apps on the buttons, those buttons are just wasted and annoying. You can't even see which buttons any individual remote will have when you buy it (they rotate, but it's pure chance what you'll get). I just really hate buying a product and then having part of *my* possession sold as ad space for a company I may or may not want to support or have any interest in. Roku offers a version that has programmable buttons--but it's the most expensive version, it's only two buttons, and those are *in addition to* the four buttons that they sell as ad space. I wish Roku would focus more on their customers than their vendors/business partners and instead put the ad buttons only on the very cheapest model or as a cheaper version of each model (so you get a discount for agreeing to see the ads) and just make all four buttons programmable by the user as the default.

I am wondering why when I try and play two specific apps, The Roku Channel and 4k Spotlight my stick just quits and the screen says NO INPUT DETECTED. Every thing else works fine, MLBTV NFLGAMEPASS, NHLTV, but when it comes to Roku channel and 4k spotlight it just shuts off, I have great internet speed and a 4k TV 2018 model LG 55”. I have looked online for answers and Roku is like looking for Bigfoot when it comes to answers, I’m not sure if I have a faulty stick, a month old or what. I have to decide quickly as the time to return it free of charge is winding down. My AppleTV 4k works fine on everything, why not this stick, did they not include a 4k connection adaptable for hdcp 2.2? Be aware when you buy for this problem if 4k is what you seek and Roku channel issues. Frustrating trying to get answers. Otherwise it has been good for me. The 4k works fine when it works.

As a long time fire tv user, it was time to make a switch after my Fire TV box died after 3 years.  I tried the Fire Stick 4k, but after it trying to complete updates for 4 hours, I decided to return it.  Boy am I glad I did.  The set up on the Roku is way simpler.  I like that the home screen just shows apps, rather than the Fire TV interface which bombards you with ads.  I like that the home screen can be customized and reorganized while the Fire TV had different screens you had to navigate through to find certain channels.  I did have to toy around with it, plugging it into different HDMI ports to get the best configuration, but that is more on my TV than the Roku.  My only issue with it is that you have to use the power USB cable that it comes with and it is not too long, but I plan on buying an USB extension cord, as I prefer it to be plugged into an outlet.  If you are debating between the Fire TV and this, buy this.  I am a devoted Amazon user, but this product is worth every penny!

#3 Review:  6/3/20  Roku is not operating again.  Sometimes it does, other times it doesn't.  The problem is with getting Prime video to work with Roku. Sometimes yes, sometimes no.  Neither Roku nor Prime Video really do anything about this.  it is very hard to suggest this disappointment to anyone else#2 Review: Wrote 5 emails on May 2 to tech support re: the Roku did not work.  Received non-robotic email reply on May 6.  But they had not read my emails, b/c they provided me with alternative ways to "power on the device", and that was not the problem. Today, I have emailed back asking them to please my 5 emails to them on May 2.#1 Review: Was very excited to get this. I have made it through most of the stages of set up, but nothing is working.  The setup instructions are terrible -- not very clear at all.  I did exactly as was said and kept getting error messages, even though Roku showed there was a good connection with the Internet. The tech support at the Roku website is very poor -- only written so that the only people who can understand are those who don't need to. And, to top it off, Roku offers effectively NO tech support.  The only option is emailing requests for help, but those are only answered robotically by a machine, promising help (when?).If I had known that all the advertising indicating that the setup was  simple, but it is actually very complex, or confusing, or just doesn't work, I would not have bought this.  I am still waiting for tech support to help me get it working

I strongly advise against buying this streaming stick.  I replaced my older Roku stick with this SS+ thinking it will be faster while also having a stronger Wifi antenna.  When I first installed it I was not disappointed.  It worked great...for about 2 weeks.  Out of nowhere it would not play a single video from any streaming service, displaying a "HDCP error" and advising me to unplug it and plug it back in.  Well that didn't work.  I did a 'system reset'.  Nope.  I changed the display type and dropped the resolution down to 780p.  Nope.  It even said HDCP compliant on the display type!  I went to the Roku forum and saw hundreds of other customers having the exact same problem - it worked for a while and then suddenly the HDCP error out of nowhere.  Some said it would go away for a while and then come back intermittently.  For many others like myself nothing worked.  I sense there is a firmware issue that Roku refuses to acknowledge.  Customers called into Roku only to be disconnected.  They said the customer service was horrible.  I'm returning it and buying the Amazon Stick.  Until Roku admits and addresses the problem I am done with them.  This is a big black eye for Roku.

1) The streaming seems flawless on this device - and on the "ultra", which I purchased first.2) There is a dizzying number of channels, and except for the movies at the apple store, you essentially get all the channels found on apple.3) Subscription for YouTube TV is $50 when you use the YouTube TV app in Roku. I'm told it is $55.00 if you subscribe to YouTube TV on Apple TV; you pay Apple $60.00 extra bucks per year - the price of a good Roku device.4) However, some areas are significantly less developed than others. It has excellent connectivity, and streaming, programming are great. But even though it’s been around for many years, it has some frustrating interface problems.a) You cannot setup any of the device parameter from your computer. On the other hand, Apps and individual channels allow you to setup setup online, and the settings are preserved from one Roku device to the other. An example is YouTube TV and PBS.b) On your computer, you can select Roku channels/apps and your work will apply to to all the devices. But you cannot setup any particular sequencing for the icons. You can sequence them on a device, but Roku doesn't let you share that sequencing on other devices. For example, if you want YouTube TV at the top, followed by Netflix, you must separately rearrange the icons on each device.c) The buttons on the remote are not programmable. If you don't want a subscription to Netflix, why should a button devoted to Netflix be in your face all the time? why should you be subjected to the risk of pressing the button in the dark? Roku's solution to accidental button presses is to ask: "are you sure you want to exit whatever you're watching?" - but this addresses a totally different problem. THERE SHOULD BE A WAY TO DEFEAT THESE BUTTONS OR TO PROGRAM THEM AS YOU WISH. Netflix pays money to Roku for this, but Roku subjects the customers to frustration, as they are likely to press the button my mistake and then have to go through several steps in order to get out of, for example, Netflix.Still and all, I think Roku is every bit as good as Apple TV. Roku's most expensive device, during discounts times, is less than half the price of Apple TV.
For my TV it works great just as advertised

Roku is simply the best system on the market.  FireTV and AppleTV are fine and solid performers, but Roku's open system still provides access to the widest range of programming outside of the wire based cable world.  The setup process was easy enough that my six year old grandson had the system up and running in ten minutes.  Voice commands work well and the range is greater than anything I will ever be able to take advantage of in my home.  I can stream 4K programming without any skipping or lag (keep in mind that this is dependent upon your own wireless network speed). So, you have a low cost way to expand your entertainment network by literally thousands of options.  What's not to like?  The only problem you will encounter is figuring out what to watch next.

I have now put in three sets of batteries after the set it came with since getting this in October.  Thought it might have just been a couple bad batteries, but finally put them into my TVs remote and all of them work perfectly fine there.  Very disappointing because the device itself is great.

Device works well.  But when mine failed, I discovered that Roku Customer Service is terrible.  They have no phone support.  So support must be done via Chat.  The back-and-forth was endless.  It took much too long to explain the situation and get the representative to offer a replacement device.  Chat dropped twice during dialogue and I had to start again from scratch.  Roku requires return of defective product *before* they will send a replacement.  Turnaround time is at least a week without the device.  The customer is on the short end of the Roku (Streaming) Stick.

We mainly bought this because Disney+ wasn't available on our Vizio smart TV.The good: 4k picture is great, the apps are pretty smooth, the remote works without having line of sight, the search function is fantastic, where I can just search on Roku and it will show me where the show is available and how much it costs to rent or buy.The bad: Amazon Prime only works for about 30 minutes before I start getting the "device is overheating" warning, which is weird because it rarely happens with other apps (probably more of a critique of Amazon Prime). There's a long delay after the Roku powers up until the remote starts working (it's like it's frozen for 10-20 seconds). For the first month we would sometimes lose audio entirely and have to restart. ESPN app didn't have audio at all while we tried to use it.
