Not sure if that ever got fixed.If I could go back I'd probably spend more money and just get an Apple TV.

Never used a Roku stick before but I wanted to cut cable. It was insanely easy to install and setup. A keyboard definitely would make the sign in process easier but I was able to proceed anyways.I didn’t like that you have to think about what you want to watch. With cable you flip it on and find something  interesting. I have gotten used to it though and have found some really great shows on Hulu. Nothing is Live. If I want Live the Hulu Live is an additional 54.99 per month. If I want News I guess Pluto is the way to go. With the Roku stick and streaming you can definitely binge on specific shows. In fact I over binged as I didn’t know how to change channels at first ( top arrow to left pulls up guide )Unfortunately I was unable to cut my cable completely. I added spectrum TV. I love love love it. I had direct TV prior and was paying about $300 per month for internet plus satellite tv. Crazy! With the roku stick on 2 of my TVs ... I have A spectrum DVR and cable on the main tv ( instant tv:)) and the spectrum tv app on the other 2.( a 4th tv has the Xbox one which can download the spectrum app). I still have Hulu for $5 a month . My total now is about $200. The Roku sticks have definitely helped me cut down on my tv entertainment bills. They are really easy to use for someone who isn’t tech savvy. They are portable since you create a Roku account ( free) and plug them into the hdmi spot on The TV. You can either plug them into a wall outlet or the usb tv port for power. They also act as the digital box you need to rent from your cable company if your TV isn’t smart.I feel that the Roku stick has allowed me to get closer to my goal of cutting cable completely. They are definitely user friendly:) Five stars Roku!!

I ordered this stick to get rid of cable and as I’m setting the stick up , I had to call Roku to set it up with the code and they wanted to charge money to have their services! Wtf it was never mentioned that I need to pay for their services to work the Roku stick , one I don’t have the money and 2 it was never mentioned anywhere while purchasing these device saying I would have to pay them to be able to use the rocku Stick . So has anyone else have to pay to use rocku ? This is unbelievable and I read everyone reviews on here before I bought the stick and no one ever mentioned this so do you have to pay lots of money to use this device?

I happen to get my first ROKU about a year back at Home Depot. It sat on the shelf for 6 months until I was at a location with high speed internet before I attempted to use it but since then, I have grown to use it with more and more appreciation each time.The first thing I did was to sign up for CBS All Access ($10US/mo) and I had Amazon Prime. The picture quality is definitely HD and as good or better than satellite HD with the upside that so many "channels" are available of my own choosing. There is a lot of free material available outside any subscriptions and beside the subscriptions, there is one-time buy offered on those things you really want. There is no charge for ROKU services and ROKU bills any charges through the provider you choose (simple set-up for each). After that, it's just like punching into a channel. On top of that, the ROKU Streaming Stick + offers voice recognition so you can search for things using voice prompts and ROKU is very good at it (actually excellent). If an old movie (or other video content) is available, ROKU can find it using a voice prompt. YouTube works the same way and voice prompting saves a lot of typed in requests for searching. I had very rare glitches on a 1.5MB/s internet connection, and none on my home 3MB/s service (though not using any other device at the time) - just rock-solid video and audio.In summary, I would recommend this item to anyone interested in streaming programming and feel it is a great deal for the low cost it is offered at.

So, I ordered a new Roku stick for my new TV. When I got the package, it appeared unopened, but when I went to do the setup, I didn't have to do all the steps I had to do with my previous Roku devices (pairing the remote, logging in, downloading apps, etc). I thought it was odd, but just figured that since I hadn't done it in awhile, things had changed. Then I went to the Netflix app. Lo and Behold, there was someone else's sign in, and credentials. Same with Amazon Prime. It appears that I got a return and it wasn't restored to the factory settings. So, not only did I get a retuned unit, I got one that had personal info on it.I did reset the unit to the original condition, then signed in to all the apps using my credentials. The unit works fine, and I do not plan to return in case this this happens  to someone else.Pretty bad form by Roku.

I bought a projector for outside but needed a way to show cable shows, Netflix, Disney+ and Amazon Prime video. I bought Amazon Fir Stick and it was easy and great but did not support Xfinity app unless you download a third party app. I then learned Roku supports them all. Bought this Roku stick and set-up was very easy and fast. All the streaming channels I have subscriptions with work and I have access to Xfinity cable so Cubs canes and HBO and other movies are accessible. Wonderboom Bluetooth speaker works but perfectly but had to figure out link it through phone first and then in Roku app click the headphones symbol for private audio and sound cane out speaker for movie. I’m now returning Amazon fire stick which is ironic bc I love Amazon and almost never return any purchases and I buy a lot of stuff and the one thing I return is their product. Weird.

Its a great piece of equipment and no other can beat it on price. If you have Netflix or Apple TV, you can log it in and it works great. My complain is more about Amazon Prime and its geographic limitations. Im using this outside of the US and there is an insane amount of content the is not licensed and you simply cannot watch it. That is a disappointment given that all this services are used where? On the world wide web! Access could be anywhere right? Funny but true. After two months, Im cancelling Amazon Prime Video as its annoying to sort out what to watch given all this restricted content.

Don’t need to control your TV and want a fire stick? This is literally it. It is pretty much the same as the 4K version in terms of speed, and I use this on my projector since the fire stick won’t be able to control it even if I want it to. Everything else is the same, and it is cheaper than the 4K version. I am thinking of setting a projector up in the basement too, so may grab another one of these for that. This is 100x better than roku sticks for a projector. Trust me, this is the way if you want to turn into projector into an entertainment powerhouse!

I bought this for a friend who doesn't have a smart TV, but owns two homes.  She can take this with her to her mountain cabin or use it down here in So LA county.  I haven't been able to give it to her yet because of Covid, but I'm sure she will find it useful.  I got it for her on black Friday when it was super cheap.  But when buying one of these for yourself, but the more expensive one that can control your TV as well.  This friend isn't that into TV, but she does like to watch YouTube religious videos, so this will work for her.

Bought it to use with the older TV....  almost bought another TV figuring the loss of sound must be a TV problem.  Turns out the new firestick is the reason the sound occasionally disappears and you have to reboot the firestick by unplugging it.  Previous version was loosing network connection in a similar manner.  Probably some sort of power saving features in the software that is not waking things up correctly.  Either way.  If you are looking for something, that just cheap and basic and works out of the box look somewhere else.

This thing is garbage when you look up the system X-ray in advanced developer options it does not show 4 processors in the CPU the CPU does not show up at all I call shenanigans Amazon is lying about this having 4:processors there's a huge difference between a 4K fire stick and this garbage I will never buy this model again stick to the 4K Fire Sticks they're worth the money all I could say is garbage you could tell the difference between a 4K fire stick and this bar none

At $17.99, this seems like a STEAL.  Has all the functionality of a regular HD FireStick with the exception of the ability to control the TV (on/off, volume up/down/mute) with the Firestick Lite remote.  If you can live without those features on the Firestick Lite remote, then this is a great buy.  Also, since this is part of Amazon's latest release of Fire TV products, I already got the software update to the new Fire TV interface, while my older Fire TV devices have not (coming in a few months to the older devices apparently).

I bought this FireStick Lite because I wanted to binge The Mandalorian on my TV rather than on my puny computer screen - but my TV was too old to get apps and my usual pathway to WiFi, a blu-ray player, kept removing apps from its available lineup and also was incompatible for Disney+.  Give me Fire!It streams Netflix better than my blu-ray ever did (just streams better overall really), gives me Disney+, and enables me to get a bunch of apps to watch a slew of TV shows and movies.  With its low price, it's been a bargain.

The firestick lite is an inexpensive way to provide streaming services to lesser used tvs in your home. It has a great number of apps available to install and if you have cable it might be a means to eliminate a cable box. Another plus is the remote which eliminates the need to use your phone to play the apps. Only issue I've experienced is that some buffering issues have occurred with some of the apps. I've used an ethenet adapter to resolve this problem. I haven't used Alexa with it enough to judge how well it works with it.

Initially I was pleased with the Firestick lite.  It was easy to set up but now I find when I try to connect to Fire TV there are problems with connecting to the internet.  I need to restart the Firestick one or more times before I can get the home screen. It requires a good bit of fooling around to get to Prime and is a bother.  The problem is not with my internet but with the Firestick.  I have not encountered this issue with my older Firestick.  I don't know if I have a bad unit or if it is a problem with the version of the Firestick.  I would not recommend the Firestick Lite.

3 stars because it works well when it’s properly functioning. The stick was working fine for the first 2 months, until a couple weeks ago it has been acting up. Once The Fire Tv Stick is turned on after being off there is no sound. Seems to be a recurring issue for other users as I was able to find a temporary resolution. I have to disconnect it and reconnect it DAILY.

After a lot of procrastination, we finally "Cut the Cord" and dumped our satellite provider. We signed up for YouTube TV and love it. With this Amazon Firestick, we have access to a lot more content and mobility. We now have three firesticks and each works very well. I was particularly pleased with how easy the setup was. And even more surprised that it was instantly compatible with a 14-year-old Visio 32" flat-screen TV.  I am also pleased that that old TV still works perfectly. I will probably get one more for the RV.

GREAT PRODUCT HANDS DOWN... DONT REALLY CARE ABOUT NOT BEING ABLE TO TURN THE VOLUME UP OR DOWN I HAVE A REGULAR REMOTE 4 THAT LOL ...I Was Originally just going to buy a replacement remote 4 my other Firestick Since The Phone App Stop picking it up due 2 A Wifi Problem,  But Seen The Price 4 This was About The Same ... NO BRAINER.. JUST BUY A NEW 1 (ESPECIALLY Since My Other 1 Is Maybe The 1st Model Made ...)I Like The Voice Control Also ... Beats Having To type In everything...Might Buy Another One Of The Price Is Still Low U CAN'T BEAT IT

I use a NAS to store and serve up videos, not only does the Fire Stick Lite get me access to all the popular streaming platforms (Amazon Prime, Disney, etc), but I can get to the NAS files more consistently than with other devices.It took me a while to find a video app I liked, but once I found it, I have been nothing but please every time I use the device.I love the simplicity of the remote the most: it does the basics very well!I have not used the voice recognition or built-in Alexa.

I bought this unit to test if I can use it as an additional cable outlet as opposed to renting and additional box from my cable provider. This proved to be a good experiment as all you need to do is download the appropriate apps for the channels you want to watch and login to them (a one time operation) using your cable providers credentials. If using this way you need to make sure you are subscribed to these channels with your cable provider ahead of time. You can also use without a cable provider but then would need to subscribe to each channel you want to see which could be more cost effective.

It's very easy to setup, just need to connect to the tv and internet.  There are so many tv apps  to choose from.  I use the sling to watch all my favorite channels and games. It's much cheaper than cable.  I finally can get rid of crazy cable bill. But the remote control is not good. Tooks me a while to figure it how to used and there is no power button. Everytime when the TV is off. The device is off too. When I turn the tv but the device won't turn on automatically.  I can't turn it on with remote control either.  I have to unplug to power and plug back in again to turn it on.

This worked as advertised and I like it very much.I do worry that Alexa is always listening.Not just when I push the microphone button.This is located in my bedroom and I often wonder if it counts how many times I pass gas in my sleep and then reports it to Bezos who then of course tells China who then of course tells Joe Biden. I don't mind them all knowing, I imagine they would be very impressed with not only the frequency of the events but also the volume and lengths.  I just hope it actually records ALL of them so I get proper credit.

MY FIRST TIME USING A FIRE STICK,  I LOVE IT,  SO SIMPLE TO SET UP, THANK GOD, I THOUGHT IT WOULD BE A DISASTER, BUT THE SET UP WAS GREAT, AND I IT WORKS PERFECT ,I NEVER THOUGHT I WOULD GET RID OF MY CABLE BOX, AND THAT EXPENSIVE  OVER RATED CABLE  BILL, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS FIRE STICK AND THE PRICE IS UNBEATABLE, I  HAVE ORDER 2 MORE, JEANETTE PARHAM

I have a $200 AppleTv and this.  For the money I will probably stick with the Fire stick from here on out.  I admit the AppleTv seems slightly speedier and more refined.  However, for the price this Fire stick is really hard to beat.  One thing I’ll say is that if you have a lot invested in a Vudu account this is absolutely not for you.  That app is not available.  Most of my stuff has been synced over movies anywhere though, so I’m good.  I can live with it only being available on my other premium streaming box.

Update: Amazon contacted my right after posting but could not help me. The stick just doesn’t work right with the app. Also, I got this new one because it’s got a much faster processor, but the new OS (which sucks) must be dragging it down because it’s slower than my old one.Replaced my 4 year old fire tv box with this stick. I use the app a lot to control the fire tv but this new one doesn’t connect to the phone more than half the time! The old one was much more reliable.Also, they asked for a rating on the volume control and there is none!

This works as well as the other Firesticks but doe not have TV power/volume integration, and that's fine if you are trying to save a couple bucks.I do ding these one star because the stick itself never turns off, and as with most computing devices they need to be powered down occasionally.  If you want to restart it you have to go through a series of menu selection until you get to the reboot screen.  Just give us the option to let it sleep or power down when you hit the power button.
Basics: faster then our 4K smart TV. Just 1080p, but still looks great. Love alexa on it. Great value!!!

Thank goodness everything was wrapped in plastic because the batteries had leaked everywhere. I wasn’t sure the plug would work since they were right next to them. Curious why the batteries themselves weren’t wrapped when everything else was since they’re the potential damaging component in the package. Also, I didn’t need the dongle due to my hdmi being at an angle, I had to use it because the stick is too wide for standard-distance placement between hdmi ports. So I’m glad it came in the package. They could have easily avoided this in design by making the stick narrower and longer.

This product is awesome.  It is so easy to install and an inexpensive way to access your digital movie content when you don't have a smart TV. Some of my username and passwords were able to sync by just opening the app my smartphone. I mean who honestly remembers all of their different passwords. If your on the fence do it. Definitely worth $20.

I purchased one for my tv upstairs and one for the tv downstairs. I thoroughly enjoy using this newer version of Firestick because I had an old one.  I enjoy the variety of shows and ease of use. It has better functionality, is faster, and has better on-screen layout than the older model.  I like it so much that I bought one for my daughter and son-in-law as a gift during the holidays.  They both enjoy using their Firestick TV with Alexa.. I highly recommend Firestick to anyone who is thinking about purchasing it.

Works well with my older Samsung TV that has outdated apps that no longer work. It was really easy to install all of the apps I use (Netflix, Hulu, ESPN, Disney+). I found instructions online to download HBO max as well. The only drawback is that the fire stick wasn’t able to get enough power through the USB outlet in my TV. I had to run an extension cord with a splitter up behind my TV to plug in through the USB adapter so that my cords were still hidden. Overall, it’s a great value to access streaming apps. I recommend getting one for every TV.

We have a 10-year old non-smart TV. It still has good pictures and sound, so it was worth finding an inexpensive solution to get it online. We looked into the original Fire TV Stick but it didn't support YouTube TV. Fortunately, the new one does, and it works great. Set-up took about 5 minutes, and then maybe another 5 to register with Netflix and YouTube TV Prime Video pops up right away. Alexa integration is good ("Play videos by Ike and Tina Turner.")For the money, I don't think you can go wrong.

I've gone back and forth between Roku and Amazon Fire TV Sticks and I'm leaning to the Fire TV Stick. I do think the Roku interface is better. The Fire TV Stick plays on integrated content with your Amazon account so if you're fully invested in Amazon services, the Fire TV stick is a better option. What tips the scale for me however is the ability to integrate 3rd party apps like TiviMate and various IPTV type services. Roku still has no good answer for that and if you're cutting the cord with your cable provider, Amazon is a better choice.
I got a small 14" portable tv and wanted a way to get streaming for it and not pay such cost. works great and I found almost all the channels I wanted with ease

I'm a big fan of the Amazon FireStick. It's a great streaming device. Lots of content, easy to set up and use, affordable -- it's terrific. However, if you already have a FireStick 2nd Gen, it's not worth upgrading to the new one. I saw that this new stick had a faster processor, so I upgraded and it IS faster, but not enough to make it worth the $40. If you're moving up to the 4K model, then, yes, it's a good upgrade (if you have a 4K TV). But it's not enough faster than the 2nd Gen to make it a smart decision to upgrade.

I purchased two of the Roku Stick + units, having the same problem with both.The remote and unit frequently lose the ability to connect and I find myself taking the batteries out of the remote in order to control the Stick.I have been a Roku supporter since they first came out many years ago, this is the most frustrating unit yet.When it works, it works well, but you cannot depend on being able to use it without frustration.I purchased a Roku Ultra and I am very pleased.My recommendation, skip the Stick + and buy an ultra or a Roku 3 if you can find one.

The setup was awful and it forces you setup a Roku account and insert credit card info. Luckily you can go into your account on a computer and remove the credit card, but that is not cool at all.You can't connect to any Bluetooth devices, unless it is Roku specific products. Lame.The ads on the main screen are pretty annoying. The main reason I got this was to get away from the Amazon excessive self advertising on their FireStick, but this isn't a whole lot better. Really annoying when we pay for these things.The remote works fine but I don't care for the volume and mute being on the side, is just awkward and annoying. I thought I would get used to it, but I haven't.The only good thing is it performs pretty well and streaming quality looks very good. I also like that I can search for a TV show or movie and get a list of services it is on and the price - FireStick doesn't do that.Overall, meh... I'm about ready to just get a PC on a stick and put Linux on it, get a mouse/keyboard remote, and be done with this crap.

Well compared to my Roku ultra and myRoku express. This stream stick is garbage. My tv doesn’t see it and this stream stick is running really hot. And amazon tech support wants me to wait and see. Nope not going to mess up my new 55 inch lg tv. I am going to send this thing back. And if they give me any crap. I am shopping elsewhere. Amazon customer support has degraded lately. Sad. I just want to send this defective product back. Get something that works.

Love Roku and decided to upgrade my dad's Roku to go with his 4K tv and I thought the stick would be easier, more convenient. I have the Roku 3 and it's great. I realize this may sound ridiculous but I didn't think it would have to have cords attached (I'm so sick of cords everywhere!), but I should've just got the other Roku for 4K...I still would've had cords but not the problem I encountered with this one. I can't stand the design on this one. The way the cord plugs into the stick, it's on the top of the stick and hangs down around the top instead of plugging into the bottom of the stick. The result is, it pulls on the stick, which kept creating a loose connection with the port. It was a real pain and I thought a bad design. Because of that we constantly were getting the purple screen. Next time I'll skip getting the stick type.

I had an old Roku and didn't realize it was the reason my sling TV was super slow to change channels, always buffering, and my TV remote was useless to change the volume. I always blamed it on the internet. I literally had to set the volume I wanted, turn off the TV and turn it on again. What a disaster. Not sure why it didn't occur to my little pea brain sooner, but I thought maybe I should upgrade my Roku. So happy I did. It's been a game change for my nightly TV watching routine. Everything moves fast, and the single remote can now turn on and off the TV AND control the volume. This has been life changing.

Roku has come a long way since I last used one many years ago. This thing is a just a stick yet it performs well. My favorite surprise feature was when I realized I could use the Roku app on my iPhone and iPad to send the audio to my AirPod pros (or whatever headphones you happen to be using with your phone/tablet) and use the noise cancelling features of my AirPods which is great.  The streaming quality is superb. Navigating the interface isn’t super speedy but it’s not sluggish either.Another plus of this stick is its ability to use hotel and dorm Wifi. I couldn’t manage to get my chrome cast device to work with hotel Wifi because of the sign-on page the hotel uses, but it was pretty easy using this stick and my iPhone/iPad. I’m not sure if it would be possible if you don’t have a smart phone or tablet with you.

There are a ton of options for streaming on line. Recently my Samsung big screen smart system died & it's crazy expensive to fix. But, the TV itself still worked great & I can connect it to my laptop (but this is a huge PITA). I also have a small TCL model 6 in the bedroom and really love it's Roku platform. So, I decided to try this streaming stick before I said F'it and just buy another big screen (which seems like a waste when the TV still works). I'm glad I did!The Roku stick connects great & works flawlessly! I really like the voice feature on the Roku. And it has IMO the easiest to use interface. I'd totally buy this again! And for around $40 bucks, it fixed a $1000 TV. Yay!

I bought this because I thought it was just a USB stick that plugs in to your TV. What it actually is, is a stick that plugs in to your hdmi port but still needs a charger! You still have to find a way to stretch this tiny cord to an outlet, directly from the stick plugged in to the back of the tv. Which means not only do I still have cords to deal with, I can't even hide them as well as the old Roku (which already did not work well). They stick directly out the side of my tv (the cord won't reach if I plug it into the back of the tv).It also did not allow me to skip the "option" of having the roku remote control the tv power and volume, which I absolutely do not want.Roku somehow made a WORSE product than the defunct one I was trying to replace.

So I have a 5 year old LG TV and a separate sound system. The TV does not control sound through the optical port out for my sound system (just outputs max line level volume always then set my amplifier to a reasonable level). Currently I have a mini computer, which I can control the sound through my wireless keyboard. Therefore the Roku, while it controls the TV sound is unable to control the output to my sound system. Called tech support and they said my TV is too old, although it's not that old... Don't see why the roku can't just control the sound out from the HDMI like a computer can, maybe it takes too much extra electronics. Also, I can't buy a receiver with IR and control it from the remote either because it's only programmed with TV IR codes for some reason (it specifically says cannot control AVR in setup...), seems like another thing they could have added... Either way it doesn't work so I'll either return it or get a pass through line level volume controller with it's own remote, not ideal but it might work.

The wifi connected remote NEVER worked properly from day 1.I ordered the longer dongle, which made ZERO difference - and also a new remote; same story.I found an odd work-around out of frustration, by simply pushing on the remote buttons repeatedly until the remote finally connected with the device, and that lasted for a year.Now, almost a year to the date of purchase, NEITHER of my two remotes will connect, and neither will my iphone using the ROKU app.My tech level knowledge I'd rate at 7 out of ten, and I know how to manipulate my wireless router to allow for different masking and sub-categories relevant to setup of this device.  All attempts have failed, and I am positively TIRED of looking for workarounds.I will attempt to get ROKU to rectify this situation.  Like I said, this is a good unit WHEN it works.I do like the wireless remote, but it is THE weak point of this system.As info I have an older basic Roku unit that is nearly 8 years old, and it still works flawlessly in a separate room, on an older tv.  Makes me wonder if I should have purchased another one of THOSE instead of the Streaming Stick Plus??I like the speed of this unit, and the menus are intuitive and functional - better than the onboard android OS on my Sony Bravia TV.I do on occasion, also experience the Dual-Screen "green-out" anomaly that others have reported as well. But that is an easy fix with a simple restart.I dont think I'd buy THIS particular unit again - but I do like ROKU.Support online has been mediocre to this point, and it took jumping through some hoops and a few nasty emails to get them to send me a new dongle and remote at the beginning of this year long journey.

Am sick and tired of the cable companies and their pricing. But am not going to go into that here. These Roku units have helped us sever the cords and we are not turning back. We got the voice recognition due to the fact that we were hoping for a better search feature. Its ok but not great. The Roku device does provide for a affordable way to watch TV. Multiple channels. and of course if you're not careful you can run up the monthly bill. We are still finding channels that we like. Only complaint so far is the speed seems slow even though we have pretty good (GB) internet. But its a fair trade off for the money we will save.

I got a Roku TV and love it so now I'm getting rid of a cable box and replacing the firestick with a Roku. The main issue with the firestick is it's not compatible with the Spectrum channel and I really need to have that. Plus now all my devices are on the same format. Add a channel to one and they all have it. Set up was pretty simple. I have a Roku TV and two Roku sticks. Not sure what some reviews were talking about having to pay a registration. I didn't have to pay anything extra to have 3 devices on my account.The devices work well, no issues using the remote. The remote is super easy to sync to the TV so you can operate the volume and power. Just go to set up, music plays, when the music stops, hit the button. The Roku TV is better than the stick as it starts up right away and seems a bit more responsive so while this works great, getting Roku built into the TV is even better.So I guess that's my only con to this, it does take half a minute to get started watching something. Also wish it could navigate the guides a bit faster. It would be nice if I could just speak the channel number while on the Spectrum guide but it tries to take me to another app/channel.

If you're watching 4K video the stick will overheat very easily. Luckily, I have 3 HDMI ports on the back of my 4K tv. I had to move the stick from HDMI 1 to HDMI 2 because the stick ruined the first port due to overheating. I have it placed in a well-ventilated area but it doesn't seem to help the issue. I have ordered an HDMI extender to get the stick away from the TV port. Hopefully, that will solve the problem.Also, the ROKU stick does NOT have a web browser!  What? Not recommended.

The ROKU device works great if the WiFi is currently active, but if the previous connected wifi is not active, this devices is horrible.I use two different Hotspots that I use to connect to the Roku.  If the last connected device is not on, Roku is not smart enough to scan for the 2nd wifi connection.  When it is searching for the 1st wireless connection it locks up the entire system for 2-3 minutes while it tries to connect.  You can't use the back button, search for new wifi, etc until it finally gives up.  It is a major pain when I have to switch between Wifi/Hotspot connections.  Every other digital device I have ever owned knows to scan previous used wifi connections if the first one is not available.  Major disappointment.

Been using Roku for years. the nice thing about it is all the apps that you can use on it. Also if you have Xfinity/Comcast you can get rid of one of your small digital boxes that you use in like bedrooms that I think at like $7 month. You can get the Comcast/Xfinity stream on this and watch all your channels. So basically this will pay for itself of in like 3 to 5 months depending on what Roku Device you get.

I would have given this 5 stars, but the Streaming Stick + does not live up to the claim of extended wifi range. Mine is about 30 feet away from the router. It sometimes plays video quality worse than the crappiest VHS. When it works well, which is most of the time, it buffers at the most inopportune moments. Within 20 feet it probably works great.12/09/2019 - I am amending this review. I got sick of constant buffering and crappy picture. Tonight, it would not connect to the internet at all. I tried rebooting everything, 0 Mbs. My laptop, across the room was connected at 20Mbs. I switched the Streaming Stick + with the Roku Express in my bedroom and the connection speed matched the computer! I put the Streaming stick + in the bedroom, 15 feet closer to the router, and got a whopping 6 Mbs. What a piece of crap! The Express version works 3x better at half the price, twice as far away from the router! Do not buy this over-priced piece of garbage!

Arrived on time in solid packaging. Very, very pleased with my purchase. I cut the cord years ago but I've been steadily looking for a platform that met all my needs and wants, that didn't cost an arm and a leg, and didn't take a NASA engineer to hook up. I got EVERYTHING and MORE! I was THRILLED to only make a one-time purchase and have no monthly fee. This mini-computer hooks up to the back of your tv in a snap, and if you can use a cell phone, you can program it. Very clean, simple user interface; thorough, but concise, directions. Once I got it hooked up, I was astounded by all the choices. I don't watch much regular TV at all, but I can get a reel of my local and regional newscasts, the big three US networks stream 24/7, and the choices of tv show/movie programming is mind-boggling. You can use Prime or any of the other major streaming channels, they have TONS of free programming, and you can order any movie ever produced, basically. You can get music channels, watch YouTube, and I'm sure I'll discover more. I upgraded and got the voice remote. This has everything Xfinity has and way more than Spectrum, with no stupid $85/mth for basic cable. Oh, if you're a FoxNews fan or any channel that only comes with a cable subscription, you do have to sign in with that. But I don't watch any 24/7 news so that wasn't an issue for me. If you're looking to cut the cord and still get value out of your programming choices, buy this. I consider this one of the most valuable, cost-effective purchases I've made in recent memory. 100% satisfied. They could design volume modulation between apps but I can live with it.

Extremely disappointed in this Roku. I purchased this because my other Roku would lose connection to the internet often. This one is not much better. It took forever to set up because I couldn’t connect. Finally I have it working, and after just a few days I had to change the batteries. Only a week later the remote was dead again. And, I only used the Roku a handful of times. Replaced batteries a third time, again they only lasted one week. And, I am using good Equalizer batteries! After reading the reviews, I see this is a consistent problem with this Roku.

Tired of paying the increasing cable bill - for the 300+ stations of which were mostly duplicates or foreign-language versions of the others (not to mention all the shopping channels that are useless to me) - I cut the cable, opted to test ROKU because of what I saw some friends had while using it, and I do NOT regret it at all (cable even has ads on some ROKU channels). It opens up a entirely new viewing arena - one that truly allows you to cater your viewing to your time, needs and desires (plus, with Amazon Prime! - wow! tons of movies). I get the local news - if and when I want - the national and global news, and am saving tons of money! I think the quality of the pix for the most part are better than cable.

This streaming stick consistently overheats and crashes after a few hours of use. The manufacturer provided an extension cable that was supposed to fix the problem but it doesn't. Now It loses the voice stream after a few hours of use and eventually crashes and loses its information regarding streaming services. It also pulls more power from the usb port than the Sony Bravia is willing to provide.I have used roku devices for many years and this is the worst product I have had from Roku.I would not buy again and I would not reccommend it to anybody.

We just got rid of our cable tv package, which was not my idea. I loved my dvr box. My husband has used a Roku stick for the past year. We do not have smart tv’s. Upon set up my husband swapped my new Roku stick for his older one because this newer Roku model is able to control the tv’s power and the volume control, eliminating the need for two remotes.  There is definitely a learning curve to using a Roku stick and setting it up, at least there is for for us middle-aged parents. I’m not sure my elderly parents could figure this out. The only disappointment so far has been the Duracell batteries that came with the Roku stick were almost dead and it took me a while to figure that out as I thought the remote wasn’t working but it turns out the batteries were just dead.  My husband prefers the Roku to the Firestick. We own both. This Roku comes with the charging block, remote, smart stick and an extension cable.  It has no trouble streaming with our spectrum WiFi.

Lots of problems with function. I was really looking forward to Roku being better than our Fire TV sticks. A cousin talked Roku up so I bought one. I am not happy with it.First off, the remote fails to connect to the Roku stick EVERY TIME I USE IT. I have to carry the remote to the TV, take off the remote cover and push the pairing button several times to get it to work. I have paired the remote several times it does not help.Also, the Roku often gets the time alignment messed up -- sound and video do not match. The sound it a couple of seconds behind the video. To fix this I have to turn off the TV unhook the Roku. Reinstall the Roku and restart the TV. It's not a big deal, except that I have to do this a few times a week. This NEVER happens, or has happened with firetv sticks.I have contacted Roku support three times with no real help. They're very confusing on customer service and tech support. All done in emails. They have not been of any help thus far.I'm pretty disappointed in the Roku streaming stick plus. Wish I'd never bought it and had just reset my old firesticks before I bought it. After resetting the firetv sticks and reinstalling apps, these years old streaming sticks run circles around the Roku for less money.

Wow. Loved the Roku at 1st. It worked great. Fast forward a few months... my son and I watched several videos- maybe an hour ot two. The unit cut off. We were perplexed. He went to reset it and it was hot, when I say hot, I mean REALLY HOT. We decided to let it be for the night. A few days later, we wanted to watch a movie so we tried to fire it up... NOPE, would not connect.  We tried all hdmi ports, we googled blinking lights and how to reset and error messages, etc. NOTHING worked.  We gave up. Now, about a month later, I decide to try again, even bought new cord and checked the TV for issues - still cannot connect to the thing. Very disappointed with this purchase. Thought we were going to do better with the Roku vs the firestick, but seems they both have flaws. So sad that I can't watch my show 😢

Late last year I broke my 1080p tv. Luckily was able to get a brand new 4k tv a few months later. At first I thought since it was a 4k smart tv I could watch 4k movies. Man was I wrong. Learned only select devices can no matter the tv. So I knew it was time for a new Roku player (had a gen 1 so didn't look good even on 4k). After shopping around and asking questions I went with the Roku streaming stick+. I love it. It even makes non 4k movies and shows look amazing. For the price its so worth it. I was nervous at first because I read my 4k tv needed hdcp 2.2 hdmi outlets or else at best would be 1080p and I couldn't find anything in the manual and behind the tv to say it did. But found out through research my tv did.What is also nice is the fact its not a box, its a stick that goes into a hdmi port (rather then hdmi cable connecting the two) so less clutter on the shelf. Also you don't need to aim the remote directly at it to use it. You can be in front of a wall and it would work. So no need to worry about where you stick it in the tv (for me the hdmis were behind the tv and not on the side).  It is your typical Roku player, has the same apps as the first gen plus any 4k apps (there is a section for it). Also some of the apps (Netflix, hulu) looks completely different then their older model counterparts so had to get used to it.The remote is your standard Roku. Same set up with some very nice features. If you sync it to your tv you can turn off the tv without tv remote and even control the volume (volume controls are on the side) so makes it easier versus using two remotes. A very nice feature is audio control. Kind of like siri or alexxa.. You push the button and make a command to open an app or search for a movie, show or app.Overall the pros are great and cons are nothing to worry about. Id do some research before buying to make sure your tv has the right hdmi ports or else you spent more money on the same thing as a cheap model for non 4k tvs. Defiantly recommend.Pros:-amazing picture for both 4k and hd-No box-don't need to aim remote at device-price-remote features-voice controlCons:-needs a specific hdmi for it to work-some apps are different then the ones on other Roku models

I've owned multiple Roku devices over the years.  I took a chance on the stick and regret the purchase.  This seems to be powered by a combination of wall plug and USB port.  It starts very slow.  After watching for twenty minutes, it delivers a low power warning and will no longer work.  USB etc is providing power, the device status light is properly illuminated.  I suggest you skip this particular product and buy one of the higher quality Roku devices.  Alos, this device is not portable.  If you travel with it and plug it in, you get stopped with a notice that the device can only be used in your home where you first registered it.  Not consumer friendly.

Weve had Rokus for years.  This one is great as well, minus 1 major problem.  It drains batteries within 2 weeks or so with very little use.  You'd be spending plenty in batteries over 1 years time.  Roku failed. The remote must be "looking" for the roku when the TV is off, I cant think of any other reason why the batteries would drain. I have a replacement coming, so we will see if the issue is persistent.Update: Got the  new roku stick from Amazon, thanks to their great return policy. Unfortunately it was not a defective issue. Again same problem. The remote kills batteries within a week with little use.  Solution? I thought I would move on without the remote and just download the roku app to use my phone as the remote.  STILL A FAIL!  The app will not "see" the Roku stick, and it wont even connect manually using the IP address.  What a joke.  Come on Roku, the user interface is the most important part of the device.  If I dont have a remote control, how can i use it?

I purchased for an older Polaroid flat tv used in a bedroom and had issues from day one.  I always assumed the issues stemmed from the older tv, not the Roku. At first I was able to unplug the tv, let stand ten minutes, and it would start up just fine with access to Roku apps.  I would need to do this unplug routine each time, finally that work around stopped working all together.  I changed the Roku batteries a number of times.  During this time, the tv itself was clearly getting power. Finally, after a little over two months of minimal use, I placed the tv in the garage for garbage and gave the Roku to my son.  This Roku is an upgrade for the one that he has because he's able to control the volume and such. After hooking the "new" Roku up, it did not work for him either. His tv is not even a year old and never had any issues with the older Roku. We quickly determined it wasn't my older tv that was the issues but the Roku itself. Unfortunately at this time, I no longer have the packaging and for all I know, it's past it's return period anyways.  Going forward, I will purchase in person at a box store.

This was my third Roku device purchased.  Up until now I was extremely happy and would highly recommend Roku to all of my friends and family.  I was having difficulty with the Roku that was in my bedroom mainly because my room is located at the furthest location from my wi-fi so I decided to try the streaming device with the long-range wireless.  I received the device and set it up just like the others, put in information, etc.  At this point I was given a code to enter online to activate my Roku, which I did and was given a phone number to call to assist.  I did this and here is where the problems begin.  For the first time ever from Roku, I was given the hard sell.  I had told them that I had Spectrum and the customer service rep began telling me about how I could pay them a one time $100 fee to get 500 channels or $150 to get 1000 channels.  I said "no thank you, just activate my device."  Pressure continues.  I finally said that I'm not giving out my credit card number and I have never had to with my 2 previous roku devices.  He finally activates it.  Still trying to sell me the other channels.  I say "no thank you" a final time then hang up.  A short time later my device has been deactivated and here is the worst part, ALL OF MY DEVICES HAVE BEEN SHUT DOWN!!  I'd like to give them another chance but as of right now I am a very DISSATISFIED customer!

I really don't like that. In order to get the device to work, you must sign up for an account with them and have a credit card on file.  For a company that advertises on and on about "free" that was a bit of a shock. It really should say that up front in the description.

I'm posting this review mostly to document my experience with Roku support.  I have three of these in my home, and am pretty happy with how they work.  Recently, one of them "bricked", not sure if it was due to an update or just hardware failure (after about 7 months of use).  Went on Roku and did chat-based support.  It took about 30 minutes to walk through the hard reset, restart, etc. steps with the rep that I had already done.  When we got to the end of the process, the rep sent me an RMA number and address to mail my Roku stick to.  A week, later, I got a replacement.  Bottom line, the company stand behind its product.The product hasn't really changed, although I did notice that the remote now has a "non-slip" type finish as opposed to the slick glossy finish my previous remotes had (which is a little nicer).  Yet to be determined if the remote eats batteries as quickly as the old one.Other than the remote's battery consumption, my only complaint as a multiple device owner has to do with setup.  When activating the Roku, I have to go through the whole "channel selection" setup again, which is kind of annoying.  My devices are registered with Roku, and they should know what I use.  It's also painful to have to re-register each channel (Hulu, Netflix, etc.) but I'm guessing that is because of "differences of opinion" in how registration should work (i.e. does Hulu trust Roku to act as an authentication proxy).

It works as well as all my previous Fire TV Sticks, but keeps dropping the audio. I have to reboot before using it every day, and sometimes more than once. I hope it goes away after the next update as it seems to have started after the new software version release came out this month. Fingers crossed. Great value for functionality though to get the most out of a Prime subscription.

That's essentially my critique. I love the features and that I can play my music from Amazon on it. The bad side is, it freezes. The sound disappears and I have to unplug it and plug it back in like we do frozen computers. Seeing as the tv is on the wall with little wiggle room, it's a royal pain.I like that you can't see it (I'd been using an ancient Roku that no longer worked for anything but Pandora). I have to give it time to see if I'd buy it for my main TV.

When my LG Smart TV became a non-SMART tv (known problem with LG TVs), I was contemplating on either getting it fixed or just buying another smart TV.  But then I saw the FireStick lite for $18, so I gave it a try.  It arrived the next day and I immediately hooked it up and downloaded apps...I got my "smart" TV back.  It works great on wifi.  Since my tv is located just on the other side of the wall where our router is, I don't need the adapter.  No buffering.  I like it so much that I bought another one for another TV.

The Fire Stick Lite is the upgrade that I've been waiting for. I purchased the first generation Fire Stick when it came out and it worked wonderfully. But then it began to slow down response-wise so I knew it was time to step it up! But I can say the 1st Gen Fire Stick ran its course very well, and the Fire Stick Lite is that next level for streaming music, movies, and so much more. I couldn't be more happier with this upgrade. One of the best choices I've ever made.

I love the Firestick and all of the smart features it added to a dumb TV. However, the only drawback is the Firestick disrupts my cable service everytime my wife watches it. So, that means every time she wants to switch back to cable, I have to reboot the system. I've recently been doing a fix I have found online, "Fire Stick causes interference with my TV when viewing with an HD antennae. Only fix is to unplug Fire Stick from wall outlet." In the end, I'm hoping for a permanent fix so that I can enjoy the Firestick without getting off the couch.

I installed this on the back of a Samsung television (HDMI port). I used a spare USB port connection on my Netgear mesh network satellite instead of plugging it in with the 120VAC USB power adaptor that it comes with. I was getting an error message saying not supported device and insufficient/low power but it runs just fine despite the error message. This is just a little tip in case you are strapped for 120VAC sources behind your television like I was. I didnt have any room to add the 120VAC USB power adaptor. The software update took a little longer than I would have liked to have waited but oh well.  I am happy with the remote despite it not being able to control my televisions volume, I figured it was worth saving the $10.

This worked surprisingly easy on our 42 inch Samsung.  Connection was a piece of cake, and to get it set up was done automatically.  Only thing to remember is to have your passwords handy to connect to your paid services such as  Netflix and also your wifi connection.  Flipping from the Firestick services back to our Direct TV is really easy. The only downside, which isn't a problem for us is that you have one more remote to deal with!  Buying one for my 84 yr old father now that I know how easy it is to use!

Just got it today and the installation was a bear...after freezing multiple times, unplugging and plugging in again and again, using advice from the internet about resetting, etc, it finally installed.From the looks of it it may bite the dust soon, like another stick I had. They keep shipping shoddy products, be it the hardware or the software. The irony is: the programs, like children's stuff via Prime are terrific, so other offerings.... go figure...

Our cable bill got very high and on top of that our carrier charged a late fee because the post office did not our payment to them on time, one day late, post mark show it was mailed in time. We made the purchase of a second fire tv control and found so many free channels to watch. The picture and sound are great and it only took a few minutes to set up. This is the best way for us to watch tv and not have to scan channels all day to find something to watch.

I had a Firestick with TV control already, however, my particular TV brand was not supported. I wanted another Firestick anyway, and used my original Firestick for a TV that was supported, and purchased this one for the TV that wasn't. It works exactly the same as the original one, you just can't control your TV with it. In my case, it was no loss. The set up was easy, quick, and using it is simple and self explanatory. For an older or off brand TV, this is a great alternative at a lower price.

I was really happy with my Roku stick + at first. I'm still happy with the Roku but the remote is quitting on me bit by bit. It worked fine at first but then the Back button (the one by the OK button) stopped working. Now this week the Up button stopped working. I'm wondering if the Next button and the Down one will stop next.I've looked all over their site and the Roku tips and troubleshooting channel and can't find anything that addresses this problems. I changed the batteries. I reseated the batteries multiple times.I tried re-pairing the remote to the TV. I have tried every remedy I could find and not only do none of them work but it's slowly getting worse.I would have rated this quite highly if not for the remote issue. I've ordered one of their HDMI extender cables but somehow I don't have a lot of faith in it working either. I've only had this since July which seems really soon for the remote to stop working right. I wonder if they just expect me to order a new remote every 6 months or so.PS  I wrote this but got distracted and never submitted it. The remote suddenly started working the same day the extender arrived. Since it was here, I went ahead and connected the extender anyway, even though the remote was now working again. All went well for a while but today the remote went on semi-strike again.Not only can I not use the up or back buttons near the OK button again but now when I try to operate the remote, it randomly goes to a window asking if I want to add ESPN. (For the record, I definitely do NOT.) I tried rebooting and now it wants me to sign into my internet account, something I can't do because the remote won't move the cursor up or back.For the record, I have a Roku Ultra in the living room and it works great. For that matter, when the remote feels like working, the Stick is great too. The thing is, however, that if you can't count on it to work, the Stick is useless. I'd return the thing if I weren't past the return date. If you want a Roku, pay extra and get the Ultra. Don't waste your money and sanity on this version. Seriously, run away fast and hard from it.

I got fed up with The constant “low storage” notifications from my Fire TVs and decided to try a Roku. After setting it up I immediately bought 2 more and ditched all my Fire TVs. Overall experience is a bit cleaner since you’re not constantly beaten over the head with Prime Video recommendations and banner ads. The app sign in experience seems better overall and the companion app is a huge step up over FTV. The private listening feature is an unexpected winner for me, it allows you to shift the audio from the Roku to your phone which is great for late night viewing.

I ordered my first Roku in 2012.  It was an LT.  it has been great!  When we upgraded to a 4K tv, I wanted to get a 4K streaming device, so I ordered this.  The picture is really awesome and we have not had buffering issues, like we had started having with our LT.  It was nice at first to not have to point the remote at an IR device.  Despite all the channels and niceties of the device, two things were annoying.  Only one of this things so bad that it absolutely won’t work for us.  First, the addition of amazon ads was a surprise and a TRULY annoying one, as now we need to have our children cover eyes and mute the tv during ads.  Typically they are ok, but we have a particularly visually sensitive child and he can’t handle some of them.The thing that made us have to return this twice and downgrade to the Roku Express is the fact that the remote will NOT stay paired.  It goes great for initial setup but loses the remote soon thereafter.  It says there is a paired remote, but it does not work.  This happened the first time and we thought it was a fluke so we returned it.  The second one did the same.  At this point I don’t want anything that pairs with a remote via WiFi.  So, I looked at the ones that I am assuming are infrared and it just seemed silly to pay for the premiere so we are going to try the express.  It doesn’t have 4K so I am very frustrated, but there is no way I am buying the Ultra.  If the express doesn’t work I am not sure what I will do.  I have read similar negative reviews where the remote would not stay paired so I am not the only one with this issue.  Such a disappointment!

I bought this streaming device for our basement that we use for friends at at times as a rental. I've never owned a roku and was at first hesitant because due to being so used to iOS streaming device.Since I didn't want to spend so much money, I decided to go with the streaming stick. It honestly took me about 10 minutes out the box to set up (would have been less but have to test volume, screen, etc). All I had to do was plug in to HDMI cable, attach power cord to stick and then that cord to usb behind tv an viola! (note: if for some reason the stick doesn't fit or is to tight, you can get a free HDMI extender from ROKU).Pros:Easy set-upUser friendly interfaceRemote has Netflix/Disney +/Hulu and Sling buttonsHas a un-biased platform (basically, all apps are available on Roku, including xfinity stream-can't get this on iOS).Has a free (ad-supported) channel called the Roku channel. This is good for cord cutters.Cons:Bulky Remote

I love the Roku product. They have always been easy to set up, easy to use and they stream great. I've got smart TV's and they tend to be wonky at times. Some of the apps on my TV won't load, or they have to be restarted. Roku fires right up and is a great product. I ordered this one for an older smart TV it was easy to connect to the WiFi, and aside from having to log into all of my apps (which you have to do for any new device like this) it was great. Roku has a mobile app as well, so i can use my phone as a remote, and i can plug my headphones into the app to listen as well. Works great at night when others are sleeping, or when you have a fan or other background noise. I just ordered the Roku sound bar for our living room!

This does not complete the setup procedure.Calls to their support was fruitless. They suggested that the stick was defective and I should send it back to Amazon. Not only did the replacement have the same problem, buying a third one behaved the same problem. It updates for new software and loops back to the beginning. Checking the users group, many other people who like me had the misfortune of also purchasing this product. Now with Covid 19, you cannot have a live conversation with tech support, not even by chat, you have to email them and they get back to you in 24 hours. Having email them of all I did, rebooting my router maybe 1 times, even though all my other wireless products were working fine, that was their suggestion, I knew they were wrong. There last suggestion was to try it on another tv. I have up. As an electronic technician, I question what that have to do with this issue. Should I throw my TV in the garbage. My feelings are that there is a software problem. If they are correct, which I doubt, the product should be sold with a list of television’s that are not comparable with this unit. So in short I put back my older Roku and it works fine, although it is not a 4K.Beware

I've had Roku's for years, the erector set solution for streaming. Complaints in the past have been more along the line of having to unplug the device every week or so, otherwise it would just turn unresponsive (you think they'd put a reset switch on it). Bought a new one hoping for improved performance.....and now I must pair my remote with the stick at random times. Simply said, poor quality remote. Amazon was nice enough to show me how to do the pairing (I'm lucky enough to have had a remote with the pair button on it), but frankly pairing the remote multiple times a day is pretty lame.So......I bought a replacement remote, looks like the one that came with the unit, but alas it doesn't have the pairing button, and when paired with no instructions and a little time on the internet yielding nothing.....I'm done with Roku.If you like spending your time getting cheap commodity equipment to work, this unit is for you. I'm going to try the Firestick and see if it is any better.

Update 12-22-19: Have to knock this down to 3 stars from 5. Not sure what the issue is here but 30-40% of the time we switch from watching TV over to the HDMI for the Roku the thing is hung up. Sometimes it snaps out of it after 30-60 seconds but today for the first time I had to restart the TV. SUPER annoying.We finally replaced our 5-year-old box unit because we were tired of seeing the mess of cords around the TV. This stick works fantastic. Just a couple of things to note.1. Same old user interface that has always been there--totally fine with us because it makes sense and works.2. Plugs into HDMI port in TV but also REQUIRES power via the 4" USB dongle. So your USB port needs to be right next to  the HDMI port or the dongle won't work. We have an OLD TV where there was an HMDI port on the side but no USB so that was out. I am sure you can get an extension for that but we never looked into it. It also comes with a wall power adapter but that defeats the point in some ways, we were trying to get rid of wires. Also some HDMI ports are close together and it may be difficult to get the wide ROKU stick plugged in while other components are plugged in. The manual states that if this is a problem you can contact Roku for a free HDMI extender dongle.3. The downside to plugging ROKU dongle into your TV's USB power is that the ROKU has to start up each time you power up your TV. Not a deal breaker for us but it takes a minute or so to power it up so just something to think about.4. The remote is perfect. It's not complicated and it just works. Some how we can adjust our TV volume with it and did not have to set anything up, that's a nice touch. It also has a Netflix button, Disney+, Sling, and Hulu button.5. If you lose your remote or want an extra one it is easy to download the Roku app to your phone and control things that way.6. Some of the channels or apps available on the Roku include: Fox Sports, CBS, NBC and NBC Sports, Bravo, HBGO, YouTube, PBS (our fav), Hulu, Disney+, Sling, Vudu, Netflix, ESPN, Pandora etc etc.Overall, awesome product for the $50 or so it costs.

I appear to be one of MANY who are experiencing the battery drainage issue. We bought two of these for Christmas and installed them on the same day. In 5 weeks, one of the remotes has been through 3 sets of batteries and the other has been through 2. Ironically, the TV we use daily has been through the lesser of the two. Roku does not have a solution and simply says, "we're aware and are working on it." We're at the point where we're going to need to buy rechargeable batteries, because we can't keep going through batteries like this. Please, please fix this, Roku!

My television stopped working all of a sudden so to save money since I didn't know if it was the Roku or tv I bought an updated Roku.  Luckily it was the Roku.  Everything is pretty much the same as the old one although setting up the television to 1080p the picture is far superior than the tv with the old Roku.  I can't say what the old setting was but I'm happy with the outcome.I also think the wireless connection is better with the newer Roku because the television doesn't seem to be as slow.All in all I'm very happy with the new purchase.

First to install the Fire Stick hook up was fine but to get it to connect was really  hard and if it wasn't for the neat Amazon Fire Stick customer service in South Africa I would be such a muddle - she really knew which of the buttons to press for so long and what 3 to press at the same time , I swear I never could have figured it out. That information is NOT on that little connection folder. She should be awarded a medal . I did great hooking it up but after that it was good grief what do I do NOW.!  She kept guiding me through the steps and my TV is working like a charm. She showed me the benefits of also Amazon and all the other programs but with my budget, I need Jeff Bezos to send a few  hundred thousand and No problem.  My husband had passed away last year and was so ill with Parkinson so it is  budget world 101.  Love Netflex ! Love Amazon!  Dena

Amazing positive difference from the original Fire Stick......so much more responsive, with uninterrupted streaming.  I'd become frustrated with the old stick. I thought the 21.99 price was worth the gamble that I could get back the performance I had enjoyed with the original.  I'm very happy with the Fire Stick Lite, enough so that I have ordered the next step up with the TV volume control.  Good product.  My only reservation is the TV setting icon is inconvenient and I keep hitting it instead of the pause/play.

i liked the ease of hooking up an external usb to get extra storage dont have any dislikes am updating everything great except there seems to be problems with remote it freezes a lot dont know if that is a software problem or a remote problem was going to send back the remote but thought why go thru the hassle being without one just put up with it

I TRY TO BE DETAILED AND INCLUDE PICTURES WHEN I CAN SO HERE GOES. ITS A GOOD PRODUCT. ALL YOU NEED IS INTERNET. THE SETUP WAS PRETTY BASIC JUST LIKE MY OTHER FIRESTICKS. AN ADDED FEATURE IS THAT WHEN YOU CLICK ON THE LITTLE TV TUBE ICON, IT OPENS PLUTO TV RATHER THAN YOU LOOK FOR IT MANUALLY. THE DOWNSIDE IS THERE NO VOLUME CONTROL WHICH MEANS YOU HAVE TO USE YOUR REGULAR T. V REMOTE TO ADJUST THE VOLUME. I WOULD BUY AGAIN ESPECIALLY WITH THIS PRICE. ITS A STEAL. SIGNED, ONE SATISFIED CUSTOMER.

From the second day on the sound would not come on unless you manually reset when turning the tv on. At first it was only the first time of the day, now its every single time you turn on the tv. Even if it was on the same input or not.I was using the extender and i read somewhere that may be the cause, but then either fix the extender that you ship inside the orange box with this or dont include it. Well see if that was the problem but im still returning for something different.

An impulse buy but a good one.Easy to setup. Like freakishly easy. I would have preferred a USB C connector to micro but oh well. Reasonably small. Settings are not intuitive but you can learn it fast enough. Interface could use some simplifying but that's where the Alexa comes into play.I mostly use it with my monitor that's got crappy speakers but that's where the Bluetooth pays off.Overall it adds more life to any device that's got a good HDMI port.

I bought this in hopes of using it instead of our xbox, and there were some apps that were not available on the xbox but were on the fire stick.  I am definitely unhappy that we have yet to be able to watch anything on the disney plus app.  I have had to restart it a few times in only a couple of weeks because it would not open up my profile and then my husband's profile, then mine again.  We also had to restart it because it froze up a couple of times while watching a show.... the voices would continue to play, but the screen froze up.  There definitely needs to be some updates or something to fix these issues.  One positive is that it was easy to set up.

I’m not the right person to review this item but I got it because I wanted an upgrade from my first generation Fire Stick. There were no guarantees that it would work with my older model Visio television and it didn’t. When I got it home and qset it up one show streamed perfectly and after that the only thing I could get was an onscreen error message which said “not support.” No matter what I tried, including powering down, turning off the router, etc. would bring it back. I returned it but assume that most everyone else will have a very good experience with the product.

The Fire Stick Lite is the same as the Fire Stick other than the missing TV controls, so if you don't mind using 2 remotes then you can save about 10$ for it.It has 1080p support which is good enough for most content and the connection is pretty stable.It directly goes into the HDMI port of the TV and needs a power supply. Then you can use all the supported streaming apps which are optimised for Fire TV.Overall a very good deal if you're looking for a cheap streaming device for your TV. The Alexa integrations and support makes it better as it can essentially make your TV a smart TV/display.

I bought this Fire Stick primarily because it had the HBO Max App that my Rokus did not have.  Ironically, Roku added the HBO Max App soon after this arrived, but I am still impressed with the Fire Stick.  It has very clear (1080P) picture and sound, no buffering (works well with my wifi router), and a nice selection of Apps.  The voice search is also a plus, especially in a product this inexpensive.  If you're looking for Apps such as Spectrum or Xfinity, this product doesn't download them, but it does have the Premium channel Apps associated with mainstream cable companies.

I bought the Fire Stick because my older Samsung TV would not connect to BritBox. I received a gift subscription to BritBox and wished to use it. I was told that I had to purchase one of several devices to interface between the internet and my TV. Fire Stick was recommended. When I set up my Fire Stick I could not activate it without first agreeing to a trial subscription to Amazon Prime (I already had an Amazon account) and also agreeing to a trial subscription to BritBox (to which I already had the one year gift subscription). I have since cancelled both of these forced agreements. I'm not sure what will happen next.

I load a channel, and it's like the tv is giving me the long, clueless "blink". The menu will come up...but you just get to look at it. This happens multiple times a day. Or the channel will keep playing after I have excited the channel (app) I have to turn off the tv, wait for a little while and turn it back on. Yes, I've re-set it. A couple of times. I've watched the tutorial videos, keeps happening.  I shouldn't have to reset it at all. I regret buying the fire stick instead of the other well-known streaming device.

This has worked out just great.  We have Xfinity Flex but didn't want to pay a monthly fee for a second flex box.  The Xfinity rep expressly told me a Fire stick would not work with the system, but it works fine.  Xfinity flex does not support AppleTV or Disney Plus so this works out great for our family.  I just wish the buttons were lit so when we are watching a movie in the dark and need to pause or rewind, I could see the buttons and stop accidentally hitting the home button.

All I can say is that "THE FIRE STICK IS AWESOME" I don't know why it took me so long to discover it.  Even though I've had it for a couple of weeks now I'm still in the process of learning more unique things about what it gives me access too like things I was not even aware existed.  The set up was easy just put the connecting pieces together and plug it into the HDMI port and get started.  My advice don't wait too long like I did and get your fire stick now!!!!  It's well worth it!

Bought a fire stick so I can watch all the streaming services I have. Still can’t have them all in one place. They all work great, EXCEPT PRIME VIDEO. I’ve restarted the fire stick and filled out my logins and passwords so many times. I’m over it. That’s obnoxious doing that. Still can’t get it to work. The one time while trying it signed me up for a new prime account and charged me and to get that fixed and my money back took 4 different customer service reps and wasted over an hour of my time. Every person kept telling me they didn’t see the charge and they wanted me to dispute it with my bank. I’m over it. I just want to watch all my streaming services in one place. Was ready to put a firestick on all my TVs, but whats the point? Very frustrating and I’m over it. I’m sure the problem will eventually find a solution some how, but I’m sure I’ll have to do my logins and passwords for the billionth time.

The new presentation is very nice. Thing appear to move faster.However the move from the prior Fire TV was not as easy and seamless as it should have been. I neded to reload several apps and sign in again with ID and password... time consuming and unpleasant experience. Tune-in was not moved over and the new Tune-in app is bare bones and essentially useless.  So i brought back mu old Logitech internet radio to listen to my stations. too bad.AMAZON, you can do better !

I have 3 of the Lite 2020 versions.  All 3 devices have issues with the sound.  Every time I turn on the TV and the Fire,I have to navigate to settings on the Fire Stick and restart for the sound to work.  It isn’t just the one TV happens on 3 different TV’s.  The 4K version does not have this issue.

I love this fire stick.  Because the price was right, and what it comes with is unreal.  It has a remote control, Alexa she can talk back.  And it is so easy to set up. It takes you anywhere you want to go.  If Alexa can’t take you there she will tell you. And you can put it on six TVs love it.  I would buy this product again , but I don’t have too. Because I just told you it can go on six TVs anywhere you  cannot beat this.  Just get it you won’t be sorry.  It’s a keeper.

I LOVE the amazon photos. Along with streaming my Disney, Netflix, You Tube. Photos are a great way to view family photos on the TV. I have setup for a screensaver to come on when I am not using the FireStick. I have uploaded almost 9000 pictures and we thoroughly enjoy the application.When friends and family come over we just sit back and discuss the memories. The Amazon Music that I enjoy on my phone is now playing in my home. Just press the Microphone button and say" Play my Soundtrack" , "Play Van Halen" and it does what I ask.We love it!

I like being able to watch Netflix and other programming options (which I didn't realize I would have) by using this Fire Stick Lite.  The little remote control works OK, and allows for typing in the name of a program.  However, Alexa (which I did not realize I would have since I do not own a separate Alexa device) is a little fussy.  Sometimes the 'show' will begin but the voice activation issues such as no volume (in one instance) and / or no picture (in another) will occur.  So, I go back and manually plug in what I want to watch, where is works as intended.  I have yet to figure out how to use the volume control separately from my cable box remote.

I received on Thursday. Hooked it up. Everything worked well. Friday, everything worked. Saturday, everything worked. Sunday, no picture or menus. I know the trick of unplugging the power, waiting a few seconds, plugging it back in and letting in reboot. Tried that. Nada. Switched electrical jacks. Switched HDMI ports. TV still works. Roku still works. Nothing from Firestick. Dark screen. No menu. No Alexa. Took it upstairs to see if it would respond to a change of scenery. No dice that way either. It was on a surge protector. Just apparently a bad device. If you're reading, Amazon, how do you make good?

Update on 7/25/2020:2 Remotes have quit working within 8 months of my purchase. I have replaced batteries, tried to resync and nothing solves the issue. We now have to use my cell phone and Roku app in 2 different rooms of our home just to use the streaming sticks which are our only source of TV news and movies.  I purchased 2 replacement devices about one month thinking I was giving us backup devices and now I am past their return window and I know those remotes are going to crap out on me too...NOT HAPPY with dropping a total of $250+ when the remotes last less than 1 year.Update on 01/07/2020:We now have three if these because our Daughter’s “smart” TV that is just over a year old suddenly decided to have issues with all of the built in apps.  This stick is perfect for those who have this happen, or have a TV without built in apps, or those like me who used their game system for streaming until too much use fried an expensive console and caused the loss of hundreds and hundreds of hours of save game data! I recommend these to everyone because they are perfect for our streaming only household.Orig Review:Okay...I absolutely fried my PS4 because as much as I would use it to game on I would also use it to fire up my Amazon Prime, Netflix, Hulu, etc.  I never checked into these types of devices before because I guess I just thought my PS4 would be eternal (LOL).  As all things tech related eventually do, my PS4 completely crashed and hundreds of hours on my games were lost to me, but in that awful sad moment I decided to replace my PS4 AND go ahead and buy 2 of these to use here at home so that our XBox One wouldn't suffer the same fate in our living room.  I know...I'm terrible, huh?Anyways - ROKU.  LOVE IT, LOVE IT, LOVE IT!  So easy to setup, easy to add apps to your menu, easy to navigate, quick to load the apps and most important of all I no longer have to worry about using my gaming consoles as entertainment beyond the games they are meant to play!  Win Win!!!!I am seriously amazed at how quick the apps launch/load - it's darn near immediate and the interface is clean and easy to use.  I love that I can add apps/manage everything from anywhere even when I'm not at home - adding and removing channels is a breeze.  It even recognized our TVs without any issues and even some of the universal TV remotes we've bought cannot do that as efficiently as the ROKU did.  We are definitely going to be long-time ROKU fans and will buy new ones when needed because they are well worth the price.  My husband loves the one in the living room and he has never watched as much TV as he has since I installed the ROKU out there.  If we had more TVs we would have more ROKU's.

This unit replaced an original Fire TV Stick from several years ago that had become painfully slow! What a difference! It is fast, clear, easy to use and works great! I really didn't need the voice remote feature and there is a Alexa Dot within a foot of the TV so I didn't need that feature either. But - I wanted a faster experience on our non-smart, kitchen TV where the old Fire Stick lived - this does the trick perfectly for not a lot of money!

This is the 5th Fire Stick I have bought.  it was to replace the oldest one which was getting flaky.  The original remote suffered from being too symmetrical But this new one is truly stupid layout.  Doesn't Amazon have any ergonomics experts on staff???  You should at least do some testing of changes before applying them.  Luckily, one can pry off the "Guide" rubber button to get it out of the way.  Someone could make a lot with a "filler" plug.

We have four tv's in the house, and this will be the second Firestick for us.  The voice remote is nice, as it's faster to search for a title than inputting the alphabet.  I like the way profiles can be created for different users.  I don't use the Alexa feature because Alexa, Siri, and Cortana are not welcome here.  Since we cut the cord to cable the Firesticks are what we use to stream all our shows.  We also have two Roku's and like them just as well.
