I have been watching more TV since I got this.  I enjoy the weird type of programs and this provides.  Being technologically challenged, I have not set up Alexa or any type of voice commands.  I enjoy the programming, so have no major complaints.  The only complaint is that every day I have to let it reboot before the audio comes on.  The video is no problem.  There’s just no audio until I reboot it.  My husband showed me what to do, so it’s no big deal for me ant more. Otherwise, I enjoy the programming on the fire stick.

Even though this version did not come with the compatible option to change the volume of the TV, I love being able to see movies and shows that are free on Prime but are quite expensive and only available for rental on my cable tv. For now I will keep both because there are some shows that aren't available on Firestick but are available to me on cable. But I am truly loving the extra movies that I get to watch from my phone instead of trying to watch them from the miniture screen on my mobile devices.

We love Amazon fire sticks so much that we have purchases three as well as one for my parents house. So easy to download several streaming apps to be able to watch anything you want. I’ve also downloaded the fire stick app for those times I can find the remote and I’m too tired to get out of bed to find it. Fire Remote app has been a life saver the time our kid hid two of them in her toy box until we found them weeks later. We’ve tried the competitors “remote” service and found Fire stick was much easier to navigate, download, search...ect, highly recommend!

My only complaint for this item is the lack of an on/off button. I bought this as gift for my parents so it was a bit frustrating. Upon setting it up we realized they would need to use the TV remote to turn on and off before using the firestick. Maybe this was mentioned somewhere in the details and I somehow overlooked it?Regardless, the firestick works great but I was hoping to help them eliminate the need for more than one remote.I'm giving 2 stars because I wouldn't buy another of this style just for that reason.

I installed the fire stick on an old 32 inch TV running 720p. Within 10 minutes I was surfing programs on Amazon Prime and YouTube. It is a simple device without bells and whistles which is what I wanted. The only hitch is with an Echo on my desk which "hears" commands for the TV and doesn't know what to do. I just need to be careful about where I'm pointing the stick. Great device, simple to set up, works as it is supposed to and lots of fun to play with.

I wish Amazon made it easier to install third-party apps from APK files as well as apps from the Google Play store (so that we don't have to re-purchase all of our paid apps on the Amazon app store).  I also wish it were easier to remove the icons for Amazon music and such, but it WAS 15 bucks, so I can understand why Amazon would want us to buy more stuff.  Be warned: it's not just the video output that's limited to 1080p; if you try to play a 4K video, this stick will NOT downscale it, and will simply crash instead.  All that being said, one good thing about it is that I was able to plug it into my TV's USB port WITHOUT the special "Made for Amazon" power cable (sold separately) that costs $20 more.  If you have some promotional credit that only works on products sold by Amazon, this isn't a bad way to spend it, just remember that you get what you pay for.  If you're looking for the ultimate Android TV experience, go with an NVIDIA SHIELD instead!

Bought this for my cheaper Westinghouse 50” 4K UHD LED because the tv only has pre-programmed apps. No app market.First setup only allowed 1080p. Switched hdmi port to the only one that has HDCP 2.2. It recognized 2.2, but only at 30 refresh when my tv is 60. Changed tv to hdmi 2.0 (it was on 1.4), then 60 refresh was recognized but wouldn’t recognize HDCP 2.2. Funny how it DID recognize 2.2 with tv settings on 1.4 hdmi at 30 refresh. I let it run at 4K 30 refresh with hdmi set to 1.4 hdmi. It acted fine for 2 days, then HDCP 2.2 error started up.Second install: change tv to hdmi 2.0 and ran 4K 60 refresh check. It recognized 60 refresh, but not hdmi 2.2. So, I ran factory reset and tried the same. Same issue. Then I tried “force output” and loaded Netflix. It ran a 2hr movie perfectly fine with great picture. I selected a show after, then BAM, HDCP 2.2 error all over again. I then changed settings to auto adjust screen type (resolution and refresh rate). Still got error. Then changed 4.2.0 to 4.2.2 and whole system locked up for several seconds. Started working fine again for 20 mins, then HDCP 2.2 error again.Ran through every error trouble-shooting guide Roku Tech Support gave me. Time after  time, HDCP 2.2 error.Today, I said F it. It’s hitching a ride with UPS later today. This particular model has a lot of people irritated for the same reason.

Preface: This is our first streaming device and we are old school, this may help other dinosaurs... Our stick came complete, set up was easy and straightforward and it works great. We subscribe to several streaming services (Netflix, Amazon Prime, CBS All Access, Sling, Disney+ etc. and the free ones, YouTube and Roku) but our bill is still only 1/2 of what it was with cable. We have good internet so there is no buffering problems. We have way more TV to watch now, in part because we like educational and documentary type material and don’t mind an old movie or original content. (We have so much it is easy to forget where you found something, but the home button is easy to find.)I watched the Roku set up video and read other reviews to prepare. For whatever reason, I have not experienced the problems that others have.

Beware, this thing works fine now but I got charged 99 bucks to register.  It asked for registration pin and when the pin didnt work asked us for 100 dollar per 5 year subscription.  I was convinced that there was no other way to get the thing working so I did it.  He promised a bunch of special apps but looked like the same ones we had with our old roku.  I'm pretty sure I was scammed.

After months of use, I have never managed to get this to stream an entire movie or TV show without intermittent flickering picture or outright HDCP errors and loss of picture. I've tried everything, and the problem persists and is only getting worse.My setup is as follows:Roku stick plugged into Marantz A/V 11.2 receiver, feeding through a Fiber Optic HDMI cable to an Optoma 4K Cinemax UST laser projector.I've swapped the HDMI cables, plugged the Roku stick directly into projector, changed settings in the receiver and Roku stick... You name it, I've tried it. To make sure it is in fact the Roku and not any of the other home theater components, I've switched the streaming stick out for a 4K Amazon Fire Stick from a different room, and have yet to have a single problem. We use Roku devices in 3 other rooms of the house, but I'm not impressed with this one. Unfortunately, It will be going in the trash.

This would have been a good product. But there is a catch to it so BEWARE! When you buy it They don't tell you that in order to install the update you will have to pay $80.00 to $150.00 for the update. I told them to forget it I'd send it back and that's exactly what I have done

Do not trust their support service, I called because Roku would not activate. They are from India and you can not even under stand them, thy said it was a problem with my network ,so he asked if I had a laptop he could gain accessto. he messed up my windows system by deleting files he said were  keeping the  Roku from connecting. I tried to get them to fix it but they clam it was not their fault . I ended up reinstalling windows . This is why I hate buying from Amazon so much.

I recently purchased this product to compare with my Xbox one X. I wanted something that could work with the apps that I have and for family so they dont need to use my xbox.But my issues are this. The roku’s surround sound options doesnt compute completely with my set up. Yesterday I logged into my accounts, and I tried playing movies that I owned. Surround worked on what I purchased, yet there was audio lag and my subwoofer would make noises when someone spoke. On apps that I didnt personally buy, surround sound was non existent. And if it did, it was totally random and loud af. I kept messing around with the settings hoping I could find the right one but due to the rokus limitations. I just stopped looking because for some reason the movies I have were playing in Dolby Digital DTS and the regular apps only played in Stereo regardless of what setting I put in. Another issue is you also gotta understand that I have 4K HDMI splitter, so I couldnt have the option to just turn off the roku. It would turn off everything. And even so, when I would turn off the tv and sound system, the roku would still be playing. I took alot of my time trying to figure out the simplicity of this product only to just fall on my face with disappointment. And to remind you all, my Xbox set up took my sound system perfectly. I didnt have to change my subwoofer setting, the ONLY thing that roku has alil bit better is the screen quality in certain movies. But it doesnt mean a damn thing if the sound isnt fully there to accommodate that. I spent about 6+ hrs trying to research or work on the settings or cross checking between the roku and xbox.

The "Point-Anywhere" Wi-Fi Remote is annoying and distracting from the watching experience. While RF (2.4 GHz or 5 GHz) travels at the speed of light just like the IR (infrared),  with the "point at the Roku" remote there is nothing between the remote and the Roku. IT is in essence its own Network with immediate response. With the "Point-Anywhere" Wi-Fi  there is the whole network/system that needs to all work perfectly to get a reasonable response. With 3 - 7 Wi-Fi devices operating in the house at any one time the "Point-Anywhere" Wi-Fi Remote does not necessarily have the priority connection at any given time. Dumb idea. But then if you "hide" the Roku behind the TV as you have to with the Streaming Stick IR is not an option, although a dedicated Wireless link would be (Think Logitech Mouse). I have sent the Streaming Stick back for a refund.

In order to setup and use this device you need to submit a credit card number. I tried every option I could to bypass this features as I don't intend to pay (ever) for streaming videos via Roku and yet I can't use their device unless I give them a credit card number.Sent it back waste of time and money.I have purchased several Firesticks and get access to all prime videos but was not asked to enter a credit card number in order to configure and use the Firestick, seems Roku would understand this but as long as people flippantly give out their personal data without resisting companies like Roku will get away with these kinds of practices.I strongly disagree with this basic business model and will not support companies that act like they can force a customer's hand.

This is a heaping pile of garbage.  Do not buy!  The remote barely works sometimes... maybe 1 in every 20 clicks actually goes through to the Roku device, but it controls the TV and TV volume perfectly... go figure.  It also won't connect to your wireless network unless you log into your router via a web interface and change the security settings.  Once I did that, the Roku connected to the network... for about a week and now won't talk to the network.  This is the worst purchase I have ever made and is I credibly infuriating.To point, their website is loaded with troubleshooting videos related to the remote not working and network problems.  I went through them all to no avail.  Instead of building a quality product, they opted for the "self help" video route which essentially is an attempt to blame it on the customer. I have first gen Amazon sticks that still work like a charm and never had a problem setting up.

I purchased the Roku Streaming Stick in 2016 and was happy with it. The Streaming Stick+ is an improved version with voice recognition that works well and the added TV controls to the remote is a handy new feature.The Stick+ is connected to a 2014 Sony 1080p TV. Set up was quick and easy. What's particularly nice about the Stick+ is that it stays hidden behind the TV so there's no additional clutter. Using the 5 GHz band, streaming quality is excellent with great picture and no issues with buffering. It's a great streaming device that offers a wide variety of both paid and free content.One nit is that while Roku claims the Stick+ has long-range wireless capability, I've found the wireless range is similar to the 2016 Streaming Stick with no discernible improvement. The Stick+ in my bedroom has no issues with either the 2.4 GHz or 5 GHz bands which is about 30 feet from the router. A Stick+ used in another bedroom about 12 feet farther away from the router has difficulty accessing the 5GHz band and really only works with the 2.4 GHz band.I've read other reviews which state the Stick+ tends to overheat. Even now during the heat of summer and after using the Stick+ for several hours at a time, I haven't that issue in 3 months of use. The only real problem I've had is that the device indicated that there was insufficient power. The Stick+ is powered through the TV's USB port. Simply unplugging the USB connector and plugging it back in solved that problem. It's happened only once and hasn't come up again. Overall, this device is trouble-free.This is my second Roku product and has cemented Roku as my my favorite streaming device. It's tough to go wrong with Roku.

Ok. This is going to be long…but maybe something through my experience will help you solve something faster than me.I ended up with the Sony x800g 75” led 4k UHD HDR10 tv.Lots of numbers there. And often times you will hear stuff used interchangeably.• 4k isn’t all the same. So the term 4k related to the number of pixels on your screen.o 1080p was previous HD (high definition) and was 1920x1080 pixels.o 4k is generally 3840x2160• UHD is ultra high definition which also refers to the resolution of 3840x2160, however there are two versions of this.o One is 30hz. Normal movies and tv look “normal”o 60hz is great for action movies and fast movement such as sports• HDR/HDR10 also has two versions, but in simple terms, HDR is used to describe a certain grouping of picture settings to make your 4k look better. Higher contrast rates(darker black and whiter white). However there are 2 versions of this alsoo 30hz for traditional movies and tvo 60hz is great for those action movies and sports.What happened for me. It was time for a new tv. I already had a Yamaha surround sound receiver that all my consoles, and fire/roku sticks, and blueray players plugged into, and one single cable going to my tv. So the setup of a new tv was going to be fairly painless. Find the tv, buy the tv, remove the old tv and replace it with the new one. I got home, got the new one in place and hooked up with one hdmi connection…and it didn’t do 4k. WTF! So I did some research and realized the roku stick that we use for amazon prime, hulu, and Netflix…wasn’t 4k compatible. So I went online, ordered a Roku Premier. I got it the next day, thanks amazon. Hooked it up, and it worked well…but the remote had to be line of site with the roku box. Unfortunately, my home theater setup made this a huge pain in the butt because the roku was hidden behind the Yamaha surround sound receiver. So, I returned this and ordered the Roku Streaming Stick +. Because these are meant to plug in behind the tv or to a surround sound receiver. This in place, and I ran the setup on the roku stick for display and it would do 4k uhd but only in 30hz. Fearing I had bought the wrong one. I took it upstairs to my lg 40” tv and plugged it in, turned on the tv. And the tv recognized the roku stick and I saw the screen go from normal black screen (kinda dark grey really) to true solid black with the HDR logo flashing on screen. When it showed the roku menu, I ran the same display setup and it clicked green check marks next to 4k uhd 30hz, 4k uhd 60hz, 4k hdr 30hz, and 4k hdr 60hz. And the movies (6 underground on Netflix) was just a freaking work of art. So now I knew that it was not the roku stick. So doing more research I found out that my Yamaha rx-v685 surround sound receiver would accept this beautiful signal and would pass through 4k but that the configuration had to be adjusted to do this. So I dug around in the menu, found the setting and clicked it into 4k. It looked okay on the new screen, but didn’t look amazing. So I went back to the google, and found out that my receiver would pass through only 4k uhd 30hz. So…it would look okay. But wouldn’t be jaw dropping. Did some research and found that I needed to buy the newer version of the receiver the RX-v683BL, that was $400 on ebay for a new in box one. It showed up a week later in a damaged box, but was fine cosmetically and functionally. I installed this new receiver with all the same connections and such. And ran the same roku display test, got it to do 4k uhd 30hz, and 4k uhd 60hz but it wouldn’t do 4k hdr 30 or 60. Annoyed at this point, I started scouring everything I could, and started seeing that folks said they solved this problem with better cables. I figured why not. So I found a set that had great reviews on amazon (info below) and those showed up two days later. I ran one of these from the new Yamaha receiver to the tv. Because the roku stick plugged in directly to a port on the back of the tv. Ran the test and got the 4k uhd’s working but only the 4k hdr 30hz working. I wanted the last step because I wanted the 4k resolution with the hdr picture quality with the 60 hz for high speed smooth movements. Annoyed again, I found that the tv instead of using HDMI port 1, needed to have me use HDMI port 2 or 3. I tried that, same. Then I went into the menu for the tv and found that there was a picture setting under settings>watch tv>external inputs>hdmi signal format>select the port 2 I was plugged into now and change it from standard to enhanced 4:4:4 or 4:2:2 mode. Tried again, the image was looking better but the roku still wouldn’t let me have the 4k hdr 60hz. So I checked the Yamaha receiver and the HDMI mode had to be in mode 1 as well as the roku stick had to be in ports 1-5. I ran the test again…still no luck. A final run at google and someone said there was a buried adjustment within the settings>advanced system settings>HDMI output and it also had to be set to the 4:4:4 or 4:2:2. Ran the settings and success! So when I boil it all down, when hooking something up to a 4k UHD HDR10(60hz) tv you need to have the correct device, the correct settings on the device, the right cable, the right port plugged in for the device, and also have the settings enabled for that device. I know that was long winded, but I figure I’ll use this story in the amazon review and maybe it helps someone sometime.

What’s not slow about this thing? Maybe the amazon delivery. Everything else is slow! The remote will turn on my tv but then the Roku stick won’t respond to the remote for like 30 seconds. The download speed is much slower compared to my last Roku 4 that had a hard line. The image quality is worse. Everything about this thing is worse than the Roku 4. I ended up replacing the 4 with this one because the fan in the Roku 4 started whining horribly. This one doesn’t whine but I can make dinner in the time it takes to load a show.

I’ve used most every streaming device available and the Roku is by far the most user friendly, the easiest to set up, has the best remote and is overall the best streaming device out there.  Soon after setting up my first Roku Stick+, I ordered another one for our second TV to replace the Roku Premier, which was fine but I liked having a volume control on the Stick+ that was lacking on the Premier.

I love this streaming stick. It is my first foray into streaming and it’s rather a Wonderland! It has worked perfectly. I haven’t integrated it with my Echo Dot yet and I don’t think the remote is a voice remote (?) so that’s why I couldn’t rate those two in this review. I read several reviews online before purchasing this Roku streaming stick+ and the reviews were very good and inspired confidence in this little device. So I purchased it and I’m glad I did. The reviews said that you get a lot of bang for the buck and it seems to be true. When you activate it however and it asks you to type in your email address, you have to hit the OK button to go to the next screen. I was confused by that and was trying to use the up-and-down arrows to get down to the area to type in the email address. They should put the words “press OK” because it wasn’t obvious to me that that was what I should do to toggle to the next screen. I wasted a bunch of time trying to figure it out. When in doubt, press OK!!🤷‍♀️

I LOVE my ROKU.  I recently re did my cable/streaming set up.  I now only get internet.  There are so many other options out there that will cut your cable bill in half and in my case in fourths.  I get free NETFLIX with my T-mobile phone plan.  I am a member of AMAZON prime so I get streaming with them.  I added HULU and I'm golden.  I do not miss my cable, HUZZAH!!This little stick has a VERY small footprint.  It plugs right into the back of my TV, it has all the features plus a voice recognition ( I have not tried yet) like their small ROKU box.  You can program it to do just about ANYTHING a cable box does.  It is ridiculously easy to use the interface is VERY FRIENDLY.  Try it, you'll like it.  I am very happy with my purchase.

The stick itself seems great. The way the stick is made you have to plug straight in. Almost all TVs are flat wall mounted with HMDI ports in rear. This made it impossible to inbox and immediately play. We had to purchase a dongle adapter to allow the stick to hang freely. Most adapters are in packs of 2 or 3- so now I have extra I don’t need. It would have been nice to have one in the box.Once plugged it- setup was easy. Pairing with Alexa wasn’t in the automatic set up and so I have to go and figure out how that works.I like that you can just download a few channels and it’s not a lot of unnecessary scrolling since this is for a young child tv. Parent controls were easy to set up.

After a few months of using the cheaper basic Roku, I decided to upgrade to the Streaming Stick+, though I couldn't seem to get answers to some tech questions here or on their website.The video is wonderfully clear when streaming from my desktop computer or when streaming from the Xfinity streaming service - or through the Roku channel for that matter.  I think some serious upscaling is going on. The sound is amazing streaming from my computer, but be aware that most streaming services don't broadcast in surround sound - you'll have to settle for stereo until they decide there's enough demand for it.Set up was mostly easy, except that in my case, there was some sort of glitch that caused streaming errors at first. The solution was simple: go into settings and find the "restart" option, and then re-install the services you subscribe to.If you rip your own video, you'll find that the Stick won't render vobsubs or PGS subs at all. Those are the subs that come with DVDs and BluRay disks. But you can easily download srt subs from various websites. Streamed movies and TV shows do, of course, have subs that work. The subs are displayed in compact form with a black background for easy reading without getting in the way of opening credits.And here's the question nobody could answer for me: The stick WILL handle the x265 HEVC codec. This is a real advantage if you rip your own video from your disks. HEVC will pack some great clarity into much smaller files.One thing I don't like, is the menu navigation in the media app (where it streams from your computer in the other room). When you go into a folder, and then come back out, the other folders are sometimes not displayed. The solution is to go "home" and then enter the app again. Then you can select from all the content. The same bug was in the cheap Roku, so I think they don't know about it.Given the price, this is a compact workhorse that will deliver your entertainment reliably in hi-def. Pretty much anything I watch from now on will come through this little stick, except for when I play a physical disk.

I have had a Roku for years, works great finally died after all the hard work at dead. I bought this one and now they’re forcing you to pay $100 on top of what you purchased the item for before you can use it. They said it has something to do with them right now running their own servers. So no if you buy it you will also have another fee unless you have a Roku account that you already purchased with that $100.

In fairness I am giving this 1 star based on my experience so far of trying to install the Roku stick since I haven't been able to test my new Roku.  Because of the poor design of having the power cable connect on the side of the Roku stick it is sure to cause interference problems on many TV's (mine included). Roku must know this is an issue since in the instructions they note that if it doesn't fit they will ship you a free adapter 4-5 days after you discover you can't use your Roku stick.  Including the adapter in the box would have been a nice customer satisfier even if it is not needed for some installations. However, it is a major dissatisfier to not include it and make customers wait another 5 days to get their product workable. Hopefully the stick will perform better than the installation process (once I get my adapter next week), but not impressed with Roku so far.

Reviews from 2018 suggested that Roku was charging $79  per additional Roku to update and activate more than two of their devices.  I ordered this from Amazon and two more from Best Buy and had no difficulty activating any of them.  All work well.  I gave it four stars in part  because my wife's hands are shaky and I could not find a Roku remote with large buttons that would do everything that the included  manufacturer's remote does.  Also because  (in part) the voice search is not currently working when signed into an app -- and it was working until a few days ago.  And also because at the time of this review they had not worked out a contract with Spectrum to include their app.  Roku is now saying in the ad for this device that there is no charge for support "of any kind."  Nor have I had any problems with respect to upgrading the software.  So four stars instead of three.

I have finally been able to sit down (Covid 19 stay at home order) to install Roku.  When I did, it comes up with Missing Advanced Wireless Receiver.  I have installed the Receiver that came with this item.  If another receiver is needed, then there is some level of deception.  If no other AWR is needed except what came in the box which is what I believe, then the product is defective.  I was about to have it replaced but my return window is passed by 2 days.  That is unfair that I have to purchase a new product due to a defective AWR.  Why would I need a AWR if my product came with a long range wireless receiver?

I have an old Sony Bravia that of course worked well with cable, that I use in my bedroom. But because I recent went to all streaming (to get away from the crazy high cost of cable). It needed and upgrade.This unit gave my old Sony new life.I’d tell anyone in the same circumstances not to through there old tv’s out—Give it new life with a Roku Stick.

This is an update to my earlier review (see below).  I received the free extension cord from Roku, and it did solve the problem, so I have upgraded my rating to four stars.  But since Roku is well aware of the problem, they should be supplying this cord with all shipments so that customers don't have to waste a lot of time sorting out the issue.I was not aware of this before I bought it, but evidently this device is not adequately designed to dissipate heat very well.  This shows up whenever we watch something with HDR on Amazon Prime.  Evidently Amazon HDR makes the stick work extra hard and heat builds up to the point where you get an onscreen warning that the unit is overheating.  Netflix shows are fine.  Roku has a "fix" where they'll send you a free extension cord to try to move the device farther away from the TV, but according to a number of users on the Roku users group, this does not always fix the problem.  I have sent for the extension cord, but in the meantime, we can't watch Amazon HDR shows.

Roku stick is advertised with 3 months free Apple TV. Amazon says deal is over and there is nothing you can do but return the product. I believe if it’s advertised on amazon and sold by amazon warehouse they should go er what they advertise

I actually purchased a firestick before this and I returned that to purchase the roku stick. My main complaint witht eh firestick was the fact that the default home screen was too cluttered with too many things going on. It also tried to keep pushing some prime video content which I did not appreciate. And the screen mirroring with laptop did not seem to work on the firestick. I've been using the roku stick for a couple weeks now and I am very pleased with it. The screen mirroring works fine with my laptop though there is some input delay. However, watching movies using screen mirroring works fine. The home screen by itself is not cluttered and only shows the apps you have installed which is a huge plus for me. My friend had an older roku stick which was very slow but this one is very fast and breezy. The voice integration works perfectly and something I love about it is the fact that when you ask it for a movie/tv show, it shows you all the streaming services the movie/tv show is available on which is super helpful. The roku store also has a ton of screensavers and wallpapers so you can customize it exactly the way you want. I was a little surprised the box didn't come with a HDMI extender, like the firestick did. But it wasn't a big deal because roku ships it to you for free if you provide the serial number on your roku stick. The HDMI extender is tiny however and that was a bummer for me because I wanted to use the extender to have the stick right beside my TV instead of behind it to get higher wifi strenght. Overall, as somebody who has used the firestick and roku stick, I would recommend the roku stick 100%!

Bought a new one yesterday and plugged it into my TV. Completed the initial setup steps like Language selection , Remote pairing and Wifi selection. The stick said it needed a software update and will reboot. Post the reboot, the stick would flash the initial startup logo and then just shutdown..Extremely disappointed with the purchase . Wish Roku had better QC in place.  No phone help.  Cant find anywhere on help forums ame issue.  Only place i can find exact problem is on amazon reviews.  Im sending back.  This thing should work!!!!!
I really dislike that you NEED to put in payment information to set this up.

I got the Roku Streaming Stick+ to replace a ChromeCast.  The Roku gave me the thumbs up as being HDCP 1.4 compliant during setup.  After painfully typing in my long Netflix password using the dpad it then proudly displayed a HDCP refusing to work.  I'd like to point out the ChromeCast enforces DRM and HDCP checks too and had no problem.  If you are doing ANYTHING more than plugging this Roku directly into a TV don't bother.  It's not worth the HDCP headache.  Literally refused to work with anything despite validating my setup during install.  If they refuse to accept HDCP 1.4 connections it'd be nice to know that before requiring me to setup an account and requiring me to setup a method of payment on the account to even finish creating the account.  Awful.  All around.  1 star.

Remote would randomly stop working and would only reconnect if batteries were removed and reinserted. Batteries are new. Did this about once per day. Worse than this, 4K video streams from Netflix or Hulu have horrible video quality, with blocking, streaking, and off-color artifacts, especially in dark areas of the picture. Same exact content when viewed through my smart TV’s apps (also over wireless-this is on a 65” Vizio) is beautiful and free of all artifacts. I prefer using a Roku due to the simplicity of the interface, but I had to return this one.

I was still using the 1st generation fiestick in the room I put this in, and it was not the slightest improvement.  I don't know why they redesigned so much about the parental controls on this thing, when it still doesn't give me any more specific control. I was hoping I could filter what apps are available. Nope. It's either only for little kids or only for adults. No more specific than that. After a few weeks struggling with it, it was ruined after the blackout. I certainly would never waste a dime buying it again.

This clearly is a lemon and now I can't return as I missed the deadline due to trying to get back from Covid restrictions.  By the time I did get back and checked this, was too late.  All I want is to replace it and now I have no idea how to do that because it's so difficult to reach anyone on here.  Please see this whoever matters.  I'm sure it's a good product but this doesn't work and I watched every tutorial, had my tech son work on it but nothing.How do you get any service on here?  I did send message directly to ROKU but haven't heard.I will write a real review if I get to have the product that works.  Thank you and my apologies as I normally don't rant on here, but provide a real review of a product which helps people to purchase with honest reviews.

I had to change the batteries 3 times in less than a month. Remote would randomly die. Not sure if it’s a glitch or not, but I returned it. Also when turning on the tv the hdmi input would work on there first try 70% of the time. I returned it, I’ll stick with my FireStick for now. Also if using the Xfinity stream app, you can pause live tv! You can pause live tv with the FireStick though.

after initial setup, a phone number appears on screen telling you to call! Then a person from Indian answers telling you, you need to pay a one time lifetime use to roku! NOT THE CASE, it is a scam.Unsure how they taped into software...do not give any information to them,roku is a free set up!

You can tell they spend all their time with adds and stupid themes that you never ask for.  Real problem is that IT DOESN'T WORK.  First it was the audio would disappear and we'd have to unplug and plug it back it 5 times, now the remote does nothing half the time.  Not sure if it's the remote or the thing plugged in... But I assure you, they make sure you get their stupid adds and themes just right... So if you like adds and stupid holiday themes grab it up, if you'd like this POS to work, this ain't the one.  HEY ROKU LET ME RETURN THIS POS AND I'LL CHANGE MY REVIEW, IF IT WORKS FOR MORE THAN 3 MONTHS.

Well, after a week of troubleshooting attempts, I've thrown in the towel and decided to return this, my first Roku product. While the UX is quite good (fast, reasonably well designed), and the feature set is appealing, there were two problems for me that led to this outcome:1. Surround sound issue due to lack of Dolby Digital support for older equipmentDuring my fall into the Roku support forum rabbit hole, I learned that there are two varieties of Dolby surround: Dolby Digital (DD) and Dolby Digital Plus (DD+). Providers such as Disney+ provide surround audio in DD+, but not DD; my older receiver (a Denon) can't decode the former, so I only get stereo audio from those programs. Competing streaming devices apparently can convert DD+ to DD in these cases, but the Roku can't (in spite of what the available device settings would lead you to believe). Comments in the forums suggest that some older Roku models can perform this conversion, and that this product used to until recent Roku updates.As a work-around, I routed the Roku through my Blu-ray player, which can process DD+ streams. Not as convenient, but not a deal-breaker on its own.2. Video stutters after rewind on Netflix, Disney +I've observed this problem on Netflix and Disney +, on multiple shows. (I hadn't tried any other services.) Typically, when I play a program for the first time, motion is pretty smooth; no noticeable artifacts. However, If I rewind the program a bit and then play, I see a choppiness that seems to be a frozen frame every 1/4 sec. or so. This is most noticeable on pans and slow zooms. (Some might describe this as a stutter.) The effect is sufficiently severe to make this a deal-breaker for me.I went through the troubleshooting steps covered on the support forums, with no success. I also have a Comcast X1 box with Netflix; I tested the same shows on that device, but could not reproduce the problem there. So it sure seems that the problem lies with the Roku.So, given all of the above, I'm giving up on this product. Customers with more recent gear might not encounter the problems I did, but for others this would be something to consider before choosing this as your streaming device.

Easy to set up? You would think it is just a matter of plugging it into the TV by the description. Well, it has to be in view of the remote, which probably not the case by plugging it directly into the TV. In my TV the stick is too long to plug into the TV.So you need the HDMI but you will also need a male to female HDMI adapter which doesn’t come with the product.While you may have enough power cord to plug into the USB port in the TV, USB power probably isn’t enough so you should go into a wall plug. The cords sent will probably not reach if you still want to keep the stick in view, so you will need an extension cord.The Get Started instructions fail to go into detail especially about where the stick has to be placed and a need for the HDMI.I decided it wasn’t worth it. I replugged in my old Roku and returned the stick.

I like this 2019 Roku Stick + better than the previous (2017) version primarily because it puts off less heat.  The previous stick version would physically get very hot.  Then intermittently  a warning would come up on the screen that it was overheating.To resolve that, the power had to be cut to let it cool down.  I purchased a USB hub with power buttons to do that daily.  So far the new version has not felt as hot to the touch nor has a warning popped up.The new version also has a small box integrated into the USB power cord.  This may be the resolution for the heat problem.Other than that, this new version also has includes a mute button on the remote.  It is supposed to have a quad core processor.  I have not noticed any significant speed increase how it operates.  I will say that the sticks have 802.11ac network capability that makes them run better than the Roku Express. which only has up to 802.11n network speed.As for voice recognition, that does not work as well as I would hope.  Many times it does not recognize what I am saying.  So I don’t use it.I purchased many of these for home and as gifts as they were on sale in December for $29 each, which was a good deal.  I have had good feedback from others that it works well.I recommend the Roku Stick + of you want a fast, cooler streaming channel device.By the way, as of this time, the CBS Roku app will not allow use without a CBS ALL ACCESS subscription.  The smart phone app does allow broadcast show access at no extra cost, which can be streamed to a Google Chromecast device, not to Roku.  That is CBS’ choice.

Was looking forward to replace my clunky "old-reliable" Roku box with the sleek Roku Stick. Last night, within 45 minutes of the 1st use, it overheated and I received the following message on my Samsung SmartTV “Your device is overheating”.  The stick overheated 3 times within 90 minutes. Each time, the stick was very hot. I followed the "Unplug & wait 10 minutes until the unit is cool" directions. My TV sits on a cabinet. There are no other electronic devices near the TV and there's 10 inches between the back of the TV and the wall. I'm returning the stick and will reinstall my trusty Roku box.

When it comes to streaming media devices, IMHO Roku is the brand to beat.  I already had an older Roku, which I've used since 2012.  When I decided to move it into my bedroom, I realized I wanted something more than the few "smart" apps on my living room TV.  After doing some research I chose to get a Roku Streaming Stick+, and fell in love with it immediately.My girlfriend's bedroom TV had absolutely no "smart" features, so I got her a Streaming Stick+; but she decided she didn't want to get into the habit of watching TV in bed (except for the morning newscasts) and gave it to her daughter.  A few months later, she upgraded her bedroom TV -- larger and better screen, but again no "smart" apps -- and then she injured her hip and had to spend a couple of weeks off her feet as much as possible.  Ity was nearly Christmas anyway, so I bought her another Streaming Stick+, and this time she loved it!  (She's hooked on "The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel".)Then I decided to give a Streaming Stick+ to my sister for Christmas.  Yep, she loves it too!  She prefers classic movies and TV series from her childhood, and the various Roku channels have a wealth of such programming.  Dhr has hinted that she wouldn't mind having a second Streaming Stick+, for her bedroom TV; so I may be guying my fifth one soon.  Or perhaps my fifth and sixth, since the Streaming Stick+ has a few channels available that my original Roku doesn't seem to have.

The latest update to the “new fire tv”  took a great interface experience and made it laborious and very user unfriendly.  The apps are smaller, harder to see. You have to go through a lot of stuff they are trying to sell you before you can get back to what you were watching last (7 rows down instead of 1st row) I have a hard time imagining any purpose for this upgrade except some tech saying “look I changed a whole lot of stuff”  trying to justify their paycheck.Great Job of taking a silk purse and turning it into a sows ear!

I’ll start with I love the fire stick. I got this one for my 6 y/o for the voice feature.HOWEVER! It turns off randomly in the middle of shows and restarts itself.  There is no rhyme or reason to why. When it works it is awesome. Tried resetting , tried everything. Don’t let this steer you away but be aware this could happen with this product

Seems to work just as well as our regular fire stick in the living room. We got this one for our family room TV. Connects well. Really enjoy that we are able to connect to our dish Network app and watch dish on our other TV now instead of having to pay Dish Network to use their Joey.

I have to restart my fire stick almost every time I use it because it doesn’t want to play sound. I thought it was my tv at first, but the regular cable worked just fine and the fire stick was fine after restarting. Really inconvenient since I’ve only had it for about a month... unfortunately I think at this point I can’t return or exchange it. Overall not impressed with the quality of the fire stick, but I definitely see the benefits of having it make any tv into a smart tv.

This turns a regular TV into a smart TV. My only issue is that the second day I had it I thought the TV had broken, I had no sound. I checked everything with the TV even unplugged it and plugged back in and still no sound. Then I was thinking maybe it has something to do with the fire stick. I unplugged it and plugged back in and sound was fine. This has happened 8 think 3 times within about 4 days. Kind of a pain. Other than that I like what it does.

This device freezes my tv up A LOT! I can be in the middle of a movie, right at the end, and it freezes up. Turning tv off and on, unplugging firestick and plugging back in, and even turning the internet off and on doesn't even help. I have to leave it overnight before it will start up again. And this time, it didn't even do that. I thought the issue was with my internet, so I upgraded my internet, sent a Cox technician out who changed settings, but the tv still froze up. Then I switched to GoogleFiber internet a couple days later, that didn't help either. I don't know what to do at this point except to return the Firestick.

Absolutely love the fire stick. It instantly made our TV smart by providing smart features. I love all of the apps and it even has access to other things like Amazon shopping, free games to play on the TV, you can ask questions like measurement conversions using the voice recognition on the remote. It's small so it doesn't take up a lot of space. It hooks up to the hdmi port on the TV. Love it. I actually bought a 2nd one after trying this out. I'm about to get rid of my cable bill.

The home menu on this thing populates nicely as you add all your accounts and watch thigns. I like the list of recommendations it gives me and how it goes across some apps. Not ones like hulu. I imagine you give preference to those who pay you money so I don't blame hulu for being buried on this thing.Otherwise it's nice. I do have 4K in my living room but this is great for the bedroom.I don't use any of the voice crap so I can't review..

Apparently I haven't experienced all firestick is after reading all these comments. As far as I am concerned I am loving my firestick. I dont care it has no tv controls on it. (It wouldn't have had the capacity to change to HDMI3 anyways only my TV controller does) Very very easy to set up. Mine was already attached to my home network. I didnt have to do anything extra.  I got the youtubetv trial and I am enjoying this. I should gotten this along time ago.

I picked this up to throw in a small TV to put in the garage or move out on the deck. It's great when we're working on stuff or just hanging out outside to be able to put something on to watch or listen to like sports or what have you. The inexpensive stuff means I won't cry if someone steals it, but as with most Fire TV products it works really well.If you're looking for an inexpensive way to stream TV and you're part of the Amazon ecosystem, you cannot go wrong with this.

As someone who moves around a lot (home, church, and community centers) to teach courses, this has been a life saver and SO EASY to plug and play.  Once it is set up, there is nothing else to do but connect it to WIFI at the location I am using that day!  I absolutely LOVE it!  The ONLY thing I would say is I wish it had screen casting so I could share power point or the screen from my device. But that is not a HUGE deal if I bring my laptop.

The instructions given don't work. Not sure if my model is defective, but am about to return it. Frustrating!UPDATE: I managed to get the compartment open by slipping a sharp knife in the slot next to it and twisting. So the problem is solved. To my astonishment, I got a phone call this afternoon from an Amazon representative about this (I guess they actually read the reviews!), and he was pleased to hear that I had gotten it open.

Set thIs up, and used twice , and the unit now doesn’t work. It gives me a green screen. Totally useless.ADDENDUM UPDATE:AMAZON MADE CONTACT WITH ME TO TROUBLESHOOT FIRESTICK LITE. THEY  OFFERED ASSISTANCE, AND IT WAS DISCOVERED A PROBLEM WITH THE AGE OF THE TV AND THE COMPATIBILITY OF THE FIRESTICK WITH THE PORT.THIS WAS GREATLY APPRECIATED, AND THEY WERE MORE THAN COURTEOUS, WANTING THE PRODUCT TO WORK FOR THE CUSTOMER.

I have to say that it is a great streaming device. I don’t mind that I can’t control volume or channel with the remote. What I do care is how the fire stick brought the tv back to life. I already have a smart tv and I can watch Netflix and all that but when I watch it streaming it through the fire stick, the tv’s picture is enhanced. I am very pleased and will recommend. If I have to say something to work on it might be the fact that when I turn off the tv, the next day I have to reset or restart the fire stick because the apps don’t have volume, but once I restart which is super fast everything goes back to have volume.

Overall a good device, easy to use and customize with your favorite apps, however, a technical issue causes it to frequently boot up without sound, requiring a restart before it will work properly again. It reboots fairly quickly, but I feel like they've created enough of these fire sticks now that a simple, essential feature like sound should work at least 99% of the time.

I don't use the voice recognition ....still "old fashion" and not a fan of all voice activated stuff.  I do watch some of the movies and the applications that are free (I'm cheap).  I already have a membership to Netflix (it was a gift) which I can also access through the firestick. Took me a bit to get it working correctly (I'm not a "techy") but now that I have it working I'd say it was well worth the purchase and do recommend.

When I first received this, I was constantly having to reset it to work. After talking with support, who was excellent, I reset it to factory and it has worked fine. Bummer was I lost all the apps I had put on it, but having it work was a better trade-off. Apps are easy to install or delete. Customer Service, after I wrote a one star review, contacted me by phone within 10 mins of submitting it. Now that's customer service! Thank you CS.

I've owned quite a few Fire Sticks over the years, and they changed very slightly if at all. This new one has a different format, so can I take a little getting used to, however I could not get it to sync with my echo Dot. My previous firesticks had no problems. Perhaps because my echo dot is old, but it was extremely frustrating the amount of work I had to put into getting one Alexa device to link with another. It should be seamless and require no effort.

Was not able to use HBOMax with Comcast & Smart TV because we did not subscribe through Comcast. TV Stick Lite worked like a charm. Only negative is the remote is sluggish- takes a long time to advance show selection manually . Voice recognition was very good. Very easy to set up. Well worth the expense.  Don't use Alexa although I would like to use the Echo to mirror what's on TV (watchHBO) but have not figured out how to do it yet.

This Firestick freezes at least once a day and the only way to get it back and rebooted is to pull the power connection out and reinstall it. This is totally unacceptable and I am going to return it to Amazon and choose a new replacement. I have had at least 4 or 5 Firesticks over the years and this is the second one that has had problems. This one worked very up until the time the image froze. Hope I have better luck next one.

Again another half baked idea from Amazon, What good is it if you need two remotes. ( aka TV remote & firestick) to operate your TV. For the price at Best Buy of 17.99 i guess it was worth it verses buying a 1k of 4 new smart TV's. The main problem is going from Hulu, to Prime to Netflix the remote gets stuck and will not let you change services or shows in the middle of a show. You will always have to end an APP and restart surfing otherwise your locked out. Amazon does offer the full remote for $30 but again does the same thing function wise except TV controls are included. Just watch out for all of the add-on's which aren't free and a click of a button and you bought the farm. WARNING KEEP THE REMOTES AWAY FROM YOUR KIDS OR THEY WILL BE BUYING EVERYTHING WITH A CLICK OF A BUTTON AND YOUR CREDIT CARD ON FILE YOUR DONE.

i love this!! so easy to connect to any TV with an HDMI, any channel you want is available and it’s fast and good quality. bought 3 of these and turned a random non-smart TV that was siting in the garage into a TV with every single streaming service. 10/10 recommend

Way easier than expected, just sign it into your Amazon account, put in the Code as verification.. that's it lol, easy peasy. Also I somehow am able to watch movie and show free (No I didnt pay or sign up for anything by accident), But I'm grateful cuz I the movies are actually good well known ones, Obviously they have ads but the Quality is 100% A+ perfect. Nice work Amazon, Seriously. I'll reccomend this to many of my family and friends as well.

Love the firestick. It's been an all around great streaming tool! I have them hooked to every tv in the house. it started out with a "jailbroken" firestick that i didn't even use whatever they had on it to call it jail broken i just logged into hulu disney espn and netflix and started streaming it's a breeze to setup all you have to do is hook it to your wifi and connect it to you streaming services and you're up and running!

I love this thing. I had a bulky console for my kids room prior to this, and now with the stick it takes up less room, no long cables, parental controls are awesome (timers and passwords especially), and with my prime I have access to a ton of shows. However, right off the bat the remote is glitchy. I thought maybe it was too far from the unit or some kind of interference but nothing has helped. Even standing right by the stick does nothing. It set up fine but once all the updates happened it started skipping or not responding. Probably just need a new remote. Love the product otherwise!

I decided to use my 12-year old plasma television in my bedroom when I bought a new television for the living room. Didn't want to get another cable box and my son recommended getting an Amazon Firestick. The firestick works just as good without the cable box on streaming content. I don't watch much in my bedroom, but having the firestick on my old plasma, I've been streaming shows without interrupting other viewers in the living room.

After returning the first one because it permanently froze and would not reset I became frustrated with the replacement when I needed to reset it every few days by unplugging and plugging it in. Other than that it is the same thing less the volume controls.

I love this device. My Panasonic TV was too old to have access to Netflix and Amazon Prime so I purchase the FireTV device. I'm glad I did as the app on the TV only plays through the TV speakers whereas the FireTV is hooked into my A/V receiver so it gets full Dolby surround sound. The only drawback is that I have to use my A/V remote to control the sound and switch back and forth between the FireTV device and my AT&T U-Verse box.

When it works, it works fine although the navigation is late/slow to respond when you push the button on the remote.  The unfortunate issue is that about once a week, the audio stops working requiring us to unplug and plug the Fire Stick back in to reboot the stick and get the audio working again.

I am not completely able to use the product for which I bought it for. This product used to stream DISH. I don't know when it quit but it did. I am able to stream Amazon and Netflix but I watch a lot of dish. I tried to get help with a chat and he was speaking way over my head. He didn't know how to translate it to layman's terms. I was given a phone number to call. When I called the phone number I was placed on hold indefinitely. This is on my cell phone that has limited minutes. I am completely wireless right now and this is not going how I thought it would. Very frustrating trying to get through to customer service. There is no way to leave a message. I even have a ticket and there's no way to enter that information or to get them to call me back. I am not going to use my precious minutes for Dead air. If I don't get this hooked up in the next week I will send it back. It's already been two weeks.

What a cheap remote control first time I dropped it from less than a foot above my wood floor it stopped working. Tried everything but the cheap remote although looks great doesn't work. I would have bought a Fire Stick but they and Xfinity are at odds and Xfinity won't give them permission to have the Xfinity app on a fire stick so I pay the price lol!

We bought this Roku about two months ago. It streams nicely. One big problem has come up. When you you navigate from one item to another after about three item it jams up and stop working for about 5 or 10 minutes. So we’re ever you end up when it jams your stuck on that movie or item. I would suggest you buy a different stick and this does not seem to have robust processing power to allow you to easily move around. I was very disappointed in this product. In the past Roku was the best but now I am stuck with one that is definitely not very good.

This device works great, as long as you don't mind replacing the remote batteries every few days. For some reason they are drained with 2-4 days, depending on usage (confirmed by battery meter). From information available online, this is a longstanding issue and ROKU has no interest in resolving it. I complained about this issue thru chat support and was promised an email response, but after 2 weeks no response was forthcoming. Based on other reviews, it is unlikely I will ever hear from ROKU (if I am wrong, ROKU, respond to this review).

This is our second steaming stick, for our spare bedroom. We've been using our first streaming stick for about 6 months. We replaced our very old (but still functioning) Roku when it wouldn't stream Disney+. We love our streaming stick. It loads apps like Netflix and Disney+ immediately. Navigating within the apps is easy and intuitive. We paired the remote with our TV, and now only use the original remote when we need to switch the TV input away from our Roku. We even took it traveling, and were able to quickly set up the hotel TV to stream our favorite shows.

This works great for wireless connection and picture quality, but...1) The stick does not support IR (Infrared) communication. It will only use RF (Radio Freq) communication, so you are locked into using this remote (or a universal remote that supports RF). I watch more than just the Roku, so I need to change the input on my TV. The Roku stick+ will NOT allow you to do change input on your TV.2) Be aware, there is a scam! If you try to connect more than 2 Roku devices from your home and get the "003 error". If you call the number shown, they will give you some BS story about paying anywhere from $70 to $150 to get it connected. Hang up! Go to the settings on your Roku and reset the stick. It will give you a new valid ID.I returned the Stick+ and purchased the Roku Ultra. The Ultra supports IR and login via your computer to your existing Roku account when you setup your new Roku.

RETURNING; Useless - literally.Still waiting for necessary HDMI extension to SHIP from Roku(!? almost 1 week...).Roku offers it for free which I guess would be nice, so why not have it in the package already? - especially since they were obviously prepared with an answer to what, I would extrapolate, is a not-uncommon issue of the "stik" being too large to fit in limited size HDMI plug-in area on/behind the TV?Instead, $50 paperweight - not for long...Amazon would be wise to offer the extender right along side;"Free" from Roku is entirely irrelevant if you don't have it.Disappointed as this was our first forray into "cut cord", and this device - per extensive research- was our choice as it was otherwise rated well...

It's such as amazon sham to depict the Disney quick button on the remote in all their images to only send you the original ESPN button on the remote which was their original set.  I wanted what was depicted which was the "Netflix, Hulu, Disney, Sling"  what I got was Netflix, Hulu, ESPN, Sling"They should send you the correct remote that is advertised an option or which remote you want.  I'll be speaking with Disney that amazon is not sending people the Disney remote they advertise and paying Roku a lot of money for.

I bought this streaming stick specifically to take with me when I travel. I stay in a lot of hotels and some of them don't have smart TVs. For the ones that do, I don't want them to store my credentials for streaming services.  Having read the reviews and thinking I had done my research, I was confident I made the right choice with the Roku streaming stick. It sounded ideal for my situation, but it turns out connecting to the hotel wifi is a disaster with this thing.I'll preface this with saying I'm an IT consultant and have an extensive background setting up many wireless devices. I've tried 2 different Marriotts in two different states and the method of connecting the device to authenticate simply doesn't work when it requires loading a webpage. I ended up having to connect my laptop to the hotel wifi, enable the hotspot feature, and connect the roku to that in order to work. In other words, I have to have my laptop on if I want the roku to work at all times. It's advertised as a standalone device that can do this by itself.What this device needs is a way to directly open the authentication webpage for hotel wifi directly in the roku interface instead of the method of connecting to the roku via wifi and trying to complete all the steps before the connection troubleshooter turns off the roku access point. It times out too quickly to finish the steps. I tried with 3 different devices: My laptop, phone, and tablet. Each time, the roku timed out the connection before the steps could be completed.I realize not all people are in my situation where they need to travel often. Connecting to your home network is easy and the device works well when it does connect, but having it advertised as working easily with hotel wifi networks that authenticate with a webpage is misleading. I'm planning on using a firestick instead for travel.

Dont waste your money on this. After 2 weeks using it, the remote stop to works, i changed the batteries, worked for another week, then failed again. I was checking the status of the remote batteries from the Roku Home, and after change the batteries, were on 100%, one day after that, 89%, 5 more days, the remote was dead and they make you to buy a new control for the device.Also the amazon support request to send the device back to them, to check the device and make a refund of the money.After check on google about this matter, a lot of people have the same issue, so this means that amazon sell this devices know it that the device is deffected.Again, do not waster your money on this.

I've had two Roku's for less than a month.  Both have presented simple black screens and they are non-responsive to remote inputs.  This has forced me to power cycle them.  This isn't a problem for those techno minded, but it is a hassle to have to be the frequent IT person in the house.  The remotes that come with the Roku are not ergonomical.  I have accidently hit the volume mute and down buttons frequently when simply grabbing the device.  The remote is to small to have such controls on the side.Even with these issues, I'm still overall happy that I cut the cable and went with Roku.

Roku is charging me $100 to activate this ROKU stick!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Everything says "No Charge for setting up an account"!It CLEARLY SAYS THAT A ROKU ACCOUNT IS FREE!!!!!This is a RIP-OFF!!!How can you allow such a False Advertising ????THey have CUT OFF MY accoubt!!!I have had it since becoming a Prime Time member!!!I want  to make a FORMAL COMPLAINT I will vonsult more legal help tomorrow when I can talk to someone.Amazon does not want to listen to my complaint,giving the same "No oNe is available to hel me!I PAID for this through AMAZ)ON!I am TOTALLY FRUSTRTED!!I NEED HEL FROM YOUR .....team,but I cannot get any.

Easy setup. Really easy; easier than the Amazon Fire TV. I got this to replace my Fire TV box, being on the fifth one now; it was pretty unreliable. The Roku also gets the Amazon Prime TV, and has dedicated pushbuttons for Hulu, Netflix etc. Part of the setup is to get it to recognize the TV so it's single-button on-off, volume control from the Roku control, also nice. It has much better wifi sensitivity than my old Fire TV box, too. The only mildly annoying part of setup is that you have to go to Roku.com/connect to activate it and finish the setup. Otherwise, it's a snap, took maybe 10 minutes to install and activate Prime, Netflix, and Hulu.

Third update.  Just keeps getting worse. What was saved with the app on my phone is no longer saved as app has stopped recognizing my roku stick so it is completely unusable.  Crazy enough but it still loads on my TV but with a dud remote and a dud app, there is no way for me to control it for use.  Utter junk product.Second update: it's only gotten worse. I've had to re-pair the roku remote several times while I'll had it. Now the remote is completely dead. Since there are no buttons on the roku stick,  I was worried I wouldn't be able to use it at all. Then I downloaded the app and use my phone to control it. It isn't ideal but at least I can still use my Roku.  Maybe I just got a dud but I still stand by my statement that my old Roku is much more stable.  I won't be buying another Roku stick.Update: not even 2 years in and the remote doesn't work properly. Volume buttons and power button no longer register.  Batteries are new and the roku says they're full strength but the remote still doesn't work right.Original review: Far more glitchy than my original old Roku

I always need a roku, even with a SmartTV, because of the number of apps available. I have been a loyal user since the first version of the box.I'm happy with this stick except for one small thing (and i do mean small): the power cord is really, really short. Unbelievably short. Unless your TV sits on the ground right next to the power outlet (with the wall outlet fortunately on the same side of the television as the HDMI ports), this cannot be plugged in without a weighty extension cord, which will put strain on the device. Not sure what they were thinking. Surely one of the designers must own an actual television and realize that it's very rare for an HDMI port to be only 3 feet or less from a wall outlet. You either need to get a longer M-F HDMI cable in which to plug the stick, or you can do as I did and plug the stick into a switcher and plug the switcher directly into the TV's HDMI port. There is really no way to plug the stick directly into the TV.Hopefully they'll figure out what a tragic mistake they've made and provide a significantly longer power cord next time.

The beauty of this stick is that you can plug it into your TV or receiver's USB port as long as the port has sufficient amps to power it. Most modern TVs and receivers do. This way there is no extra power cord dangling from your beautiful wall mounted TV.The problem is that Roku's engineering team really screwed up. Unlike every single other product on the market that remembers the pairing of a remote to the device, Roku's doesn't. So when you shut off your TV or receiver that is powering your Roku stick, then the remote does into pairing mode. It will attempt to find, and pair with, the Roku device until either you turn the TV back on (thus powering up the Roku stick) or until the batteries die. with typical usage having a TV off most of the day and at night while you are sleeping, the batteries in the remote will be dead in 2-3 days.This is unacceptable. Discussion forums on Roku's site have pages and pages of comments on this. Once thread has 122 pages and was closed, only to have a new thread opened.Roku has no fix for this.So, if you are planning on keeping your Roku powered 24/7 by plugging it directly into the wall (and you don't mind having that extra power drain on your utility bill) then the product is fine. But if you are going to power this from your TV, receiver, or a switched outlet (or otherwise have it unpowered when you aren't using it) then the product is useless as you will need to replace the remote batteries every couple of days or alternatively yank the batteries every time you turn your TV off.

I bought a new TV for my office/craft room and I wanted a new Roku with updated software to go with it.  I bought this on Black Friday so I got it for a great price.  It only took a few minutes to set it up because everything automatically popped up on the screen for me to just hit enter.  I love that it turns my tv on/off and also controls the volume so for the most part, I can use this remote for everything except changing channels when I watch local stations with the aerial.  I will use the tv remote for that.  This Roku remote has voice control and can also be integrated with Alexa.  I haven’t set that up yet but I’m sure it will be a breeze the same way setting it up on the tv was.  I’m very pleased with this purchase.  I have Roku on all my TVs around the house.  I find it easy to navigate and find what I’m looking for.

Speed is good. Remote suffers periods of non-responsiveness when you first turn the TV on and therefore power the stick on. The voice search has limited usefulness. It says it doesn't support sports. It doesn't work inside of Youtube TV. If you try to use it, it takes you out of the youtube tv app. I saw others complaining about the remote not having a mute button. The one I received had a remote with a mute button. I think this is relatively new as the remote for same roku stick I bought on Black Friday from Walmart.com did not have a mute button. The price was cheaper I guess because it was old stock (with the old remote with no mute) that was being liquidated.  Product ordered going foward will have the remote with the mute button I am guessing.

Been using a few weeks now and been very pleased with how capable this device is until today. It has begun to overheat while streaming 4k content (the reason I didn't get a cheaper one was to watch 4k...). This unit was extremely hot to the touch. I have it mounted on the back of my open air tv setup with the AC power adapter for reference. I have ordered the HDMI cord in hopes that getting it away from the tv helps but Im skeptical as it is winter right now and my living room is the coolest it will be all year. The streaming stick+ while packed with features cannot dissipate heat well on it's own sadly and is design flaw. After some quick searches this is a wide spread issue so not just a oneoff issue. If the HDMI cord doesnt work I'll probably be asking for a replacement (doubt it'll help)...

I just want to go on the record and say Roku remotes are crap. I’ve been using Roku since it’s inception, since the first generation Roku. The remotes sucked then (would stop working with good batteries) and it still happens now. I’d love to know the technological issue here - why are Roku remotes so terrible? It’s happened with every Roku I’ve had, which is now about 7. Would love to hear from someone.

I recently changed my internet provider and was having difficulty getting an older Fire TV device to work with one of the televisions. When this went on sale, the price was really good and having TV remote control wasn't important so I didn't see the point in spending more time on the existing device.  The new Fire stick set up quickly and flawlessly as had every new one I've gotten and has worked well every since.  I'm quite satisfied with it.

I use the fire stick lite mostly to stream Disney Pkus which is not supported by my internet provider. I ordered two, one for each of our televisions. The order arrived in time. The included directions were clear. The only issue was removing the battery cover. I found the answer on you tube. Use any rubber gloves to make it very easy. The fir sticks were easy to install, and the fire stick gave clear set up instructions. They work just great and are easy to use. The fire stick lite has no volume control, but that is not very important to me. Amazon was having a special which made the cost very reasonable. I would definitely recommend the fire stick lite.

Prime and Netflix went on the fritz for us about 2 years ago. The screens would fail to load, they'd take FOREVER to load, or it would just plain old crap out.There was nothing wrong with the old fire stick, but apparently Amazon has learned some evil tricks from Microsoft and will force you to upgrade your device in order to run their new shiny software.Well played Amazon. Well played.

What I don’t like that it does not have a on and off button nor does it have a volume control button! What I do like that for the $29.99 price that it’s one of the fastest device out there in that price range! Easy to add extra storage with a flash drive of any number of storage! Picture quality is awesome it has the same Dolby Atmos as the fire cube and it comes with a guide button with built in Alexa!

I liked how the fire stick works great with lower end internet service.  While watching movies there were no pauses for buffering  The user interface works really slick you can ether navigate with the arrow keys or voice commands.  The price was inexpensive. It also comes with an adapter cable for hard to fit HDMI locations on your TV.

I was encouraged to order a Fire TV Stick by my millennial niece during a visit to New Orleans. She impressed upon me the usefulness and versatility of a Fire TV Stick especially during a cable connection mishap. I ordered 3 Fire TV Sticks and received them within 2 days of purchase. I returned to my home in another state and low and behold the cable connection was malfunctioning. I called my software engineer son to explain my challenge with the cable connection and I can't make this up, he asked if I had a FIRE TV STICK! Within an hour he guided me through the process of setting up my FiresTV Stick and I was able to view my favorite programs for 2 days - the length of time it took for my cable company to send out a technician.

This would have been a perfect streaming device except for the following:1. It comes with small storage capacity and I started getting hard disk full error, and I had to delete most apps.2. Unlike ROKU that gives the option of an SD Card, this did not give you that luxury.3. You cannot connect your USB with this.4. Once it disconnects with your wifi modem, you virtually had to restart is like 2ce before it reconnects.5. It cannot shut off your TV or increase volume even though its a smart TV, they just dont mix.What I love about it is1. The picture clarity is super sharp2. the News channel app can be grouped so you dont need to start searching for the app in the app store3. Voice Assistant is good with search mode4. It integrated with my Echo Dot very easily.Overall Ill give it a 3 because the disk space is just to small. I have removed all my installed apps to like 7 apps and Im still seeing the disk full error. Just so annoying.

Please read through the 3 star reviews. A lot of people are having the same audio problem. Often this starts up with no sound so it has to be restarted. Amazon needs to fix this with a software or firmware update, or stop selling a faulty product!I bought this as an upgrade from a much older version and it was definitely worth the modest cost. My old fire stick had become very slow when connecting to streaming feeds. There's only one inconvenience with this new one: every now and then it starts up with no sound output. I must go into the settings and restart it, then it's fine. Not a big deal, just a small annoyance. I hope it doesn't get worse over time. Maybe a software update will fix it?

I bought the Fire TV Stick as I am in an area where I'd have to get satellite TV. I didn't like the basic packages or the prices. I like my local TV and a few shows or movies as an extra. I have Amazon Prime plus there's lots of free streaming apps/stations. I'm VERY happy with this! I can watch regular TV or switch over to my Fire Stick and watch a series or movie at NO EXTRA COST!!! for a senior citizen that means a lot!!!

I desperately needed to replace my old Fire Stick that was years old.  The remote was unpredictable and the unit was very slow.  Love this one for the voice response.  For $17 I was willing to sacrifice the volume and on/off control on the unit as I use it on a TV that I don't use very much.  If that's a concern, spend the extra money and get the more expensive one but I highly recommend this one.

I got fed up with cable cost after their last increase and looked for an alternative. I'm 62 and not familiar with all the new tech that's out there, but got a recommendation on the Roku from a Millennial. I ordered the Roku streaming stick to try it out before I cancelled our cable. After receiving it, I plugged it into the HDMI port of the TV, easy onscreen connection to my WiFi and haven't been happier. Immediately cancelled the cable and added YouTube tv for the live news feeds. It's as clear as my cable was and after several months haven't experienced any problems. It had gone out several times, but that was due to a WiFi outage. I would suggest ordering it and try it yourself and insure your WiFi, TV and any other technology you have, is comparable. Old dog learned some new tricks..

I've being using the Amazon Firestick for a year without any complaints. When needed to buy a second streaming unit, Amazon wouldn't send theirs to a forwarding address. This forced me to buy a different brand: Roku.At the beginning I wasn't happy (resistance to change) but as soon as I started using it all I could say is: WOW!! THIS IS GOOD!Roku is very fast and responsive. The interface can be customized and I believe it is better. I get exactly the same functionality as before, but with a faster response time. I love the fact the the Roku controller can turn on/off the TV and control the volume; makes streaming a bit easier. When the cell is used as a controller, the sound can be heard through earbuds without any noticeable lag.I'm very happy with this streaming stick. Roku is highly recommended, and will never go back.

(I have reviewed the Fire Stick, since I have purchased both, unable to make up my mind which one I wanted for my 2 smart TVs).  This device has performed flawlessly, although it helps I have the best available residential internet service (Cox Gigablast), cable modem (Arris SB8200) and wifi mesh router (Orbi, with 3 satellites).  Comparing the remote to the one sold with the Fire Stick, I prefer the layout of buttons on the Fire Stick.  The voice button on the Roku remote is hard to find, located in the middle among other buttons.  And the volume buttons are tiny, located on the side where it is too easy to hit the mute button inadvertently.  The large, conspicuous buttons for Netflix, Disney, Hulu, and Sling are nice (since I subscribe to 3 of these services), but are redundant since most of us prefer voice.  Both remotes badly need buttons that light up in the night, similar to the Cox Contour remote I just gave up.  Highly recommend either Stick; you might select based on slight differences of contracted streaming services and whether you need without extra cost an HDMI extension adapter (I did with my Samsung), which for now only comes with the Fire Stick.

The Roku works great.  However there are a few things I would change.  1.  Roku does not need my credit card information and I dont like having it out there.  I have paid plans directly through providers.  But, you have to provide credit card information to use the Roku.  2.  The remote is nice, a little slow, but works well.  What I don't like is the convenience keys are set for particular providers ( most I don't use).  I would like to set my own convenience buttons to go to the providers I use.  3.
